questions.text: A 35-year-old individual comes to the physician due to low-grade fever and skin discoloration. The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy three days ago. The surgery was complicated by an episode of acute hemorrhaging when an artery was inadvertently ligated, and the patient was given two units of blood. The patient’s postoperative period was normal without any complications, and the patient was discharged yesterday. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 120/80, and pulse is 70/minute. On physical examination, the physician notices skin pallor and mild jaundice in the patient’s eyes. The patient’s incisions are healing well without any discharge, bleeding, or erythema. The abdomen is soft with appropriate tenderness in the area of the incision. Both legs are symmetrical in circumference with no signs of swelling, warmth, or tenderness on palpation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with mild jaundice and low-grade fever three days after the patient had an operation and was given blood transfusion. One of the important differential diagnoses that should be suspected is a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction. 

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions are a complication of blood transfusions that result from antibodies that form against minor RBC antigens (e.g. Rh) transfused to patients. Before the transfusion, the titers of these antibodies are usually very low. However, after exposure to the antigens on transfused RBCs, more antibodies start forming, and within days, hemolysis occurs. This hemolysis mostly occurs extravascularly and is typically much more mild than acute hemolytic reactions (which are mostly due to ABO incompatibility).  

Patients with delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction typically present between 24 hours and one month of a transfusion with low-grade fevers and jaundice. However, many patients are usually asymptomatic. The serum bilirubin will be mildly elevated, and the patient's hemoglobin might decrease. Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions are rarely serious, and management is usually supportive.  

Option Analysis

✅ Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical site infection :
Incorrect: Although surgical site infections can lead to fever post-operatively, this complication is unlikely to be the cause in this patient as their incisions are without any pain, discharge, or erythema. 
❌ Postcholecystectomy syndrome:
Incorrect: Postcholecystectomy syndrome (PCS) is defined as the persistence of biliary colic (right upper quadrant pain) along with other gastrointestinal symptoms after cholecystectomy. The condition can occur early after the operation or years later. However, this patient is experiencing mild fever and jaundice without biliary colic, making PCS an unlikely diagnosis.
❌ Deep venous thrombosis:
Incorrect: Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is one of the causes of postoperative fever. However, this patient does not show signs of deep venous thrombosis (e.g., leg pain, unilateral leg swelling). Additionally, DVT does not usually cause jaundice. 
❌ Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction :
Incorrect: Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions can cause fever within 1-6 hours after transfusion; however, the condition does not typically occur after more than 24 hours.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy living in the Southwest United States is brought to the office by his parent because of a nonpruritic rash on his hands for the past two days. He has also had mild shortness of breath, dry cough, and malaise since last week. He has no prior medical conditions and does not take any medication. Vaccinations are up-to-date, and he has not traveled recently. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg. Examination of the hands reveals the following:  


Reproduced from Flickr  
Lung auscultation reveals bilateral coarse crackles. Chest x-ray shows patchy, non-segmental bilateral opacities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s skin lesions?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with multiple nonpruritic targetoid lesions on the dorsum of his hands is consistent with erythema multiforme (EM), most likely due to a T-cell mediated cytotoxic immune response to Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection (dyspnea, dry cough, low-grade fever, chest x-ray demonstrating opacities).

EM is a type IV hypersensitivity immune-mediated condition that results when the cytotoxic T-cells initiate an inflammatory cascade against the peripherally phagocytosed pathogen (brought to the epidermis), causing epithelial damage. Common causes include herpes simplex virus infection (HSV), Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection, medications (e.g., sulfonamides, antiepileptics, beta-lactams), malignancy, and collagen vascular disease. EM typically presents as nonpruritic papules, macules, and vesicles with multiple rings and a dusky center, with a red inflammatory zone surrounded by a pale halo at the periphery. It usually affects the skin of extremities, face, trunk, neck, and mucous membranes of the mouth and genitals.

Diagnosis is clinical, but a biopsy can confirm the diagnosis in atypical cases. Histopathology typically reveals basal vacuolar cell degeneration, perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate, and epidermal necrosis. It usually self-resolves within 1-2 weeks, but identification and removal of the trigger are of utmost importance.  

Option Analysis

❌ Urticaria  :
Incorrect: Acute urticaria, which results from mast cell degranulation, presents with pruritic, well-demarcated, erythematous plaques that usually last no more than 12 hours. Nonpruritic papules and macules with multiple rings and a dusky center would be atypical.
❌ Erythema migrans  :
Incorrect: Erythema migrans is an early manifestation of Lyme disease that presents with a “bull’s eye” rash 1-2 weeks after an infected tick bite. This patient’s history is not significant for travel to Lyme endemic areas. Moreover, his respiratory symptoms are suggestive of atypical pneumonia.  
❌ Erythema marginatum:
Incorrect: Erythema marginatum is found in association with acute rheumatic fever secondary to a streptococcal throat infection. It presents a pink, nonpruritic rash with a pale center and  serpiginous margins. It most commonly occurs on the trunk, spreads centrifugally, and can disappear within hours to days on its own. This patient has no history of a sore throat and instead has a respiratory infection.  
✅ Erythema multiforme:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Steven-Johnson syndrome  :
Incorrect: Steven-Johnson syndrome (SJS) presents with erythematous macules, vesicles, and bullae with epidermal necrosis and sloughing 4-28 days following exposure to a trigger (e.g., trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, lamotrigine). Mucosal involvement is commonly seen. Although targetoid lesions can be seen, SJS is usually associated with abnormal vital signs. This patient’s vitals are within normal limits.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents to the office because of flaky, itchy, white scales on the scalp. He is unable to recall its onset but states that it has been bothering him for “a while now.” He washes his scalp with mild shampoo once every two days and his face with cold water twice daily. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. During the encounter, he repeatedly scratches his face over the area between the nose and the mouth. Physical examination shows greasy scaliness of the skin of the face and the area behind the ear as shown:  


 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons


Reproduced from: flickr.com


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with flaky and itchy white scales on the scalp (dandruff) and well-demarcated, erythematous, scaly lesions on the naso-labial folds and behind the ears. This presentation is consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic dermatological condition affecting the parts of skin with abundant sebaceous glands, although sebum production in the affected areas is typically normal. It has a bimodal incidence occurring in infants and adults and is thought to result from decreased T helper cell response to Malassezia species or their byproducts.

Commonly affected areas include the scalp (dandruff), face (in the skin folds around eyebrows, nasolabial folds, and external ear canal/posterior ear), chest, intertriginous areas, interscapular area, and umbilicus. Dandruff is the most common presentation, which can be asymptomatic or present as mild pruritus. In severe cases, it may present as greasy scales with salmon-coloured or grayish-white plaques. It tends to get worse in times of stress, or during winter, and improves in the summer.

Seborrheic dermatitis is sometimes associated with Parkinson disease and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. The topical antifungal ketoconazole and ciclopirox are both effective for the condition.



Cradle cap

Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis is an immune-mediated hyperproliferative disorder that causes pruritic, well-demarcated, erythematous lesions with silver-scaling. Extensor areas (knee and elbows) are most commonly affected. Greasy scales on the face are atypical.
❌ Atopic dermatitis:
Incorrect: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is often associated with personal or family history of atopy. In adults, it usually manifests as dry, thickened, pruritic flexural surfaces (mainly neck, ante-cubital fossa, popliteal fossa, wrists, and forearms). Greasy, erythematous lesions with a flaky scalp would be atypical.
❌ Rosacea:
Incorrect: Rosacea is a dermatologic condition that presents with ocular and cutaneous manifestations, commonly in individuals with lightly pigmented skin. Cutaneous symptoms include telangiectasias, papules, and pustules on the central face with minimal or no scaling. Scalp involvement is not usually seen.
❌ Tinea capitis:
Incorrect: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp which presents with pruritic, scaly, erythematous patches that are associated with hair loss, residual black dots, and/or cervical lymphadenopathy. The absence of these findings makes this diagnosis unlikely.
✅ Seborrheic dermatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents to the office for the evaluation of a skin rash. He reports that initially, there was a singular pruritic, salmon-colored patch that appeared on his back ten days ago. After two days, the patch slowly began to clear centrally. Approximately four days after the appearance of the initial rash, multiple similar but smaller lesions started to appear on his back and chest. Review of systems is significant for malaise and headache. Past medical history is significant for a recent cold that resolved spontaneously two weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination findings are shown.


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best describes the progression of this patient’s skin rashes in the next several weeks?
questions.solution:
This patient with a recent history of a common cold presents with a pruritic, salmon-colored rash followed by the development of multiple similar, but smaller, rashes on his back in the distribution of cleavage lines. He is most likely suffering from pityriasis rosea (PR).

PR is an acute, self-resolving skin exanthem thought to result from a human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) reactivation. It is common among older children and young adults, and a prodrome of pharyngitis, malaise, and headache may be observed. It clinically presents with a one to two centimeter pink or salmon-colored, scaly patch with subsequent central clearing and cigarette paper-like scaly edges, also referred to as a “herald” patch (Fig A) or a “collarette" of scale affecting the neck, back or chest. This rash is followed by the development of smaller, macular rashes in the classic “Christmas tree” distribution following cleavage/tension lines. Diagnosis is based on history and clinical appearance. Most patients do not require therapy, except for occasionally a medium potency topical corticosteroid for itching. The rash spreads centrifugally (moving away from the center) and disappears within 6-8 weeks after desquamation.


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
Fig A

Option Analysis

✅ Spontaneous resolution:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ulceration and bleeding:
Incorrect: Pyogenic granuloma, a polypoid capillary hemangioma, rapidly grows in size and can bleed and ulcerate. It appears commonly on lip or oral mucosa and is associated with pregnancy and trauma. A pruritic, scaly, erythematous rash suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Formation of bullae:
Incorrect: Formation of bullae is characteristic of bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disease. A pre-bullous prodrome, however, presents as urticarial or eczematous lesions, not a centrally clearing “herald” patch.
❌ Progression to squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion which can progress to cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. It usually presents with less than one centimeter erythematous macules or papules, with or without scaling, on sun-exposed areas. Physical examination shows a sand-paper-like, rough texture on palpation. In contrast, a “herald” patch on the back with smaller crops in the direction of cleavage lines is atypical.
❌ Color variegation:
Incorrect: Color variegation (variable mixtures of brown, tan, red, and black) is a common feature of melanoma and is a usual finding of evolving nevi. Variation in color is not typically observed in pityriasis rosea.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to her physician endorsing recurrent, painless lumps throughout her body. The patient noticed the lumps on her neck and groin several months ago, and they often cycle between enlarging and reducing. The patient does not have any fevers, night sweats, or weight loss. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals several small non-tender and immobile right-sided cervical masses, as well as enlarged axillary and inguinal lymph nodes. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of painless, waxing-and-waning lymphadenopathy, which is clinically characteristic of follicular lymphoma (FL). FL is a variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The majority of cases have a characteristic (14;18) translocation that fuses the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the IgH locus on chromosome 14. This rearrangement results in inappropriate overexpression of the BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis.

Patients typically present with painless peripheral adenopathy in the cervical, axillary and inguinal regions. The adenopathy commonly waxes and wanes but never completely disappears. A small portion of patients (20%) present with B symptoms (i.e., fevers, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss).

Diagnosis relies on excisional tissue biopsy of a lymph node. Follicular lymphoma is histologically characterized by clusters of packed follicles composed primarily of centrocytes (small cleaved cells) and few centroblasts (large non-cleaved cells). Staining for BCL-2 can be helpful, as this protein is overexpressed in these cells.  



Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of programmed cell death   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Constitutive activation of transcription   :
Incorrect: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with translocations involving the MYC gene on chromosome 8 that result in overexpression of the MYC transcription factor. This patient presents with features of follicular lymphoma, which has a different pathologic mechanism.   
❌ Defective DNA repair   :
Incorrect: Defective DNA repair can be seen in cancers due to underlying mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene. This patient presents with features of follicular lymphoma, which has a different pathologic mechanism.   
❌ Integration of viral genetic material   :
Incorrect: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) has been linked to the growth of various lymphomas, including Burkitt lymphoma. EBV infects B-cells and integrates its genome into the host chromosome, resulting in the production of oncogenes. However, this patient presents with features of follicular lymphoma, which has a different pathologic mechanism.   
❌ Constitutive tyrosine kinase activation   :
Incorrect: In chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), a part of the ABL gene on chromosome 9 (which encodes a tyrosine kinase) is translocated to chromosome 22, where it fuses with the BCR gene. This fusion gene encodes a BCR-ABL hybrid protein that results in constitutive tyrosine kinase activity. However, this patient presents with features of follicular lymphoma, which has a different pathologic mechanism.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old nonbinary individual presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath with exertion. The patient reports increasing shortness of breath over the past several weeks to the point where they can no longer climb a flight of stairs without becoming winded. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and deep vein thrombosis following a knee replacement surgery ten years ago. The patient has not seen a physician in years and is currently not on any medications. They currently smoke one pack of cigarettes daily. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 188/92 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 91% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an additional heart sound heard just after S2, and diffuse rales on lung auscultation. Jugular venous distension, pitting edema, and hepatomegaly are absent. A chest X-ray is obtained and demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s pulmonary findings?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features consistent with left-heart failure including an S3 gallop and pulmonary edema. The primary pathophysiology underlying pulmonary edema secondary to left-sided heart failure is an increase in pulmonary venous pressure and subsequent transudation of fluid into the lung parenchyma.  

Left-sided heart failure refers to anatomical failure of the left-side of the heart only and presents with characteristic symptoms and examination findings. Notably, patients present with orthopnea (shortness of breath when lying supine), paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (breathless awakening from sleep), and pulmonary edema. The former two findings are largely due to increased venous return and redistribution of blood when lying flat, whereas pulmonary edema results from impaired forward arterial blood flow and vascular congestion.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased pulmonary venous pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased pulmonary venous pressure :
Incorrect: Increased, not decreased, pulmonary venous pressure likely underlies this patient’s pulmonary findings. With left-sided heart failure, poor ejection fraction manifests with increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, increased pulmonary venous pressure, and subsequent transudation of fluid into the lung parenchyma.
❌ Increased central venous pressure :
Incorrect: Increased central venous pressure occurs in the setting of right heart failure. Right heart failure can manifest with pitting edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and jugular venous distension. In contrast, these findings are absent in this patient. 
❌ Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure:
Incorrect: Increased, not decreased, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure leads to the development of pulmonary edema.   
❌ Recurrent pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of a remote deep vein thrombosis, he has no evidence of right heart failure on examination. This patient’s pulmonary findings are more likely secondary to left-sided heart failure and a different underlying etiology.

questions.text: A 35-year-old individual develops severe shortness of breath four hours after a blood transfusion was started in the emergency department. The patient was involved in a road traffic accident and was given 3 units of blood in the emergency department. Past medical history is noncontributory. They have no history of prior blood transfusions. On admission, vital signs showed temperature 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse 100/minute, respiratory rate 13/minute, and blood pressure 100/70. Reevaluation of vital signs now show temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 120/minute, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 22/minute. Oxygen saturation has dropped from 97% to 88% on room air. Complete blood count shows leukopenia. The transfusion is stopped immediately, and subsequent chest radiography shows bilateral lung infiltrate. Pulmonary arterial wedge pressure is 10 mmHg (normal = 6-12 mmHg). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), one of the deadliest complications of blood transfusions.  

TRALI is a rare but life-threatening complication of blood transfusion; it is defined as an acute lung injury that develops within six hours of blood transfusion. TRALI is one of the causes of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, in which left ventricular function is normal. Although the pathophysiology of TRALI is not yet completely understood, it is believed that the condition develops secondary to the presence of anti-leukocyte antibodies (e.g. anti-HLA antibodies) in the donor’s plasma. These antibodies bind to recipient neutrophils and lead to their activation in the pulmonary capillaries. This activation then initiates an inflammatory response in the pulmonary capillaries, causing endothelial cell damage, massive cytokine release, and pulmonary edema.    

Patients with TRALI develop severe shortness of breath within six hours of transfusion, commonly along with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension or hypertension. Hypoxemia develops and is characterized by oxygen saturation <90% and a ratio of PaO2/FiO2 <300. Chest radiography shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and pulmonary edema. Because left ventricular function is normal, pulmonary artery wedge pressure is normal at ≤18 mm Hg. Finally, leukopenia and neutropenia are commonly seen in patients with TRALI.  



It is important to differentiate TRALI from transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). TACO is also an acute transfusion complication that develops after transfusion of massive amounts of blood. It is characterized by hypervolemia. Like TRALI, TACO usually presents with acute dyspnea associated with bilateral pulmonary edema. However, TACO is associated with decreased left ventricular ejection fraction, which is normal in TRALI. In addition, because TACO is a volume overload state, it is associated with jugular venous distension, elevation of beta natriuretic peptide (BNP), and sometimes an S3 can be heard. All of these are not seen in patients with TRALI.  



Option Analysis

✅ Transfusion-related acute lung injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anaphylactic transfusion reaction:
Incorrect: Anaphylactic transfusion reactions develop within minutes of transfusion; this reaction is characterized by fever, urticaria, pruritus, and wheezes. Pulmonary edema, hypoxemia, and leukopenia are not usually seen. 
❌ Sepsis:
Incorrect: Sepsis is a rare complication of blood transfusion and is characterized by fever, hypotension, and shock. However, pulmonary edema is not usually seen. 
❌ Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction:
Incorrect: Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction is characterized by a triad of fever, back pain, and red urine. Pulmonary edema and hypoxemia are not seen. 
❌ Transfusion-associated circulatory overload:
Incorrect: Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) is one of the differential diagnoses of acute shortness of breath after blood transfusion, along with transfusion-associated acute lung injury (TRALI). However, TACO is also associated with jugular venous distention and sometimes S3 heart sounds (suggestive of cardiac overload)—none of which are present in this patient. Additionally, unlike TRALI, TACO is associated with elevated pulmonary arterial wedge pressure.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the family physician with concerns of delayed pubertal development. The patient has not yet had menarche and is concerned she is “falling behind” her classmates. According to her parent, the patient has been previously diagnosed with a chromosomal abnormality. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse 110/min, and blood pressure 130/70 mm Hg. She is at the 5<sup>th</sup> percentile for height. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck, cubitus valgus, and mild lymphedema of the upper extremities. Which of the following best describes the hormonal imbalances associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history and physical examination are notable for a webbed neck, cubitus valgus (abnormality wherein the forearms are angled away from body), lymphedema, short stature, and primary amenorrhea. Furthermore, the patient has been previously diagnosed with a chromosomal abnormality. She likely has Turner syndrome.  

Patients with Turner syndrome are born with either a 45 XO or a mosaic 45 XO and 46 XX genotype. A key feature of Turner syndrome is the formation of streak ovaries. Streak ovaries describe the phenomenon of ovarian dysgenesis where in lieu of normal functional ovaries, patients are left with bands of scar tissue that do not produce hormones. As a result, patients will have reduced levels of estrogen and progesterone, both of which are normally produced by the ovaries. Due to a lack of negative feedback from estrogen and progesterone, patients will, in turn, have elevated FSH and LH levels.  

Due to the aforementioned changes, patients with Turner syndrome will often have primary amenorrhea, or the absence of menstruation. Furthermore, patients may have a delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics.  


Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has physical examination findings suggestive of Turner syndrome. Individuals with Turner syndrome will have ovarian dysgenesis, which would result in reduced estradiol and progesterone levels. Due to the absence of negative feedback from estrogen, FSH and LH levels will in turn be elevated.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has physical examination findings suggestive of Turner syndrome. Individuals with Turner syndrome will have ovarian dysgenesis, which would result in reduced estradiol and progesterone levels. Due to the absence of negative feedback from estrogen, FSH and LH levels will in turn be elevated.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings would be present in a pituitary cause (e.g., prolactinoma, Sheehan syndrome) or hypothalamic cause (e.g., hypothalamic tumor) of amenorrhea. Both types of conditions would cause low FSH and LH levels, which would, in turn, result in reduced estrogen and progesterone levels. In contrast, Turner syndrome causes amenorrhea due to gonadal dysfunction and would instead present with elevated FSH and LH levels.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the findings in a healthy individual. In contrast, this patient has primary amenorrhea secondary to Turner syndrome, which would cause ovarian dysgenesis and decreased estrogen and progesterone levels. Due to the absence of negative feedback from estrogen, FSH and LH levels will in turn be elevated.

questions.text: A 9-week-old infant is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of somnolence. The parent states that he left the infant sleeping on the couch, but after stepping away for a few minutes to make lunch, he found his baby on the floor next to the couch. Since then, the infant has been sleepy. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the infant appears lethargic and difficult to arouse. The anterior fontanelle is full and without associated bruising on the scalp. Ocular examination demonstrates bilateral retinal hemorrhages. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant has evidence of severe intracranial trauma as evidenced by bilateral retinal hemorrhages. In addition, the proposed mechanism of injury is inconsistent with the infant’s development stage; infants are not able to roll over until at least four months of age, and therefore, this 9-week-old infant does not yet have the motor control to roll off the couch as the parent suggested. Thus there remains substantial concern for underlying child abuse.

Abusive head trauma (previously called "shaken baby syndrome") refers to cranial, cerebral or spinal injuries caused by blunt forces, shaking, or a combination of both. The classic injury pattern includes unilateral/bilateral subdural hemorrhage, retinal hemorrhages, and diffuse axonal injury with or without additional extracranial injuries.

Retinal hemorrhages are highly suggestive of child abuse; however, they can occur in other conditions. Other signs that should raise suspicion for child abuse include posterior rib fractures, unusual bruises (e.g., loop mark, bite mark, handprints), bruises in various stages of healing, cigarette burns, and injuries to the genitalia. Additionally, it is important to recognize when the proposed mechanism of injury is inconsistent with the developmental stage of the child, as in this case.

It is important for the clinician to look for and recognize these red flags, as physicians are mandated reporters to social services in all cases of suspected child abuse. If concern arises, a full skeletal survey should be performed, and child protective services should be contacted immediately.  




Option Analysis

❌ Meningitis:
Incorrect: Meningitis can present with lethargy and sleepiness; however, patients are typically febrile.  
❌ Vitamin K deficiency bleeding:
Incorrect: Vitamin K deficiency bleeding (VKDB), previously known as hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, results from a newborn's inability to efficiently utilize vitamin K. Infants have low vitamin K stores due to a sterile gut, low placental transfer, and low content in breast milk. VKDB presents with cutaneous bruising, mucosal bleeding, GI bleeding, bleeding from the umbilicus, and/or intracranial hemorrhage. However, this condition rarely occurs outside the first one to two weeks of life.  
❌ Accidental trauma:
Incorrect: Accidental trauma can cause subdural hemorrhage, but this injury pattern is unlikely after a fall from couch height. The paucity of external bruising suggests a different mechanism. In addition, this proposed mechanism of injury is inconsistent with the infant’s development stage; infants are not able to roll over until at least four months of age, and therefore this 9-week-old infant does not yet have the motor control to roll off the couch as the parent suggested.  
✅ Non-accidental trauma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteogenesis imperfecta:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a genetic bone disorder marked by brittle bones secondary to reduced production of type 1 collagen. Manifestations include fractures from low intensity trauma (e.g. birth), bone deformities, blue sclera, conductive hearing loss, and tooth abnormalities.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of altered mental status. He appears disoriented and agitated. Per review of the medical record, past medical history is notable for hypertension. He has a 35-year smoking history and consumes 5-7 beers per day. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 148/55 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is oriented to self but not place or time. His pupils are equal and reactive to light, and fundoscopic examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing is performed and shown below. Which of the following additional findings will most likely be present in this patient?

choices.text: Calcium oxalate crystals on urine microscopy

questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status and disorientation. Laboratory testing reveals an increased osmolal gap (equation can be found below) and anion gap metabolic acidosis. These findings are suggestive of ethylene glycol poisoning.


Ethylene glycol can be found in antifreeze, engine fluids, and brake fluids. It is a toxic, colorless, and odorless liquid with a sweet taste. Ethylene glycol toxicity usually develops when it is consumed as a substitute for ethanol. Initially, patients will experience altered mental status, abdominal pain, and vomiting. Over time, alcohol dehydrogenase metabolizes ethylene glycol to glycolic acid and oxalic acid. Glycolic acid is toxic to renal tubules, and oxalic acid binds calcium, causing hypocalcemia and calcium oxalate crystal formation. As a result, patients may develop flank pain, hematuria, and oliguria.

Laboratory testing will reveal metabolic acidosis, elevated anion gap, and increased osmolal gap (ethylene glycol is osmotically active).

Treatment options include fomepizole, a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, or ethanol, which has a higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase than ethylene glycol. Both treatment options prevent the further breakdown of ethylene glycol into its toxic metabolites. Furthermore, sodium bicarbonate can be administered to alleviate the acidosis, and some patients may require hemodialysis.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

  

Option Analysis

❌ Radiopaque pills on abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: This answer choice is suggestive of iron poisoning. Iron poisoning often develops in children after accidental ingestion. Although iron toxicity can present with an anion gap metabolic acidosis, an osmolal gap is usually absent. Moreover, affected patients will typically present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and gastrointestinal bleeding.  
✅ Calcium oxalate crystals on urine microscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased serum and urine ketones:
Incorrect: This answer choice suggests diabetic ketoacidosis. However, this patient is euglycemic and does not have a history of diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Prolonged QT interval on electrocardiogram:
Incorrect: A prolonged QT interval can be seen in patients with tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity. Patients will also present with anticholinergic symptoms such as mydriasis, increased body temperature, dry mouth, tachycardia, and flushed skin. In contrast, this patient does not have anticholinergic symptoms, making TCA toxicity unlikely.  
❌ Elevated carboxyhemoglobin level:
Incorrect: Elevated carboxyhemoglobin levels are usually observed in association with carbon monoxide poisoning. A history of exposure to fire or exhaust is usually present. Although carbon monoxide poisoning can present with altered mental status, it would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis or increased osmolal gap.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a three week history of worsening fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, and lower extremity swelling. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, but notes no recent travel, sick contacts, or illnesses. She recalls one episode of nausea and diaphoresis while she was lifting boxes at home approximately one month ago, but she does not recall any chest pain or shortness of breath at that time. She is a life-time non-smoker and reports drinking one glass of wine every night with dinner. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9° F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 142/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities and prominent jugular veins. An additional heart sound is heard just after S2, and faint bibasilar crackles are heard on auscultation of the lungs. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrates a dilated left ventricle and increased end-diastolic volume, and wall motion abnormalities are noted along the anterolateral heart border. Ejection fraction by visualization is estimated at 34%. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Infection with a positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus

questions.solution:
Systolic heart failure is most commonly due to ischemia or myocardial infarction, which causes decreased cardiac contractility that leads to systolic dysfunction. The inability of the heart to effectively pump blood forward through circulation results in clinical features of left-sided heart failure causing pulmonary edema: fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, as well as bibasilar crackles and an S3 heart sound (ventricular gallop) on examination. This often progresses to right-sided heart failure, resulting in jugular venous distention (JVD), pitting edema, and hepatic congestion. The patient in this question likely suffered an atypical or silent myocardial infarction while she was moving boxes several weeks ago, and without appropriate treatment, she has now developed systolic heart failure. Other causes of systolic heart failure include etiologies of dilated cardiomyopathy including alcohol, coxsackie B virus infection, chronic cocaine use, or Chagas disease. Echocardiography typically shows an increased end diastolic volume (EDV), decreased contractility (or wall motion abnormalities), and reduced ejection fraction (EF).

In contrast to systolic heart failure, diastolic heart failure is most commonly due to cardiac hypertrophy from long-standing, untreated hypertension. It presents with the same clinical features as systolic heart failure. Echocardiographic findings generally demonstrate a preserved EF and a normal EDV. Patients with diastolic heart failure will also have decreased compliance (increased end diastolic pressure) due to stiff ventricular walls. Other etiologies of diastolic heart failure include infiltrative diseases such as amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, or post-radiation fibrosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Long-standing untreated hypertension:
Incorrect: Long standing untreated hypertension typically results in findings of diastolic heart failure due to concentric hypertrophy. Findings include a preserved ejection fraction and a normal end-diastolic volume. The patient in this vignette has an increased end diastolic volume and a reduced ejection fraction making an etiology of systolic heart failure more likely.
✅ Ischemic heart disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Repetitive vasoconstriction of pulmonary vasculature:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathophysiology of chronic smoking and COPD leading to cor pulmonale or isolated right sided heart failure. Prolonged vasoconstriction of pulmonary vasculature increases demand on the right heart, eventually leading to peripheral edema and hepatic congestion without pulmonary edema. The patient in this vignette has findings of pulmonary edema and is not a smoker, making this diagnosis less likely.
❌ Alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: Alcohol can cause dilated cardiomyopathy and systolic heart failure; however, this occurs only with heavy consumption. The patient in this vignette is described as consuming within the recommended drink limit per day, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Infection with a positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus:
Incorrect: This question stem describes the pathophysiology of a dilated cardiomyopathy from coxsackie B virus, which can cause systolic heart failure (as seen in this patient). This answer choice is less likely in this patient without a recent history of infectious illness.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a one day history of dull chest pain. The patient reports he was out for a jog yesterday when he suddenly experienced dull chest pain radiating to the back, with associated shortness of breath. The patient reports he is otherwise healthy but has smoked 5-10 cigarettes per day for the past ten years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 130/66 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. He does not appear to be in acute distress. Physical examination shows a thin, tall man, with a concave anterior chest wall. Cardiovascular examination shows 2+ pulses in the upper extremities bilaterally, and a mid-systolic murmur at the cardiac apex is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has features of Marfan syndrome, including pectus excavatum (concave anterior chest wall) and mitral valve prolapse, given the mid-systolic murmur at the cardiac apex on examination. Both of these features, in conjunction with a history of smoking and dull chest pain radiating to the back, are concerning features for a diagnosis of a thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA).  

TAAs are true aneurysms, meaning all three layers of the blood vessel - intima, media, and adventitia - are dilated >50% greater of the normal diameter of the aorta. Other risk factors for thoracic aortic aneurysms include hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Significant genetic risk factors aside from Marfan syndrome include other inherited connective tissue disorders such as Loeys-Dietz and vascular type Ehlers-Danlos syndromes, large vessel inflammatory diseases such as giant cell arteritis and Takayasu's aortitis, as well as infections such as tertiary syphilis.    

Most cases of TAAs are silent, meaning they do not produce symptoms until they are large enough to compress on adjacent structures. The symptoms of TAAs depend largely on their location: 
  •  Aneurysms of the aortic arch result in ascending aneurysms and can present signs of aortic regurgitation due to dilation of the aortic valve annulus; this can eventually progress to heart failure. In addition, symptoms can be related to compression of nearby structures: for example, the coronary arteries (chest pain) as seen in this patient, the tracheobronchial tree (wheezing) or the esophagus (dysphagia). 
  •  Aneurysms of the descending aorta are less likely to lead to symptoms until the aneurysm has become very large due to the capacity of the thoracic cavity. If large enough, the aneurysm can affect the adjacent spine, causing back pain.  




Option Analysis

❌ Aortic dissection:
Incorrect: While people with marfanoid habitus and thoracic aortic aneurysms are at risk for the development of aortic dissection, the clinical presentation is usually much more severe. Patients are often extremely uncomfortable, hypertensive, and describe a sensation of ripping or tearing chest pain radiating to the back.  
✅ Thoracic aortic aneurysm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Coronary artery disease :
Incorrect: While compression of the coronary arteries may occur with large aortic aneurysms, inducing dull chest pain, the patient in this vignette is less likely to have true coronary artery disease from atherosclerosis.  
❌ Pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism (PE) can be associated with shortness of breath, but are typically described as pleuritic, or sharp pain with deep inhalation. Patients with pulmonary embolisms typically present with either tachycardia, hypoxia, or non-specific T-wave changes on ECG. The patient in this vignette does not have typical PE risk factors such as recent travel, malignancy, or family history of clotting disorder.  
❌ Costochondritis :
Incorrect: Costochondritis remains an incredibly common cause of musculoskeletal chest pain in otherwise young, healthy individuals. It is a diagnosis of exclusion made by first ruling out dangerous pathology. It is less likely in this patient with marfanoid habitus, an ejection click, and ECG changes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the office due to daily headaches for the past few months. She describes the location to be all the way around her head, and she feels like her head is under a lot of pressure. She rates the pain as a 5 on a 10-point scale, and it often worsens in severity throughout the day. She works as a secretary, and she states that she has been under a lot of stress lately. Her medical history is significant for bacterial sinusitis treated with antibiotics one month ago, and family history is significant for migraines on her mother's side. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild tenderness on palpation of her posterior neck and occiput. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with a bilateral, moderate intensity headache without associated symptoms, in conjunction with her recent stress at work, most likely has a tension headache.    

Tension headaches are the most common headache worldwide. The typical presentation of a tension headache includes a bilateral, mild to moderate intensity, non-throbbing headache without other associated features. The pain is often described as “pressure-like” or “band-like” and patients often have pericranial muscle tenderness. The pathophysiology is uncertain, but proposed mechanisms include peripheral activation or sensitization of myofascial nociceptors. Common precipitating factors are stress and muscle tension. Acute abortive treatment includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatories and acetaminophen, with prophylactic treatment options including behavioral therapy and tricyclic antidepressants (e.g. amitriptyline).  



Option Analysis

❌ Cluster headache:
Incorrect: Cluster headaches manifest as unilateral excruciating periorbital pain with lacrimation and rhinorrhea. They are more common in men than women and usually are short in duration (15 minutes – 3 hours). This patient has bilateral pain of moderate-intensity, favoring the diagnosis of a tension headache.  
❌ Migraine headaches:
Incorrect: Migraine headaches are characterized by episodic unilateral pain which is throbbing and pulsatile in quality. It is often associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity and noise sensitivity. Patients may describe an aura preceding an attack. Although this patient has a family history of migraines, the characteristics of her headache are more consistent with a tension headache.     
❌ Bacterial meningitis  :
Incorrect: Bacterial meningitis often presents with the classic triad of fever, nuchal rigidity, and a change in mental status. Tenderness over the posterior neck and occiput is most likely caused by muscle tenderness, which is characteristic of tension headaches, and the absence of the classic signs of meningitis favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Tension headache:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Pseudotumor cerebri :
Incorrect: Pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension, IIH) commonly presents with headache, tinnitus, diplopia, visual changes, and papilledema. Risk factors include female gender, use of tetracyclines, obesity, vitamin A excess, and use of danazol. This patient’s type of headache, with an absence of risk factors or classic IIH symptoms, favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Chronic sinusitis:
Incorrect: Sinusitis often presents with a mucopurulent nasal drainage, nasal obstruction, facial pain/pressure, and reduced sensation of smell. Although this patient was treated for sinusitis a month ago, her presentation with the absence of nasal symptoms favors another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 54 year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to a seizure. People in the homeless shelter who witnessed the event report that she fell to the ground and started having rhythmic jerking movement of the limbs. Her medical history is unknown. Physical examination reveals the patient to be dishevelled, confused, and barely responsive. Computed tomography of the head is obtained and shown below before (left) and after (right) the addition of contrast (shown below):  



Credit: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely origin of this patient's primary tumor?
questions.solution:
This female patient with an unknown medical history is now presenting with seizure. Her CT shows multiple lesions at the gray-white matter junction, which are indicative of brain metastases.   

Brain metastases are the most common type of intracranial tumors in adults, accounting for more than 50% of brain tumors. The most common sites of primary tumors that spread to the brain are the following: lung > breast > melanoma, colon, kidney. Metastases are typically located at the junction of the gray-white matter where blood vessels decrease in diameter and trap clumps of tumor cells. Brain metastases also tend to occur at the "watershed areas" of arterial circulation. Common presenting symptoms include seizure, headache, cognitive dysfunction, focal neurologic deficits, and stroke.   

Option Analysis

✅ Breast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Liver:
Incorrect: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) sites of metastasis include the lung, abdominal lymph nodes, and bone. Brain metastasis, although possible, is very unlikely.   
❌ Brain :
Incorrect: Primary brain tumors are usually singular. Multiple lesions at the grey-white matter junction are most likely to be the result of metastasis rather than primary lesions.   
❌ Bone:
Incorrect: Metastatic cancers to the bone greatly outnumber primary bone cancer and include prostate, breast, kidney, thyroid and lung. Primary bone tumor metastasis to the brain is very unlikely.   
❌ Stomach:
Incorrect: The most common sites of metastasis for stomach cancer include the liver, peritoneal surfaces, and non-regional or distant lymph nodes. Metastasis to the brain and central nervous system, although possible, is much less common.   
❌ Thyroid:
Incorrect: Thyroid cancer is usually contained in the thyroid at the time of diagnosis. Common locations for metastasis include the local lymph nodes, lung, and bone. Spread to the brain, although possible, is rare.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the office due to the progressive growth of skin lesions that appear on his back. He first noticed them 6 months ago, and since then they have increased in number. He mentions that the lesions often bleed with minor trauma. He is worried that he might have cancer because his father died of skin cancer, but he cannot recall the type. He is a retired computer engineer and spends most of his time reading and playing with his grandchildren. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertriglyceridemia. Physical examination reveals multiple dome-shaped, dark-red lesions with some coagulated blood surrounding a few of them. Biopsy of the lesion is obtained and shown below.  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has cherry hemangiomas, which are benign, mature proliferations of capillaries. His biopsy results show vascular tumors with abundant red blood cells, which helps to distinguish the lesions from other dermal proliferations (e.g. acrochordon).  

Cherry hemangiomas often occur as multiple lesions, typically on the trunk, and they tend to bleed with trauma. They are usually dark-red, purple, or blue-black, dome-shaped lesions, and they blanch with pressure. The pathogenesis is not completely understood. The diagnosis is based on the clinical appearance of the lesions. Treatment of cherry angiomas includes different topical interventions (e.g., cryotherapy, laser removal), and the decision to remove is based on whether the patient finds the lesions bothersome.  

Option Analysis

❌ Angiosarcoma:
Incorrect: Angiosarcomas are rare, aggressive, blood vessel malignancies which typically occur in the head, neck, and breast areas. The tumors are often difficult to resect due to bleeding risk and delays in diagnosis. Risk factors include sun exposure, radiation therapy, and chronic postmastectomy lymphedema. Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with vinyl chloride and arsenic exposures. This patient has none of these risk factors, and the characteristics of his lesions favor another diagnosis.  
✅ Cherry hemangioma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Strawberry hemangioma:
Incorrect: Strawberry hemangiomas are benign tumors of the vascular endothelium. They are the most common childhood tumor, and they are characterized by an early growth phase and involution after the first year of life. This patient’s age and presentation favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Seborrheic keratoses:
Incorrect: Seborrheic keratoses are flat, pigmented squamous epithelial proliferation of immature keratinocytes. They are often described as having a “stuck on” appearance. Lesions can occur on the head, trunk, and extremities. They are the most common benign neoplasm seen in older individuals; however, rapid appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses indicates possible GI adenocarcinoma (Leser-Trélat sign). This patient’s characteristic lesions and biopsy results favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Acrochordon :
Incorrect: Acrochordons, also known as skin tags, are an outgrowth of normal skin often seen in older individuals. They appear as pinkish, skin-colored, pedunculated lesions with narrow stalks. Similar to cherry hemangiomas, their number often increases with age. However, they typically appear in sites of friction, particularly the axilla, neck, inframammary, and inguinal regions. Diabetes, obesity and Crohn's disease (perianal) are contributing factors for developing the lesions. This patient’s characteristic lesions and biopsy results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of fatigue and shortness of breath with physical activity. Her symptoms started five months ago. The patient has no past medical history and has not been taking any medications. Family history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis in her mother. The patient’s temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 73/min and blood pressure is 156/92 mmHg. An accentuated S2 sound is auscultated over the upper left sternal border. Diffuse skin thickening and tightening is observed. Small calcium deposits are observed at the elbows. Detection of which of the following antibodies will most likely confirm the patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has diffuse cutaneous systemic scleroderma. Scleroderma starts with injury to endothelial cells that line the interior surface of small blood vessels, causing a non-inflammatory vasculitis. This prompts T-cell migration. The T-cells release cytokines, which attract other immune cells, and activate fibroblasts that produce and deposit collagen. In time, collagen accumulates and forms a highly stable matrix. This buildup of excess connective tissue is termed fibrosis.  

In diffuse cutaneous systemic scleroderma, extensive fibrosis takes place in both the skin and visceral organs. Thickening and tightening of skin throughout the patient’s body is expected. In the lungs, excess collagen deposition can result in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and pulmonary fibrosis. This presents with dyspnea, restricted inhalation, and coughing. On auscultation, PAH can cause a loud pulmonic component (P2) of the S2 heart sound. In addition, since the right ventricle must pump against an increased afterload, right heart failure will eventually develop (a process known as cor pulmonale).  

Three autoantibodies are often found in patients with scleroderma. Diffuse scleroderma is associated with anti-Scl-70 (also called anti-topoisomerase I) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies. Limited scleroderma is more commonly associated with anti-centromere antibodies.   

Option Analysis

❌ Anti-centromere antibodies:
Incorrect: Anticentromere antibodies are associated with limited scleroderma. Patients with this condition present with mild visceral organ involvement and skin findings restricted to the face and distal extremities. In contrast, this patient has diffuse skin thickening and tightening. Moreover, the patient’s dyspnea, accentuated S2 heart sound, and elevated blood pressure all raise concerns for cardiopulmonary involvement.  
❌ Anti-signal recognition particle antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-signal recognition particle (anti-SRP) antibodies are specific for polymyositis. The condition presents with muscle weakness in the absence of skin findings. In contrast, this patient has skin tightening and calcium deposits. Moreover, it would be atypical for polymyositis to cause the cardiopulmonary findings found in this patient.  
✅ Anti-topoisomerase I antibodies  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Anti-Mi-2 antibodies  :
Incorrect: Autoantibodies against the Mi-2 nuclear antigen are specific for dermatomyositis. This condition presents with proximal muscle weakness and cutaneous findings such as a malar rash, Gottron’s papules, and a shawl sign. However, it would be atypical for dermatomyositis to cause sign tightening or calcium deposition.  
❌ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. The patient’s mother has rheumatoid arthritis, which increases the patient’s risk of developing the condition. However, it would be unusual for rheumatoid arthritis to present with skin thickening, tightening, or calcium deposition.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his physician for a routine colonoscopy. A sample image from this procedure is demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia  

No other abnormalities are seen. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for developing this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Diverticulosis refers to outpouchings that form in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon. The exact pathogenic mechanism for diverticula formation is unknown, but one theory is that diverticula form in response to increased intracolonic pressure generated when the colon is processing smaller, non–fiber-containing stools. This increased pressure eventually pushes out part of the colon, forming sac-like appendages at the weakest segments, in the points where the colon is fed by blood vessels called the vasa recta. The most significant risk factors for the development of diverticulosis include diets low in fiber, high in red meat and fat, obesity, physical inactivity, and smoking.  



Most cases of diverticulosis are asymptomatic and are discovered incidentally as in this vignette. When symptomatic, they classically cause chronic nonspecific abdominal complaints, including bloating, crampy pain, excessive gas, and a change in bowel habits. Patients may also develop hematochezia. Sometimes, diverticula can become infected, causing diverticulitis, and patients may require oral or intravenous antibiotics depending on the severity of infection.  

Option Analysis

✅ Low dietary fiber intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anti-gliadin antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-gliadin antibodies are more commonly associated with celiac disease. On endoscopy, patients with celiac disease will typically have normal appearing mucosa. Pathologic biopsy will demonstrate scalloping of the small bowel folds.  
❌ Coronary artery disease  :
Incorrect: Coronary artery disease is a risk factor for atherosclerosis of mesenteric vasculature, resulting in mesenteric ischemia. Patients with mesenteric ischemia will tend to have an area of colon that is pale, necrotic, or appears to have recently bled.  
❌ Mutation of the APC gene:
Incorrect: Mutation of the APC gene is associated with the condition familial adenomatous polyposis, which results in the early formation of precancerous polyps. The image above demonstrates diverticular disease, not precancerous polyps.  
❌ HLA-B27 mutation:
Incorrect: Mutations in HLA-B27 are associated with an increased risk of ankylosing spondylitis and ulcerative colitis. The lesions of ulcerative colitis are typically described as erythematous and friable  mucosa with superficial ulceration, with near universal involvement of the rectum.

questions.text:
A male newborn is delivered prematurely at 26 weeks gestation, and he is found to be in severe respiratory distress. His mother did not receive any prenatal care during her pregnancy. His temperature is 36.0° C (96.8° F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 50/min, and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nasal flaring and subcostal retractions. A chest radiograph is obtained (see image below):  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

He is given artificial surfactant and supplemental oxygen, and the condition resolves within a few days. At a follow up appointment two weeks later, ophthalmoscopic examination shows neovascularization of the retina and slight retinal detachment. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's retinal findings?
questions.solution:
This premature male newborn, delivered at 26 weeks gestation, is presenting with severe respiratory distress associated with nasal flaring and subcostal retractions. These clinical features, along with his chest X-ray showing the classic ground glass appearance, indicates neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) due to surfactant deficiency. Surfactant is responsible for decreasing the alveolar surface tension. With insufficient surfactant levels, the surface tension of the alveoli becomes too high, leading to alveolar collapse. Surfactant production begins around 20 weeks of gestation but reaches sufficient level only at 35 weeks. Risk factors for NRDS include prematurity (as seen in this case), maternal diabetes, and C-section delivery.  

NRDS can be prevented in certain cases through maternal administration of corticosteroids prior to labor. In newborns with NRDS, treatment includes supplemental oxygen and administration of artificial surfactant. Supplemental oxygen, although crucial, can lead to several important complications, including retinopathy of prematurity, intraventricular hemorrhage, and bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

The pathogenesis of retinopathy of prematurity consists of two phases. During the hyperoxic phase (from oxygen supplementation), expression of the proangiogenic vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is decreased, leading to endothelial cell apoptosis. With the return to room air oxygen levels, VEGF levels rebound, inducing rapid retinal vessel proliferation (neovascularization).This rapid neovascularization and scarring of the retina may cause retinal detachment and blindness.   

Option Analysis

❌ Maternal high blood glucose:
Incorrect: Maternal diabetes during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk for developing respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in the newborn; however, it is not the cause for retinopathy of prematurity.   
❌ Maternal alcohol use:
Incorrect: Maternal alcohol use during pregnancy can cause fetal alcohol syndrome, which is characterized by pre- and post-natal developmental delay, facial abnormalities, microcephaly, limb dislocation, and heart defects. It is not a cause of retinopathy of prematurity.  
❌ Maternal dexamethasone therapy:
Incorrect: Maternal corticosteroid therapy before labor helps facilitate fetal lung maturation. It is used to help prevent respiratory distress in premature infants. It is not a cause of retinopathy of prematurity.  
❌ Maternal indomethacin therapy:
Incorrect: Indomethacin therapy can be used to delay premature labor or to close a patent ductus arteriosus. It is not a cause of retinopathy of prematurity.  
✅ Neonatal oxygen therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neonatal enzyme deficiency:
Incorrect: Disorders of galactose metabolism, such as classic galactosemia or galactokinase  deficiency, can lead to infantile cataracts due accumulation of toxic galactose products within the eye.  Disorders of galactose metabolism are not a cause of retinopathy of prematurity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman currently at 28 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. She reports frequent urination and worsening dysuria over the past several days. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She denies headaches and changes in vision. Her vital signs are 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 107/64 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination shows suprapubic as well as left-sided costovertebral tenderness on palpation. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: High white blood cell count and hyaline casts
Positive leukocyte esterase with no bacteria
Red blood cells and positive leukocyte esterase

questions.solution:
This pregnant female patient presents with nausea, vomiting, fever, and costovertebral angle tenderness. Her clinical presentation is most consistent with pyelonephritis, which will demonstrate a high white blood cell count and hyaline casts on urinalysis. Hyaline casts or white blood cell casts, while not always seen in the setting of pyelonephritis, are highly specific for pyelonephritis when compared to other forms of urinary tract infections. In addition, other forms of urinary tract infections, such as urethritis and cystitis, do not present with systemic symptoms like fever, nausea, or vomiting.  

Pyelonephritis refers to an acute kidney infection, where neutrophils infiltrate the renal interstitium, causing inflammation in the cortex while relatively sparing the glomeruli and vasculature. The most common cause of pyelonephritis is an ascending bacterial infection, usually due to E. coli, but other common organisms include Klebsiella, Proteus mirabilis, or Enterococcus species. Hematogenous spread due to bacteremia is also causative but less common overall. Laboratory markers will typically demonstrate an elevated white blood cellcount, and urinalysis will typically demonstrate positive leukocyte esterase, positive nitrites, as well as possible white blood cell or hyaline casts. CT scans will often demonstrate striated parenchymal enhancement in the affected kidney.  

Option Analysis

✅ High white blood cell count and hyaline casts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 4+ Proteinuria:
Incorrect: Significant proteinuria is more likely to occur in the setting of pre-eclampsia or eclampsia, which presents in gestational women with hypertension, headache, and blurred vision. This patient’s symptoms and vital signs are more consistent with pyelonephritis.  
❌ Positive leukocyte esterase with no bacteria:
Incorrect: This laboratory finding is more consistent with sterile pyuria, which is encountered in the setting of urethritis or appendicitis, among other conditions. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with pyelonephritis.  
❌ Urine pH 8.5  :
Incorrect: Alkaline urine is more commonly seen with infectious organisms such as Proteus mirabilis, a common culprit in patients with chronic pyelonephritis. However, this pregnant patient more likely has acute pyelonephritis.  
❌ Red blood cells and positive leukocyte esterase:
Incorrect: These urinalysis findings are more commonly found in the setting of nephrolithiasis, which presents with lancinating flank radiating to the groin, nausea, and vomiting. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with pyelonephritis.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of painful lesions on his penis. Five days ago, he noticed the gradual onset of redness and tenderness over the glans and foreskin of the penis, which was associated with itching and a white, curd-like coating. The patient has a history of six urinary tract infections treated with antibiotics over the past year. Family history is significant for prostate cancer in the patient’s father. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg. BMI is 42 kg/m2. Physical examination shows symmetrically descended, non-tender testes. Penile examination shows the following:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

Which of the following laboratory studies is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with the acute onset of pain and pruritus localized over the glans and the foreskin, which is most consistent with balanitis. Balanitis refers to inflammation of the glans penis and/or foreskin. The most common cause is inadequate hygiene in uncircumcised men, leading to a building up debris. Other predisposing factors include diabetes mellitus and obesity. Balanitis with candidal infection, as suggested in this patient by the curdish-white exudate, is more common specifically in diabetic patients.  

In addition to obesity and being greater than 40 years old, this patient’s history of frequent, recurrent urinary tract infections is strongly suggestive of undiagnosed and uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) caused by insulin resistance. There are four clinical symptoms of uncontrolled diabetes: polyphagia, glycosuria, polyuria, and polydipsia.   



Polyphagia is explained by starved cells breaking down and triggering hunger. Glycosuria is caused by high blood sugar spilling over into the urine; since bacteria and fungus can utilize the glucose for their own growth, diabetic patients are thus predisposed to genitourinary infections. Polyuria occurs because glucose is osmotically active and water tends to follow it, resulting in an increased volume of urine production. Finally, because there is so much urination, people with uncontrolled diabetes become dehydrated, resulting in polydipsia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Serum creatinine:
Incorrect: Creatinine is elevated in the setting of acute or chronic kidney injury, representing decreased glomerular filtration rate. Diabetes causes chronic kidney disease over years rather than months.  
❌ Serum potassium:
Incorrect: Potassium is most often elevated in the setting of kidney disease, where diminished filtration causes higher levels. Potassium homeostasis is not directly affected by hyperglycemia.  
✅ Serum glucose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ​Prostate specific antigen:
Incorrect: Prostate specific antigen (PSA) can be elevated in the setting of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer. Although this patient complains of polyuria, which could be from BPH, recurrent genitourinary infections are more likely to be caused by uncontrolled hyperglycemia.  
❌ Erythrocyte sedimentation rate:
Incorrect: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) refers to how quickly red blood cells drop to the bottom of a test tube. Inflammation causes production antibodies that attach to the RBCs and slow them down, increasing the ESR. ESR is non-specific and is not directly associated with balanitis or diabetes.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents after he fell to the ground and started shaking uncontrollably. According to his parents, while the boy was playing, his body suddenly stiffened, and he fell to the ground and started shaking. The episode lasted approximately one minute, after which the patient briefly lost consciousness. The parents state he regained consciousness within a minute but seemed confused and disoriented. The patient has been experiencing a fever, sore throat and runny nose for the past two days. The symptoms were improving with acetaminophen until today, when he developed high-grade fever and chills. Medical history is noncontributory, and the patient has been achieving developmental milestones appropriately. The patient’s temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 92/55 mm Hg. The child is comfortably playing with a toy and does not appear to be in distress. Physical examination shows an erythematous pharynx without exudate or vesicles. There is no nuchal rigidity or photophobia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of generalized tonic-clonic activity and high-grade fever (most likely due to viral upper respiratory infection) are consistent with the diagnosis of febrile seizure. Occurring in up to 3% of children between six months and six years of age, febrile seizure is the most common neurologic disorder in this age group. It is defined as a convulsive episode associated with elevated body temperature in the absence of central nervous system (CNS) infection, metabolic abnormality or a history of afebrile seizure. It can be:

 


Maximum height of fever and previous history of febrile seizure are important determinants of risk of having a febrile seizure. Viral upper respiratory infection (as seen in this patient with sore throat and runny nose) is the most common culprit. The diagnosis of febrile seizure is clinical, and further neurologic evaluation is not necessary unless there are findings concerning a secondary cause of seizure (metabolic abnormality, meningitis, encephalitis). Generally, reassurance, treatment with acetaminophen as needed, and appropriate follow up is all that is necessary for management.  

Option Analysis

❌ Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy:
Incorrect: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy manifests as involuntary jerking movements involving bilateral extremities, and consciousness is preserved during and after the episode. Episodes generally occur in the morning. However, this patient with fever and no history of similar episodes is more likely to have had a febrile seizure.  
✅ Febrile seizure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Febrile status epilepticus:
Incorrect: Febrile status epilepticus is diagnosed when there is a continuous seizure activity of ≥30 minutes. It is a neurological emergency. This patient’s seizure activity lasted for only a minute, and the patient has fully regained consciousness.  
❌ Meningitis:
Incorrect: Meningitis is unlikely in this patient with no nuchal rigidity or photophobia. Moreover, CNS infections usually cause altered consciousness or petechial rashes, none of which are observed in this patient currently playing comfortably.  
❌ Complex partial seizure:
Incorrect: In complex partial seizure, only one cerebral hemisphere is involved initially, causing symptoms on the contralateral side ranging from motor, sensory, autonomic to psychic. It is accompanied by loss of consciousness and postictal confusion or drowsiness. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a simple febrile seizure.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician’s office by his parents due to persistent crying and abdominal bloating. His parents noticed the patient’s abdomen appears swollen, and they think that he cries due to abdominal pain. They have tried to change his diet without relief. There is no history of recent infection, sick contacts or change in the color of his stool. The patient was born at term through normal vaginal birth and delivery. At birth, the patient was diagnosed with a right eye condition, but his parents can’t remember the name. His parents report that the patient does not yet smile at them or say “mama” or “dada,” and he mainly bables. The child can grasp toys with both hands but is unable to stand or walk. The results of the right eye examination are shown below.  


 
Reproduced from: flickr

Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found on physical examination?
questions.solution:
This infant presenting with abdominal pain, developmental delay, and aniridia (absent iris) on eye examination most likely has WAGR syndrome. The abdominal pain and bloating that did not resolve with diet changes implies an abdominal mass, which along with other findings is most likely nephroblastoma.   

WAGR syndrome is characterized by Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma), Aniridia, Genitourinary anomalies, and intellectual disability (mental Retardation). In children with WAGR syndrome, there is approximately 50% risk of developing Wilms tumor. WAGR syndrome is caused by “loss of function” mutations of tumor suppressor gene WT1 located on chromosome 11. The WT1 gene product is a transcription factor that is involved in gonadal and renal development.  

Wilms tumor arises from proliferation of the embryonic metanephric blastema without normal tubular and glomerular differentiation. It is the most common renal malignancy of early childhood (ages 2–4) and may arise sporadically or as a part of a syndrome. Patients often present with a large, palpable, unilateral flank smooth mass that does not cross the midline and/or hematuria and possible hypertension.  

Option Analysis

❌ Macroglossia:
Incorrect: Macroglossia can be seen in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the development of Wilms tumor, macroglossia, organomegaly, hemihyperplasia. It is caused by WT2 mutation in the 11p15.5 region. Aniridia is not seen in this syndrome.   
❌ Gonadal dysgenesis :
Incorrect: Gonadal dysgenesis (specifically male pseudohermaphroditism) can be seen in Denys-Drash syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the development of Wilms tumor, diffuse mesangial sclerosis (early-onset nephrotic syndrome). It is caused by WT1 mutation. Aniridia is not seen in this syndrome.   
❌ Pheochromocytoma:
Incorrect: Pheochromocytoma can be seen in neurofibromatosis type I, a genetic disorder characterized by café-au-lait spots, lisch nodules (iris hamartoma), cutaneous neurofibromas, pheochromocytomas, and optic gliomas. This patient’s eye examination shows an absent iris rather than lisch nodules.   
✅ Nephroblastoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nevus flammeus:
Incorrect: Nevus flammeus can be seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome, a congenital nonhereditary anomaly of neural crest derivatives characterized by nevus flammeus (port-wine stain), leptomeningeal angioma, intellectual disability, glaucoma, and epilepsy. It is caused by somatic mosaicism of an activating mutation in the GNAQ gene. This patient’s eye examination shows absent iris rather than glaucoma.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a rash that has been present the past two months. During this time, she has noticed red areas on her upper chest that slowly enlarge, then partially heal, leaving scar-like areas in the periphery. The patient has also been experiencing fevers and joint pains. Medical history is significant for primary essential hypertension, which is well controlled on amlodipine. She takes no other medications and has no allergies. The patient’s temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. Physical exam shows discrete, erythematous, indurated plaques, covered with adherent scale, localized to the upper chest, as pictured:  



 Reproduced from: U.S. National Library of Medicine 
*Dark red spots are biopsy sites  

Biopsy histopathology shows hyperkeratosis, follicular plugging, and a mononuclear T-cell infiltrate. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
