Cutaneous lupus erythematosus describes the broad group of cutaneous lesions that are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Cutaneous lupus erythematosus encompasses both the lupus erythematosus-specific skin diseases (malar rash, discoid lupus) as well as the lupus nonspecific skin diseases, including nonscarring alopecia and vascular abnormalities like livedo reticularis and Raynaud's phenomenon.  



Among patients who present with isolated cutaneous lupus erythematosus, approximately 10% will be diagnosed with SLE within 5 years. This association highlights the fact that skin manifestations may be the earliest signs of SLE.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cutaneous lupus erythematosus:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Hepatitis C infection:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C infection has been associated with the skin condition lichen planus, in which autoreactive T lymphocytes attack basal keratinocytes in the skin. Lesions are purple, planar, polygonal, pruritic papules or plaques.  
❌ Psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis is a chronic, intermittently relapsing disease caused by aberrant T cell and keratinocyte function. Skin lesions are characterized by sharply demarcated, erythematous, silvery, scaly plaques on the elbows, knees, and scalp.  
❌ Dermatomyositis:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is a multisystem autoimmune connective tissue disease characterized by symmetric, proximal inflammatory myopathy. The pathognomonic lesion is the heliotrope rash: a violaceous, edematous periorbital edema that may be slightly scaly.  
❌ Polymyositis:
Incorrect: Polymyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by symmetric proximal muscle weakness and elevated creatine kinase (a muscle enzyme). Skin lesions are not typically associated with polymyositis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the clinic due to intermittent difficulty swallowing for the past few months. The patient describes intermittent difficulty swallowing solids, which is often relieved by drinking fluids and after self-induced regurgitation. There is no associated weight loss or fatigue. Medical history is notable for a sliding hiatal hernia, hypertension, and long term gastroesophageal reflux disease. Medications include proton pump inhibitors and thiazides. The patient does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. The rest of the physical examination is normal. Endoscopy is performed, and the results are equivocal. Barium esophagogram is obtained and reveals the following:  


 

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a long history of gastroesophageal reflux disease is now presenting with intermittent dysphagia to solids. The barium swallow test reveals distal, symmetric, circumferential narrowing of the esophagus, favoring the diagnosis of a Schatzki ring.   

Schatzki rings (esophageal rings) are concentric bands of mucosa and submucosa that typically occur at the lower esophagus. The etiology is unknown but has been mostly associated with chronic damage from gastroesophageal reflux. Schatzki rings are almost always associated with hiatal hernias. Patients typically present with intermittent dysphagia to solids, although some may be asymptomatic depending on the size of the ring. Diagnosis is made with an endoscopy or barium swallow test (more sensitive), showing a concentric band of mucosa, protruding into the lumen. On biopsy, rings are composed of mucosa and submucosa, hyperkeratosis and occasional eosinophils. Biopsy is always performed on endoscopy because Schatzki rings are often associated with eosinophilic esophagitis. Treatment consists of proton pump inhibitors and surgical intervention (e.g. balloon, myomectomy).  

Option Analysis

❌ Esophageal carcinoma:
Incorrect: Esophageal carcinoma typically presents with progressive dysphagia to solids initially, followed by dysphagia to liquids, and it is usually accompanied by weight loss. The most common types are squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma. Esophageal carcinoma typically presents as an irregular mass on endoscopy and/or on a barium swallow test. This patient’s presentation and imaging favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Esophageal stricture:
Incorrect: Esophageal stricture is caused by fibrotic changes in the esophagus most commonly caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Similar to rings, it presents with symptoms of dysphagia; however, strictures are longer in axial length and have tapered ends rather than symmetrical concentric narrowing.   
✅ Esophageal ring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Esophageal web:
Incorrect: An esophageal web is a thin mucosal membrane that grows into the esophageal lumen and may cause dysphagia. Esophageal webs are often missed on upper endoscopy because of their proximity to the upper esophageal sphincter. Esophageal webs are more common in the proximal esophagus and are usually not circumferential. Webs are also associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.   
❌ Achalasia :
Incorrect: Achalasia is a motility disorder of the esophagus caused by degeneration on the inhibitory neurons in the esophageal wall, resulting in dysphagia to both solids and liquids. Barium swallow typically shows distal stenosis (“bird’s beak”), rather than symmetrical circumferential narrowing.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to dysphagia accompanied by food impaction and upper abdominal pain for the past few months. He had tried multiple over the counter antacids with minimal relief. Past medical history is notable for gastroesophageal reflux disease and seasonal allergies. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 10 years. An endoscopy is performed, and the results are shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely pathogenesis involved in this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Transient decreases in lower esophageal sphincter tone

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of atopy (e.g. allergies) is presenting with dysphagia, food impaction, and upper abdominal pain. Along with the endoscopy results showing stacked circular rings ("feline" esophagus) and refractoriness to antacid therapy, the most likely diagnosis is eosinophilic esophagitis.   

Eosinophilic esophagitis is a chronic, atopic, inflammatory disease of the esophagus. The condition is frequently seen in men aged 20-40 but may also be seen in children. Patients typically present with complaints such as dysphagia, food impaction, chest pain unresponsive to antacids, refractory GERD, and upper abdominal pain. Patients typically have an atopic history (e.g., asthma, dermatitis). The diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis is based on the symptoms, endoscopic appearance, and histological findings.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Loss of postganglionic inhibitory neurons:
Incorrect: Loss of postganglionic inhibitory neurons is the pathogenesis behind achalasia, which is characterized by progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids. An upper endoscopy may reveal a dilated esophagus and difficulty passing through the lower esophageal sphincter. Barium swallow would likely show a dilated esophagus with an area of distal stenosis (“bird’s beak”).   
✅ Eosinophilic infiltration of the esophagus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transient decreases in lower esophageal sphincter tone:
Incorrect: Transient decreases in lower esophageal sphincter tone is the pathogenesis behind gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Patients typically present with heartburn, regurgitation, dysphagia, and occasional cough or hoarseness. Although this patient has some features of GERD, the symptoms have been unresponsive to antacid treatment, and the endoscopy results favor another diagnosis. 
❌ Smooth muscle atrophy:
Incorrect: Smooth muscle atrophy is the pathogenesis behind sclerodermal esophageal dysmotility, which can present as reflux, dysphagia, aspiration, and strictures. However, other systemic symptoms would be expected (i.e., calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia [CREST]).   
❌ Iron deficiency anemia:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency anemia is the mechanism behind Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which presents with a classic triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs (as seen in the endoscopic image below). Other symptoms may include glossitis, angular cheilitis, koilonychia, splenomegaly, and symptoms of iron deficiency anemia (e.g., fatigue, conjunctival pallor). This patient's presentation favors another diagnosis.    


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath. The patient was sitting on the couch watching television when symptoms began. Past medical history includes a myocardial infarction 7 days ago, after which he was started on multiple medications including aspirin, atorvastatin, carvedilol, heparin, lisinopril, and clopidogrel. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Physical exam reveals clear breath sound bilaterally. Electrocardiography (ECG) shows sinus tachycardia. Computed tomography (CT) of the chest is obtained and shown below.  

 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons  

Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has acute shortness of breath, tachypnea, tachycardia, and saddle embolus on chest CT in the setting of recent heparin administration. He has a pulmonary embolism (PE) likely due to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).   

HIT is an immune-mediated disease that occurs in patients following heparin administration. Normally, heparin acts by binding and inhibiting antithrombin III, thus preventing secondary hemostasis. However, in HIT, heparin molecules bind proteins on the surface of platelets called platelet-factor-4 (PF-4), forming immunogenic heparin-PF4 complexes that are destroyed in the spleen. Activated platelets also release procoagulants, such as thromboxane A2 (TXA2), which cause more platelets to activate. This process leads to a hypercoagulable state, increased clot formation, and thrombocytopenia due to excessive consumption of platelets.  

 


The gold standard for diagnosing HIT is the serotonin release assay. Management of HIT includes immediately discontinuing heparin and administering a thrombin inhibitor, such as argatroban and bivalirudin. If the patient had a thrombotic event, such as a deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism, argatroban therapy should be continued for 3-6 months. In the absence of a thrombotic event, the patient should be given argatroban therapy until platelet count normalizes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Thrombocytopenia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Leukocytosis:
Incorrect: Leukocytosis would be present in patients with infection, inflammation, and certain malignancies. In contrast, this patient has a history and imaging findings more consistent with a pulmonary embolism, which would not typically cause leukocytosis.    
❌ Anemia:
Incorrect: Conditions such as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) may cause anemia. However, this patient has no history of risk factors (e.g., systemic infection, malignancy) that would predispose him to any of these conditions.   
❌ Increased prothrombin time  :
Incorrect: Increased prothrombin time would be expected in warfarin toxicity. Patients with warfarin toxicity would present with increased bleeding, as opposed to a hypercoagulable state.  
❌ Increased activated partial thromboplastin time:
Incorrect: Increased activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) would be expected in patients with heparin overdose. However, a patient with heparin toxicity would present with increased bleeding, as opposed to a hypercoagulable state.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the physician's office due to progressive fatigue, chest discomfort, and dyspnea. One week ago, he had an upper respiratory infection that resolved without treatment. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the last 25 years. Temperature is 38.0°C ( 100.4°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 85/67 mmHg. ECG is obtained and shown below:  

 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is most likely to be found on physical examination of this patient?

choices.text: Drop in systolic pressure during inspiration
Absence of an inspiratory decline in jugular venous pressure

questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with fatigue, dyspnea, hypotension, and tachycardia following an upper respiratory infection, raises concern for cardiac tamponade due to pericarditis. The ECG shows electrical alternans, which refers to the beat-to-beat variations in the amplitude of the QRS complex. These changes are thought to be caused by the anterior-posterior swinging of the heart with each contraction in the fluid-filled pericardial sac. As the heart swings posteriorly, the electrical signals detected by the electrodes travel over a greater distance through the fluid, resulting in reduced voltage at the electrodes. This finding is fairly specific but not very sensitive for cardiac tamponade.  

Cardiac tamponade occurs when large amounts of fluid accumulate between the layers of the pericardium (pericardial effusion), resulting in compression of the heart. Common etiologies include infectious, trauma, metabolic, autoimmune, cancer or idiopathic. Presentation may be acute and develop over minutes (e.g. trauma) or subacute, which develops over hours to days (e.g., uremia, post-viral) when enough fluid accumulates. The classic triad of symptoms, known as the Beck triad, consists of hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds. Other signs and symptoms include syncope, chest pain, and pulsus paradoxus. The latter refers to an abnormal decrease in the systolic blood pressure (>10 mmHg) observed during inspiration.  

Option Analysis

❌ S4 heart sound:
Incorrect: The S4 heart sound is an extra heart sound that occurs during late diastole (“atrial kick”), immediately before S1. It is associated with ventricular noncompliance seen in conditions such as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, and hypertension. It can also occur during an acute MI due to stiffness of the involved myocardium. This patient’s presentation and ECG findings instead favor the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.   
❌ Pulsation of the nail bed:
Incorrect: Quincke's pulses refers to the capillary pulsations observed in the fingertips or lips seen in aortic regurgitation due to a widened pulse pressure. This patient’s presentation and ECG findings instead favor the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.   
❌ Slow-rising low-amplitude pulse:
Incorrect: Slow-rising low-amplitude (weak pulse with delayed peak) pulse also known as “pulsus parvus et tardus” can be seen in aortic stenosis due to left ventricular outlet obstruction. In contrast, this patient’s presentation and ECG findings favor the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.   
✅ Drop in systolic pressure during inspiration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Absence of an inspiratory decline in jugular venous pressure:
Incorrect: Kussmaul's sign refers to the absence of an inspiratory decline in jugular venous pressure seen in conditions such as constrictive pericarditis, restrictive pericarditis, and right atrial or ventricular tumors. Under normal conditions, the jugular venous pressure decreases during inspiration because the fall in intrathoracic pressure produces a “sucking effect” on venous return. In patients with constrictive pericarditis, the increase in intra-abdominal pressure during inspiration contributes to the increase in CVP, although the exact mechanism is unclear. This patient’s presentation and ECG findings instead favor the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 2-hour-old newborn boy is evaluated in the nursery for breathing difficulty. He was born at term to a 22-year-old primigravida mother who received no prenatal care. He is at the 35th percentile for length and below the 10th for weight. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. On physical examination, the infant appears in distress. Subcostal retractions and nasal flaring are present. Low-set ears, retrognathia, flattened nose, and bilateral feet deformities are noted. Abdominal examination reveals bilaterally enlarged masses. Which of the following additional findings would most likely be discovered upon further evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
This newborn infant has Potter sequence, which is characterized by limb deformities, facial anomalies, and pulmonary hypoplasia. Potter sequence is caused by low amniotic fluid volume, which leads to compression of the fetus and abnormal development. Although Potter sequence is associated with many conditions, the presence of bilateral abdominal masses suggests that autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is the underlying cause.  

ARPKD, as the name implies, is an autosomal recessive genetic condition characterized by cystic dilation of the collecting ducts. It is also associated with biliary dysgenesis and hepatic fibrosis. The condition is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene located on chromosome 6p21, which encodes for a membrane protein called fibrocystin (or polyductin). Fibrocystin’s function is unknown, but it can be found throughout the kidneys and hepatic ducts.  

The clinical presentation of ARPKD varies and is based on the age of onset as well as extent of hepatic and/or renal involvement. Patients may present with Potter sequence, bilateral flank masses, hypertension, progressive renal insufficiency, and portal hypertension due to congenital hepatic fibrosis. Note that in contrast to ARPKD, autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease manifests in adulthood.  

Option Analysis

❌ Saccular aneurysm:
Incorrect: Berry aneurysms are associated with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). ADPKD typically presents in adulthood with flank pain, hematuria, hypertension, urinary tract infections, and progressive renal failure. The condition is also associated with mitral valve prolapse, benign hepatic cysts, and diverticulosis. This patient's early presentation favors another diagnosis.    
❌ Aniridia :
Incorrect: Aniridia is associated with the WAGR complex, a genetic condition that presents with Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma), aniridia (absence of the iris), genitourinary malformations, and intellectual disability. It arises due to mutations in the WT1 or WT2 genes. Wilms tumor presents as a unilateral smooth mass that does not typically cross the midline. In contrast, this patient has bilateral abdominal masses.  
❌ Duodenal atresia:
Incorrect: Duodenal atresia is associated with Down syndrome (trisomy 21). Down syndrome would not present with the bilateral foot deformities, hypertension, and bilateral abdominal masses described in this vignette.  
✅ Hepatic fibrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Horseshoe kidney:
Incorrect: Horseshoe kidney is an anomaly wherein the kidneys are fused in the inferior pole and trapped under the inferior mesenteric artery. Most often, patients are asymptomatic and have normal kidney function. Some patients may develop hydronephrosis, renal stones, and infections. The condition is associated with chromosomal aneuploidy syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome, trisomies 13, 18, 21). However, the constellation of findings in this patients is more consistent with autosomal recessive polycystic disease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male college student suddenly collapses and dies while playing in a football game. His teammate reports that the patient mentioned “feeling off” just before the game started but attributed it to being nervous for the game. Medical history is noncontributory, and the parents report that he was completely healthy and took no medications. According to friends, the patient drank approximately 2-3 beers on weekends and did not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy young athlete died from sudden cardiac death (SCD) [or sudden cardiac arrest (SCA)], which is most commonly due to a fatal ventricular tachyarrhythmia (e.g. ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation). SCD (or SCA) refers to the sudden cessation of cardiac activity along with hemodynamic collapse, which most commonly occurs in the setting of an ongoing ventricular tachyarrhythmia. The majority of patients experience chest pain and/or dyspnea 1 hour prior to the event.  

Causes of SCD can be divided according to the etiology as follows: in adults over the age of 35, it is most often associated with coronary artery disease; however, in younger adults, other causes should be investigated, including cardiomyopathies and hereditary ion channelopathies. Risk factors for CAD overlap risk factors for SCD. These include hypertension, dyslipidemia, physical inactivity, cigarette smoking, obesity, diabetes mellitus, and a family history of premature CAD or myocardial infarction.    

Option Analysis

❌ Aortic dissection:
Incorrect: Aortic dissection presents with sudden-onset of tearing chest pain radiating to the back. Aortic dissection can be fatal; however, it is usually seen in patients with risk factors such as hypertension, bicuspid aortic valve, and inherited connective tissue disorders (e.g. Marfan syndrome).   
❌ Ventricular free wall rupture:
Incorrect: Ventricular free wall rupture is a possible complication seen after acute myocardial infarction (MI), and usually occurs within the first 2 weeks following the MI. This young patient has no known medical history or risk factors suggestive of coronary artery disease.   
❌ Pericarditis :
Incorrect: Pericarditis can be seen after myocardial infarction (MI) or viral illness, and is not a common cause of sudden cardiac death. Patients commonly present with sharp chest pain that is aggravated by inspiration and relieved by sitting up and leaning forward.   
❌ Atrial fibrillation:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation is a common cause of arrhythmias; however, it is not a common cause of sudden cardiac death.   
✅ Ventricular tachyarrhythmia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic due to abdominal discomfort, fatigue, and weight loss for the past three months. He states the pain is mainly in the right upper quadrant and describes the pain as vague, 3/10, and constant. He immigrated from Bolivia 2 years ago. Immunizations are up to date. Medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals an icteric patient. On abdominal examination, pain is produced when pressure is applied to the right subcostal area. An abdominal ultrasound examination shows calcification within the gallbladder. When the patient is asked to lie on his side, the calcifications are observed at the same location. Which of the following is a risk factor for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with constitutional signs (e.g., fatigue, weight loss), vague progressive abdominal pain, and jaundice; this presentation, in conjunction with the abdominal ultrasound findings, suggests a malignancy of the gallbladder. The ultrasound exam depicts a calcified mass that does not move with position change, indicating that the mass is fixed rather than moveable like gallstones.

Gallbladder cancer (GBC) is a rare but highly fatal malignancy. The most common types are adenocarcinomas and less commonly squamous cell carcinoma, small cell neuroendocrine tumors, lymphoma, and sarcoma. The majority of cases are found incidentally in patients undergoing exploration for cholelithiasis. The poor prognosis is likely to be due to the typically advanced stage at the time of diagnosis, which is thought to be the result of both the anatomic position of the gallbladder and the nonspecific symptoms of the condition. Patients with early invasive disease are usually asymptomatic or may present with nonspecific symptoms that mimic or are due to cholelithiasis or cholecystitis. Among symptomatic patients, common presenting symptoms are pain, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, malaise, and weight loss. Patients with GBC may also present with obstructive jaundice, either from invasion of the biliary tree or from metastases to the area of the hepatoduodenal ligament.  

Multiple risk factors have been identified to be associated with GBC: 
  •  Gallstone disease ‐ a history of gallstones appears to be one of the strongest risk factors for the development of GBC 
  •  Porcelain gallbladder ‐ an uncommon manifestation of chronic cholecystitis that is characterized by intramural calcification of the gallbladder wall 
  •  Gallbladder polyps ‐ outgrowths of the gallbladder mucosal wall that are usually found incidentally on ultrasonography and can be classified as benign or malignant lesions 
  •  Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) ‐ a chronic inflammatory state associated with ulcerative colitis 
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hepatitis B infection:
Incorrect: Chronic hepatitis B infection is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma, not adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder. Additionally, this patient has updated immunizations.   
❌ Primary biliary cholangitis:
Incorrect: Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by progressive destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts of the liver, scarring, and fibrosis. It is commonly seen in middle-aged women. It is associated with other autoimmune conditions (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis, rheumatoid arthritis), but it is not associated with adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder.   
✅ Gallstone disease  :
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Ionizing radiation:
Incorrect: Ionizing radiation is associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma and leukemias. It is not associated with adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder.   
❌ Clonorchis sinensis infection:
Incorrect: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis, a trematode (fluke), increases the risk of cholangiocarcinoma, a cancer of the bile ducts. Cholangiocarcinoma, like other malignancies, can present with fatigue, abdominal pain, and weight loss. However, an abdominal ultrasound would instead show biliary ductal dilatation, rather than a calcified mass within the gallbladder.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to persistent nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for one day. The patient has been unable to tolerate oral intake. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The patient’s parents report he has been meeting all developmental milestones, but sometimes does not respond when his name is called. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg. On physical exam, the patient is actively vomiting and has dry oral mucous membranes. The patient is given intravenous fluids and ondansetron. Several minutes later, the following is observed on telemetry:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following features most likely precipitated this electrocardiographic finding?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy child presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea likely due to a viral gastroenteritis. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable, aside from possible concerns for sensorineural hearing loss. This, in conjunction with the telemetry findings of torsade de pointe after ondansetron (which increases the QT interval) administration, raises suspicion for the inherited QT-prolongation disorder Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome.   

Torsade de pointes means “twisting of the points” and is a subtype of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, defined by a ventricular rate >200 beats per minute, undulating QRS axis, and paroxysms of < 90 seconds. If untreated, torsade de pointe can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation, cardiogenic shock, and sudden cardiac death. Overall, the major risk factor for developing torsade de pointes is QT interval prolongation, of which there are numerous causes.  

The most common causes of QT prolongation include electrolyte abnormalities such as hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia (often precipitated by gastrointestinal losses) and medications such as class IA and IC antiarrhythmics, antidepressants, antidopaminergics, antiemetics or anticonvulsants. Less commonly, congenital conditions such as Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome (associated with deafness, autosomal recessive) or Romano-Ward syndrome (normal hearing, autosomal dominant) can cause QT prolongation. Treatment of torsade de pointes involves empiric intravenous magnesium sulfate and cardioversion or overdrive pacing for patients with sustained torsade de pointe and unstable vital signs.   

Option Analysis

✅ Prolonged QT interval  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prolonged PR interval :
Incorrect: Widened QRS complex
❌ Widened QRS complex:
Incorrect: Widened QRS complexes are generally seen when conduction is triggered by the ventricles (in the setting of tachyarrhythmias). Other etiologies include hyperkalemia, sodium channel blockade, hypothermia, and pre-excitation syndromes such as Wolff-Parkinson White.   
❌ T-wave inversion:
Incorrect: T-wave inversions are often the first indicators of ongoing cardiac ischemia. They do not precipitate polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.   
❌ ST-segment depression :
Incorrect: Similar to T-wave inversions, ST-segment depressions are ominous signs of ongoing cardiac ischemia. However, T-wave inversions do not typically precipitate polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of progressive exertional dyspnea. He states he has had worsening shortness of breath when walking down the block to the grocery store. He does not have a productive cough. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. He has a 42-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a thin male with an increased anterior-posterior chest diameter. Lung auscultation reveals scattered wheezes bilaterally. Cardiac auscultation reveals normal S1 and S2. Neck veins are nondistended. Which of the following additional findings is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Reversal of dyspnea with albuterol administration

questions.solution:
This patient has dyspnea, wheezing, and increased anterior-posterior chest diameter in the setting of a long smoking history. He most likely has emphysema.

Emphysema describes permanent alveoli enlargement and loss of alveolar wall elasticity. It is most commonly caused by an irritant, such as tobacco smoke, which triggers inflammation in the alveoli. Inflammatory cells (e.g. neutrophils) gather in the lungs and release destructive proteases, which degrade connective tissue in the alveolar walls. The alveoli become progressively weaker, lose their ability to stretch and recoil, and eventually collapse, resulting in air trapping.  

To mitigate this symptom, patients learn to expire slowly with pursed lips, which raises airway pressure and prevents airway collapse. The classic emphysematous patient is described as a “pink puffer,” since in the early stages of the disease, the alveoli are still able to participate in gas exchange, and cyanosis is absent. Additionally, due to air-trapping and hyperinflation of the lungs, individuals tend to develop a barrel-shaped chest.   

In contrast, patients with chronic bronchitis are classically described as “blue bloaters”. This is because obstruction of airflow can get so severe that deoxygenated blood from the right heart reaches the left heart without participating in adequate gas exchange. As a result, patients with chronic bronchitis can appear cyanotic.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Pursed-lip breathing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Clubbing of digits:
Incorrect: Clubbing of the digits is not typically seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), even in patients with associated hypoxemia. If digital clubbing is present, it raises concerns for comorbidities such as lung cancer, interstitial lung disease, or bronchiectasis.
❌ Hepatomegaly:
Incorrect: Hepatomegaly can be seen in patients with alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. The condition causes liver injury and emphysema, due to increased elastase activity and lung tissue breakdown. AAT deficiency typically manifests in individuals between 40 to 50-years-old who have little or no smoking history. In contrast, this patient is more than 60-years-old and has a long smoking history, making another diagnosis more likely.
❌ Reversal of dyspnea with albuterol administration:
Incorrect: Dyspnea that improves with albuterol administration is characteristic of asthma, which is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction. In contrast, this patient has persistent shortness of breath, wheezing, and a long smoking history, which is concerning for emphysema. Symptoms of emphysema would not improve with albuterol administration.
❌ Peripheral edema:
Incorrect: Over time, pulmonary hypertension puts strain on the right heart and can lead to right heart failure (RHF), also termed cor pulmonale. RHF typically manifests with jugular venous distention, peripheral edema, S3 heart sound, and hepatomegaly due to congestion. This patient’s non-distended neck veins and normal heart sounds make RHF unlikely.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male comes to the clinic due to a productive cough. The patient has had a purulent, productive cough for the past few years and has recently noticed bloody streaks in his sputum. He has a history of recurrent sinus infections that improve with antibiotic treatment. The patient does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit substances. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 124/75 mm Hg. Lung auscultation reveals diffuse wheezes and crackles. Cardiovascular examination shows a cardiac point of maximal impulse that is palpated at the right 5th intercostal space. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a productive cough in the setting of recurrent sinus infections and situs inversus, as indicated by the point of maximal impulse being located in the right chest. These findings are suggestive of bronchiectasis secondary to primary ciliary dyskinesia (also termed Kartagener syndrome).  

In healthy individuals, coordinated movement of the cilia is necessary for removal of overlying mucus and pathogens. Therefore, the mucociliary escalator is the primary defense mechanism of the airways. In patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia, an autosomal recessive mutation results in dysmotile cilia. These patients have impaired clearance of mucus and pathogens, which leads to chronic sinopulmonary symptoms. Recurrent infections cause permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles due to destruction of smooth muscle and supporting elastic tissue, resulting in bronchiectasis.   

Bronchiectasis presents clinically as a persistent cough that produces copious amounts of purulent, foul-smelling sputum. Pulmonary function testing will reveal findings consistent with obstructive pulmonary disease secondary to air trapping.  



Option Analysis

❌ Episodes of bronchial hyperreactivity :
Incorrect: Asthma can cause a persistent and chronic cough in patients. However, this patient’s recurrent pulmonary infections and situs inversus (presence of cardiac point of maximal impulse in the right chest) are more suggestive of a different diagnosis. 
✅ Ciliary dysfunction :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Abnormal ion conductance:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis is caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene, which encodes for a transmembrane chloride channel. Although this patient is presenting with recurrent pulmonary infections and a chronic, persistent cough, the finding of situs inversus makes another diagnosis more likely. 
❌ Protease-mediated destruction of alveolar walls:
Incorrect: Emphysema secondary to alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency can result in dyspnea and a chronic, persistent cough. However, patients also typically present with signs of hepatic dysfunction (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis). This patient’s situs inversus makes another diagnosis more likely. 
❌ Widespread formation of noncaseating granulomas:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis can result in a chronic, nonproductive cough. However, it would not account for the patient’s situs inversus.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old male is in the cardiac intensive care unit due to decompensated heart failure. He has been undergoing diuretic therapy with a bumetanide intravenous infusion for the past week. The patient’s hospital course has been complicated by Clostridium difficile colitis, and he has had multiple episodes of profuse diarrhea. During rounds, the patient becomes acutely altered. A telemetry monitoring rhythm strip is shown below.  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia  

Which of the following electrolyte disturbances is the most likely precipitant of these ECG findings?
questions.solution:
The above telemetry strip is consistent with torsades de pointes, or polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. This dangerous arrhythmia is most commonly associated with hypomagnesemia and can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation if the underlying cause is not promptly addressed. This patient has been undergoing loop diuretic therapy with concomitant diarrhea, which likely led to dangerously low magnesium levels.  

Magnesium is a divalent cation that has importance in membrane stability, muscle contraction, metabolism, and neuronal transmission. Hypomagnesima generally occurs due to either gastrointestinal losses or renal losses. Examples of gastrointestinal losses include prolonged malnutrition, diarrhea, malabsorption syndromes, or proton pump inhibitor therapy. Renal losses occur commonly due to diuretic therapy, uncontrolled diabetes, or congenital conditions such as Gitelman syndrome.    

Regardless of the cause, the symptoms of hypomagnesemia are similar and include convulsions, seizures, tetany, and ventricular arrhythmias. Hypomagnesemia may also cause a prolonged QT interval that can degrade into torsades de pointes.   

Option Analysis

✅ Hypomagnesemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypophosphatemia:
Incorrect: Hypophosphatemia is not commonly observed in patients taking loop diuretics. Conditions associated with hypophosphatemia include chronic alcohol use, urinary phosphate-wasting syndromes (e.g. Fanconi syndrome), or chronic ingestion of antacids and phosphate binders.
❌ Hypocalcemia :
Incorrect: Hypocalcemia can cause a prolonged QT interval and degrade into torsades de pointes. However, it is a much rarer cause than hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia. 
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Diuretics and dehydration from infectious colitis can precipitate hyponatremia; however, acute hyponatremia tends to present with nausea, headache, malaise, and seizures. In addition, hyponatremia tends to present with non-specific ECG findings. 
❌ Hypoglycemia :
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia can present with altered mental status and stupor; however, hypoglycemia in and of itself is not associated with ECG changes.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe lower abdominal pain for the last 4 hours. He has not urinated for the past 24 hours and adds that he has had poor urine flow and difficulty initiating urination for the past 6 months; he also needs to get up multiple times throughout the night to urinate. He denies weight loss, dysuria, or urinary urgency. He has had seasonal allergies for the past week, for which he started taking diphenhydramine as needed. He does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a palpable mass in the suprapubic area. A symmetric, enlarged, non-tender prostate is palpated on digital rectal examination. Urinary catheter is placed with immediate collection of 700 mL of urine and relief of the patient’s symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with severe lower abdominal pain, inability to urinate (anuria), palpable suprapubic mass and evidence of excess urine in the bladder is consistent with acute urinary retention (AUR).   

Given the long-standing history of obstructive symptoms (poor urinary flow and hesitancy) in this patient, it most likely occurred secondary to untreated benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) which can lead to bladder outlet obstruction (BOO). BOO can be precipitated by over-the-counter medications, such as diphenhydramine, an antihistamine with anticholinergic activity (inhibiting bladder contraction) that is used to alleviate allergic symptoms (as in this patient). Diagnosis of AUR is made on bladder ultrasound or catheterization demonstrating retained urine in the bladder.  

Other complications of BPH include: 
  • Overflow incontinence: Occurs due to contraction of the enlarged prostate against the urethra, which impinges on the bladder neck, leading to incomplete emptying of the bladder that may progress to overflow incontinence over time. 
  • Urinary tract infection (UTI): The residual urine in the bladder may serve as a growth medium for pathogenic microorganisms, leading to UTI. 
  •  Chronic kidney disease: Hypertrophy of bladder musculature and dilation of the ureters, renal pelvis and calyces (hydronephrosis) occur in response to increased hydrostatic pressure at the bladder neck. If left untreated, it can lead to chronic kidney disease. 

Option Analysis

❌ Transitional cell carcinoma of bladder:
Incorrect: Bladder carcinoma usually manifests as hematuria in patients with a history of smoking or chemicals/carcinogen exposure from a workplace. Obstructive urinary symptoms (poor urine stream and hesitancy) are less common. An enlarged symmetric, non-tender prostate on DRE suggests an alternative diagnosis.
✅ Bladder outlet obstruction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: UTI can present with poor urine flow and difficulty initiating urine. Bacteria can grow in stagnant urine in the bladder resulting in UTI. The findings of an enlarged symmetric, non-tender prostate on DRE and acute urinary retention are inconsistent with this diagnosis.
❌ Chronic abacterial prostatitis:
Incorrect: Chronic abacterial prostatitis usually manifests as chronic pelvic pain (perineal, testicular, suprapubic or penile) for at least three months in the absence of other identifiable cause. Obstructive urinary symptoms and an enlarged, symmetric, non-tender prostate on DRE are atypical.
❌ Prostate adenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Prostate adenocarcinoma can cause urinary symptoms by compressing or invading the urethra or bladder. Digital rectal examination, however, would reveal prostatic nodules, induration, and/or asymmetry.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, presents to the emergency department with complaints of lower abdominal pain and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She gave birth to a healthy female newborn 2 days ago. Vaginal delivery was converted into emergency cesarean section due to obstructed labor, and the placenta was removed manually. Past medical history is significant for pre-gestational diabetes mellitus type II as well as Neisseria gonorrhoeae cervicitis when the patient was 19, for which she was treated appropriately. Temperature is 101.4°F (38.5 °C), pulse is 100/minute, respirations are 19/minute, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. BMI is 33 kg/m2. On physical examination, there is mild peri-incisional tenderness, minimal discharge at the surgical site, and no erythema or edema around the incision site. Foul-smelling greenish-yellow lochia is observed in the vaginal vault. Bimanual examination shows cervical motion and uterine tenderness. Complete blood profile shows hemoglobin of 12 g/dL and leukocyte count of 18,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of lower abdominal pain, foul-smelling purulent vaginal discharge, high-grade fever and uterine tenderness are consistent with the diagnosis of endometritis. 

Endometritis is a polymicrobial infection of the endometrium. Most of the organisms are part of the endogenous cervicovaginal flora that travel upwards during labor and delivery. Route of delivery is the most important risk factor in the development of postpartum endometritis. Up to 30% of cases occur after cesarean deliveries (especially those performed after the onset of labor or rupture of membranes) as compared to <3% after vaginal birth. Other proposed risk factors include prolonged rupture of membranes, retained products of conception following delivery, uncontrolled maternal diabetes and heavy vaginal colonization by E. coli. However, none is as significant as the route of delivery.    

Endometritis can be either acute or chronic. Acute endometritis typically presents with symptoms like fever, vaginal discharge and/or bleeding, lower abdominal pain, dysuria and cervical motion and uterine tenderness, whereas chronic endometritis is usually asymptomatic with normal physical examination. Presence of neutrophils on microscopic examination is the hallmark of acute endometritis, whereas as plasma cells are seen in chronic endometritis. Combination of clindamycin and gentamicin is the treatment of choice for these patients.  



Option Analysis

❌ Surgical site infection:
Incorrect: Although this patient has systemic signs of an infection, and surgical site infection is a likely cause after this patient’s cesarean delivery, it is unlikely given the physical examination findings showing minimal incision-site erythema, edema, or discharge. 
❌ Pyelonephritis:
Incorrect: Pyelonephritis is characterized by fever (>100.4°F), chills, flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, and lower urinary tract symptoms. Pyuria and/or a positive urine culture supports the diagnosis. This patient has no costovertebral tenderness or urinary complaints, and the uterine tenderness supports a different diagnosis. 
✅ Endometritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis:
Incorrect: Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis (SPT) is a rare condition that occurs in the setting of pelvic vein damage, venous stasis, and hypercoagulability, often following delivery or surgery. SPT should be suspected if there is a persistent fever in the weeks following delivery despite antibiotic therapy. Given this patient’s uterine tenderness in the days following cesarean delivery, however, another diagnosis is more likely. 
❌ Pelvic inflammatory disease:
Incorrect: Pelvic inflammatory disease occurs secondary to a vaginal or cervical infection, typically caused by N. gonorrhoeae or C. trachomatis.  Common presentations include acute pelvic pain, cervical motion tenderness, vaginal discharge, fever, dyspareunia, and leukocytosis. Although this patient has vaginal discharge and cervical motion tenderness, the recent cesarean delivery and uterine tenderness support a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn male is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit for breathing difficulty. The patient was born at 39 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery at home, and this is his first medical evaluation. The mother is a 26-year-old woman who had minimal prenatal care. She reports that he “was fine” after birth, but after the first few days, she noted a constant bluish color of his lips. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 84% on room air. Physical exam shows low-set ears and bulbous nasal tip. Cardiac auscultation reveals a loud, single second heart sound and bounding peripheral pulses. Chest radiograph shows pulmonary congestion with increased pulmonary markings and decreased soft-tissue attenuation in the right anterior mediastinum. Which of the following cardiac defects is most likely to be seen with further analysis of this patient?
questions.solution:
This infant presenting with progressive cyanosis, absent thymus tissue (decreased soft-tissue attenuation in the right anterior mediastinum) and increased pulmonary markings on chest radiograph as well as characteristic facial appearance (low-set ears and bulbous nasal tip) most likely has DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion) with concomitant persistent truncus arteriosus.   

During the early stages of embryological heart development, the great vessels originate from a single truncus arteriosus (single arterial root). Persistent truncus arteriosus occurs when the single trunk fails to divide into the aorta and pulmonary trunk due to a defect in the aorticopulmonary septum formation. This is often accompanied by a single truncal valve and ventricular septal defect.  

Immediately after birth, the pulmonary vascular resistance is initially high, which causes relatively little left-to-right shunt through the single trunk. This allows a relatively normal amount of blood flow into the pulmonary circulation. However, as the pulmonary vascular resistance drops, the left-to-right shunting increases, leading to pulmonary overload, cyanosis, and heart failure.    

Cardiovascular findings include single second heart sound, ejection click at the apex or left sternal border, bounding peripheral pulses, and in patients with truncal valve regurgitation, a diastolic murmur may be heard along the left sternal border. On chest radiograph, cardiac enlargement, increased pulmonary markings and congestion are expected. The diagnosis is made by echocardiography and treatment includes medications for stabilization followed by surgical repair.

 



Option Analysis

❌ D-transposition of the great vessels:
Incorrect: D-transposition of the great vessels is another cause of early cyanosis and usually presents in the first days of life, depending on the associated cardiac defects (e.g., VSD, PDA). The chest radiograph of D-transposition of the great vessels will likely show an “egg on a string” appearance. However, the typical facial characteristics and the chest radiograph findings seen in this patient are consistent with the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion). DiGeorge syndrome is associated with Tetralogy of Fallot and persistent truncus arteriosus, not D-transposition of the great vessels.   
❌ Tricuspid atresia:
Incorrect: Tricuspid atresia often presents in the first days of life, depending on the presence of a ventricular septal defect. On physical examination, a single second heart sound (S2) can also be heard; however, the presence of bounding pulses and the chest radiograph findings in this case favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Tetralogy of Fallot:
Incorrect: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is also characterized by early cyanosis. The presentation is variable and depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. The typical facial characteristics and the chest radiograph findings seen in this patient are consistent with the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion). On physical examination, a single second heart sound (S2) is also heard; however, bounding pulses are characteristics of persistent truncus arteriosus. Moreover, TOF chest radiographs typically reveal a “boot-shaped” heart and decreased pulmonary markings, as the right ventricular outflow obstruction leads to decreased pulmonary flow.   
✅ Persistent truncus arteriosus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR):
Incorrect: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) is another cause of early cyanosis in which the four pulmonary veins fail to make their normal connection to the left atrium and instead drain into the right atrium. On physical examination, fixed splitting of the second heart sound occurs (S2) due to right ventricular overload, as well as a systolic ejection murmur due to increased volume across the pulmonary valve. On chest radiograph, the classic “snowman” appearance can sometimes be seen. The typical facial characteristics and the chest radiograph findings seen in this patient are consistent with the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion); DiGeorge syndrome is associated with Tetralogy of Fallot and persistent truncus arteriosus, not TAPVR.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of an enlarging painless neck mass. She first noticed the mass 3 weeks ago and reports that it has gotten progressively larger over time. The patient has also gained 10-lb in the last 6 weeks, and frequently has to wear a sweater when taking a walk in the park, even on hot days. She has not experienced any night sweats or fevers. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 52/min, blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg, and BMI is 27 kg/m2. Palpation of the neck reveals a fixed, hard, painless goiter. There is delayed tendon reflex relaxation in the lower extremities. A biopsy of the mass is performed, which shows compression of follicles by extensive dense fibrous tissue. Laboratory studies are done and show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 ESR  6 mm/h 
 TSH  7.1 μU/mL 
 Anti-thyroid peroxidase   Negative 
 Anti-thyroglobulin antibody  Negative  
 
If left untreated, which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hypothyroidism (e.g., feeling cold on a hot day, weight gain), as well as an enlarging neck mass. Taking into consideration the biopsy findings showing fibrous tissue growth in the thyroid, this patient likely has Riedel thyroiditis (invasive fibrous thyroiditis).  

Although the etiology of Riedel thyroiditis is unknown, it is thought to be related to systemic conditions that affect immunoglobulin G4, such as autoimmune pancreatitis, retroperitoneal fibrosis, and noninfectious aortitis. Patients most commonly present with a slowly growing, painless neck mass. The progressive growth can impinge on nearby structures, leading to dysphagia (esophagus), dyspnea (bronchial compression), hoarseness (recurrent laryngeal nerves), and even hypocalcemia (parathyroid glands). Biopsy findings show infiltration of the thyroid with dense, fibrotic tissue. Although some cases resolve spontaneously, surgery is frequently indicated to relieve the compressive symptoms.    

 

Option Analysis

✅ Dysphagia from esophageal compression:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Metastasis to distant organs:
Incorrect: Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid is an extremely aggressive, poorly differentiated neoplasm of the thyroid. Biopsy would show undifferentiated giant cells, as well as discrete areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Clinical symptoms are usually related to mass effect, such as esophageal compression resulting in dysphagia and bronchial compression resulting in dyspnea. Although this patient’s presentation could be worrisome for anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, the biopsy results make this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Elevated calcitonin levels :
Incorrect: Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is classically seen in patients with MEN2 (RET gene mutation). Biopsy would show cells of C-cell origin, as well as amyloid in the stroma that stains with Congo red. Calcitonin is a hormone that is over-secreted by the neoplastic C-cells and is often used as a tumor marker to detect recurrence. This patient’s biopsy results suggest a different diagnosis. 
❌ Protrusion of the eyes:
Incorrect: Exophthalmos, or protrusion of the eyes, is commonly seen in patients with Graves disease. TSH autoantibodies stimulate retro-orbital fibroblasts to secrete glycosaminoglycans, which pull water into the interstitial space, resulting in protrusion of the eyes. This patient is presenting with signs of hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism, which therefore makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Non-Hodgkin lymphoma of the thyroid  :
Incorrect: Chronic autoimmune (Hashimoto) thyroiditis is currently the only known risk factor for primary thyroid lymphoma. Hashimoto thyroiditis is typically diagnosed by the presence of anti-thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies or anti-thyroglobulin (Tg) antibodies, neither of which are present in this patient.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to odd behavior for the past several months. He was born at 38 weeks by vaginal delivery to a 29-year primigravida mother. The patient’s development has been normal, and all milestones have been reached. He performs well at school and language development is normal. The parents report that a couple of months ago, the patient started blinking excessively, which she attributed to dry eyes and allergies. Recently, the patient started grimacing often and occasionally moans for no apparent reason. The parents are worried because the patient has been bullied in school for the behavior. Vitals and physical examination are within normal limits. This patient is at increased risk for developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient has vocal tics (moaning) and motor tics (blinking, grimacing), a presentation that raises concern for Tourette syndrome (TS). The diagnosis of TS can be made if symptoms persist > 1 year.  

TS is a neurological disorder characterized by motor and phonic tics that occur during childhood. TS is thought to occur due to a disturbance in the cortico-striatal-thalamic-cortical (mesolimbic) circuit which results in disinhibition of the limbic and motor systems. Tics are the clinical hallmark of the condition and are typically sudden, brief, intermittent movements (motor tics) or utterances (phonic tics). The diagnosis of TS is based upon clinical presentation with onset before age 18.  

The majority of patients with TS have at least one or more comorbid problem. Most associations include attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Other comorbid conditions are learning disabilities, conduct disorder/oppositional defiant disorder, anxiety disorders, sleep disorders, mood disorders and increased risk of suicide.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.



Option Analysis

✅ Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Epilepsy:
Incorrect: Epilepsy has not been shown to be associated with Tourette syndrome.
❌ Antisocial personality disorder:
Incorrect: Although children with Tourette syndrome are at increased risk for conduct disorder, there is minimal evidence showing predisposition for developing antisocial personality disorder. 
❌ Type 1 diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Patients with Tourette syndrome (TS) are at increased risk of obesity, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular disorders. An added risk factor is that many children with TS are managed with antipsychotics (such as olanzapine), which carry the risk of adverse metabolic effects, such as weight gain, diabetes and hyperlipidemia. However, there is minimal evidence suggesting an increased risk of type 1 diabetes.
❌ Borderline personality disorder:
Incorrect: This patient has vocal tics (moaning) and motor tics (blinking, grimacing), a presentation that raises concern for Tourette syndrome (TS). The diagnosis of TS can be made if symptoms persist > 1 year.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the clinic due to progressive abnormal movement of the hands for the past several years. The patient first noticed both of his hands started shaking 3 years ago, and since then, the shaking has gotten worse. It occurs mainly when he reaches for objects, such as a glass of water or a magazine. The patient mentions that he had “shaky hands” in college when he studied for his finals and drank multiple cups of coffee. Medical history is non-contributory. The patient’s mother died from Alzheimer disease complications at the age of 79, and his father died of myocardial infarction at age 55. He recalls his father had a similar condition but cannot recall any details. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress and no shaking is present at rest. When the patient is asked to outstretch his arms, a mild oscillating, flexion-extension movement is noted bilaterally. Neurological examination, including gait, is within normal limits, except a positive finger-to-nose test, which shows mild tremor after reaching the target. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with a progressive, bilateral intention tremor along with a normal neurological examination, most likely has essential tremor (ET). In contrast, the tremor that occurred during college was most likely physiologic tremor, exacerbated by sleep deprivation and excessive caffeine intake.  

Tremor is defined as a rhythmic, involuntary, oscillatory movement of a body part caused by either alternating or synchronous antagonist muscle contractions. ET is the most common cause of action tremor in adults. Classically, ET involves the hands and becomes apparent by arm movement during an activity (intention tremor) or sustained antigravity postures. The tremor can be quite disabling, affecting daily activities such as writing, drinking from a glass, and using utensils. The tremor is typically slowly progressive, bilateral, slightly asymmetric, and with moderate to high frequency (6 to 12 Hz). ET may also affect the head, voice, and less commonly the face or trunk. A helpful clue often seen on USMLE exams is that ET is often relieved by small amounts of alcohol intake, and therefore, patients often self-medicate with alcoholic beverages. The neuropathologic basis of ET remains poorly understood, but involvement of the cerebellum and brainstem (locus coeruleus) has been suggested. ET has a strong genetic component, often referred to as "familial tremor." The diagnosis of ET is based purely upon the clinical features, according to the following criteria:  

  •  Isolated, bilateral upper limb action tremor, without other motor abnormalities 
  •  At least three years in duration 
  •  With/without a tremor in other locations (e.g., head, voice, or lower limbs) 
  •  Absence of other neurologic signs (e.g., parkinsonism, ataxia) 
First-line treatment consists of beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol) or certain barbiturates (e.g. primidone).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Essential tremor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Physiologic tremor:
Incorrect: Physiologic tremor is a very low-amplitude, high-frequency (8 to 12 Hz) action tremor that can be seen in healthy individuals. Physiologic tremor is typically not visible under ordinary conditions and may become apparent with increased sympathetic activity (e.g., stress, anxiety, hyperthyroidism, hypoglycemia, alcohol or opioid withdrawal) and certain drugs (e.g. excessive caffeine intake). Physiologic tremor, however, is not progressive or disabling, as seen in this patient. 
❌ Parkinson disease:
Incorrect: Parkinson disease-associated tremor is typically a resting tremor characterized by "pill-rolling" flexion-supination movement, with a frequency of 4 to 6 Hz. The tremor usually disappears with movement, in contrast to this patient’s tremor that worsens with activity. This patient’s tremor characteristics and normal neurological examination favor another diagnosis. 
❌ Cerebellar lesion:
Incorrect: Cerebellar tremors can occur with conditions that damage the cerebellum. The tremor frequency is typically low (3 to 4 Hz) and intention-type (worse when reaching the target). Although this patient had a positive finger-to-nose test and signs of an intention tremor, the absence of other cerebellar signs such as ataxia and nystagmus favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Dystonia:
Incorrect: Dystonia is a neurological movement disorder characterized by involuntary, sustained or intermittent muscle contractions that result in repetitive movements or an abnormal fixed posture. It may be focal or generalized. Writer's dystonia, also known as writer's cramp, is an example of a task-specific hand dystonia elicited by writing. Overlying dystonic spasms are often confused with essential tremor. However, in contrast to essential tremor, dystonia tremor is often unilateral and triggered by task-specific activities, such as writing or typing.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the clinic with his partner due to episodes of uncontrollable crying and laughing, as well as abnormal body movements. The partner states that the patient has not been himself for the past year. In the beginning, she thought that he was going through a tough time because he was fired from his job as an accountant. He was constantly making mistakes, and his boss eventually released him after multiple poor performance reviews. The patient’s partner started worrying when she noticed him making odd movements with his hands. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears restless and sad. There is a mild hand tremor present on the right and occasional brief, abrupt movement of the right upper extremity as well as occasional facial grimacing. The patient walks in slow small steps. Which of the following is most likely to be found on brain imaging of this patient?

choices.text: Cortical atrophy of the parietal and temporal lobe region
Apparent ventricle enlargement with diffuse brain atrophy

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with Huntington disease, a progressive neurodegenerative disease that follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.  

The underlying pathophysiology is an increased number of CAG repeats in the huntingtin (HTT) gene on chromosome 4. Mutant huntingtin contains an expanded tract of glutamine residues that results in an abnormal protein toxic to neurons. The condition is characterized by anticipation, which refers to increased severity and earlier onset in succeeding generations due to expansion of CAG repeats. On imaging, atrophy of the caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly can be seen. The latter refers to the apparent enlargement of the ventricles when the brain is atrophied. Symptoms manifest between the ages of 20 and 50 and include chorea, athetosis, aggression, depression, and dementia. There is no cure for Huntington disease, and treatment is aimed to control the symptoms.    

Option Analysis

❌ Periventricular and juxtacortical plaques:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with multiple sclerosis (MS), an autoimmune  neurodegenerative disease characterized by immune-mediated inflammatory demyelination of the central nervous system. Common presenting symptoms include pyramidal signs (e.g., weakness, spasticity), cerebellar syndromes (e.g., diplopia, ataxia), and spinal cord symptoms (e.g., neurogenic bladder, paraparesis).
❌ Cortical atrophy of the parietal and temporal lobe region:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Alzheimer disease, the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. Alzheimer disease typically presents with early memory loss and dementia. While motor signs (e.g., pyramidal, extrapyramidal) do occur in patients with AD, these are usually late-stage findings.
❌ Temporal and frontal lobe degeneration:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with frontotemporal dementia, which is characterized by early changes in personality and behavior, aphasia, and occasionally parkinsonism. 
✅ Apparent ventricle enlargement with diffuse brain atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Multiple cortical and subcortical infarcts:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with vascular dementia, a condition caused by multiple infarcts and/or chronic ischemia. Common presenting symptoms include a stepwise decline in cognitive ability and late-onset memory impairment.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male comes to his provider’s office for evaluation of fatigue, weakness, and 8 kg (17.6 lb) unintentional weight loss over the past 2 months. Moreover, the patient reports feeling bloated after eating small quantities of food during this same time period. His past medical history is notable for hypertension, and the patient is currently taking hydrochlorothiazide. Physical exam reveals oral mucosal pallor. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Abdominal exam reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory testing results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  9.5 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  28.5% 
 Leukocytes  2,700/mm3 
 Platelets  100,000/mm3 

Biopsy of the bone marrow biopsy shows increased fibrosis and reduced cell count. Polymerase chain reaction testing reveals a mutation in a gene encoding for a non-receptor tyrosine kinase. Which of the following diseases is also caused by an identical mutation?
questions.solution:
This patient has primary myelofibrosis, which is one of the myeloproliferative disorders. These are a group of blood disorders characterized by the excess proliferation of cells of myeloid lineage. The four high-yield myeloproliferative disorders are: polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, primary myelofibrosis, and chronic myeloid leukemia. The first three conditions are most often caused by a Janus Kinase 2 (JAK2) gene mutation. CML is caused by a t[9;22] chromosomal translocation.  

Primary myelofibrosis is characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of megakaryocytes and scar tissue deposition. Over time, the hematopoietic stem cells residing in the bone marrow are crowded out by scar tissue. This results in pancytopenia and a “dry tap” on bone marrow biopsy. This pancytopenia results in reduced production of red blood cells (anemia), platelets (increased bleeding) and white blood cells (increased infections). Some of the stem cells migrate to other organs (e.g., liver, spleen) and proliferate there. This is termed extramedullary hematopoiesis and may cause hepatosplenomegaly. The enlarged spleen and liver can compress the stomach, ultimately resulting in decreased appetite/weight loss.    

Option Analysis

❌ Fanconi anemia:
Incorrect: Fanconi anemia is caused by defects in homologous DNA recombination. Patients with this congenital condition present at a young age with pancytopenia, short stature, microcephaly, and cafe-au-lait spots. In contrast, defects in homologous DNA recombination play no role in the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition (primary myelofibrosis).
❌ Chronic myeloid leukemia:
Incorrect: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is caused by a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. This results in fusion of the BCR and ABL gene, producing a tyrosine kinase with increased activity. However, the JAK2 gene mutation responsible for this patient’s condition plays no role in the pathogenesis of CML.
❌ Follicular lymphoma:
Incorrect: Follicular lymphoma is caused by a mutation in the gene encoding the Bcl-2 protein. Normally Bcl-2 keeps the mitochondrial membrane intact and prevents apoptosis. The mutation results in overexpression of Bcl-2, which prevents apoptosis and causes uncontrolled cellular proliferation. In contrast, this patient has primary myelofibrosis, which is most often secondary to a mutation in the JAK2 gene.
✅ Polycythemia vera :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute myeloid leukemia:
Incorrect: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is caused by a translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17. This disrupts the retinoic acid receptor (RAR), which is needed for myeloblast maturation. As a result, there is proliferation of myeloblasts, the unipotent stem cells that can differentiate into neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils, and monocytes. However, the JAK2 gene mutation responsible for this patient’s condition plays no role in AML.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents to her outpatient provider for symptoms of fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance that started 2 weeks ago. Past medical history is notable for seizure disorder that is currently managed with phenytoin. In addition, the patient had an episode of pyelonephritis several weeks ago that was successfully treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. The patient has menstrual periods every 28 days, and denies dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia. Physical examination is notable for conjunctival pallor. Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin on 9.3 g/dL. A peripheral blood smear is performed and shows the following:  

Reproduced from: Flickr  
Which of the following sets of red blood cell characteristics is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Impaired Process  Red Blood Cell Maturity  Mean Corpuscular Volume  Heme Synthesis  Immature  75 mm3
Impaired Process  Red Blood Cell Maturity  Mean Corpuscular Volume DNA SynthesisMature 75 mm3
Impaired Process  Red Blood Cell Maturity  Mean Corpuscular Volume  Heme Synthesis  Mature 105 mm3
Impaired Process  Red Blood Cell Maturity  Mean Corpuscular Volume  DNA Synthesis Immature  105 mm3
Impaired Process  Red Blood Cell Maturity  Mean Corpuscular Volume  DNA SynthesisMature 105 mm3

questions.solution:
This patient is taking phenytoin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Phenytoin impairs folate absorption. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole prevents the conversion of folate into tetrahydrofolate, the active form used in DNA synthesis. As a result, this patient most likely has impaired DNA synthesis secondary to folate deficiency, which results in a macrocytic megaloblastic anemia.  

Macrocytic anemias (MCV > 100 mm3) can be classified based on the presence/absence of megaloblasts. Megaloblasts are large, immature red blood cells produced when the cytoplasm develops normally, but the DNA synthesis is impaired and cell division is delayed. Therefore, when there are defects in DNA synthesis or repair (e.g., folate deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency, Fanconi anemia, orotic aciduria, etc.) there will be megaloblastic macrocytic anemia. Megaloblastic anemia can also affect white blood cell production, resulting in the release of immature neutrophils with hypersegmented nuclei into the bloodstream. The observation of these hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral blood smear can help distinguish megaloblastic from non-megaloblastic anemias.  

In contrast, non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemias arise from conditions that do not affect DNA synthesis. Causes of non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia include Diamond-Blackfan Anemia, which results from a defect in protein synthesis, and chronic alcohol use, which has a toxic effect on the bone marrow.  


Option Analysis

❌   Impaired Process  Red Blood Cell Maturity  Mean Corpuscular Volume  Heme Synthesis  Immature  75 mm3 :
Incorrect: Iron deficiency, lead poisoning, and thalassemias can impair heme synthesis and result in a microcytic anemia. Female patients are generally at higher risk of iron deficiency due to menstrual blood loss. However, this patient has no history of overly frequent or heavy menses. In contrast, the patient’s history of phenytoin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole use puts her at risk of folate deficiency, which is a more likely cause of her anemia.
❌   Impaired Process  Red Blood Cell Maturity  Mean Corpuscular Volume DNA SynthesisMature 75 mm3 :
Incorrect: In normal red blood cell (RBC) development, large red blood cell precursors (erythroblasts) undergo DNA replication and cellular division. This results in the creation of several smaller mature RBCs. Impaired DNA replication would prevent RBC maturation and cause immature and macrocytic (mean corpuscular volume > 100 mm3) RBCs to be observed on laboratory testing.
❌   Impaired Process  Red Blood Cell Maturity  Mean Corpuscular Volume  Heme Synthesis  Mature 105 mm3:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency, lead poisoning, or thalassemia can result in impaired heme synthesis. DNA synthesis will be unaffected and hence the RBCs will be mature. However, the RBCs will most likely be microcytic. This is because the body attempts to preserve a normal RBC hemoglobin concentration. So when hemoglobin production is decreased, the body makes smaller RBCs to compensate.   
✅   Impaired Process  Red Blood Cell Maturity  Mean Corpuscular Volume  DNA Synthesis Immature  105 mm3 :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Impaired Process  Red Blood Cell Maturity  Mean Corpuscular Volume  DNA SynthesisMature 105 mm3 :
Incorrect: Causes of impaired DNA replication include vitamin B12 deficiency, folate deficiency, orotic aciduria, and Fanconi anemia. However, defects in DNA synthesis would hinder RBC maturation and cause immature RBCs to be found in the patient’s circulation.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of pain during urination, in addition to increased urinary frequency and chills. The symptoms have been present since yesterday. He denies any pelvic pain, myalgias or malaise. He has not been sexually active since his spouse died 2 years ago. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus and hypertension for 20 years. Current medications include metformin and amlodipine. Family history is significant for bladder cancer in his deceased father. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.4°F), pulse is 100/minute, and blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg. Digital rectal examination reveals a warm, tender, and boggy prostate. Complete blood profile shows hemoglobin 11 g/L and leukocytes 14,000/mm3. Urinalysis is as follows:  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Urinalysis 
 Specific gravity  1.013 
 Glucose  Negative 
 Blood  Negative 
 Leukocyte esterase  Positive 
 Nitrites  Positive 
 Leukocytes  10-12/hpf 
 Erythrocytes  1-2/hpf 

What of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Proliferation of microorganisms in the prostate gland
Proliferation of microorganisms in the urinary tract

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with dysuria, urinary frequency, fever, chills and a warm, tender, and boggy prostate on digital rectal examination (DRE) in combination with pyuria (leukocytes >10/hpf) is consistent with the diagnosis of acute prostatitis.



Acute prostatitis results from the passage of foreign microorganisms in the prostate gland via the urethra or less commonly via direct inoculation, which typically occurs iatrogenically (e.g., transrectal prostate biopsy, catheterization, cystoscopy). Escherichia coli is the most common causative organism in older adults, followed by Proteus species and other Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, Enterobacter, and Serratia species). In contrast, Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are the most common pathogens in sexually active young adults.   

Complete blood count (CBC) reveals leukocytosis, and urinalysis shows pyuria, positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites (suggestive of E. coli). Urine gram stain and culture should be performed to identify the causative organism and to guide appropriate antibiotic therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Proliferation of microorganisms in the prostate gland:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperplasia of the prostate gland:
Incorrect: Hyperplasia of the periurethral zone of the prostate gland is seen in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
