It usually manifests with lower urinary tract symptoms (frequency, urgency, nocturia, dribbling) that develop gradually over time, as opposed to this patient’s acute presentation. Moreover, DRE typically reveals a non-tender, enlarged prostate, as opposed to a tender and boggy prostate.
❌ Proliferation of microorganisms in the urinary tract:
Incorrect: This answer is the etiology of a urinary tract infection (UTI). Although it can present with dysuria, urinary frequency, fever, and chills, the presence of a warm, tender, and boggy prostate on DRE would be atypical.
❌ Neoplastic proliferation of transitional cells:
Incorrect: Bladder cancer results from neoplastic proliferation of transitional cells and usually manifests as hematuria in patients with a history of smoking. Dysuria, urinary frequency, fever, chills and a tender prostate are inconsistent with the diagnosis.
❌ Inflammation of the epididymis:
Incorrect: Epididymitis is the inflammation of epididymis. It presents with acute scrotal pain, swelling and tenderness of the epididymis. A warm, tender and boggy prostate is suggestive of a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the office for a routine prenatal appointment at 28 weeks of gestation. The pregnancy has been uneventful, and she has been compliant with prenatal care. During the past week, she has been feeling a severe throbbing headache, with minimal response to acetaminophen. Medical history is unremarkable, and she has no history of migraines. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. Review of medical records at 24 weeks of gestation shows blood pressure of 135/80. Which of the following would prompt further evaluation in this patient?

choices.text: Dilatation of the ureters and renal pelvis on ultrasound
Elevation of liver enzymes 2 times the upper limit
Proteinuria of 200 mg/day in a 24-hour urine specimen

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a new onset of hypertension and severe headache resistant to pharmacological therapy after 20 weeks gestation, raising concerns for preeclampsia.  

Preeclampsia is a multisystem progressive disorder defined as a new onset of hypertension and proteinuria or significant end-organ dysfunction after 20 weeks gestation. The disorder is caused by placental and maternal vascular dysfunction and typically resolves after delivery. The pathogenesis involves abnormal development of the uteroplacental circulation that results in placental hypoperfusion and adverse pregnancy outcomes, including preeclampsia, second trimester fetal death, abruptio placentae, intrauterine growth restriction, and preterm labor. On examination, preeclampsia is associated with a variety of manifestations such as generalized hyperreflexia or clonus, amaurosis fugax, epigastric pain, oliguria, peripheral or pulmonary edema, and even stroke. Cardinal risk factors for developing preeclampsia include past or family history of preeclampsia, nulliparity, preexisting diabetes, chronic hypertension, obesity, and multiple gestation.  



Option Analysis

❌ Dilatation of the ureters and renal pelvis on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Hydroureter and hydronephrosis are physiologic changes of pregnancy that can be seen in up to 80% of pregnant women and are considered benign features. These changes have been attributed to hormonal effects (progesterone relaxes the urinary tract), mechanical compression from the enlarging uterus, and intrinsic changes within the ureteral wall. 
❌ Lower extremity edema :
Incorrect: Water retention, with edema of the ankles and legs, is a physiological phenomenon seen in many pregnant women, whether or not they have preeclampsia. However, a sudden weight gain (e.g., >5 lb [2.3 kg]/week) and/or facial edema can be signs of preeclampsia and should prompt further evaluation. 
❌ Air hunger:
Incorrect: Dyspnea (also known as "air hunger") is common during the course of normal pregnancy, and can be seen in up to 70% of women. The exact mechanism is not clear but may be related to an increase in abdominal girth and/or upward pressure on the diaphragm as well as progesterone-induced hyperventilation. Pulmonary edema, however, is consistent with findings of preeclampsia or peripartum cardiomyopathy and would prompt further evaluation.  
✅ Elevation of liver enzymes 2 times the upper limit:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Proteinuria of 200 mg/day in a 24-hour urine specimen:
Incorrect: Normal urinary protein excretion is less than 100 mg/day. During pregnancy, levels rising from normal levels to 150 to 200 mg/day in the third trimester is considered normal. However, urinary protein excretion greater than 300 mg/day is considered abnormal and should prompt further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old primigravid woman comes to the office at 18 weeks gestation due to palpitations and pelvic pressure. She has been consistent with prenatal care. She is following a healthy diet and takes prenatal vitamins daily. She does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient’s skin is moist and warm. Uterus size is consistent with 22 weeks of gestation. When the patient is holding her hands stretched, a mild tremor is noted. The thyroid gland is normal to palpation and nontender. Laboratory tests show hCG concentrations of 110,000 mIU/mL. TSH is 0.1 μU/mL. An abdominal ultrasound is obtained and shown below.  


 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Further evaluation would most likely reveal which of the following karyotypes?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tremors, suppressed TSH) and size-date discrepancy. The hyperthyroidism is most likely caused by extremely high levels of hCG, which has weak thyroid-stimulating activity. The ultrasound results show a classic "Swiss cheese pattern," favoring the diagnosis of molar pregnancy.  

Hydatidiform mole (also known as a molar pregnancy or mole), is a premalignant disease that is caused by aberrant fertilization. A molar pregnancy can be categorized as a complete mole or partial mole, which differ by pathogenesis, gross morphology, histopathology, karyotype, and risk of malignancy. Complete moles are formed by the duplication of the haploid genes of a single sperm following fertilization of an empty ovum and therefore are diploid 46,XX. Less commonly, 46,XY karyotype may occur due to dispermic fertilization of an empty ovum.    

Partial moles occur due to fertilization of a normal ovum by two sperm and therefore are triploid (69,XXX, 69,XXY, or 69,XYY). Compared to complete mole, hCG levels are typically far lower in partial moles, and uterine size is often normal. Additionally, hyperemesis gravidarum, hyperthyroidism, and theca lutein cysts are less common since these features are caused by severely elevated b-hCG levels. On ultrasound, both conditions are characterized by ultrasound appearance of cystic spaces ("Swiss cheese pattern"), but fetal parts may be seen in a partial mole.    

Although benign, molar pregnancy increases the risk for invasive disease (e.g., choriocarcinoma, invasive mole). The risk is higher with a complete mole. Treatment is evacuation, which is both therapeutic and diagnostic. Monitoring hCG following treatment is required to detect signs of invasive disease. At the same time, contraceptives are used for several months during the monitoring phase to prevent confusion with normal pregnancies.  



Option Analysis

✅ 46, XX:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 46, XO:
Incorrect: This karyotype is consistent with Turner syndrome, a genetic condition characterized by partly or completely missing an X chromosome in a female. Ultrasound findings in utero of Turner syndrome include large septated cystic hygroma, total body lymphangiectasia (hydrops fetalis), cardiac defects (e.g. coarctation of the aorta), and nuchal thickening. In contrast, this patient’s ultrasound does not show a fetus. 
❌ 69, XXX:
Incorrect: Partial moles occur due to fertilization of a normal ovum by two sperm and therefore are triploid (69XXX, 69XXY, or 69XYY). Compared to complete moles, hCG levels are typically far lower, and uterine size is often normal. Additionally, hyperemesis gravidarum, hyperthyroidism, and theca lutein cysts are less common, since these features are seen in patients with severely elevated b-hCG levels. On ultrasound, both conditions are characterized by ultrasound appearance of cystic spaces ("Swiss cheese pattern"), but fetal parts may be seen in partial moles. 
❌ 69, XYY:
Incorrect: Partial moles occur due to fertilization of a normal ovum by two sperm and therefore are triploid (69XXX, 69XXY, or 69XYY). Compared to complete moles, hCG levels are typically far lower, and uterine size is often normal. Additionally, hyperemesis gravidarum, hyperthyroidism, and theca lutein cysts are less common, since these features are seen in patients with severely elevated b-hCG levels. On ultrasound, both conditions are characterized by ultrasound appearance of cystic spaces ("Swiss cheese pattern"), but fetal parts may be seen in partial moles.  
❌ 47, XY,+21:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Down syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of all or part of the third copy of chromosome 21. Sonographic findings of Down syndrome include endocardial cushion defects, VSD, duodenal atresia, and thickened nuchal fold.

questions.text: A 2-year-old otherwise healthy male presents to the emergency department with left knee pain and swelling. The toddler was running down the hall when he suddenly tripped and landed on his left knee. He takes no medications, and vaccinations are up to date. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle who died from a spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 104/54 mmHg, and respirations are 26/min. Physical examination of the left knee demonstrates erythema, warmth, and a large intra-articular effusion. Examination of the patient’s oral mucosa reveals no petechiae or bleeding. This patient's laboratory findings are most likely to demonstrate which of the following?

choices.text: Platelet CountBleeding TimeProthrombin TimePartial Thromboplastin TimeNo changeNo changeNo change↑
Platelet CountBleeding TimeProthrombin TimePartial Thromboplastin TimeNo change↑No changeNo change
Platelet CountBleeding TimeProthrombin TimePartial Thromboplastin TimeNo changeNo change↑↑
Platelet CountBleeding TimeProthrombin TimePartial Thromboplastin Time↓↑No changeNo change
Platelet CountBleeding TimeProthrombin TimePartial Thromboplastin Time↓↑↑↑

questions.solution:
This male patient presents with hemarthrosis after a minor fall, and he has a maternal family member with a suspected bleeding disorder. Laboratory testing will likely demonstrate findings consistent with hemophilia. Of the hemophilias, type A is the most common.    

Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disease, so patients may have a history of a maternal family member with a bleeding disorder. The disease is caused by a deficiency of factor VIII, which is a coagulation factor involved in the intrinsic pathway of secondary hemostasis. Deficiency of factor VIII results in impaired conversion of factor X to Xa and subsequent prolongation of the PTT, which is reflective of both the intrinsic and common pathways. In contrast, INR and PT will largely be normal, since these parameters are reflective of the extrinsic pathway.    

Hemophilia A and B are clinically indistinguishable and present with symptoms including hemarthrosis, deep soft tissue hematomas, prolonged bleeding after procedures, and intracerebral hemorrhage. Most patients with hemophilia present in early infancy or childhood. If left untreated, recurrent hemarthrosis can cause chronic joint pain and deformity, and intracerebral hemorrhage can cause chronic neurologic disorders or death.  

Diagnosis of hemophilia A is performed by obtaining coagulation parameters and performing a mixing study. In a mixing study, the patient's plasma is mixed with normal plasma, which will demonstrate a correction of PTT since factor VIII is now present. Treatment options include recombinant factor VIII replacement, emicizumab, and desmopressin.

Option Analysis

✅ Platelet CountBleeding TimeProthrombin TimePartial Thromboplastin TimeNo changeNo changeNo change↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Platelet CountBleeding TimeProthrombin TimePartial Thromboplastin TimeNo change↑No changeNo change:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a primary platelet disorder that typically presents with a prolonged bleeding time despite a normal platelet count; abnormally large platelets are seen on peripheral smear. This disease is due to a deficiency of GpIb, which results in impaired adhesion between platelets and von Willebrand factor (vWF).  
❌ Platelet CountBleeding TimeProthrombin TimePartial Thromboplastin TimeNo changeNo change↑↑:
Incorrect: Vitamin K deficiency is rare in the developed world due to improved nutritional standards. However, the condition may still be present in neonates and in individuals from developing countries. In severe cases of vitamin K deficiency, both PT and PTT will be elevated due decreased synthesis and activity of factors II, VII, IX, X, as well as proteins C and S.
❌ Platelet CountBleeding TimeProthrombin TimePartial Thromboplastin Time↓↑No changeNo change:
Incorrect: These laboratory findings are reflective of several disorders of primary hemostasis, including thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, immune thrombocytopenia, and hemolytic uremic syndrome. Typically, these conditions will present with clinical evidence of platelet abnormalities (e.g., petechiae, epistaxis, mucosal bleeding). 
❌ Platelet CountBleeding TimeProthrombin TimePartial Thromboplastin Time↓↑↑↑:
Incorrect: These coagulation parameters describe disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which is a mixed primary and secondary disorder resulting from consumptive coagulopathy. In contrast, this disease typically presents with diffuse purpura and bleeding from IV sites, as opposed to swelling of a single joint.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of severe pain in his right big toe. The toe has been painful, warm, and red for the last several hours. The patient has not had similar symptoms before. He has been consuming 1-2 beers daily for the last 4 years, but recently had a binge-drinking episode 2 nights ago, where he consumed 9 beers. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals swelling, erythema, and warmth of the right metatarsophalangeal joint. The joint is tender to palpation with decreased active and passive range of motion. Arthrocentesis of the joint yields cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 18,300/mm<sup>3</sup>. Gram stain is negative. Polarized light microscopy reveals yellow, negatively birefringent crystals. Which of the following cell types is the primary mediator of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with severe, acute-onset pain, swelling, and erythema of the right big toe after a night of binge-drinking. He most likely has an acute gout attack.  

The inflammation in gout is triggered by precipitation of urate crystals in the joints, which stimulates the production of cytokines by synovial lining cells. The cytokines help recruit leukocytes, such as neutrophils and macrophages. The incoming leukocytes phagocytose the urate crystals, which activates inflammasomes within these cells. This process can be seen in the microscopy image below, wherein monosodium urate crystals can be seen among and within the abundant neutrophils.    

The inflammasomes are involved in the production of active IL-1. IL-1 is a proinflammatory cytokine, which ultimately promotes the accumulation of even more neutrophils and macrophages in the joint. This progressive cascade of inflammation results in an acute arthritis, presenting as severe joint pain, swelling, and erythema.  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Neutrophils:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Natural killer cells:
Incorrect: Natural killer cells arise from lymphoid precursor cells and are involved in the detection and destruction of cells that lack MHC-I receptors, such as cells infected with viruses or tumor cells. Natural killer cells are not involved in the pathogenesis of acute gout attacks. 
❌ B-cells:
Incorrect: B-lymphocytes are part of the acquired immune system and are involved in the secretion of monoclonal immunoglobulins (e.g., IgM, IgG), which target specific antigens. These cells are not involved in acute gout attacks. 
❌ T-cells:
Incorrect: T-lymphocytes are part of the acquired immune system. There are various T-cells, whose functions vary depending on the specific type. CD4-positive T-cells initiate the humoral immune response in coordination with B-lymphocytes and also initiate the cellular immune response and cause macrophage stimulation. CD8-positive T-cells are involved in recognition of foreign antigens presented on MHC-I. However, T-lymphocytes are not involved in acute gout attacks. 
❌ Fibroblasts:
Incorrect: Fibroblasts are the most common cell type in connective tissue and are involved in the synthesis and organization of the extracellular matrix. These cells are not involved in acute gout attacks.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of intermittent crampy abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting for the last five days. She had an episode of vomiting with hematemesis six hours ago. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus, gallstones, and hypertension. Current medications are metformin and lisinopril. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows distention and tenderness, and hyperactive high-pitched bowel sounds are heard on auscultation. An abdominal radiograph shows pneumobilia and dilated loops of small bowel. Laboratory results are shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value Result 
Leukocyte count  23,250/mm3 
 Hemoglobin  12 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  46% 
 Platelets  400,000/µL 
 Lipase  140 U/L 
 AST, SGOT  47 U/L 
 ALT, SGPT  45 U/L 
 Total bilirubin  0.8 mg/dL 
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of gallstones and is presenting with intermittent abdominal pain with persistent nausea and vomiting and an episode of hematemesis. The physical examination features suggest a bowel obstruction (e.g. abdominal distension, hyperactive high-pitched bowel sounds). Finally, the abdominal radiograph shows dilated loops of small bowel associated with pneumobilia (air in the biliary tree), which indicates a small bowel obstruction due to a gallstone lodged in the ileocecal valve, known as gallstone ileus. The term “ileus” is a misnomer because the obstruction is a true mechanical phenomenon. This condition is often seen in elderly individuals who have significant comorbidities.  

The pathogenesis begins with cholelithiasis complicated by cholecystitis. The impacted gallstone causes inflammation and pressure buildup within the gallbladder, which leads to the inflamed gallbladder’s adhesion to surrounding structures. This adhesion leads to the formation of a fistula between the gallbladder and intestine (biliary-enteric or cholecystoenteric fistula). Once fistulization has occurred, a large enough stone can enter the intestine and lodge at the ileocecal valve, leading to a small bowel obstruction. Transient gallstone impaction produces abdominal pain and vomiting, which subside when the gallstone is dislodged.    


Gallstone ileus should be suspected in patients with the above presentation in addition to radiologic evaluation. Abdominal computed tomography (CT) is most often used, but a plain radiograph can be used when CT is unavailable. The Rigler triad describes the presentation of gallstone ileus on plain radiograph and includes pneumobilia, small bowel obstruction, and an obstructing gallstone. Treatment involves symptomatic management, nasogastric suctioning, and emergency surgery. 

 

Option Analysis

❌ Emphysematous cholecystitis:
Incorrect: Emphysematous cholecystitis is an acute infection of the gallbladder wall by gas-forming bacteria, which is considered a medical emergency. Similar to acute cholecystitis, patients with emphysematous cholecystitis present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. It can also cause air in the biliary tree; however, dilated loops of small bowel would not be consistent with this diagnosis.   
❌ Superior mesenteric artery syndrome:
Incorrect: Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome is an unusual cause of proximal intestinal obstruction. This condition involves the compression of the third portion of the duodenum due to narrowing of the space between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. It is most often caused by significant weight loss leading to loss of the mesenteric fat. However, this patient has pneumobilia on the abdominal radiograph, which would not be present in SMA syndrome.  
❌ Colonic pseudo-obstruction:
Incorrect: Colonic pseudo-obstruction, also known as Ogilvie syndrome, is characterized by acute dilation of the colon in the absence of mechanical obstruction. It is often seen in acutely sick patients or with the use of certain medications (e.g., opioids). Patients present with signs of large bowel obstruction. This patient has a small bowel obstruction with air present in the biliary tree, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Diverticulitis :
Incorrect: Diverticulitis is often seen in elderly patients, but it usually presents with left lower quadrant pain, fever, and hematochezia. Air seen under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray would be concerning for a perforation; however, air in the biliary tree would not be expected.  
❌ Acute hepatitis :
Incorrect: Acute hepatitis infection presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, malaise, and anorexia. Within a few days, dark urine and pale stools appear, followed by jaundice and pruritus. This patient’s radiograph instead demonstrates a small bowel obstruction with air present in the biliary tree, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
✅ Mechanical bowel obstruction:
Correct: See main explanation

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of pain during sexual intercouse for the last 2 months. She also has difficulty swallowing food, especially bread and crackers, and she needs to chew food for longer periods of time before swallowing it. The patient has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 73/min, and blood pressure is 138/76 mmHg. Physical examination reveals diffuse, nontender enlargement of the parotid glands bilaterally. Oropharyngeal examination reveals multiple new dental caries and halitosis. Ophthalmologic examination reveals 20/40 visual acuity in both eyes. Laboratory studies reveal the following findings:
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  10.2 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  31% 
 Platelet count  350,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count  3,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  52 mm/h 
 Antinuclear antibodies   Positive 
 Rheumatoid factor  Negative 
 Anti-dsDNA  Negative 
 Anti-Ro/La  Positive 
If this patient remains untreated, which of the following is she at increased risk of developing?

choices.text: Gastroesophageal reflux disease due to excess collagen deposition
Blindness due to ophthalmic artery vasculitis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with dyspareunia (painful intercourse) and dysphagia, most likely due to impaired exocrine function resulting in vaginal and oropharyngeal dryness. Taking into account the laboratory finding of positive anti-Ro/La antibodies, she likely has Sjogren syndrome (SS).  

Sjogren syndrome results in 2 classes of clinical features: glandular symptoms and extraglandular symptoms, as seen in the table. SS is commonly associated with an increased risk of corneal ulcers, which may result in vision loss. Another rare, yet serious, complication of SS is malignant transformation of chronically inflamed glands. This transformation results in mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, which is a form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. MALT lymphomas are characteristically nodular on palpation, as opposed to the diffusely enlarged glands seen in most patients with SS.    



Option Analysis

✅ Malignant transformation of glandular tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gastroesophageal reflux disease due to excess collagen deposition:
Incorrect: Fibrosis of smooth muscle and deposition of excess collagen in the lower esophageal sphincter is the pathogenesis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in CREST syndrome. Although this patient has dysphagia, it is more likely due to an underlying diagnosis of Sjogren syndrome, in which dysphagia occurs secondary to decreased saliva production.
❌ Violaceous periorbital rash:
Incorrect: A violaceous periorbital rash (also termed heliotrope rash) is a rash that occurs on the upper eyelid. It is commonly seen in patients with dermatomyositis, an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy in which autoantibodies attack skeletal muscle and cause profound muscle weakness. In contrast, this patient is not presenting with muscle weakness, making dermatomyositis unlikely. 
❌ Ischemic stroke due to hypercoagulability :
Incorrect: Antiphospholipid syndrome is a condition that increases the risk of thrombosis throughout the body due to procoagulatory antibodies. Although this condition may occur on its own (primary), it often occurs secondary to another disorder (e.g. systemic lupus erythematosus). This patient lacks the clinical findings of SLE (e.g., rash, arthralgia, photosensitivity) and is negative for the specific antibody, anti-dsDNA, commonly found in SLE patients.
❌ Blindness due to ophthalmic artery vasculitis :
Incorrect: Ophthalmic artery vasculitis can occur in giant cell (temporal) arteritis. Although patients with temporal arteritis also have an elevated ESR, this patient lacks the classic symptoms seen in this condition, such as fever, weight loss, unilateral headaches, or jaw claudication.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with significant abdominal pain. The patient reports intermittent, worsening upper abdominal pain after eating.  She initially saw her primary care physician when the symptoms began several months ago and had a negative work up that included a normal urea breath test, liver function tests, and lipase. Yesterday, the patient noticed that her stools were darker than normal, and she felt like she was going to faint at home. Past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis, hypertension, and hyperthyroidism. Medications include naproxen, synthroid, and hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is  37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 100/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. Laboratory values are shown below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
CBC, Serum
 Hemoglobin  11.2  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  33.6% 
 Leukocyte count  12,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  149,000/mm3 
 MCV                        72 fL 
 RDW                    11.5-14.5% 
 Serum
               Sodium  134 mEq/L 
           Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
              Chloride  97 mEq/L 
                 BUN                    40 mg/dL  
             Creatinine  2.2 mg/dL 
              Albumin  3.1  g/dL 
Which of the following best summarizes the pathophysiology of this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Mucosal degradation caused by Gram-negative bacteria

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic naproxen use, epigastric pain, and symptomatic anemia with an elevated BUN raises concern for a bleeding peptic ulcer due to chronic NSAID use. The laboratory results demonstrate an elevated BUN due to an increase in hemoglobin digestion as it passes through the GI tract. Additionally, the patient’s vital signs demonstrate tachycardia and borderline hypotension concerning for large volume blood loss.  

NSAIDs including naproxen, aspirin, ketorolac, and diclofenac inhibit cyclooxygenase or COX, which mediates the production of prostaglandins. In the stomach, prostaglandins are produced by COX-1, as opposed to COX-2 which is expressed constitutively throughout the body. Prostaglandins in the stomach, especially PGE2, help to maintain the barrier function of gastric mucosa by enhancing bicarbonate secretion, mucous production, epithelial hyperplasia, as well as mucosal blood flow via vasodilation. As the barrier function breaks down due to NSAID-induced COX inhibition, gastric acid erodes the mucosa, eventually leading to gastritis or ulcer formation. If left untreated, gastric ulcers can cause significant gastrointestinal bleeding and anemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Mucosal degradation caused by Gram-negative bacteria :
Incorrect: H. pylori degrades gastric mucosa via several mechanisms, including secretion of H. pylori proteases, such as vacuolating cytotoxin A. This protease damages epithelial cells, disrupts tight junctions and causes apoptosis with subsequent mucosal degradation. H. pylori peptic ulcer disease is less likely given this patient’s negative urea breath test.
✅ Inhibition of a cyclooxygenase enzyme :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ischemia of gastric vasculature:
Incorrect: Ischemia of gastric vasculature describes the pathophysiology of a Curling ulcer, which is more commonly found in cases of severe burns and in mechanically ventilated ICU patients. Decreased blood flow to the gastric mucosa results in inappropriate buffering of the acidic environment and ulcer formation.
❌ Oversecretion of gastrin :
Incorrect: Overproduction of gastrin describes the pathophysiology of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, a rare gastrin-secreting pancreatic tumor. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome typically presents with additional constitutional symptoms including weight loss, malaise and cachexia.  
❌ Autoantibodies directed at intrinsic factor :
Incorrect: Autoantibodies directed at intrinsic factor describe the pathophysiology of chronic autoimmune gastritis. This disease may cause gastric ulcerations; however, it more typically presents with macrocytic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency, as opposed to a microcytic anemia as seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman with a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis presents to the primary care physician with a several-month history of fatigue and pain after eating. The patient reports burning pain approximately twenty to thirty minutes after every meal with associated nausea. She reports that she drinks one glass of wine with dinner every night. She does not have worsening of the symptoms with any particular food items, and she has not had any recent changes in diet.  Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 110/62 mmHg. Physical exam shows conjunctival pallor as well as a smoothened and shiny tongue, fissures at the angles of the lips, and a wide-based gait. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 CBC, Serum 
 Hemoglobin  10.2  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  33.6% 
 Leukocyte count  9,000 /mm3 
 Platelet count  200,000/mm3 
 MCV                        109 fL 
 RDW                    11.5-14.5% 
 Serum 
               Sodium  134 mEq/L 
           Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
              Chloride  96 mEq/L 
                 BUN                    37 mg/dL 
             Creatinine  1.8 mg/dL 
              Albumin  3.5  g/dL 
Which of the following best describes the mechanism underlying this patient’s clinical manifestations?

choices.text: Colonization of the gastric mucosa with a Gram-negative bacteria
Autoantibodies directed against a protein produced by chief cells
Autoantibodies directed against a glycoprotein produced by parietal cells

questions.solution:
This patient has a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis and is presenting with a several month history of fatigue, abdominal pain, and macrocytic anemia. The physical examination shows angular cheilitis and an ataxic gait. This constellation of findings are concerning for pernicious anemia due to chronic autoimmune gastritis or type A gastritis.  

Chronic autoimmune gastritis occurs when the patient’s immune system produces antibodies targeting both intrinsic factor and parietal cells, an example of a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. Over time, this leads to chronic mucosal inflammation, atrophy and fibrosis, as well as impaired secretion of hydrochloric acid. Loss of intrinsic factor results in an inability to absorb vitamin B12, resulting in signs and symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency, such as fatigue, numbness, and gait disturbance due to degeneration of the posterior and lateral columns of the spinal cord.   

Most patients with chronic autoimmune gastritis are asymptomatic until they develop pernicious anemia, with fatigue being the most common symptom. Diagnosis of chronic autoimmune gastritis is made by endoscopy with biopsy, which will show atrophy of the gastric mucosa, loss of glandular cells, and their replacement with metaplastic epithelium in only the body and fundus of the stomach. This is in contrast to chronic gastritis due to H. pylori, which would show multiple areas of atrophy, metaplasia, and inflammation most heavily concentrated near the antrum of the stomach. Supporting information to make the diagnosis of pernicious anemia includes the presence of anti-intrinsic factor antibodies and increased serum gastrin levels.  

Option Analysis

❌ Colonization of the gastric mucosa with a Gram-negative bacteria:
Incorrect: H. pylori is a common cause of chronic gastritis, and patients also often present with chronic dyspepsia, but they are less likely to suffer from pernicious anemia. This patient with risk factors for additional autoimmune disease and laboratory results showing megaloblastic anemia is less likely to be suffering from H. pylori gastritis. 
❌ Autoantibodies directed against gliadin:
Incorrect: This describes anti-gliadin antibodies, one of the biological markers used in the diagnosis of celiac disease. Patients with celiac disease can develop pernicious anemia, but they typically report a history of abdominal pain worse after eating gluten-containing food items, as well as a history of chronic diarrhea. 
❌ Alcohol-induced megaloblastic anemia:
Incorrect: Alcohol by itself can induce a macrocytic anemia due to its direct toxic effects on bone marrow. However, this diagnosis is one of exclusion and only occurs with chronic heavy alcohol use. 
❌ Autoantibodies directed against a protein produced by chief cells :
Incorrect: The autoantibodies produced in chronic autoimmune gastritis are directed at parietal cells, not chief cells. 
✅ Autoantibodies directed against a glycoprotein produced by parietal cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and vomiting for the past hour. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 102/58 mmHg. Leukocyte count is normal. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a right ovarian mass. She subsequently undergoes laparoscopic unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. A histopathological analysis is performed and the results are shown below:

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following tumor markers should be used to monitor the response to treatment?
questions.solution:
Yolk sac tumors make up 15-20% of all malignant ovarian germ cell neoplasms. Yolk sac tumors are aggressive malignant tumors typically found in the ovaries of young women and less commonly in the testes of young boys. Patients often present with abdominal pain and a pelvic mass. Tumor growth is often rapid with extensive intraperitoneal dissemination.  

Histologically, the tissue in these tumors resembles yolk sac tissue, with the presence of tubules lined by a simple cuboidal epithelium and may demonstrate papillary invaginations that surround a central vessel, which are known as Schiller-Duval bodies (as seen in this patient). These structures often resemble the glomeruli of the kidney. Because of the similarity of this tissue to yolk sac tissue, serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is usually elevated in these tumors and can be used to determine response to treatment and to monitor for tumor recurrence. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) may also be elevated in yolk sac tumors, although this finding is less common and is not used for monitoring the response to treatment.



Option Analysis

✅ Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH):
Incorrect: Serum concentration of AMH may be elevated in granulosa cell tumors. Histology typically shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles.
❌ Inhibin:
Incorrect: Serum concentration of inhibin may be elevated in thecomas, granulosa cell tumors, and Sertoli-Leydig tumors, but not yolk sac tumors.
❌ Human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG):
Incorrect: Serum concentration of β-hCG may be elevated in embryonal cell carcinomas, ovarian choriocarcinomas, mixed germ cell tumors, and dysgerminomas. It is not elevated with yolk sac tumors.
❌ Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):
Incorrect: Serum concentration LDH may be elevated in many types of cancer. LDH elevation is characteristically seen in dysgerminomas and less commonly occurs in yolk sac tumors. LDH is not used for monitoring treatment of yolk sac tumors.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to insomnia and anxiety over the past few months. The patient’s last menstrual period was 1 year ago, but she denies hot flashes or vaginal dryness. The patient notes that her hair has become fine lately, and she has been losing weight without intention. On physical examination, a non-tender, diffuse goiter is noted. Laboratory tests show low TSH and high free T3 and T4 serum levels. The physician suspects that the patient’s condition is due to the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Which of the following is the most specific finding for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, anxiety, goiter) which may be primary (e.g. Graves disease) or secondary (e.g. TSH secreting pituitary tumor). Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, and exophthalmos, periorbital and conjunctival edema, restriction of eye movement, and discrete locations of infiltrative dermopathy (pretibial myxedema) are findings specific to Graves disease.  

Graves disease is an autoimmune condition that is caused by the production of autoantibodies to the TSH receptor (TRAb) which activate the receptors and increase thyroid hormone synthesis. Graves orbitopathy is mediated by activation of TSH receptors and T cells in the retro-ocular space, which results in inflammation and accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAG). Likewise, pretibial myxedema occurs due to cytokine-mediated stimulation of fibroblasts, which in turn secrete GAG in the dermis.  

A patient presenting with new-onset ophthalmopathy, a large non-nodular thyroid, and signs hyperthyroidism has Graves disease. When the etiology of hyperthyroidism is not clear, the following tests can confirm the diagnosis of Graves disease:  

  • Measurement of TSH (thyrotropin) receptor antibodies (TRAb)  
  • Radioactive iodine uptake test (RAIU) showing diffusely increased uptake  
  • Measurement of thyroidal blood flow on ultrasonography  

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated creatine kinase levels:
Incorrect: Elevated creatine kinase levels are commonly seen in myopathies, including hypothyroid myopathy, but is rarely seen in hyperthyroid myopathy. Myopathy is not specific for Graves disease.
❌ Onycholysis:
Incorrect: Onycholysis, or loosening of the nails from the nail bed, can be seen in all causes of hyperthyroidism. It is not specific for Graves disease.
✅ Exophthalmos:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atrial fibrillation  :
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation can be seen in up to 20% of patients with hyperthyroidism, but it is not specific for any condition. It is more common in older patients.
❌ Myxedema:
Incorrect: Myxedema describes non-pitting edema. It is caused by infiltration of the skin with glycosaminoglycans and associated water retention. Although myxedema can be caused by Graves disease (pretibial myxedema), it can also be caused by hypothyroidism (generalized myxedema). Therefore, the presence of myxedema is not specific for this patient’s condition.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the clinic because of vague right-sided back pain over the past two months. He denies any recent trauma, heavy lifting, or new activity. The patient has also noticed a 4.2 kg weight loss during this time, despite not making any changes to diet or activity. The patient has a 20 pack-year smoking history. The patient’s temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The results of his urinalysis are shown below:  
 
Laboratory value   Result 
 Urinalysis 
 Erythrocytes  60/hpf 
 Leukocytes  4/hpf 
 Bacteria  None 
Which of the following is a possible complication of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has renal cell carcinoma (RCC) based on his vague right-sided flank pain, weight loss, hematuria, and low-grade fever. He is also a male between the ages of 50-70 years with a history of smoking, which are significant risk factors for RCC.  

Among the answers above, only polycythemia is associated with RCC, which is secondary to paraneoplastic ectopic production of erythropoietin (EPO). Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with RCC are the consequence of ectopic hormone production, namely EPO, parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), and renin. Symptoms of polycythemia may include headache, dizziness, visual disturbances, pruritus, or complications such as thrombosis and bleeding. Additionally, patients may present with intense itching after a hot shower. Laboratory findings include a high hematocrit and hemoglobin.  

Clear cell RCC is the most common subtype of RCC, which can arise sporadically or can be hereditary as a part of Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. It is the most common primary tumor of the kidneys, arising from the cells of the proximal collecting ducts of the nephron. Histologically, it is composed of polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and carbohydrates that often appear golden yellow. RCC is unique as it first metastasizes hematogenously via the renal vein.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy:
Incorrect: Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is a possible complication of adenocarcinoma of the lung. This condition causes clubbing and periostitis of the hand, especially the distal interphalangeal joints and the metacarpophalangeal joints.  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  
Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy  
❌ Dermatomyositis:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is a possible complication of adenocarcinomas, especially ovarian. It presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness, gottron papules, and a heliotrope rash.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Heliotrope rash  



Reproduced from:Wikimedia Commons  
Gottron papules  
❌ Opsoclonus myoclonus ataxia syndrome:
Incorrect: Opsoclonus myoclonus ataxia syndrome presents with diffuse or focal myoclonus, truncal titubation, ataxia and ocular motility defects, and it is associated with neuroblastoma (in children) and small cell lung cancer (in adults); the syndrome can also be seen in other conditions (e.g., viral infections, post-streptococcal pharyngitis, hemorrhage). The syndrome is often referred to as “dancing eyes, dancing feet” because of the unique findings of ataxia and ocular motility disorder seen in these patients.   
✅ Polycythemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Hyponatremia can be caused by the syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH) secretion, which is associated with small cell lung cancer.  
❌ Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome:
Incorrect: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome occurs when antibodies are produced against the presynaptic (P/Q-type) Ca2+ channels at the neuromuscular junction. It is characterized by proximal muscle weakness and autonomic symptoms that classically improve with use (in contrast with myasthenia gravis). The syndrome is associated with small cell lung cancer.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to worsening academic performance in school and a bilateral tremor in the hands. The patient’s parents state that he has been doing worse in school for the past 6 months, and they first noticed the tremor 2 months ago. Family history includes an older brother who died at the age of 20 from severe liver disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. Slit lamp examination is performed and laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below. Urinalysis shows phosphaturia, aminoaciduria, and glucosuria. Which of the following structures is most likely affected in the renal manifestation of this patient’s disease?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
 
Laboratory value Result 
 Blood, serum, plasma 
Sodium   140 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.1 mEq/L 
 Chloride   107 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  18 mEq/L 
 Phosphorous (inorganic)  2 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient with worsening academic performance in school, bilateral hand tremor, hepatosplenomegaly, and Kayser-Fleischer rings on slit lamp examination likely has Wilson Disease, a potential cause of Fanconi syndrome. Fanconi syndrome is a generalized reabsorption defect in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) that leads to decreased absorption of bicarbonate, sodium, glucose, phosphate, uric acid, and water. This leads to proximal (type II) renal tubular acidosis (RTA). The loss of excessive bicarbonate in the urine also leads to metabolic acidosis, and the loss of phosphate in the urine leads to hypophosphatemia and bone loss.  



Fanconi syndrome can be hereditary or acquired. Common causes of Fanconi syndrome include Wilson Disease, tyrosinemia, glycogen storage disease, multiple myeloma, nephrotoxic drugs, ischemia, and lead poisoning.    

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the glomerulus, which is affected in nephritic and nephrotic glomerulopathies. The renal manifestation of Wilson disease affects the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), causing Fanconi syndrome.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, which is affected in Bartter syndrome.  
❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), which is affected in Gitelman syndrome.  
❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the collecting duct (CD), which is affected in Liddle syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with fatigue, syncope, and muscle weakness. The patient’s medical history is non-contributory, and he is on no medications. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg. Laboratory tests are obtained, and he is diagnosed with a renal tubular defect that acts similar to thiazide diuretics. Which of the following laboratory findings would most likely be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with fatigue, syncope, muscle weakness, and a renal tubular defect that acts similarly to thiazide diuretics most likely has Gitelman syndrome. Gitelman syndrome is an autosomal recessive renal tubular defect that is caused by a defect in NaCl cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). The loss of NaCl leads to a loss of water and a mild volume contraction, which activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Activation of the RAAS pathway increases potassium and hydrogen excretion, leading to hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. Volume contraction also leads to increased calcium reabsorption and consequent hypocalciuria. The mutation associated with Gitelman syndrome also affects a magnesium cotransporter, and thus hypomagnesemia is also commonly found in patients with the disease.  


Thiazide diuretics also act by blocking the sodium chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Therefore, patients with Gitelman syndrome will present similarly to those chronically taking thiazide diuretics.  

Option Analysis

✅   Serum H+  Serum K+  Urine Ca2+  ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Serum H+  Serum K+  Urine Ca2+  ↑  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings of metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, and hypercalciuria  are characteristic of Fanconi syndrome, a defect of the proximal convoluted tubule. 
❌   Serum H+  Serum K+  Urine Ca2+  ↓  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings of metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, and hypercalciuria are characteristic of Bartter syndrome, a defect of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. 
❌   Serum H+  Serum K+  Urine Ca2+  ↓  ↓  - - - :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings of metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia are characteristic of Liddle syndrome, along with hypertension and decreased aldosterone. Liddle syndrome is a defect of the collecting duct.
❌   Serum H+  Serum K+  Urine Ca2+  ↑  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings of metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, and hypocalciuria are characteristic of type 1 (distal) renal tubular acidosis (RTA).

questions.text: A 27-year-old male comes to the emergency department due to acute onset of right flank pain and hematuria. Since symptom onset, the patient has had persistent nausea and vomited twice. Medical history is significant for Crohn disease diagnosed 5 years ago. During the past month, the patient suffered from multiple episodes of diarrhea. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast is performed and reveals an 8 mm stone lodged in the right ureter. The patient is given IV fluids and doxazosin. A few hours later, the patient passes the stone. Microscopic analysis reveals that the stone is composed of purely uric acid. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to this patient’s stone formation?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with uric acid nephrolithiasis following multiple bouts of diarrhea due to Crohn disease. Uric acid stones account for 5-10 % of urinary tract stones. Uric acid crystals are typically diamond or barrel-shaped and yellow to orange-brown in color. Of note, uric acid stones are radiolucent and cannot be observed on plain radiographs.  

There are three factors that promote the formation of uric acid stones:
  • High urine uric acid concentration - gout, myeloproliferative disorders  
  • Acidic urine pH  
  • Low urine volume / dehydration - common in hot, arid climates
Chronic diarrhea leads to bicarbonate loss in the stool and volume depletion, which promotes uric acid supersaturation as well as acidic urine pH. The low urine pH shifts the relatively soluble urate salt into insoluble uric acid (H+ + Urate-  ↔  Uric acid). This change leads to supersaturation and stone formation.



Option Analysis

❌ Increased uric acid production:
Incorrect: Increased uric acid production, as seen in conditions such as gout or the myeloproliferative disorders, promotes uric acid stone formation by supersaturation. However, this patient has no history of such conditions.
❌ Infection by urease positive bacteria:
Incorrect: Infection by urease positive bacteria (e.g. Proteus mirabilis) contributes to the formation of struvite stones (magnesium ammonium phosphate), not uric acid stones.
❌ Elevated serum calcium level:
Incorrect: Elevated serum calcium can be seen in conditions such as hyperparathyroidism. It leads to increased filtration of calcium through the kidneys, which promotes the formation of calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones. In contrast, elevated serum calcium would not contribute to the formation of uric acid stones.
✅ Acidic urine pH:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased intestinal oxalate absorption:
Incorrect: Patients with Crohn disease or other conditions affecting the ileum are at risk of developing calcium oxalate kidney stones due to fat malabsorption. Under normal conditions, oxalate binds calcium in the gut and is excreted via stool. When fat malabsorption occurs, the excess fat binds to calcium, making it less available to bind oxalate. As a result, more oxalate is absorbed by the body, thus predisposing patients to developing calcium oxalate stones. However, elevated serum oxalate levels would not contribute to the formation of uric acid stones.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents for jaundice and poor muscle tone. She was born full-term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient was jaundiced at birth and her symptoms have persisted. She is exclusively breastfed and produces 5-6 wet diapers per day. Family history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus in her father and asthma in her mother. Physical examination shows jaundice and reduced muscle tone throughout the body. In addition, the patient has a right eye downward gaze palsy. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Total bilirubin  23.0 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase  14 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  12 U/L 
Which of the following conditions will present with laboratory findings similar to those found in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s physical exam is notable for jaundice, which is abnormal yellowish pigmentation of the skin, as well as hypotonia and oculomotor palsy. These findings, in combination with laboratory testing notable for unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, are concerning Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I. Of note, a patient’s unconjugated bilirubin level can be calculated by subtracting the conjugated bilirubin level from the total bilirubin level.  

Hyperbilirubinemia can be divided into three categories: unconjugated, conjugated, and mixed. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (also termed indirect hyperbilirubinemia) is caused by increased breakdown of hemoglobin (e.g., hemolytic disease of the newborn), impaired hepatic bilirubin uptake (e.g., congestive heart failure, side-effect of medications such as rifampin and probenecid), or defective conjugation of bilirubin (e.g., Crigler-Najjar syndrome, Gilbert Syndrome).  

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is caused by decreased bilirubin excretion (e.g., Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome) or biliary tract obstruction (e.g., biliary atresia, primary sclerosing cholangitis).  

Mixed hyperbilirubinemia is caused by conditions that impair both bilirubin conjugation and excretion. It is commonly seen in individuals with hepatitis and cirrhosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Biliary atresia:
Incorrect: Patients with biliary atresia will have conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, since bilirubin can be conjugated but not eliminated into the intestines. In contrast, this patient has normal conjugated bilirubin levels and elevated unconjugated bilirubin.
❌  Viral hepatitis:
Incorrect: This condition will lead to mixed hyperbilirubinemia, which means that both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin levels are elevated. Additionally, liver enzymes are typically elevated due to hepatocellular damage. In contrast, this patient’s laboratory findings show normal conjugated bilirubin levels and liver enzymes.
✅ Crigler-Najjar syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dubin-Johnson syndrome:
Incorrect: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a condition characterized by an absence of a biliary transport protein found normally found in hepatocytes. This results in less conjugated bilirubin being transported from hepatocytes into the bile canaliculi, ultimately causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In contrast, this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
❌ Primary sclerosing cholangitis:
Incorrect: Primary sclerosing cholangitis causes fibrosis of the biliary tree. Over time, this can impair bile outflow and result in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In contrast, the patient in this case has elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for concerns for an asthma exacerbation. According to the patient’s parent, the patient was playing unsupervised outside and has been wheezing since then. She reports the patient was playing in the garden and had dirt over his face when he came back inside. The patient was born full-term and is otherwise healthy. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Respiratory rate is 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination is notable for coughing, transmitted upper airway sounds, faint wheezing, as well as diminished breath sounds and rales at the right lung base. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Obstruction of bronchi between alveoli and trachea
Loss of lung volume secondary to compression

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient exhibits signs of foreign body ingestion (e.g., transmitted upper airway sounds, wheezing, rales). Examination of the right lower lobe raises concerns for obstructive atelectasis, as ingested foreign objects can obstruct bronchi and cause collapse of the distal alveoli.  

Atelectasis refers to the loss of lung volume secondary to alveolar collapse. It is classified based on the underlying pathophysiologic mechanism. The fours main types are: 1) obstructive, 2) compressive, 3) contraction, and 4) adhesive.  

Compressive atelectasis is when alveoli collapse occurs due to a pressure source (e.g., pleural effusion, hemothorax) pressing on the lungs. Contraction atelectasis occurs in diseases such as sarcoidosis and pulmonary fibrosis, wherein scarring of the lung parenchyma prevents adequate reexpansion. Adhesive atelectasis results from diminished surfactant function or synthesis (e.g. neonatal respiratory distress system), which causes alveoli to stick to one another.  

Clinically, the most common symptom of atelectasis is cough. Physical examination will demonstrate tachypnea as well as diminished breath sounds or rales over the affected portion of the lung. Atelectasis is a clinical diagnosis, though radiographic imaging can be helpful and may show lung opacification or loss of lung volume.  


Option Analysis

✅ Obstruction of bronchi between alveoli and trachea:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of lung volume secondary to compression:
Incorrect: Compressive atelectasis can be caused by pleural effusions, tension pneumothoraces, hemothoraces, and other conditions that exert a pressure on the lungs. However, it would be unlikely for this otherwise healthy child with no history of trauma to be experiencing any of these conditions.
❌ Scarring of lung parenchyma:
Incorrect: Contraction atelectasis can occur due to restrictive lung diseases (e.g. pulmonary fibrosis) or scarring of previously healthy lung tissue (e.g. sarcoidosis). In contrast, this patient has no history of such conditions, thereby making contraction atelectasis unlikely.
❌ Diminished surfactant production:
Incorrect: Adhesive atelectasis occurs due to surfactant deficiency or dysfunction. It can occur in prematurely born infants who have neonatal respiratory distress syndrome secondary to inadequate surfactant production. In contrast, this patient was born full-term and has no prior history of pulmonary conditions.  
❌ Recurrent bronchial hyperresponsiveness:
Incorrect: Asthma exacerbation is unlikely in this patient without a clear history of prior asthma episodes, other atopic symptoms (e.g., hives, eczema, nasal congestion), or significant family history. Moreover, asthma tends to present with diffuse symptoms, whereas this patient’s symptoms are mainly localized to the right lower lung.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office because of several episodes of dark-brown urine. He first noticed it 2 weeks ago. The patient’s parent adds that the patient has also been getting easily tired lately and frequently takes naps after school. There is no family history of renal conditions or hearing abnormalities. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/89 mmHg. Physical examination shows periorbital and generalized edema. Vision and hearing screening are normal. Laboratory results are as follows:


Renal biopsy findings show thickening of glomerular basement membrane due to dense deposits and mesangial ingrowth appearing as “tram-tracks.” Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?

choices.text: Mesangial deposition of insoluble polymers of proteins

questions.solution:
This young boy with nephrotic-range proteinuria (3+ on urine dipstick), hematuria, edema, hypertension, and biopsy findings of thickened glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and mesangial ingrowth in between most likely has type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN).  

MPGN is defined as a pattern of glomerular injury that involves thickening of the GBM with mesangial ingrowth in between, forming the classic tram-track appearance. It mainly occurs in children and presents with nephrotic syndrome, nephritic syndrome or a combination of both. MPGN is divided into three types. Type II is a result of widespread activation of C3, which occurs due to the persistent activity of the enzyme C3 convertase. Its activity is upregulated by autoantibodies called C3 nephritic factors. Immunofluorescence shows granular deposits of C3 within (intramembranous) and along the GBM.  


Type I, on the other hand, is mainly immune complex-mediated MPGN resulting from chronic antigenemia and is usually seen in chronic infections (hepatitis B or C infection) or autoimmune conditions. Histologically, it is characterized by discrete immune deposits in the mesangium and subendothelial space.


Option Analysis

✅ C3 nephritic factor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mutation in type IV collagen:
Incorrect: Mutation in type IV collagen is seen in Alport syndrome, a hereditary form of nephritis that is usually associated with sensorineural hearing loss and ocular abnormalities. Renal biopsy findings include thinning and splitting of glomerular basement membrane.
❌ Proteinase 3 antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA):
Incorrect: These autoantibodies against neutrophil granule proteins are seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly called Wegener granulomatosis). The condition is an immune-mediated disorder and is usually associated with fever, weight loss and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. Renal biopsy is associated with few or no immune deposits in the glomeruli.
❌ T-cell dysfunction:
Incorrect: T-cell dysfunction is considered a major pathogenic factor in minimal change disease (MCD), which usually presents in children with nephrotic syndrome. Although this patient’s proteinuria is in the nephrotic range, the coexisting nephritic syndrome (hematuria, edema, hypertension, RBC casts) and abnormal biopsy findings (typically normal in MCD) make this condition unlikely.
❌ Mesangial deposition of insoluble polymers of proteins:
Incorrect: Mesangial deposition of insoluble polymers of proteins (e.g. amyloid) is seen in amyloidosis. Renal involvement usually presents with asymptomatic proteinuria or clinically apparent nephrotic syndrome. Renal biopsy findings include mesangial deposits of amyloid that can be observed with Congo red staining as apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient had spent the evening at a bar with friends and consumed 7-10 shots of liquor. Shortly after leaving the bar, he felt nauseated and vomited multiple times. The last episode of vomiting produced bright red emesis. The patient denies dyspnea or recent trauma. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which he takes albuterol as needed. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a thin male in mild distress. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. The patient has no additional episodes of hematemesis. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Sodium  139 mg/dL 
 Potassium  3.8 mg/dL 
 Chloride  100 mg/dL 
 Bicarbonate  33 mg/dL 
Which of the following would be most useful in providing a definitive diagnosis of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has Mallory-Weiss syndrome, also termed gastro-esophageal laceration syndrome, which manifests as longitudinal, partial-thickness mucosal tears at the gastroesophageal junction. The condition most often occurs due to forceful vomiting, which increases intra-abdominal pressure. Additionally, in this patient, the repeated vomiting has caused a metabolic alkalosis.  

While vomiting is one of the most common causes, Mallory-Weiss syndrome can also be due to coughing, abdominal trauma, or abdominal straining. Patients with hiatal hernias are also at increased risk of developing Mallory-Weiss syndrome; one proposed explanation is that the hernia experiences a greater pressure gradient than the rest of the stomach. Additional risk factors include alcoholism and patients with eating disorders who exhibit purging behaviors since these conditions increase the risk of frequent, forceful vomiting and retching.  

Individuals with Mallory-Weiss syndrome can be asymptomatic, or they can present with painful hematemesis. A barium swallow can be performed and may show hematomas or streaks in the esophagus. However, endoscopy is required to confirm the mucosal tears and provide a definitive diagnosis.    

In most cases, Mallory-Weiss syndrome spontaneously resolves. However, if there is severe bleeding, endoscopic techniques are needed to achieve hemostasis.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: A chest radiograph is useful in the work-up of patients with esophageal perforation and will show free air. Esophageal perforation will cause dyspnea, severe chest pain, crepitus on palpation, and crackles on auscultation. In contrast, this patient has none of the aforementioned symptoms.
❌ Esophageal barium swallow:
Incorrect: An esophageal barium swallow study can reveal mucosal lacerations. However, upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy is more accurate and is necessary to definitively diagnose the patient’s condition, a Mallory-Weiss tear.
✅ Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computed tomography of the chest  :
Incorrect: This patient’s symptom of upper GI bleeding after heavy drinking and vomiting raises concerns for a Mallory-Weiss tear. The absence of crepitus makes full-thickness esophageal perforation unlikely. Since Mallory-Weiss tears are partial-thickness lacerations, they will most likely be radiographically occult and thus are often missed on a CT scan.
❌ Blood alcohol level:
Incorrect: This patient has been consuming large quantities of alcohol and will have an elevated blood alcohol level. However, this test will not help differentiate the different potential sources of upper GI bleeding (e.g., Mallory-Weiss syndrome, Boerhaave syndrome, gastric ulcer).

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician's office for evaluation of anxiety, weight loss and blurry vision. The patient has been feeling irritable and “on edge” at work for months, and she has lost 13-lb over this same time period, despite maintaining her diet. The patient states that her eyes have been feeling “uncomfortable,” reporting excessive tearing and episodic double vision. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 142/94 mmHg. The patient appears anxious. Ocular examination reveals bilateral proptosis, excessive tearing, and periorbital edema. When the physician asks the patient to follow his finger as he moves it superiorly and inferiorly, the patient’s sclera can be observed above the iris when the patient's eyes track downward. Laboratory studies reveal an elevated free T3 and T4 level with an undetectable level of TSH. Which of the following best explains the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s ocular findings?

choices.text: Hormonal secretion from an underlying malignancy
Infection posterior to the orbital septum

questions.solution:
Graves ophthalmopathy refers to the ocular manifestation of Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Graves disease is an autoimmune disorder resulting in autoantibodies, specifically thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSH-receptor antibodies), that can also activate the T-cells in the retro-orbital space. This activation results in secretion of cytokines such as TNF-alpha and IFN-gamma, increasing fibroblast secretion of glycosaminoglycans, causing ocular muscle swelling, inflammation, and an increase in the number of adipocytes. Ultimately, this manifests as exophthalmos, an anterior bulging of the eyes. In addition, lid lag may also be observed, where sclera can be seen above the iris as the patient looks down due to the increased sympathetic stimulation of the levator palpebrae superioris and superior tarsal muscles.  

Diagnosis is confirmed by histology of the thyroid, which will demonstrate tall and crowded follicular epithelial cells with scalloped colloid. Treatment of Graves ophthalmopathy includes glucocorticoids due to their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive properties. Treatment of Graves disease itself involves antithyroid agents, such as propylthiouracil or methimazole.  

Option Analysis

✅ Retro-orbital fibroblast secretion of glycosaminoglycans:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hormonal secretion from an underlying malignancy:
Incorrect: Paraneoplastic syndrome from an underlying malignancy can result in hormonal derangements. Paraneoplastic syndromes affecting the eyes include Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) and dermatomyositis. This patient’s exophthalmos and clinical presentation are instead indicative of Graves disease.
❌ Autoantibodies binding postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is characterized by autoantibodies that bind postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors, inducing muscle weakness. Ocular manifestations of MG include weakness of the eyelid muscles, resulting in ptosis.
❌ Autoantibodies binding presynaptic calcium channels:
Incorrect: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is a neuromuscular junction disorder resulting in muscle weakness. Ocular manifestations of LEMS include ptosis and diplopia, although most patients present with autonomic dysfunction (e.g. dry mouth, sluggish pupils, erectile dysfunction). 
❌ Infection posterior to the orbital septum:
Correct: Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the connective tissue of the orbit, mostly the fat and ocular muscles. Symptoms include pain with eye movements, proptosis or bulging of the eyeball, redness and swelling of the eyelid, and in some cases, ophthalmoplegia or impairment of eye movement. These are often accompanied by systemic symptoms, such as fever and chills, which are absent in this patient.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female is brought to the emergency department “to rule out a heart attack.” She was sitting in a college class when she experienced sudden tightness in the chest. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes oral contraceptive pills. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/71 mmHg. Physical exam is unremarkable, and electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from wikipedia    

Which of the following features of this electrocardiogram defines this patient's rhythm?

choices.text: Presence of P-waves with normal axis

questions.solution:
This otherwise young, healthy patient presents with chest pain. The electrocardiogram demonstrates a regular rhythm, rate, axis, without ST-segment changes, and a P-wave for every QRS complex. These findings are consistent with normal sinus rhythm.   

Sinus rhythm is the default pacemaker activity of the heart and is defined by several criteria but primarily by the presence of a P-wave for every QRS complex. This finding is reflective of normal SA node activity controlling depolarization of the ventricles via the AV node and His-Purkinje system. Additional electrocardiographic features of this rhythm include a regular rate (60-100 beats/min), a normal P-wave axis (upright in leads I and II, inverted in aVR), constant PR interval, and QRS complex <100 ms.  

A similar rhythm, termed sinus arrhythmia, refers to sinus rhythm with a beat-to-beat variation in the P-P interval, which refers to the time between successive P-waves. Ultimately, this produces an irregular ventricular rate. This arrhythmia is generally non-pathologic and is usually due to changes in vagal tone during the different stages of the respiratory cycle.  

Option Analysis

✅ Presence of P-waves with normal axis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Normal QRS duration:
Incorrect: In general, patients in normal sinus rhythm will have a normal QRS duration (<100ms). However, this feature does not define sinus rhythm.  
❌ Normal QT interval:
Incorrect: The QT interval can provide information regarding the presence of concomitant metabolic disturbances, medication side effects, and inherited QT channelopathy. It can also predict a patient’s risk of developing torsades de pointes. However, a normal QT interval is not the defining characteristic of normal sinus rhythm.
❌ Absence of ST segment changes :
Incorrect: ST segment changes can provide information regarding metabolic disturbance or evidence of ischemia. However, it does not define sinus rhythm. 
❌ Variations in the PR interval:
Incorrect: This patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates a P-wave for every QRS complex, normal P-wave axis (upright in leads I and II, inverted in aVR), and a constant PR interval. These findings are consistent with normal sinus rhythm. In general, patients in sinus rhythm will have a consistent PR interval, without beat to beat variation.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of weight loss, fatigue, and abdominal pain. He reports a gradual onset of symptoms several weeks ago that have not abated. He has a burning pain in his hands and feet that has followed a similar time course. He has a past medical history of hypertension, does not smoke or use alcohol, and has a history of intravenous heroin use. The last time he used IV heroin was 6 months ago. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 73/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 167/92 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for a mottled reticulated vascular pattern on the arms and legs. Laboratory studies show a creatinine of 2.1 mg/dL. An arteriogram is performed and demonstrates the following finding:


 Reproduced from:

Which of the following pathologic features is most likely associated with this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with multiple constitutional symptoms and a physical examination describing livedo reticularis. The work-up is notable for kidney dysfunction as well as beading and numerous microaneurysms affecting the segmental, interlobar, and arcuate vessels on an arterial nephrogram. This presentation is consistent with polyarteritis nodosa, a medium-vessel vasculitis due to immune complex deposition that carries a high association with concurrent hepatitis B infection.  

Hepatitis B presents with multiple extrahepatic manifestations that are thought to be immune-mediated. Examples include skin rashes, arthritis, and arthralgias. Additional manifestations include aplastic anemia, membranous glomerulonephritis, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and polyarteritis nodosa. Nearly 30% of individuals with polyarteritis nodosa have concurrent hepatitis B infection.  


Option Analysis

✅ Deposits containing HBsAg-HBsAb complexes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Positive for HLA-B51:
Incorrect: HLA-B51 is associated with Behçet's disease which manifests with recurrent aphthous ulcers, genital ulcerations, uveitis, and erythema nodosum. The disease can be precipitated by HSV or parvovirus and results in small-vessel vasculitis.
❌ Cryoglobulin immune complex deposition:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C infection is associated with essential, mixed cryoglobulinemia. In contrast, this patient’s presentation with livedo reticularis and likely polyarteritis nodosa is suggestive of hepatitis B, which is not associated with cryoglobulin immune complex deposition.
❌ Anti-GpIIb/IIIa antibodies :
Incorrect: HIV and hepatitis C, as well as autoimmune disorders and malignancy, may predispose patients to the development of immune thrombocytopenia. This patient, whose presentation is consistent with polyarteritis nodosa, likely has a different underlying infection.   
❌ Deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase:
Incorrect: A deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, an enzyme involved in heme synthesis, is consistent with porphyria cutanea tarda, which is associated with hepatitis C infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation with livedo reticularis and likely polyarteritis nodosa is suggestive of hepatitis B.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with shortness of breath and snoring. His partner reports “I can’t sleep, he snores all night!” The patient reports fatigue and shortness of breath throughout the day while performing activities of daily living. His medical conditions include obesity, hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. He smokes one to two cigarettes daily but does not drink or use illicit drugs. BMI is 41 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is noted to be taking rapid, shallow breaths. A chest x-ray is performed and reveals mild cardiomegaly but is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on pulmonary function testing for this patient?

choices.text: Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  ↓  ↑  ↓
Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV) ↑  ↓  ↑
Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV) ↓  ↓  ↓
Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV) ↑ normal  ↑
