Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  ↑ ↑  ↑

questions.solution:
This patient with morbid obesity presents with snoring, fatigue, and shortness of breath—clinical findings consistent with obesity hypoventilation syndrome. This pattern of breathing is a restrictive lung disease, which tends to present with a decreased total lung capacity, increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased residual volume. 

Restrictive lung disease refers to a type of lung pathophysiology that results in restricted lung expansion, Iow lung volumes, and a subsequent increased FEV1/FVC ratio due to increased elastic recoil of the lungs. In normal lungs, inhalation results in contraction of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles and expansion of the chest cavity; however, in restrictive lung disease, inhalation fills the lungs less than normal.  

This defect in lung filling is due to either diffuse intraparenchymal lung disease (interstitial lung disease) or extrapulmonary lung diseases:

  • Interstitial diseases such as sarcoidosis, pneumoconiosis, or idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis result in stiff, fibrotic lung tissue with decreased compliance and increased recoil.
  • Extrapulmonary diseases such as scoliosis or morbid obesity interferes with breathing mechanics and prevents proper chest expansion and lung filling. 
In both cases, the parameters on respiratory function testing remain the same, which includes low lung volumes, decreased total lung capacity, increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased residual volumes. 

Option Analysis

✅   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  ↓  ↑  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV) ↑  ↓  ↑:
Incorrect: Obstructive lung diseases, not restrictive lung diseases, present with these parameters. While this patient does smoke, the chest x-ray does not demonstrate findings consistent with an obstructive process (e.g. emphysema, which would show flattened diaphragms or hyperinflated lungs).
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV) ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: A decreased FEV1/FVC in the setting of decreased TLC and RV is rarely found and is more commonly due to measurement error. 
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV) ↑ normal  ↑:
Incorrect: These parameters are often found in patients that are endurance athletes such as runners or swimmers. 
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  ↑ ↑  ↑:
Incorrect: An increased FEV1/FVC in the setting of increased TLC and RV is rarely found and is more commonly due to measurement error.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with chronic shortness of breath and cough. He reports weight loss, chronic fatigue, and dyspnea for the past 6 months. He works on a farm and recently took a vacation to Florida for several weeks, where he felt resolution of his dyspnea, but it promptly started again once he returned. He has a history of hypertension for which he takes chlorthalidone daily. He smokes ten cigarettes daily but does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 128/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination is notable for a thin, cachectic male with coarse breath sounds bilaterally. Pulmonary function testing is notable for an increased FEV1/FVC ratio. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This male farmer presents with worsening shortness of breath, cough, constitutional signs and symptoms, as well a restrictive lung disease pattern. Given that these symptoms tend to worsen while he is in contact with the suspected antigen(s), his condition is most consistent with hypersensitivity pneumonitis.   

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an immune system disorder in which the lungs become inflamed in an allergic reaction to inhaled microorganisms, plant and animal proteins, or chemicals. Common triggers include coffee bean dust, moldy sugarcane, or bacterial spores from hot tubs. Additional triggers include Actinomyces spores from farm animals, Aspergillus spores from moldy barley, and pigeon or bird droppings.   

The disease gets classified into two distinct forms: the acute form and the chronic form. In the acute form of disease, a type III hypersensitivity reaction is initiated that results in immune complex deposition in the basement membrane of pulmonary capillaries and localized inflammation. If the acute response is unsuccessful, or if there is repeated exposure to the antigen, a type IV hypersensitivity ensues, resulting in noncaseating granuloma formation in the lungs.  

Acute hypersensitivity pneumonitis often presents with fevers, cough, shortness of breath, and headache within hours of exposure and then subsequently resolves after removal of the exposure. Chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis presents similarly, but with a more insidious onset over years of exposure. These patients often have sustained shortness of breath, weight loss, pattern of restrictive lung disease, and, in its worst case, respiratory failure.    



Option Analysis

✅ Hypersensitivity pneumonitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease :
Incorrect: While this patient does smoke, the pulmonary function tests are notable for an increased FEV1/FVC ratio, in contrast to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which presents with a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. In addition, the symptoms of COPD are unlikely to resolve spontaneously, as seen in this patient.
❌ Medication toxicity:
Incorrect: Clorthalidone is not a known cause of pulmonary fibrosis and restrictive lung disease. Medications known to induce pulmonary fibrosis include amiodarone, bleomycin, busulfan, and methotrexate. 
❌ Sarcoidosis :
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis is a multi-system granulomatous disorder that can result with a restrictive lung disease pattern. It is less likely in this older male patient without associated features of erythema nodosum, uveitis, or Bell's palsy. In addition, the resolution of this patient’s symptoms after removal of antigen exposure (i.e. the farm) makes the diagnosis of sarcoidosis less likely.
❌ Squamous cell carcinoma :
Incorrect: While this patient does smoke, he has developed a restrictive lung disease pattern more consistent with interstitial lung disease. Lung malignancy is not a common etiology of restrictive lung disease. In addition, the resolution of this patient’s symptoms after removal of antigen exposure (i.e. the farm) makes the diagnosis of lung cancer less likely.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old male presents to the emergency department with altered mental status and fatigue. He is found to be critically ill and is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further evaluation and monitoring. While in the ICU, the patient has a Swan-Ganz catheter placed in the right heart for continuous hemodynamic measurements. An initial set of readings is demonstrated below:


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Bacteremia due to a Gram-negative rod
Hemorrhage due to bleeding peptic ulcer

questions.solution:
This critically ill patient had a Swan-Ganz catheter placed and hemodynamic measurements taken. The findings include a decreased cardiac output (of which the cardiac index is a surrogate measure taking into account BMI), increased systemic vascular resistance, increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), and decreased mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2). These parameters are consistent with cardiogenic shock, of which heart failure is a common etiology.  

A Swan-Ganz catheter is a flexible tube passed into the right side of the heart and the pulmonary artery. It is used to take measurements of cardiac output (heart x stroke volume), systemic vascular resistance (80x (Mean Arterial Pressure - Mean Venous Pressure or CVP) / Cardiac Output), PCWP (surrogate of left atrial pressure), and SvO2 (measure of total body oxygen consumption). While seldom used in modern ICUs, it was historically used to provide useful information in determining the etiology of a patient’s shock.  


Option Analysis

✅ Heart failure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacteremia due to a Gram-negative rod:
Incorrect: Septic shock is a subtype of distributive shock that presents with decreased systemic vascular resistance, decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, increased cardiac output, and increased mixed venous oxygen saturation. This patient’s findings are inconsistent with those of septic shock.
❌ Impaired sympathetic outflow:
Incorrect: Neurogenic shock is another subtype of distributive shock that presents with decreased systemic vascular resistance, decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, decreased cardiac output, and an increased mixed venous oxygen saturation. It is most commonly caused by spinal cord injury that disrupts sympathetic outflow. In contrast, this patient has an elevated systemic vascular resistance.
❌ Thrombus in the pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: Obstructive shock is a subtype of “cold shock” and can be caused by pulmonary embolism. It can present with increased systemic vascular resistance, decreased cardiac output, and decreased mixed venous oxygen saturation. In causes of obstructive shock secondary to pulmonary embolism, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (surrogate of left atrial pressure) is reduced since less blood is reaching the left heart.
❌ Hemorrhage due to bleeding peptic ulcer:
Incorrect: Hemorrhagic shock presents with increased systemic vascular resistance, decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, decreased cardiac output, and decreased mixed venous oxygen saturation. It is most commonly due to ongoing hemorrhage from trauma or gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with progressive shortness of breath. She reports an insidious onset of symptoms over the past several weeks and reports she can no longer climb a flight of stairs without “huffing and puffing for air.” She recently completed doxorubicin chemotherapy for breast cancer. Her other past medical history includes hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and hyperlipidemia. Her daily medications include losartan, amiodarone, and simvastatin. She does not smoke or use illicit substances. Vitals are within normal limits. Her physical examination is notable for diffuse bilateral rales more prominent at the lung bases. She subsequently undergoes pulmonary function testing that demonstrates an increased FEV1/FVC ratio. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening shortness of breath, coarse breath sounds, and an increased FEV1/FVC ratio, consistent with restrictive lung disease and pulmonary fibrosis. Of factors listed in the patient’s history, only amiodarone is associated with this condition.  

Oftentimes the etiology of restrictive lung disease can be elucidated with a careful review of a patient’s medications and past medical history. Many medications in addition to amiodarone are culprits in progressive pulmonary fibrosis and restrictive lung physiology. These include nitrofurantoin as well as methotrexate, busulfan, and bleomycin. In addition, multiple systemic disease states are associated with this condition including rheumatoid arthritis, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Goodpasture disease, and pulmonary Langerhans' cell histiocytosis.      

Option Analysis

✅ Amiodarone toxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Doxorubicin toxicity :
Incorrect: Doxorubicin is not a known agent implicated in pulmonary fibrosis—it is more commonly associated with cardiotoxicity. Chemotherapeutic drugs implicated in restrictive lung disease include   busulfan, methotrexate, and bleomycin.  
❌ Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis :
Incorrect: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease of unknown etiology. It is more commonly associated with smoking, old age, and male gender. In the setting of pulmonary fibrosis in a patient taking amiodarone, this diagnosis is less likely. 
❌ Hypersensitivity pneumonitis :
Incorrect: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis results in diffuse reticulonodular fibrosis due to a mixed type III/IV hypersensitivity reaction. Patients will typically have a history of repeated exposure to an offending antigen, history of working on a farm, or history as a bird breeder.
❌ Pneumoconiosis :
Incorrect: Pneumoconiosis refers to a set of restrictive lung diseases and interstitial fibrosis induced by types of inhaled inorganic particulate matter. This patient does not have a history of exposure to materials such as asbestos, silica, or coal.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of low back pain and stiffness for  2 months. The stiffness reaches maximum intensity upon awakening and gradually improves throughout the day with activity. He does not have a history of back trauma or any other past medical history. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms consistently. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows loss of lumbar lordosis and restricted anterior flexion of spine. Babinski sign is negative. Which of the following diagnostic findings is most indicative of this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Gram stain of lumbar synovial fluid with gram negative diplococci

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy young man’s chronic back pain, morning stiffness that improves with movement, and examination findings of restricted spine flexion and loss of lumbar lordosis are strongly suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), a seronegative spondyloarthropathy (SpA).  

Seronegative SpA refers to a heterogenous group of disorders including ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis, that share some common features, including:  

  •  Sacroiliac joint involvement 
  •  Strong association with HLA B27 
  •  Negative rheumatoid factor (seronegative) 
  •  Inflammation at the site of ligamentous attachment (enthesitis) 
  •  Predominance for male gender 
  •  Onset usually before age 40  
Seronegative SpA usually involves the spine and nearby joints, presenting with inflammatory back pain and sacroiliitis. Other clinical features include peripheral asymmetric arthritis, enthesitis and dactylitis (sausage fingers). Extra-articular symptoms include anterior uveitis, aortic regurgitation (AR), pericarditis and genitourinary symptoms due to sacral spinal cord involvement. Diagnosis requires radiologic evidence of sacroiliitis with one of the aforementioned findings and demonstration of a good response to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).   



Option Analysis

❌ Gram stain of lumbar synovial fluid with gram negative diplococci:
Incorrect: Gram negative diplococci on arthrocentesis is typical of septic arthritis. Affected patients present acutely with a swollen painful, warm joint (most commonly affecting the knee). The lumbar spine is less commonly involved. This patient’s chronic back pain with morning stiffness suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Positive rheumatoid factor:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid factor is helpful in the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis, which presents with insidious onset pain, stiffness and swelling of small joints of hands (e.g. metacarpophalangeal joints). Involvement of the axial skeleton is rare; when it occurs, it predominantly affects the cervical spine (as atlantoaxial instability).
✅ Positive HLA B27 :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Mutation in the COL1A1 Gene:
Incorrect: A mutation in the COL1A1 gene results in abnormal production of collagen and the disease osteogenesis imperfecta. This disease tends to present initially in young children or infants with blue sclera, hearing loss, and fractures following minimal trauma. 
❌ Chondrocalcinosis on knee x-ray:
Incorrect: Chondrocalcinosis on knee x-ray is commonly seen in elderly patients with associated joint swelling, stiffness, and knee deformity--reflective of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease. Chronic back pain with morning stiffness is unlikely.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old female comes to the physician for evaluation of shortness of breath over the past few months. She has had no fever or weight loss over this time period. Past medical history is noncontributory and she does not take any medications. The patient drinks 2 or 3 glasses of wine on the weekends and does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the expiratory phase is prolonged and scattered wheezes are heard bilaterally. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the costal margin. No palmar erythema, spider angiomata, or ascites are noted. Laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes. Pulmonary function testing is performed and is shown below:

Images reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

The physician suspects a genetic condition. Which of the following is most likely to reveal the cause of this patient’s underlying disease process?

choices.text: Serum levels of a protease inhibitor

questions.solution:
This patient has pulmonary and hepatic symptoms despite not smoking and consuming only minimal quantities of alcohol. Her presentation is concerning for the autosomal dominant condition known as α1-antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency.  

A1AT is a protease inhibitor produced primarily by hepatocytes. Functional A1AT inhibits proteolytic enzymes such as neutrophil elastase, which is found within macrophages and the primary granules of neutrophils. Normally, elastase helps combat infections by degrading bacterial virulence factors. However, patients with A1AT deficiency produce misfolded copies of the protein that are unable to inhibit elastase. The uninhibited elastase activity leads to destruction of fibers in the alveolar walls and gives rise to panacinar emphysema (as indicated by this patient’s obstructive lung disease pattern on pulmonary function testing). Furthermore, the misfolded A1AT proteins accumulate in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes, leading to cell engorgement, release of lysosomal enzymes, and ultimately causing apoptosis and inflammation. This chronic inflammation of the liver results in hepatitis and eventual cirrhosis.  

Diagnosis of A1AT primarily depends upon measuring serum alpha-1 antitrypsin levels, where patients with the condition would have significantly lower levels present in their serum. Pulmonary function testing should also be performed, and would demonstrate an obstructive lung disease pattern. Treatment involves intravenous replacement with pooled alpha-1 antitrypsin.  



Option Analysis

✅ Serum levels of a protease inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum ferritin levels:
Incorrect: Serum ferritin would be helpful in the diagnosis of hemochromatosis, which may also present with signs of liver damage (e.g., enlarged liver, elevated liver enzymes). However, patients would also have other signs of iron-overload, such as diabetes mellitus, arthropathy, and eventually, skin pigmentation. This patient’s additional symptoms of obstructive lung disease is characteristic of another underlying condition.
❌ Sweat chloride test:
Incorrect: Sweat chloride tests can be used in the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF), which is characterized by recurrent pneumonia, sinusitis, and malabsorptive symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, poor weight gain). However, CF is almost always diagnosed before adulthood, and is unlikely to be the diagnosis in this older patient.
❌ 24-hour urinary copper excretion:
Incorrect: Wilson disease is caused by excessive copper accumulation in the liver eventually leading to the development of cirrhosis, as well as additional neurological manifestations. This patient’s constellation of liver injury and obstructive lung disease, however, is suggestive of a different underlying condition.
❌ Viral hepatitis panel:
Incorrect: Patients with chronic hepatitis (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C), may eventually present with signs of liver damage and cirrhosis. However, viral etiologies of hepatitis are unlikely to also result in obstructive lung disease, as seen in this patient’s pulmonary function testing.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the emergency department after multiple episodes of painless hematemesis. He was at home eating dinner when he felt nauseous and vomited bright red blood. The patient has multiple prior admissions for alcohol intoxication. He has been drinking a pint of vodka daily for the last 15 years. He does not smoke cigarettes. The patient tried heroin several years ago, but has not used it since. Past medical history is otherwise not significant for any abnormal bleeding episodes. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 104/74 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and engorged paraumbilical veins. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Despite appropriate management, the patient is told there is a high likelihood of his symptoms recurring. Which of the following best explains why this patient is likely to experience a similar episode in the future?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with esophageal variceal bleeding due to underlying liver cirrhosis caused by excessive alcohol consumption. Patients with liver cirrhosis also have reduced levels of thrombin (as well as many other clotting factors), which would predispose them to future episodes of bleeding.  

In patients with liver cirrhosis, hepatic fibrosis and hepatocyte apoptosis can reduce the liver’s synthetic capabilities. The hepatocyte is normally involved in various functions, including:  

  • Uptake and conjugation of bilirubin by uridine diphosphate (UDP)-glucuronosyltransferase in the endoplasmic reticulum. As hepatocytes lose their ability to function in cirrhosis, there is increased unconjugated bilirubin due to loss of this enzyme, which results in jaundice.   
  • Albumin makes up the majority of plasma proteins and is exclusively produced by the liver. As the synthetic capacity of the liver decreases, hypoalbuminemia occurs, which can lead to decreased intravascular oncotic pressure and development of interstitial edema.   
  • The hepatocyte is the site of production of nearly all coagulation factors including fibrinogen (factor I), thrombin (factor II), and upstream factors V, VII, IX, X, and XI, with the prominent exception being factor VIII. Loss of these factors results in increased risk for bleeding -- for example, from esophageal varices.  


Option Analysis

✅ Impaired production of thrombin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thrombocytosis:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia, not thrombocytosis, can be present in patients with cirrhosis and portal hypertension. Due to decreased venous drainage secondary to portal hypertension, the spleen can enlarge in size and cause platelet sequestration. The resulting thrombocytopenia can lead to increased episodes of bleeding.
❌ Reduced synthesis of factor VIII:
Incorrect: Factor VIII levels are generally unaffected in patients with cirrhosis since it is one of the few coagulation factors that is not produced by the liver. Instead, factor VIII is produced in endothelial cells.
❌ Inherited coagulopathy:
Incorrect: Inherited coagulopathies (e.g., hemophilia, von Willebrand disease) can result in episodes of bleeding. This patient’s history is not significant for any abnormal bleeding episodes prior to his current symptoms. Furthermore, his concurrent cirrhosis makes another etiology more likely.
❌ Systemic activation of coagulation products:
Incorrect: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is characterized by systemic activation of the clotting cascade with subsequent microthrombi formation and exhaustion of clotting factors. DIC commonly occurs secondary to other disorders, such as sepsis or malignancy. Although this patient is at increased risk of infection due to his underlying liver disease, another etiology is more likely to cause recurrent esophageal variceal bleeding.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old female presents with fatigue, headaches, and weight loss. The symptoms began insidiously several months ago but have worsened to the point where her headaches awaken her from sleep. The patient also has vision changes and often “sees double.” Past medical history is noncontributory, and she does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical exam is notable for bitemporal loss of vision. A brain MRI is obtained, and the results are demonstrated below:


Image reproduced from Radiopaedia

Which of the following laboratory findings is most reflective of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, chronic headaches, and a focal neurologic deficit of bitemporal hemianopsia. These findings are highly suspicious for mass effect on the optic chiasm. The brain MRI demonstrates a pituitary macroadenoma, a common etiology of secondary adrenal insufficiency, which manifests with increased CRH, decreased ACTH, normal aldosterone, and decreased cortisol levels.  

Secondary adrenal insufficiency is due to decreased ACTH production and is commonly the result of non-functional pituitary tumors. These benign tumors grow and compress normal pituitary tissue, manifesting with decreased ACTH plasma levels and subsequent decreased cortisol levels. In contrast to primary adrenal insufficiency, secondary adrenal insufficiency will manifest with normal aldosterone levels, since adrenal gland synthetic function remains unaffected. Associated clinical features include bitemporal hemianopsia, headaches, and hypopituitarism.  

Diagnosis is achieved through measurement of pituitary hormones and MRI to determine the size and location of the tumor. Treatment involves transsphenoidal tumor resection.

  

Option Analysis

✅   Corticotropin release hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)  Aldosterone  Cortisol  ↑    ↓  normal  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Corticotropin release hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)  Aldosterone  Cortisol  ↓  ↓  normal  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with tertiary adrenal insufficiency. Tertiary adrenal insufficiency is commonly due to abrupt withdrawal of exogenous corticosteroids after chronic use. Less commonly, it is due to mass effect on the hypothalamus from a suprasellar lesion. However, this patient has a pituitary lesion, which would more likely cause secondary adrenal insufficiency.
❌   Corticotropin release hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)  Aldosterone  Cortisol  ↑   ↑  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: Primary adrenal insufficiency is characterized by decreased aldosterone and cortisol production from the adrenal gland itself. It is further characterized by increased levels of CRH and ACTH due to absence of feedback suppression. In contrast, this patient’s brain MRI reveals a pituitary mass, which would more likely cause secondary adrenal insufficiency.
❌   Corticotropin release hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)  Aldosterone  Cortisol  ↑   ↑   normal  ↑  :
Incorrect: Ectopic CRH releasing tumors are rare but are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and prostate cancer. Increased levels of cortisol would manifest with Cushingoid features (e.g., truncal obesity, abdominal striae, recurrent infections), which are absent in this patient.
❌   Corticotropin release hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)  Aldosterone  Cortisol  ↓  ↓  normal  ↑  :
Incorrect: These findings are suggestive of primary hypercortisolism, such as in the case of an adrenal adenoma or carcinoma. Hypercortisolism would present with Cushingoid symptoms (e.g., truncal obesity, abdominal striae, recurrent infections), which are absent in this patient.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old Caucasian female presents to her primary care physician with progressive fatigue, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Her symptoms have been ongoing for months, and she has been unable to obtain relief with over the counter antacids or probiotics. Past medical history is notable for Hashimoto thyroiditis, for which she is currently taking levothyroxine. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Her physical examination and laboratory findings are demonstrated below:




Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

The presence of which of the following antibodies is most indicative of this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This Caucasian patient with a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis presents with fatigue, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Physical examination demonstrates hyperpigmentation, and laboratory findings are consistent with hypoaldosteronism given her hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. Together, the patient’s findings are consistent with autoimmune adrenalitis, which is often associated with anti-21-hydroxylase antibodies.  

Two important causes of autoimmune adrenalitis are polyglandular autoimmune syndrome types I and II, although not all patients fit the exact prototype of these syndromes. Type I is due to mutations in the AIRE gene, which serves multiple important immunological tolerance roles. Mutations in this gene cause autoimmune damage of multiple organs, resulting in primary adrenal insufficiency, hypogonadism, hypoparathyroidism, and recurrent infections with commensal organisms such as candida. Polyglandular autoimmune syndrome type II is also associated with mutations in genes affecting immune tolerance. Type II can also cause primary adrenal insufficiency and hypogonadism, but is additionally characterized by the presence of type I diabetes mellitus and autoimmune thyroiditis.  

Both conditions are associated with antibodies against the steroidogenic enzyme 21-hydroxylase and less frequently 17α-hydroxylase. In general, these antibodies must yield at least 90% damage to the adrenal cortex before clinical manifestations of adrenal insufficiency arise.

Option Analysis

✅ Anti-21-hydroxylase antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anticardiolipin antibodies:
Incorrect: Anticardiolipin antibodies are often associated with systemic lupus erythematosus and antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, which can present with a hypercoagulable state and repeat miscarriages. Less commonly, these antibodies can be found in patients with polyglandular autoimmune syndrome type II, which manifests with autoimmune thyroiditis, hypogonadism, adrenal insufficiency, and type I diabetes mellitus. 
❌ IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase:
Incorrect: Celiac disease can also present with abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. However, given this patient's evidence of hyperpigmentation as well as hyponatremia and hypokalemia, a diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency is more likely.
❌ Glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies:
Incorrect: Glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies are associated with conditions such as type I diabetes mellitus, either as an isolated condition or in the setting of polyglandular autoimmune syndrome type II. However, this patient does not have symptoms that are suggestive of type I diabetes mellitus (e.g., polydipsia, polyuria, blurred vision). Instead, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with autoimmune adrenal insufficiency, which is strongly associated with anti-21-hydroxylase antibodies.
❌ Antimitochondrial antibodies:
Incorrect: Antimitochondrial antibodies are associated with primary biliary cholangitis, which leads to scarring of the biliary ducts and subsequent obstructive jaundice. However, this patient’s physical exam reveals skin hyperpigmentation, as opposed to jaundice.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to his primary care physician because of early satiety and a constant “gnawing” abdominal pain. The patient has experienced a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 4-months. In addition, he endorses having woken up at night soaked in sweat. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and atherosclerosis. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history. His diet consists mostly of salted and canned foods. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 152/84 mmHg, pulse is 79/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Physical examination is notable for conjunctival pallor and epigastric pain. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are non-contributory. Which of the following conditions is this patient also at risk of developing?

choices.text: Redistribution of adipose tissue to the face and neck
Muscle weakness exacerbated by continued use
Repeated, random, and rapid eye movements
Clubbing and inflammation of the hand joints

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has weight loss, early satiety, and epigastric pain in the setting of a long history of smoking and preserved food consumption. He most likely has gastric cancer. One paraneoplastic syndrome associated with gastric cancer is the Leser-Trelat sign, which is characterized by the sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratoses.   

The Leser-Trelat sign may be seen in patients with gastrointestinal tract adenocarcinomas (gastric, colon, rectal), with gastric adenocarcinoma being the overall most common malignancy. The exact pathophysiology underlying the sign of Leser-Trelat is uncertain, but there is strong suspicion that the release of cytokines and growth factors from the underlying neoplasm stimulates the eruptive growth of the seborrheic keratoses, such as overexpression of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR).  

On physical examination, seborrheic keratoses are well-demarcated, round or oval lesions that can appear in various colors and have a dull, verrucous and slightly elevated surface. Dermatologic examinations tend to describe them as coin-shaped, waxy, and having a typical “stuck on appearance,” meaning that they look like a spot that can be peeled away from the surface of the skin.    

Malignant acanthosis nigricans, which is characterized by velvety, symmetrical hyperpigmentation often in intertriginous sites (but may occur in any location on the body), can occur simultaneously in about 25% of cases displaying the Leser-Trelat sign. 

Option Analysis

❌ Redistribution of adipose tissue to the face and neck :
Incorrect: This symptom is seen in patients with Cushing syndrome. The condition can arise as a paraneoplastic syndrome of small cell lung cancer, as the neoplastic tissue can produce ectopic ACTH. The net result is increased cortisol production by the adrenal glands. However, this patient’s symptoms of early satiety, epigastric pain, and weight loss raise greater concerns for gastric cancer.   
❌ Muscle weakness exacerbated by continued use :
Incorrect: Patients with myasthenia gravis can present with this symptom. The condition arises due to the production of antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymomas. In contrast, this patient’s presentation of early satiety, weight loss, and abdominal pain raise concerns for gastric cancer, which has no association with either condition. 
❌ Repeated, random, and rapid eye movements :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome, which can be seen in patients with neuroblastoma or small cell lung cancer. In contrast, it would be atypical for opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome to manifest in patients with gastric cancer.  
✅ Eruption of multiple seborrheic keratoses :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Clubbing and inflammation of the hand joints :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes hypertrophic osteoarthropathy, a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer. The condition frequently affects the joints in the hands and long bones. Patients may complain of a burning sensation in the affected joints. However, this patient’s presentation of early satiety, weight loss, and abdominal pain are more consistent with the symptoms of gastric cancer. Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is not associated with gastric cancer.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician with worsening gait instability. Over the past few weeks, the patient has had several falls at school. Her mother has noticed that the patient’s gait appears uncoordinated and that she has occasionally been slurring her words. The patient’s physical exam is notable for high-arched feet, difficulty walking in a straight line, and decreased vibratory sensation in both the upper and lower extremities. She subsequently undergoes a genetic analysis, which demonstrates a GAA repeat on chromosome 9. Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in individuals with this disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient has multiple features consistent with Friedreich ataxia, including pes cavus (high heel arch), gait ataxia, diminished vibratory sensation, and dysarthria. She has a genetic test demonstrating GAA repeats on chromosome 9, which is consistent with this diagnosis. The leading cause of mortality in patients with Friedreich ataxia is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.  

Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive trinucleotide repeat disorder due to GAA repeats on chromosome nine. These repeats result in limited expression of the frataxin gene, which encodes an iron binding protein that regulates iron chaperoning, detoxification, antioxidation, and mitochondrial iron storage in neurologic tissue, cardiac myocytes, and pancreatic tissue. Current theories postulate that limited frataxin causes mishandling of iron and subsequent impairment of mitochondrial functioning, leading to cellular injury and oxidative stress in the affected tissue.  

Clinically, Friedreich ataxia tends to present in late childhood or adolescence and is a slowly progressive disease. Patients typically have limb ataxia due to spinocerebellar tract degenration, spastic paralysis due to lateral cortiospinal tract degeneration, and decreased vibratory and proprioceptive sensation due to dorsal column degeneration. Additional clinical features include scoliosis, pes cavus, hammer toes, diabetes mellitus, and cardiac dysfunction.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Heart failure :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Respiratory failure :
Incorrect: Respiratory failure is a common cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with conditions such as Guillain-Barre syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and poliomyelitis. However, this patient’s combination of gait ataxia, high-arched feet, and sensory deficits is more concerning for Friedreich ataxia. The most common cause of death in individuals with this condition is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. 
❌ Subependymal giant cell tumors:
Incorrect: The most common cause of death in patients with tuberous sclerosis is thought to be progressive neurologic decline from subependymal tumors. However, this etiology is not the most common cause of death in patients with Friedreich ataxia.  
❌ Sepsis:
Incorrect: Many neurological diseases can lead to difficulty protecting the airway, aspiration pneumonia, and subsequent sepsis. However, this patient’s combination of gait ataxia, high-arched feet, and sensory deficits is concerning for Friedreich ataxia. The most common cause of death in individuals with this condition is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, as opposed to sepsis. 
❌ Hypercoagulable state  :
Incorrect: A hypercoagulable state can be present in patients with underlying malignancies or thrombotic disorders. Hypercoagulability can predispose patients to developing pulmonary emboli. While patients with Friedreich ataxia are more prone to a hypercoagulable state due to immobility, it is not the leading cause of mortality.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of decreased hearing in the left ear. The symptoms started 2 months ago and have progressively worsened. Her parents state she has difficulty hearing voices and sounds coming from her left. Past medical history is notable for a femoral fracture, which she sustained after falling from standing-height. There is no history of similar symptoms in her family members. The patient’s older sister was recently diagnosed with multiple sclerosis at the age of 20. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, and pulse is 87/min. The patient is below the 5th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination is notable for hepatosplenomegaly and sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. Genetic testing reveals a homozygous mutation in the carbonic anhydrase type II gene (CA2). Which of the additional findings will most likely be present on laboratory testing?
questions.solution:
This patient has osteopetrosis, which is characterized by impaired bone resorption. Symptoms vary depending on the disease’s severity and which genes are affected. There are two main types of disease that can occur: infantile malignant osteopetrosis and autosomal-dominant osteopetrosis type II.  

Infantile malignant osteopetrosis (autosomal recessive) presents with severe symptoms that manifest in infancy. A commonly implicated gene is the carbonic anhydrase type II gene (CA2). Homozygous mutation in this gene can result in impaired functioning of osteoclasts, resulting in persistent bone growth. Patients may experience excessive skull bone growth, which can narrow the cranial foramina, an opening on the skull base through which many cranial nerves pass; this process can result in proptosis, blindness, deafness, and hydrocephalus. When bone tissue begins to replace bone marrow in the medullary cavity, it can cause severe bone marrow failure, resulting in pancytopenia. The body tries to compensate for bone marrow failure by stimulating extramedullary hematopoiesis in the liver and spleen, resulting in hepatosplenomegaly.  

Autosomal-dominant osteopetrosis type II presents with milder symptoms that manifest in early adulthood. Many patients are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients may present with pathological fractures and early-onset osteoarthritis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Elevated serum calcium levels:
Incorrect: This patient has osteopetrosis, which is characterized by reduced osteoclast function. As a result, calcium is sequestered for bone mineralization but has difficulty being released via bone breakdown. As a result, patients with osteopetrosis present with reduced (or normal) calcium levels, depending on the condition’s severity.
✅ Reduced red blood cell count:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid:
Incorrect: Oligoclonal bands may be found in the cerebrospinal fluid of patients with multiple sclerosis. The condition can present with focal neurological deficits. However, it would be atypical for multiple sclerosis to cause pathological long-bone fractures or present in a patient this young.
❌ Increased parathyroid hormone production:
Incorrect: Hyperparathyroidism can cause increased bone resorption and predispose patients to fracture. However, hyperparathyroidism does not present with cranial nerve deficits. 
❌ Elevated alkaline phosphatase levels:
Incorrect: Conditions such as osteitis deformans, hyperparathyroidism, osteomalacia can present with this laboratory finding. However, the presence of pathological fractures and cranial nerve deficits in a young patient raise concerns for osteopetrosis, which does not typically cause elevated alkaline phosphatase levels.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to his primary care physician because of right knee pain that began half-a-year ago and has progressively worsened. The patient previously enjoyed running marathons but had to stop because of the joint pain. Over-the-counter acetaminophen and ibuprofen help alleviate the pain. He recently returned from a camping trip in rural Connecticut. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. BMI is 24 kg/m2. No erythema or warmth is noted at the affected joint. Pain and crepitus are elicited on passive flexion and extension of the knee. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:

 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  15.2 g/dL 
 Leukocyte Count  7,100/mm3 
 Platelet Count  320,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  12 mm/h 

Which of the following additional physical examination findings will be most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Pain and redness of the uvea
Red erythematous rash with central clearing
Purulent drainage from the knee joint
Morning stiffness that resolves within an hour
Reduced range of motion in the lumbosacral spine

questions.solution:
Arthritis refers to a group of diseases that cause destruction of one or more joints. It can be classified as inflammatory or non-inflammatory.

This patient has osteoarthritis, which occurs secondary to mechanical wear and tear that destroys the joint cartilage. It is a type of non-inflammatory arthritis. Non-inflammatory arthritides usually manifest with asymmetric joint pain that worsens with use, affects weight-bearing joints (e.g., knees, hip), and morning stiffness that lasts for less than an hour. Extra-articular symptoms (e.g., uveitis, pulmonary fibrosis, fatigue) are generally absent in non-inflammatory arthritis.

Inflammatory arthritis is caused by an immune response attacking the joints. It includes conditions with unknown causes, like rheumatoid arthritis and juvenile idiopathic arthritis, or it can be secondary to diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus and Sjogren syndrome. Inflammatory conditions are usually accompanied by joint swelling, symmetric joint pain that improves with use, and prolonged morning stiffness lasting more than one hour. Most of these conditions are also associated with extra-articular symptoms, such as fatigue and malaise.



Option Analysis

❌ Pain and redness of the uvea:
Incorrect: This answer describes uveitis, which is associated with many of the inflammatory arthritides, such as rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis. However, this patient has pain in a single weight-bearing joint and history of joint overuse. As a result the patient likely has osteoarthritis, which is a type of non-inflammatory arthritis.
❌ Red erythematous rash with central clearing:
Incorrect: Patients with Lyme disease, which is most commonly reported in the Northeast and upper Midwestern United States, can have a targetoid rash and migrating arthralgia, meaning that the joint pain spreads from one joint to another. In contrast, this patient’s pain has remained in the right knee joint.
❌ Purulent drainage from the knee joint:
Incorrect: This finding would be seen in septic arthritis, which also manifests with joint warmth or erythema. Laboratory testing will show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. In contrast, this patient does not have any of these findings.
✅ Morning stiffness that resolves within an hour:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced range of motion in the lumbosacral spine:
Incorrect: This symptom is seen in patients with ankylosing spondylitis, a type of inflammatory arthritis. The condition most often affects young males, and it would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to manifest in an older male. Additionally, patients typically have pain in the lumbosacral region, which is not seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and productive cough. The symptoms began one day ago. She reports producing yellowish, non-bloody sputum. Past medical history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. Pulmonary examination reveals decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung. Examination of the hands reveals swelling and mild deformation of the bilateral metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Abdominal examination is notable for splenomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   10 g/dL 
 Platelets   400,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  84 mm/h 

The sputum shows Gram-positive staining. Which of the following additional laboratory findings will most likely be present in the patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has splenomegaly, an ongoing bacterial infection, and a history of rheumatoid arthritis. She most likely has Felty syndrome, which consists of three pathologies: rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia. Neutropenia predisposes patients to infections. In addition, patients with Felty syndrome can have thrombocytopenia secondary to splenic sequestration of platelets.

On a systemic level, rheumatoid arthritis can cause anemia of chronic disease. This complication occurs because the liver produces high amounts of hepcidin in response to inflammatory cytokines. Hepcidin decreases serum iron levels by inhibiting its absorption in the intestines and trapping it in macrophages or liver cells.

In addition, rheumatoid arthritis can cause AA amyloidosis, which is a type of amyloidosis that occurs as a reaction to another illness. Rheumatoid arthritis causes the liver to produce serum amyloid A (SAA) protein in high levels. However, if inflammation persists, a small portion of the SAA protein, called AA protein, will separate from SAA and can then deposit in organs as AA amyloid, especially in the kidneys, where it causes organ damage.





Option Analysis

❌ Positive cold-agglutinin test:
Incorrect: Patients with conditions such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection or mononucleosis can have a positive cold-agglutinin test. Pneumonia secondary to Mycoplasma pneumoniae can cause shortness of breath. However, it would not cause excessive sputum production or a gram-positive stain.
❌ Elevated liver enzymes:
Incorrect: Conditions such as hepatitis or biliary tract obstruction can result in elevated liver enzymes. However, this patient’s presentation of splenomegaly and infection in the setting of rheumatoid arthritis raises concerns for Felty syndrome. It would be atypical for Felty syndrome to affect the liver.
❌ Reduced procalcitonin:
Incorrect: Procalcitonin is a marker that can be used to distinguish bacterial from viral pneumonia. This patient has a history of sputum production that is gram-positive, which raises concerns for bacterial pneumonia. As a result, procalcitonin levels would be elevated in this patient.
✅ Reduced neutrophil count:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated anti-dsDNA antibody titers:
Incorrect: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). However, this patient’s presentation of splenomegaly and infection in the setting of rheumatoid arthritis raises concerns for Felty syndrome. Neither rheumatoid arthritis nor Felty syndrome would cause elevated anti-dsDNA antibody levels.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance. He reports having difficulty keeping up with his friends while playing soccer. The patient recently immigrated to the United States. He previously had limited access to medical care. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a heart murmur can be auscultated at the left lower sternal border. No cyanosis of the skin or mucosal membranes is observed. Cardiac catheterization is performed and yields the results shown below.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation of these findings?

choices.text: Obstruction of blood flow across a cardiac valve
Impaired oxygen exchange in the lungs

questions.solution:
This patient with exercise intolerance and a heart murmur at the left lower sternal border (LLSB), together with cardiac catheterization showing an increase in oxygenation in the right ventricle, most likely has a ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common type of acyanotic congenital heart disease. The condition can cause fatigue, shortness of breath, exercise intolerance, and failure to thrive. VSDs are a type of left-to-right shunt, wherein oxygenated blood in the left heart passes through the defect and enters the right heart. Patients are acyanotic since deoxygenated blood from the right heart is unable to enter the systemic circulation. Other causes of left-to-right shunts include atrial septal defect, patent foramen ovale, and patent ductus arteriosus.  

In contrast, in a right-to-left shunt, deoxygenated blood from the right heart passes through a defect and enters the left heart. The deoxygenated blood subsequently enters the systemic circulation, resulting in cyanosis. Causes of right-to-left shunts include Tetralogy of Fallot and Eisenmenger syndrome, among others. 

Option Analysis

❌ Obstruction of blood flow across a cardiac valve :
Incorrect: Conditions such as mitral or atrial stenosis can result in impaired blood flow across the affected valves. Patients can present with dyspnea and easy fatigability. However, a valvular disorder would not account for the elevated oxygen saturation in the right ventricle and pulmonary artery. 
❌ Impaired oxygen exchange in the lungs :
Incorrect: Conditions ranging from pulmonary hypoplasia to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease can impair gas exchange in the lungs, which results in oxygen-poor blood returning to the left heart. In contrast, the blood in this patient’s left heart is well oxygenated. 
❌ Reversal of long-standing left-to-right shunt :
Incorrect: The reversal of a long-standing left-to-right shunt is termed Eisenmenger syndrome. Since deoxygenated blood is now able to enter the left heart and eventually the systemic circulation, patients with this condition present with cyanosis. In contrast, the patient in this vignette does not have cyanosis. 
❌ Right-to-left shunting of blood :
Incorrect: Right-to-left shunting allows deoxygenated blood in the right heart to enter to the left heart and subsequently the systemic circulation. This type of shunt would result in cyanosis and reduced oxygen saturation in the left heart. In contrast, this patient is acyanotic and has normal oxygen saturation levels in the left heart. 
✅ Left-to-right shunting of blood :
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for fatigue and leg pain that began around four months ago. The pain worsens with physical activity and improves with rest. She has no notable past medical history, aside from an episode of pharyngitis when she was 12 years old, which self-resolved. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and respirations are 20/min. Upper extremity blood pressure is 135/82 mmHg, and lower extremity blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows delay in the femoral pulse compared with the brachial pulse. No signs of cyanosis are observed. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Anterosuperior displacement of the interventricular septum
Incomplete closure of the mitral valve during systole
Fusion of the aortic valve leaflets

questions.solution:
This patient with fatigue, claudication, brachiofemoral delay and hypotension in lower extremities most likely has coarctation of aorta (CoA). CoA occurs when there is a specific point of narrowing of the lumen of the aorta, and it can be divided into two types: preductal and postductal.  

The preductal type (also termed the infantile type) presents early in life and is associated with a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). In this type, aortic narrowing occurs before the ductus arteriosus. Blood pressure is elevated in the aorta before the narrowing and reduced after the narrowing. As a result, deoxygenated blood is shunted from the pulmonary artery, through the ductus arteriosus, into the aorta distal to the narrowing. Deoxygenated blood can travel to the lower extremities and result in differential cyanosis, which is when the lower extremities are cyanotic, but the upper extremities are not.  

The postductal type (also termed the adult type) is not associated with a PDA. Narrowing occurs after the ductus arteriosus/ligamentum arteriosum. No shunting or differential cyanosis is present. However, blood pressure will still be elevated proximal to the narrowing and reduced distal to the narrowing. Of note, the patient in this vignette has the postductal type.  

Both types can cause upper extremity hypertension. In addition, if too little blood reaches the legs, patients can develop claudication that is exacerbated by exercise, as seen in this patient.

Option Analysis

❌ Anterosuperior displacement of the interventricular septum :
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The condition instead causes cyanosis that is triggered by crying or exercise. Moreover, it would not account for the blood pressure difference between the patient’s upper and lower extremities. 
❌ Incomplete closure of the mitral valve during systole :
Incorrect: This pathophysiology results in mitral regurgitation, which causes a systolic murmur loudest over the cardiac apex that radiates to the axilla. Rheumatic heart disease secondary to Streptococcus pyogenes infection can result in mitral regurgitation. However, it would be atypical for mitral regurgitation to present with upper extremity hypertension or lower extremity claudication.  
❌ Fusion of the aortic valve leaflets :
Incorrect: Fusion of the aortic valve leaflets would result in a bicuspid aortic valve, which predisposes patients to aortic stenosis. Since blood now has a harder time leaving the left heart, patients can develop fatigue and exercise intolerance. However, aortic stenosis would not cause hypertension only in the upper extremities. 
✅ Postductal narrowing of the aorta :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Preductal narrowing of the aorta :
Incorrect: This answer describes preductal coarctation of the aorta, which is associated with a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Since there is low blood pressure in the aorta distal to narrowing, right-to-left shunting can occur. Blood from the pulmonary artery can pass through the PDA and travel to the lower extremities. As a result, patients can develop lower extremity cyanosis. In contrast, no cyanosis is observed in this patient.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of a positive fecal occult blood test during routine colorectal cancer screening. The patient has not experienced fatigue, changes in bowel habit, or recent weight loss. His medical and family history are noncontributory. His temperature is 36.2°C (97.1°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count reveals a hemoglobin of 14 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume of 80 μm3. Colonoscopy demonstrates two polyps in the sigmoid colon, which are then biopsied. Histological images of the polyps are shown below:  

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following gene mutations is responsible for the conversion of normal colon to the lesion found in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a positive fecal occult blood test (FOBT) and subsequently undergoes colonoscopy with biopsy. The biopsy results show a villous adenomatous polyp, which is a premalignant lesion. Clinically, adenomatous polyps are usually asymptomatic, but some may cause occult bleeding, secretory diarrhea, or partial intestinal obstruction.  

Adenomatous polyps can be classified into three categories: villous, tubulovillous, and tubular. Amongst them, villous polyps have the highest malignant potential. The transformation from normal epithelium to adenomatous polyp, and later carcinoma, is termed the adenoma-carcinoma sequence. It is characterized by a series of mutations:  

1) Normal mucosa to colon-at-risk: A change from normal mucosa to an at-risk colon occurs by acquiring a mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene, which is a tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 5. Loss of the APC gene leads to accumulation of the β-catenin protein (transcription factor), which leads to constitutive transcription and unregulated cell proliferation.    

2) Colon-at-risk to adenomatous polyps: The KRAS proto-oncogene normally encodes for proteins that regulate cell-signal transduction. Mutations in KRAS lead to the formation of stabilized forms of these proteins, which makes them resistant to degradation. The presence of these stabilized proteins leads to constant transmission of extracellular growth signals.    

3) Adenomatous polyps to colorectal cancer: This final step is believed to be caused by a loss of tumor suppressor genes, such as TP53 and DCC, which are normally responsible for negatively regulating the cell cycle.  

Option Analysis

❌ TP53:
Incorrect: TP53 is a tumor suppressor gene and often referred to as "guardian of the genome". It is responsible for the production of DNA-binding protein p53. Once activated, p53 induces the transcription of p21, which blocks cyclin dependent kinases and thus cell cycle progression. TP53 mutations are responsible for most human cancers. However, TP53 leads to the progression of adenoma to carcinoma, not from normal colon to adenoma.  
❌ PTEN:
Incorrect: The phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) gene is a negative regulator of the phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K)-AKT pathway. Loss of function of this gene contributes to the development of breast, prostate, and endometrial cancer.  
❌ BRCA2:
Incorrect: BRCA2 is a tumor suppressor gene involved with DNA repair. It is associated with breast, ovarian, and pancreatic cancer. However, it is not involved in the pathogenesis of colorectal adenomas or cancer. 
❌ TSC1:
Incorrect: The tuberous sclerosis complex 1 (TSC1) is responsible for the production of hamartin protein, which is widely expressed in normal tissues. Inactivating mutations or complete loss of the TSC genes can give rise to tuberous sclerosis. 
✅ KRAS:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ MYCL1:
Incorrect: The MYCL1 gene encodes for a transcription factor. Its mutation is associated with certain lung cancers, not colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is brought to the office by his partner for evaluation of impaired memory. About three-months ago, the patient started frequently misplacing objects and having difficulty performing his responsibilities as an accountant. His symptoms worsened two weeks ago, when he developed difficulty walking and frequently tripped over himself. The patient still enjoys playing poker with his friends weekly, but he has found it increasingly difficult to remain competitive. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, for which he takes daily medications. His last HbA1c from one month ago was 9.6%. He drinks 3-4 glasses of wine per week, and he does not consume tobacco or illicit substances. In the office, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/94 mmHg. Physical exam reveals no abnormalities. Head CT shows multiple hypodense lesions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has experienced a stepwise decline in neurocognitive function, which is concerning for vascular dementia (VD). Patients with VD typically have multiple cardiovascular risk factors, such as chronic hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and smoking. There are generally two forms of vascular dementia:  

  •  Small vessel disease is caused by lipohyalinosis, amyloid beta deposition, and/or microatheroma of cerebral vessels. These changes lead to lacunar infarcts and cortical microinfarcts. Due to the chronic nature of this disease, there is a gradual or stepwise worsening of dementia. Early symptoms include impaired memory and reduced executive functioning. In the later stages, patients can develop disorientation, mood disorders, and behavioral changes. 
 
  •  Large vessel disease is caused primarily by atherosclerosis that leads to cerebral cortex ischemia. In patients with multi-infarct dementia, there is a similar stepwise progression of symptoms. However, in patients with single-infarct dementia, there is a single major ischemic event such as a stroke, upon which there would be sudden-onset dementia.

Head imaging (e.g., CT, MRI) would show multiple cortical and subcortical infarcts that are indicative of repeated ischemic events.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebral arteriosclerosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thiamine deficiency :
Incorrect: Thiamine deficiency can result in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and is classically seen in patients with chronic alcohol use. Patients present with nystagmus, ataxia, confusion, and confabulations to fill lapses in memory. Thiamine deficiency is unlikely in this patient, who consumes only a moderate amount of alcohol and lacks physical exam findings suggestive of chronic alcohol use disorder (e.g., jaundice, ascites). 
❌ Impaired cerebrospinal fluid reabsorption:
Incorrect: Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) occurs due to impaired cerebrospinal fluid reabsorption. Patients classically present with the triad of urinary incontinence, ataxic gait, and cognitive impairments. However, the stepwise decline in this patient’s neurocognitive function is more concerning for vascular dementia.
❌ Lewy body deposition:
Incorrect: Lewy body deposition occurs in Parkinson disease and Lewy body dementia. Patients with Parkinson disease typically present with tremors, rigidity, akinesia, and bradykinesia, whereas Lewy body dementia classically presents with visual hallucinations and Parkinsonian symptoms. This patient does not have tremors or hallucinations, making Lewy body deposition less unlikely. 
❌ Major depressive disorder:
Incorrect: In elderly patients, depression can manifest with symptoms similar to dementia (also termed “pseudodementia”). This patient, however, continues to have interest in his hobbies. Furthermore, major depressive disorder would not account for the abnormal lesions seen on the head CT.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her mother for worsening “odd dancing movements.” Symptoms have been present for the past year. The patient recently moved back home after she was fired from her job due to a “lack of interest.” Additionally, the patient has found it increasingly difficult to perform daily tasks, such as housekeeping and cooking. The patient’s father had similar symptoms and eventually passed away from complications of pneumonia. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 138/77 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. Physical examination reveals involuntary, irregular movements of the patient’s head and face. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally in the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Mutant protein with expanded glutamine tract
Gene hypermethylation with impaired protein production
Mutant RNA formation with impaired translation
Point mutation resulting in loss of glutamic acid residue

questions.solution:
Huntington disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder that arises due to mutations in the HTT gene. The gene encodes huntingtin, a ubiquitously expressed protein. Huntingtin contains a polyglutamine tract encoded by uninterrupted CAG trinucleotide repeats; normally, it can contain up to 35 CAG repeats, whereas patients with HD carry expansions of 36 or more repeats. There is a strong inverse correlation between the number of CAG repeats and age of symptom onset. In other words, the greater the number of CAG repeats, the earlier the age of onset. As a result, HD is characterized by the genetic phenomenon of anticipation, wherein there increased severity and earlier disease onset in succeeding generations due to trinucleotide repeat expansion.

Clinically, Huntington disease typically manifests in individuals between the ages of 20-50. In the early stages, it can present with involuntary movements such as chorea (dance-like movements) and athetosis (involuntary writhing movements). In the later stages, cognitive decline and behavioral changes may manifest in the form of dementia, aggression, apathy, and depression.  



Option Analysis

✅ Mutant protein with expanded glutamine tract :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mitochondrial iron overload :
Incorrect: Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive trinucleotide repeat disorder that arises due to a mutation in frataxin, a protein involved in iron-binding. The mutation results in impaired mitochondrial iron management with subsequent iron overload. The resulting oxidative stress causes death of cells that are dependent on aerobic respiration (e.g., heart, neurons, skeletal muscle). Patients typically present with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and cerebellar and spinal cord degeneration in childhood. 
❌ Gene hypermethylation with impaired protein production:
Incorrect: Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked dominant trinucleotide repeat disorder resulting from hypermethylation of the FMR1 gene; methylation is a mechanism used by cells to repress gene expression. The protein product of this gene is heavily involved in prenatal and postnatal brain development. Patients with fragile X syndrome typically present with intellectual disability and a characteristic elongated face with a large jaw. 
❌ Mutant RNA formation with impaired translation :
Incorrect: Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant trinucleotide repeat disorder that results in the production of mutant, toxic RNAs. These toxic RNAs alter RNA-binding protein activity, resulting in abnormal splicing and translation of several genes involved in skeletal and cardiac muscle function. Patients typically present in early adulthood with progressive muscle wasting and weakness, as well as arrhythmias.
❌ Point mutation resulting in loss of glutamic acid residue:
Incorrect: Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the β-hemoglobin chain, which results in a single amino acid substitution of glutamic acid with valine. Patients with this condition typically present early in childhood with anemia and episodes of painful vaso-occlusive crises.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of intermittent constipation. The symptoms began several months ago. She often needs to strain during defecation and has occasionally noticed blood in her stool. The patient has no significant past medical history, but she states her father developed pancreatic cancer at a young age. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple, small, hyperpigmented macules on the buccal mucosa. Colonoscopy is performed and shows numerous polyps, with subsequent biopsy revealing hamartomatous mucosal polyps. This patient's diagnosis is most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with buccal mucosa hyperpigmentation and colonoscopy showing multiple hamartomatous polyps. She most likely has Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS), which also predisposes patients to developing breast cancer.   

PJS is an autosomal dominant condition that arises due to mutations in the STK11 gene. This gene encodes a tumor suppressor protein that is involved in cell signaling and apoptosis. Elimination of STK11 kinase activity is associated with a loss of growth suppression function, which likely contributes to the increased risk of malignancies in these patients.  

Mucocutaneous pigmented lesions are seen in 95% of patients and may be the first clue to underlying PJS. Lesions tend to arise in infancy, occurring around the mouth, perianal area, fingers, and toes. Many of these lesions fade after puberty, but those in the buccal mucosa tend to persist. Additionally, patients with PJS are predisposed to developing multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps. Although these polyps are most commonly benign, they may grow progressively and become symptomatic (e.g., intussusception, luminal occlusion causing constipation, anemia from chronic bleeding).    

The most clinically important manifestation of PJS is the increased risk for developing several gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies. The most common sites of gastrointestinal tract malignancy are the colon and pancreas, whereas the most common site of extraintestinal tract cancer is the breast.  

Option Analysis

✅ Breast cancer:
 Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intracranial masses:
Incorrect: Intracranial masses can be seen in patients with Turcot syndrome, which can be a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or Lynch syndrome. Patients with FAP-associated Turcot syndrome typically develop medulloblastomas, whereas those with Lynch syndrome-associated Turcot syndrome typically develop glioblastomas. This patient’s mucosal hyperpigmentation and presence of multiple hamartomatous masses on colonoscopy makes another underlying diagnosis more likely.  
❌ Benign mandibular bone tumors:
Incorrect: Gardner syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). Patients with Gardner syndrome typically present with multiple bone and soft tissue tumor growths, as well as hundreds of adenomas on colonoscopy. However, Gardner syndrome would not give rise to the mucosal hyperpigmentation or hamartomatous polyps seen in this patient.
❌ Supernumerary impacted teeth:
Incorrect: Gardner syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). Patients with Gardner syndrome typically present with hundreds of adenomas on colonoscopy, as well as multiple benign bone growths and supernumerary impacted teeth, none of which is seen in this patient. 
❌ Multinodular goiter:
Incorrect: Cowden syndrome is a genetic condition that can manifest with thyroid disorders as well as benign breast conditions. This syndrome also results in multiple gastrointestinal polyps and cutaneous manifestations. However, in Cowden syndrome, skin manifestations typically result in papules and hyperkeratosis, as opposed to hyperpigmentation.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department an hour after developing acute confusion. According to her husband, the patient had been experiencing headaches and blurry vision for the past several hours. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 205/110 mmHg. Physical examination shows right-sided weakness and loss of sensation. A CT scan of her head demonstrates an intraparenchymal hemorrhage. Despite appropriate treatment, the patient dies. A postmortem biopsy of her left adrenal gland is shown below:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

This patient most likely also experienced which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hypertensive emergency (e.g., headache, blurry vision, altered mental status) and subsequently develops a hemorrhagic stroke, as demonstrated by her focal neurological deficits and head CT. Postmortem biopsy of the left adrenal gland reveals an intramedullary mass, which makes pheochromocytoma the likely underlying cause of her symptoms.

Pheochromocytomas are neuroendocrine tumors found in the adrenal medulla that secrete catecholamines such as epinephrine and norepinephrine. On gross pathology, they appear as yellow-tan, well-defined lesions in the center of the adrenal gland.

The primary clinical manifestation of pheochromocytoma is hypertension. Many patients will have paroxysmal episodes caused by the sudden release of catecholamines. These episodic hypertensive episodes are associated with tachycardia, palpitations, headache, diaphoresis (sweating) and tremors. Some patients, like the one in this vignette, may develop life-threatening complications such as pulmonary edema, myocardial infarction, and strokes due to malignant hypertension.





Option Analysis

✅ Episodic diaphoresis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Muscle weakness:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome (hypercortisolism) can result in muscle atrophy and weakness due to cortisol’s catabolic effects on protein metabolism. Likewise, hyperaldosteronism can cause significant hypokalemia, which would also manifest with muscle weakness. While both of these conditions may cause hypertension, it would be unusual for either of them to present with the hypertensive emergency seen in this patient.
❌ Hirsutism and purple abdominal striae:
Incorrect: Hirsutism and purple abdominal striae can be due to hypercortisolism. Although excessive cortisol synthesis can cause hypertension, it would be unusual for the condition to cause markedly elevated blood pressures that would result in hypertensive emergency. Furthermore, this patient’s biopsy demonstrates an adrenal medullary mass, which is more concerning for an underlying pheochromocytoma.
❌ Hyperpigmentation of the skin:
Incorrect: Cushing disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary mass can result in hypertension and skin hyperpigmentation. This patient’s biopsy shows a medullary mass in the adrenal gland, which makes another underlying etiology more likely.
❌ Exophthalmos:
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism, such as in the case of Graves disease, can result in hypertension. Graves disease can also cause exophthalmos due to activation of retro-orbital fibroblasts. This patient’s biopsy shows a medullary mass in the adrenal gland, which makes another underlying etiology more likely.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the clinic after his parents noticed frequent falls and abnormal twitching of his limbs over the past month. Prior to the onset of these symptoms, the patient had been walking without assistance and developing normally. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral jerking eye movements and sporadic muscle contractions of the trunk and limbs. The patient has difficulty walking in a straight line and stumbles several times. A left-sided abdominal mass is palpated. Biopsy of the mass reveals small, round, blue cells arranged concentrically around a central neuropil. Staining with neuron-specific enolase is positive. Based on these findings, which of the following is most likely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
This young boy who is presenting with an abdominal mass, opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome, and suggestive biopsy results likely has a neuroblastoma. This condition is associated with elevated vanillylmandelic acid levels.

Biopsy of a neuroblastoma will typically show small, primitive-appearing, blue cells with dark nuclei. Some of these small, round, blue cells are concentrically arranged around a central space filled with neuropil, forming Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemical stains for biologic markers such as neuron-specific enolase, bombesin, and neurofilament can be used to aid in the histologic diagnosis of neuroblastoma.

Due to their neural crest origin, neuroblastomas express the enzymes necessary for catecholamine synthesis.
