Subsequent degradation of these catecholamines (e.g., norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine) leads to the formation of end products (e.g., vanillylmandelic acid, homovanillic acid). Detection of elevated urine levels of vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) can support the diagnosis of neuroblastoma.



Option Analysis

✅ Urinary vanillylmandelic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Aldosterone to renin ratio:
Incorrect: Patients with an aldosteronoma will have increased aldosterone levels but reduced renin levels, resulting in an increased aldosterone to renin ratio. An aldosteronoma can manifest with hypertension, hypokalemia, muscle aches, and weakness. However, an aldosteronoma would not manifest with the opsoclonus, myoclonus, and ataxia seen in this patient.
❌ 24-hour urine cortisol:
Incorrect: Elevated 24-hour urine cortisol can be seen in patients with Cushing syndrome or Cushing disease. Patients typically present with Cushingoid features (e.g., thin bruisable skin, stretch marks, muscle atrophy) as well as hypertension. This patient’s biopsy result and other clinical signs suggest a different etiology.
❌ Urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid:
Incorrect: Elevated 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) can be seen in carcinoid syndrome, which typically presents with diarrhea, cutaneous flushing, and wheezing. This patient’s biopsy results and other clinical signs suggest a different etiology.
❌ Plasma phenylalanine:
Incorrect: Elevated plasma phenylalanine can be seen in patients with phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency (phenylketonuria). The condition presents with damage to the central nervous system and intellectual disability. This patient’s normal development and presence of opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome suggest a different etiology.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man comes to the clinic due to the recent appearance of skin lesions. The patient's history is significant for chronic asthma, recurrent sinusitis, and nasal polyposis. On physical examination, tender subcutaneous nodules are present on the bilateral shins. The results of the white blood cell differential are shown below:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Leukocyte count  16,000/mm3 
 Neutrophils, segmented  44% 
 Neutrophils, banded  5% 
 Eosinophils  29% 
 Basophils  0% 
 Lymphocytes  15% 
 Monocytes  7% 
 
 This patient’s condition is associated with antibodies directed against which of the following?
questions.solution:
This young patient with a history significant for chronic asthma, recurrent sinusitis, and nasal polyposis, now presents with new skin lesions and marked eosinophilia, and therefore, he most likely has eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss).    

Patients with vasculitis have circulating antibodies that react with neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens termed antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs). ANCAs are a heterogeneous group of autoantibodies directed against neutrophil primary granules elements (mainly enzymes). ANCAs are useful diagnostic markers, and their titers mirror clinical severity and predictor of disease recurrence. ANCAs are classified accordintosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis).


Option Analysis

❌  Basement membrane:
Incorrect: Anti-basement membrane antibodies are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis and hemoptysis.  
❌ Microsome:
Incorrect: Antimicrosomal antibodies are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis, an autoimmune disorder leading to hypothyroidism.  
❌ Transglutaminase enzyme:
Incorrect: IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are seen in celiac disease, a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. 
✅ Myeloperoxidase enzyme :
Correct: See Main explanation. 
❌ Mitochondria:
Incorrect: Antimitochondrial antibodies are seen in primary biliary cholangitis, an autoimmune disorder characterized by fibrosis of the bile duct and signs of cholestasis. 
❌ Proteinase:
Incorrect: Anti-proteinase-3 antibodies (PR3-ANCA) are seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis, an autoimmune vasculitis characterized by upper and lower respiratory tract involvement, as well as renal involvement.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the office with complaints of pain in the hip joint and stiffness in the lower back for the past month. The symptoms are worse in the morning and improve with activity and exercise. Review of systems reveals intermittent abdominal pain and frequent episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea for the last 3 months. He tried over-the-counter analgesics, which helped the joint pain but made the diarrhea worse. He does not have any pain with urination and has not traveled recently. The remainder of his history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination shows mild tenderness in the hip joints and limited spinal flexion. Laboratory analysis is shown below:

 
 Laboratory value  Results 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  9.8 g/dL 
 Platelet count  460,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count  8,000/mm3 

Plain radiographs show signs of sacroiliac joint inflammation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s joint pain?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with pain in the hip joint, morning stiffness that improves with activity, together with radiographic evidence of spondylitis, is highly suggestive of a seronegative spondyloarthropathy (SpA). His history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain makes inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)-related arthritis the most likely cause.

IBD is an immune-mediated condition that is divided into two types; ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn disease. It usually presents with abdominal pain and watery diarrhea (more commonly bloody in ulcerative colitis). Various extra-intestinal manifestations are associated with IBD, including pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum, episcleritis, uveitis, oral ulcerations and spondyloarthropathy (SpA).

IBD-associated SpA usually manifests with sacroiliitis and spondylitis (low back or hip pain with stiffness that improves with movement), peripheral arthritis (most commonly involving the knee), enthesitis (inflammation and tenderness where tendons insert on joint) and dactylitis (sausage fingers). Most of the affected patients are HLA-B27 positive (characteristic of seronegative arthropathy). The diagnosis is usually made on colonoscopy and radiographic evidence of sacroiliitis. Treating IBD adequately also improves the symptoms of IBD-associated SpA.



Option Analysis

❌ Hip osteoarthritis:
Incorrect: Hip osteoarthritis is a common form of arthritis that can present with insidious pain in the hip joint. However, it is usually associated with certain risk factors (e.g., age >50, obesity) and presents on radiography with joint space narrowing, osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, and cysts, none of which are seen in this patient.
❌ Reactive arthritis:
Incorrect: Reactive arthritis may follow 2-3 weeks after the onset of infectious diarrhea caused by Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter or Shigella. It is usually associated with a travel history, concomitant urethritis, uveitis, and cutaneous rash (e.g., keratoderma blennorrhagica, balanitis circinata), none of which are observed in this patient.
✅ Inflammatory bowel disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Osteomyelitis:
Incorrect: Osteomyelitis is an infection of bone (not joint) that involves the periosteum, medullary cavity or the cortical bone. It usually presents with erythema, redness, warmth and swelling of the affected bone, along with fever. Normal leukocyte count and gradual onset are atypical.
❌ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition that is characterized by peripheral erosive arthritis. Involvement of the axial skeleton is rare. Though extraarticular manifestations are common (e.g., weight loss, fatigue), gastrointestinal tract involvement is uncommon.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 26 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding following a motor vehicle accident three hours ago. A stat transvaginal ultrasound reveals placental abruption. After adequate resuscitation, the patient is brought to the operating room for emergent c-section. Approximate blood loss is 2500 mL. Several hours following the surgery, she endorses sudden onset bilateral flank pain. Physical examination shows bilateral costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine output in the last 6 hours is measured at 30mL. Laboratory results are shown.

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  8.5 g/dL 
 Leukocytes  10,000 /mL 
 Platelets  330,000/mm3 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium  136 mEq/L 
 Potassium  5.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride  85 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  19 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.7 mg/dL 
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)  40 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis 
 Erythrocytes  30-32/hpf 
 Leukocyte esterase  Negative 
 Leukocytes  2/hpf 
 Protein  1.0 g/day 
 Urine osmolality  650 mOsm/kg 
 Dysmorphic red blood cells  Absent 
 Cast  Tubular cell casts 
   
A renal ultrasound demonstrates hypoechoic areas in the renal cortex. Which of the following pathologic processes is responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The findings of placental abruption, bilateral flank pain, rising creatinine and ultrasound findings of hypoechogenic areas in the renal cortex are consistent with renal cortical necrosis, a type of prerenal acute kidney injury.  

Renal cortical necrosis results from decreased perfusion to the renal cortical end-arteries secondary to thrombosis or vasospasm. Reduced blood supply induces tissue ischemia and inflammation of the cortex. It also results in vasoconstriction of afferent arterioles, with a subsequent decrease in glomerular filtration rate, and ultimately decreased urine output. Parts of the proximal convoluted tubule and thick ascending loop of Henle in the cortex are most commonly affected due to high metabolic activity in this anatomic region.  

Renal cortical necrosis has been associated with obstetric complications, including placenta abruption, prolonged intrauterine fetal death, infected abortion, and eclampsia. The stretching and swelling of the renal capsule causes flank pain and costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory evaluation typically shows azotemia, increased creatinine, hematuria, and increased urinary osmolality. Diagnosis requires evidence of cortical ischemia and necrosis on imaging (ultrasound or CT scan). Biopsy of the affected kidney shows patchy necrosis and atrophy of renal cortex.

Option Analysis

❌ Bacterial infiltration of renal parenchyma:
Incorrect: Bacterial infiltration of renal parenchyma is the underlying etiology of pyelonephritis. These patients present with fever, chills, dysuria, and flank pain. Urinalysis typically reveals elevated leukocytes and positive leukocyte esterase.  
✅ Ischemic necrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Glomerular inflammation:
Incorrect: Glomerular inflammation induces glomerular basement membrane damage with subsequent  hematuria and proteinuria. Urinalysis reveals red blood cell casts and dysmorphic red blood cells. 
❌ Renal interstitial inflammation:
Incorrect: Renal interstitial inflammation, also known as acute interstitial nephritis, is commonly induced by antibiotics or autoimmune disease. Though hematuria can be seen, it is usually associated with fever, rash, pyuria, and costovertebral angle tenderness.  
❌ Urinary obstruction:
Incorrect: Urinary obstruction results from blockage of ureters by a gravid uterus or iatrogenic injury to the ureters during cesarean section. Though it can present with oliguria, ultrasound shows hydronephrosis of the affected side, rather than hypoechogenic areas of renal cortex.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman presents to the office because of a lesion on the tip of her nose. She states it has been slowly increasing in size for the past 6 months and is not associated with pain, itching or discharge. Her medical history is significant for osteoporosis, for which she takes vitamin D supplements. She has worked as a mail carrier for the past 30 years, delivering mail outdoors on a daily basis. Physical examination shows a waxy, nodular lesion with telangiectasia on the tip of her nose, as shown in the image below:



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a slow growing waxy, nodular lesion with telangiectasia on the tip of the nose, in association with increased exposure to sunlight (due to her occupation), is most likely suffering from basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

BCC is the most common skin cancer, and it arises from the stratum basale and its appendages. It can be divided into 3 types on the basis of its clinical appearance:

  •  Nodular: Most frequent presentation, affects the face and presents as a pearly flesh-colored papule with telangiectasia (dilated blood vessels), as seen in this patient. 
  •  Superficial: Most commonly affects the trunk and presents as a pink-to-red colored scaly plaque or macule. 
  • Morpheaform: Atrophic flesh-colored plaque or papule with induration and irregular borders.
Definitive diagnosis is established on biopsy that shows invasive clusters of spindle cells surrounded by palisading basal cells. Treatment depends on the size, location and depth of the lesion. Electro-dessication and curettage, 5- fluorouracil, and Mohs microsurgery are available options.  


Option Analysis

❌ Squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Squamous cell carcinoma is much less common and grows faster than basal cell carcinoma, invading nearby tissues. Moreover, it usually arises from a precursor lesion (e.g. actinic keratoses), and it typically has overlying hyperkeratosis and ulceration. A pink, pearly nodule with telangiectasia would be atypical.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Nodular acne:
Incorrect: Nodular acne clinically presents as multiple deep-seated, inflamed, often tender, papules or nodules in adolescents or young adults. It is uncommon in postmenopausal women. Moreover, a solitary lesion with telangiectasia would be unlikely.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Basal cell carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rhinophyma:
Incorrect: Rhinophyma is a type of phymatous rosacea in which skin tissues of the nose exhibit hypertrophy, manifesting as thickened skin with irregular contours. It is usually associated with sebaceous hyperplasia and oily skin, neither of which is seen in this patient.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Seborrheic keratosis:
Incorrect: Seborrheic keratoses are a result of benign proliferation of immature keratinocytes that clinically appear as well-demarcated, round or oval lesion with a dull, verrucous surface and a typical “stuck-on” appearance. A pink, pearly nodule with telangiectasia is not likely to be seen in this condition.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of acute right-sided scrotal pain with associated nausea and vomiting. The patient was playing football when he felt sudden pain following a tackle to the abdomen. The patient has tried over the counter analgesia and ice pack placement over the groin without relief of symptoms. He has had similar episodes of pain that self-resolved after 30 minutes. He has no significant past medical history and has received all age-appropriate vaccinations. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals an uncomfortable adolescent in significant pain. Examination reveals an edematous and erythematous right scrotum that does not transilluminate. Stroking of the right inner thigh does not result in elevation of the right testis. The pain is worsened with elevation of the scrotum. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Inadequate fixation of the lower pole of the testis

questions.solution:
This adolescent male presents with acute right-sided scrotal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The physical examination demonstrates an absent cremasteric sign and negative Prehn sign, suggestive of testicular torsion -- a urologic emergency. The most common anatomic abnormality associated with this condition is known as the "bell clapper" deformity, wherein the testicle lacks its normal attachment to the tunica vaginalis. Ultimately, this deformity allows for increased mobility of the testes, transverse lie within the scrotum, and increased propensity towards ischemia of the spermatic cord.

The clinical features of testicular torsion include:

  •  History of intermittent testicular torsion: prior episodes of sudden, acute testicular pain that resolve without intervention 
  •  Sudden onset of acute, severe testicular pain  
  •  Swollen, tender, erythematous scrotum 
  •  High riding testis (moves to a higher scrotal position): this finding occurs due to shortening of the spermatic cord following torsion 
  •  Absent cremasteric reflex: normally, stroking of the inner thigh results in activation of the cremaster muscle and elevation of the ipsilateral testis. In testicular torsion, this reflex is almost always absent.
Several clues aid in the differentiation of testicular torsion and epididymitis. The Prehn sign is performed via elevation of the affected testis, and the maneuver results in mild relief of pain with epididymitis. Additionally, patients with epididymitis have an intact cremasteric reflex. In testicular torsion, any manipulation exacerbates the pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inadequate fixation of the lower pole of the testis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Microbial infection of the epididymis:
Incorrect: Inflammation and infection of the epididymis results in epididymitis. In contrast to patients with testicular torsion, patients with epididymitis have a normal cremasteric reflex. Additionally, patients may experience pain relief with elevation of the testis (Prehn sign), whereas patients with testicular torsion experience pain with any testicular manipulation.
❌ Ischemia of herniated bowel:
Incorrect: This answer describes an incarcerated inguinal hernia. Physical examination of children with incarcerated inguinal hernias demonstrates an inguinal mass with extension into the scrotum. Incarcerated inguinal hernias are exquisitely tender and surrounded by edema and erythema of the overlying skin.
❌ Viral inflammation of the testis:
Incorrect: Viral inflammation of the testis can be seen in mumps, which is a common precipitant of  orchitis. Symptoms develop 4 to 8 days after parotitis but can also occur in the absence of this finding. However, this patient is fully vaccinated.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A hydrocele is a collection of peritoneal fluid between the parietal and visceral layers of the tunica vaginalis. Hydroceles are a potential cause of testicular swelling, but they are painless. Physical examination also reveals transillumination, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of dyspnea, persistent cough, weight loss, and fatigue. Medical history is significant for smoking 2 packs of cigarettes per day for 40 years. An x-ray of the chest shows a 4-cm hilar mass. A biopsy specimen shows small cells with minimal cytoplasm. Staining is positive for neuron-specific enolase. This patient is at risk of developing which of the following electrolyte abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Histologic analysis of this patient's hilar mass shows small cells that stain positive for neuron-specific enolase, a marker of neuroendocrine differentiation. These findings are consistent with small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Paraneoplastic syndromes that may be associated with small cell carcinoma are ACTH production (Cushing syndrome), syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH), antibodies against presynaptic Ca2+ channels (Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome), or neurons (paraneoplastic myelitis, subacute cerebellar degeneration, encephalitis). The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) leads to the retention of free water and resultant hyponatremia.

The severity of symptoms caused by hyponatremia is related to the degree of hyponatremia and how rapidly the fall in serum sodium occurs. Early symptoms include anorexia, nausea, and vomiting. In severe cases, cerebral edema can occur, especially when the onset of hyponatremia is rapid. Symptoms caused by cerebral edema may include irritability, personality changes, confusion, coma, seizures, and death.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: The results of this biopsy are consistent with small cell carcinoma of the lung, which can cause various paraneoplastic syndromes. The associated electrolyte abnormalities do not include hyperkalemia.
❌ Hypomagnesemia :
Incorrect: Histologic analysis of this patient's mass is suggestive of small cell carcinoma of the lung, which is associated with various paraneoplastic syndromes. The associated electrolyte abnormalities do not include hypomagnesemia.
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: Small cell carcinoma is not generally associated with hypercalcemia of malignancy, even in the presence of bone metastases. Hypercalcemia can be seen in squamous cell carcinoma paraneoplastic syndrome, due to the production of PTHrP by the tumor.
❌ Hypokalemia:
Incorrect: Small cell carcinoma of the lung is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes that can cause electrolyte abnormalities, but hypokalemia is not a typical finding.
✅ Hyponatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office with complaints of irregular menstruation. She has had only two periods in the last year. Menarche was at age 12, and she had a regular menstrual cycle until 12 months ago. The patient also reports feeling flushed at night without provocation and experiencing occasional dyspareunia with post-coital spotting. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. The patient has Tanner stage V breasts and pubic hair. Pelvic examination reveals a small anteverted uterus and minimal vaginal rugations. Abdominal examination is within normal limits. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Serum TSH is 3.2 µU/mL. Which of the following set of hormonal changes will most likely be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with amenorrhea/oligomenorrhea for 12 months, hot flashes, night sweats, dyspareunia, in combination with age <40 years and physical examinations findings of minimal vaginal rugations, is consistent with primary ovarian insufficiency or POI (also known as premature ovarian failure or POF). The patient can sometimes experience postcoital spotting secondary to vaginal dryness.

Primary ovarian insufficiency is defined as failure of ovulation secondary to ovarian dysfunction before the age of 40 years. It is usually secondary to absent or dysfunctional follicles that have stopped developing and secreting estrogen in response to gonadotropin stimulation. When this happens, the pituitary gland attempts to restore balance by increasing production of gonadotropins (LH and FSH); however, the follicles don’t respond, so there are still low levels of estrogen. This pattern is called hypergonadotropic (high levels of gonadotropins) hypogonadism (low levels of ovarian hormones).

POI can be spontaneous (i.e. idiopathic or secondary to autoimmune destruction, Turner syndrome, Fragile X syndrome) or induced (secondary to early bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy or gonadotoxic therapies i.e. chemotherapy and radiotherapy). Clinically, it is characterized by menopausal symptoms, like oligo-amenorrhea, infertility and symptoms of estrogen deficiency (hot flashes, night sweats, dyspareunia and frequent headaches) before age 40.  

Option Analysis

✅  GnRH FSH LH Estradiol Prolactin Increased  Increased  Increased  Decreased  Normal :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  GnRH  FSH  LH Estradiol  Prolactin Decreased Decreased or normal Decreased Decreased  Normal :
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is caused by the decreased amplitude and/or frequency of gonadotropin pulses from the hypothalamus, leading to decreased levels of LH, FSH and estradiol. It can occur in females who maintain a very low calorie diet.
❌  GnRH  FSH  LH  Estradiol  Prolactin NormalDecreasedDecreased Decreased Increased:
Incorrect: An elevated prolactin with decreased levels of FSH, LH and estradiol are suggestive of prolactinoma. Patients can present with bilateral breast discharge, visual changes and frequent headache, in combination with amenorrhea.
❌   GnRH  FSH  LH  Estradiol  Prolactin NormalNormal/decreasedNormal/increasedNormal Normal :
Incorrect: The imbalance of LH/FSH ratio in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) can result in the failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. PCOS  is characterized by hyperandrogenism (e.g., acne and hirsutism) and testosterone levels may be elevated. This patient with menopausal symptoms most likely has estrogen deficiency.
❌  GnRH FSH LH Estradiol Prolactin DecreasedUndetectableUndetectableUndetectable Normal :
Incorrect: Patients with congenital GnRH deficiency (Kallman syndrome) can present with very low or undetectable levels of GnRH, FSH and LH. It is unlikely in this patient, as she had a normal menstrual cycle previously.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician’s office for evaluation of a rash under her breasts. She first noticed the rash two days ago while bathing. The patient reports recurrent rashes of similar appearance affecting her face and limbs since the age of two. She was recently treated for oral thrush at a local clinic. Past medical history is significant for hypothyroidism managed with levothyroxine. Family history is significant for a brother who experienced similar cutaneous symptoms and died of fulminant hepatitis at the age of six. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates red-brown, beefy, homogenous patches under the breasts and massive erythematous-desquamating dermatosis involving the face, limbs and nails. Genital examination shows multiple labial fissures. Intraepidermal injection of Candida antigens yields no reactogenicity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a red-brown, beefy rash under the breasts, with a history of recurrent similar rashes affecting her face and limbs. In addition, her history demonstrates a recent treatment for oral thrush and absent cutaneous reaction to Candida antigens, which is suggestive of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis (CMCC).

CMCC refers to a heterogeneous syndrome characterized by persistent noninvasive Candida albicans infections of skin, nails and mucous membranes.  Clinically, these rashes are characterized as erythematous, scaly cutaneous plaques in intertriginous areas, mucosae and nails. Besides the oral cavity, other mucosal surfaces including esophageal, genital and laryngeal mucosa may also be involved.

CMCC results from impaired T-cell mediated immunity towards Candida species. It can be caused by a number of genetic defects, but the classic form results from autoimmune regulator (AIRE) deficiency. In addition to chronic non invasive candidiasis, affected patients can also manifest with autoimmune polyendocrinopathy (hypoparathyroidism, hypothyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, and skin dystrophy). Diagnosis is based upon clinical features, identifying disease-causing mutations, and absence of reactogenicity with injection of candida antigens.  

Option Analysis

❌ Severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome:
Incorrect: Although severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome can present with chronic candidal infections (oral thrush), affected patients typically present in infancy with failure to thrive as well as chronic diarrhea, bacterial, viral, or protozoal infections.
✅ Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperimmunoglobulin E syndrome:
Incorrect: Although hyperimmunoglobulin E syndrome can manifest with recurrent mucocutaneous candida infections, other symptoms such as bacterial abscesses and retained primary teeth are present.
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: This patient is receiving treatment with levothyroxine for hypothyroidism and was most likely treated with an antifungal agent for oral thrush. None of these medications predispose to recurrent candida skin infections.
❌ Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome:
Incorrect: Although acquired immunodeficiency syndrome can present with mucocutaneous candidiasis, untreated infections usually become invasive with systemic spread. Moreover, in the absence of risk factors and other clinical manifestations (fever, lymphadenopathy, sore throat, rash, myalgia/arthralgia, and headache), it is an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician's office for evaluation of unsteady gait. The parent states the patient’s gait has become “wobbly,” and she has been experiencing recurrent falls. The parent also reports it is difficult to understand her speech. Her development was normal until the age of two years, when she started developing these symptoms. Past medical history is significant for recurrent respiratory tract infections. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates numerous superficial nests of distended blanchable capillaries on sun-exposed areas. The patient is unable to coordinate head and eye movements when shifting gaze. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with an unsteady gait, abnormal eye movements, recurrent respiratory infections and superficial nests of blanching distended capillaries is most likely suffering from ataxia telangiectasia (AT). Patients with AT are at an increased risk of developing lymphoma and leukemia.

AT is an autosomal recessive disorder secondary to a mutation in the ataxia telangiectasia mutated (ATM) gene. This gene encodes a protein kinase that normally phosphorylates tumor suppressor protein p53 to repair double-stranded breaks in the DNA. As such, it is important in the development and reproduction of immune cells--especially T lymphocytes.



Defects in the ATM gene ultimately manifest in a failure to detect DNA damage, an inability to halt progression of the cell cycle, and accumulation of gene mutations.




Affected patients present in the first years of life with the characteristic triad of cerebellar ataxia (due to cerebellar atrophy), increased risk of sinopulmonary infections and telangiectasias (numerous superficial blanching nests of distended capillaries on sun-exposed areas). This disease predisposes individuals to hematologic malignancies (lymphoma and leukemia) and immunodeficiency; primarily manifesting as IgA deficiency. Due to the defect in DNA repair, affected patients are hypersensitive to radiation, which can lead to chromosomal breaks.



The diagnosis of AT is based on clinical features in conjunction with mutations in the ATM gene detected via genetic testing. Laboratory analysis will typically demonstrate a low level of serum immunoglobulins and a high level of alpha-fetoprotein.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hypocalcemia:
Incorrect: Hypocalcemia can occur as a complication of DiGeorge syndrome, which presents with pure T cell deficiency (infections), abnormal facies, and hypocalcemia (due to parathyroid hypoplasia). Neurologic abnormalities like ataxia are atypical.
✅ Lymphoma and leukemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Non Invasive Candida infections:
Incorrect: Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis is characterized by persistent noninvasive Candida albicans infection of the skin, nails and mucous membranes. It results from impaired T cell mediated immunity against Candida due to AIRE deficiency. Neurologic abnormalities like ataxia, respiratory infections, and superficial dilated blood vessels are atypical of this condition.
❌ Recurrent infection with Neisseria sp.:
Incorrect: Terminal complement deficiency (deficiency of complements C5-C9 ) a component of membrane attack complex, can cause recurrent infections with Neisseria sp. Aside from pulmonary involvement, other infections are uncommon in patients with ataxia telangiectasia.
❌ Hematochezia:
Incorrect: Hematochezia can occur as a complication of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome secondary to thrombocytopenia. In addition to bacterial infections and thrombocytopenia, eczema is also commonly observed in these patients. Superficial blanching nests of distended capillaries are atypical.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the office because of joint pain and stiffness. The patient reports bilateral pain of her hand, wrist and knee joints for the past 10 days. The symptoms are worse in the morning and get better with movement. The patient has had no associated chills, fever or rash. Past medical history is significant for hereditary spherocytosis. Family history is significant for gout in the patient’s father.  The patient is a school teacher and does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows mild swelling with no redness, warmth or tenderness of the affected joints. Oropharyngeal examination is unremarkable. X-ray of both hands is normal. Considering the most likely cause of this patient’s condition, she is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient’s acute symmetric arthropathy with normal x-ray is consistent with parvovirus B19 infection. Her history of hereditary spherocytosis puts her at increased risk of having transient aplastic crisis.   

Parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease) in children and arthritis in adults. It is primarily transmitted by respiratory droplets and replicates in erythroid progenitors in the bone marrow. Parvovirus B19 binds the P antigen on proerythroblasts’ cell membranes. Viral replication in the nucleus leads to cell lysis, which can cause transient aplastic crisis (TAC), in which the temporary suspension of erythropoiesis leads to severe anemia and related complications. This complication usually occurs in individuals with hematologic abnormalities, including increased RBC destruction (e.g., sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis) or decreased RBC production (e.g., iron deficiency anemia, thalasemia).  

Parvovirus B19 in a pregnant female can interrupt erythropoiesis in the fetus, causing profound anemia,  congestive heart failure, and pleural and pericardial effusions (hydrops fetalis).

Option Analysis

✅ Transient aplastic crisis:
 Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Coronary artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: Coronary artery aneurysm is a life-threatening complication of Kawasaki disease. Such patients usually present with fever, strawberry tongue, a rash, lymphadenopathy and bilateral conjunctival injection. This patient’s joint pain is likely secondary to parvovirus B19 infection.
❌ Encephalitis:
Incorrect:  Measles is characterized by a prodromal illness of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis that is followed by Koplik spots and a maculopapular rash spreading in a cephalocaudal progression (sparing the palms and soles). In the absence of a rash and a flu-like prodrome, measles is unlikely.
❌ Rheumatic fever:
Incorrect: Rheumatic fever is a known complication of acute group A streptococcal infection, which can cause scarlet fever and pharyngitis. Patients typically present with a sandpaper-like rash that blanches with pressure, along with fever and gray white pharyngeal exudates. This patient’s oropharyngeal examination is unremarkable. 
❌ Orchitis:
Incorrect: Orchitis is a common complication of mumps. Patients usually present with fever, malaise and myalgias followed by the development of parotitis within 48 hours.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath and a cough productive of yellowish sputum. His symptoms began 6 hours ago. Past medical history is notable for asthma and type I diabetes mellitus. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler and takes daily insulin injections. His temperature is 39.5°C (103°F), pulse is 87/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mmHg, and respirations are 10/min. Physical examination reveals a somnolent patient in respiratory distress with audible wheezing, accessory muscle use, and a prolonged expiratory phase. The patient’s blood glucose is 140 mg/dL. A chest x-ray is ordered and is demonstrated below:


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

Which of the following set of laboratory findings will most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an asthma exacerbation likely secondary to pneumonia (note the consolidation in the apical segments of the left lower lobe). In the early stages of asthma exacerbation, patients develop a respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation (blowing off CO2). Over time, and without treatment, these patients develop signs of respiratory fatigue (e.g., reduced respiratory rate, accessory muscle muscle) and respiratory acidosis secondary to hypoventilation.

The primary driver of respiratory acidosis is CO2 accumulation. Specific causes include airway obstruction (e.g. obstruction by a foreign object), respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., trauma, obesity, fatigue), and alveoli damage (e.g., chronic pulmonary obstructive disease, pulmonary edema). In certain circumstances, hypoventilation occurs secondary to damage or action on the respiratory centers of the brain stem--such as after a stroke or medication overdose (e.g., opioids, sedatives).

Overtime, the body compensates for respiratory acidosis by increasing bicarbonate levels. This phenomenon is termed “respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation” and is mediated via the kidneys via increasing HCO3− reabsorption. This effect, however, takes 24 hours of persistent respiratory acidosis before compensation takes effect. Thus in an acute respiratory acidosis, the pH is low while the HCO3− is normal or slightly elevated. In patients with chronic respiratory acidosis (e.g. COPD or obesity hypoventilation syndrome), the kidneys have time to compensate, resulting in a pH that is closer to normal but with a markedly elevated HCO3−.

 

Option Analysis

✅  Serum pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial PaO2  (mEq/L)  HCO3-  (mEq/L)  7.30  52  70  25 :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Serum pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial PaO2  (mEq/L)  HCO3-  (mEq/L)  7.30  52  70 35:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. This patient’s asthma exacerbation began less than one day ago, which is not enough time for renal compensation via increasing bicarbonate reuptake.
❌  Serum pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial PaO2  (mEq/L)  HCO3-  (mEq/L) 7.404090 25 :
Incorrect: These lab values are consistent with those of an asymptomatic individual. In contrast, this patient has signs of abnormal breathing (e.g., reduced respiratory rate, accessory muscle use) secondary to asthma exacerbation.
❌  Serum pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial PaO2  (mEq/L)  HCO3-  (mEq/L) 7.5025100 25 :
Incorrect: This answer choice is consistent with a respiratory alkalosis, which may be seen early in the clinical course of an asthmatic patient with hyperventilation. However, this patient has signs of respiratory muscle fatigue (e.g., reduced respiratory rate, accessory muscle use, somnolence).
❌  Serum pH  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial PaO2  (mEq/L)  HCO3-  (mEq/L) 7.50409030:
Incorrect: These findings demonstrate a metabolic alkalosis. This patient’s presentation is consistent with impending respiratory failure and acidosis secondary to an asthma exacerbation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of severe abdominal pain,  nausea, and vomiting. The pain started three hours ago and has been increasing in severity. The patient admits to swallowing 30 pills of acetaminophen in an attempt to end his life. Temperature is 37.9 C° (100.2 F°), respirations are 15/minute, pulse is 92/minute, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg.  On physical examination, right upper quadrant tenderness is noted. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiologic process underlying this medication toxicity?
questions.solution:
This patient is having acetaminophen toxicity and is currently complaining of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. Acetaminophen toxicity is the most common cause of acute hepatic failure in the United States from either intentional or unintentional overdose.

Acetaminophen is an antipyretic that works via inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme and subsequent inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis. The metabolism of acetaminophen occurs in the liver, and under normal circumstances, most of the acetaminophen is metabolized by glucuronidation and sulfation into non-toxic metabolites that are excreted in urine. A small amount is metabolized by cytochrome P450 into N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI), a highly toxic metabolite for the liver. Fortunately, NAPQI produced with appropriate doses of acetaminophen is quickly metabolized by glutathione into nontoxic metabolites.



 In case of acetaminophen overdose, the glucuronidation and sulfation pathways become overwhelmed --shunting remaining acetaminophen to be metabolized by CYP450 into NAPQI. The high amount of NAPQI depletes intracellular glutathione, resulting in accumulation of NAPQI within hepatocytes, causing cellular necrosis and death.

In addition to intentional overdose, some patients may develop toxicity with therapeutic doses. For example, people taking CYP450 enhancers (e.g. barbiturates) simultaneously with acetaminophen will increase NAPQI production and accumulation, leading to toxicity. Furthermore, patients with a baseline deficit in glutathione may develop hepatocyte injury with therapeutic doses of acetaminophen.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Depletion of intracellular glutathione:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of cytochrome p450:
Incorrect: Cytochrome p450 (CYP450) is the enzyme responsible for converting acetaminophen into NAPQI-- the toxic metabolite known to induce hepatocyte necrosis. Inhibition of CYP450 will protect against acetaminophen toxicity.
❌ Inhibition of cyclooxygenase-2:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen exerts its analgesic and antipyretic effects by inhibiting COX-2, thereby reducing the production of prostaglandins. However, this mechanism does not describe acetaminophen-induced liver injury.
❌ Increased acetaminophen sulfation:
Incorrect: Metabolism of acetaminophen by sulfation yields non-toxic metabolites that are excreted in the urine. Overdose of acetaminophen leads to saturation of the sulfation pathway, with subsequent shunting towards metabolism by CYP450, which yields NAPQI, the toxic product responsible for hepatotoxicity in acetaminophen overdose.
❌ Increased acetaminophen glucuronidation:
Incorrect: Like sulfation, acetaminophen glucuronidation is another metabolism pathway of acetaminophen that yields non-toxic metabolites.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to his primary care physician’s office accompanied by his partner following an episode of syncope two days ago. The patient was working in his garden when he suddenly felt light headed and lost consciousness for one minute. His partner, who witnessed the incident, states that he did not jerk uncontrollably or hit his head. The patient endorses worsening shortness of breath and occasional chest pain during his usual morning walk for the past month. Medical history includes benign prostatic hyperplasia, which is managed with finasteride. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 138/87 mmHg. On physical examination, the lungs are clear to auscultation. Neurologic examination is within normal limits. ECG demonstrates voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. Cardiac auscultation will most likely reveal a murmur in which of the areas marked on the diagram below?

choices.text: Area 2: Ejection murmur accompanied by a fixed split-second heart sound (S2)
Area 5: Opening snap followed by diastolic murmur

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of aortic stenosis (AS) including exertional dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope. On physical examination, AS is heard as a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur over the right 2nd intercostal space.

AS is the most common cause of left ventricular outflow obstruction and is commonly associated with age-related calcifications in patients over the age of sixty, though it can manifest in younger patients due to bicuspid aortic valve or rheumatic heart disease. Common clinical findings include exertional dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, syncope, exertional angina, and arrhythmias. During exertion, left ventricular dysfunction ensues as the heart pumps against a stenotic valve--thus limiting ejection fraction and blood flow to both peripheral tissues and coronary arteries. Additional physical exam findings include an S2, ejection click, or weak carotid pulse with a delayed peak (“Pulsus parvus et tardus”). An early-peaking murmur typically correlates with mild to moderate AS, whereas a late-peaking murmur often indicates severe AS.



Option Analysis

✅ Area 1: Crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Area 2: Ejection murmur accompanied by a fixed split-second heart sound (S2):
Incorrect: Ejection murmur accompanied by a fixed split-second heart sound (S2) over the left 2nd intercostal space (pulmonic area) can be auscultated with atrial septal defects. Patients with small ASDs are usually asymptomatic.
❌ Area 3: Systolic ejection murmur:
Incorrect: A systolic ejection murmur over the 3rd right intercostal space is associated with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). Patients with HOCM are usually young and present with dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, syncope, palpitations, and sudden cardiac death.
❌ Area 4: Holosystolic murmur:
Incorrect: A holosystolic murmur can be heard over the 4th left intercostal space (tricuspid area) in patients with tricuspid regurgitation and ventricular septal defects. Tricuspid regurgitation often presents with signs of right-sided heart failure (HF), including hepatic congestion, ascites, and peripheral edema. Mild VSDs may be asymptomatic, while large VSDs may induce heart failure.
❌ Area 5: Opening snap followed by diastolic murmur:
Incorrect: An opening snap followed by a rumbling and mid-to-late diastolic murmur best heard at the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space (mitral area) is indicative of mitral stenosis (MS). Clinical features of MS include dyspnea, chest pain, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to left atrial enlargement.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with Marfan syndrome presents with exertional dyspnea and pounding headaches for several months. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac auscultation reveals the murmur demonstrated below over the right sternal border. Palpation of the radial arteries shows a rapidly rising and falling arterial pulse. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of Marfan syndrome presents with exertional dyspnea and pounding headaches and an exam demonstrating a diastolic murmur and "water hammer" pulses; this combinantion is suggestive of aortic regurgitation secondary to aortic root dilation.

Aortic regurgitation (AR) refers to incomplete closure of the aortic valve leaflets during diastole, resulting in backflow of blood into the left ventricle. With this backflow of blood, the left ventricular end-diastolic volume increases, and the heart compensates for this higher pressure via eccentric hypertrophy in order to maintain ejection fraction.

Regurgitation during diastole often manifests as a rapid drop in diastolic blood pressure, and an increase in pulse pressure (systolic pressure minus diastolic pressure). This wide pulse pressure is responsible for many of the phenomena observed in aortic regurgitation, including “water hammer” pulse, pounding headaches, and head bobbing (de Musset sign). Aortic regurgitation is characterized by a diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard over the 3rd intercostal space (‘Erb point’) in the case regurgitation from valvular disease. In the setting of aortic root disease, the murmur is best heard over the right sternal border and apex.



Option Analysis

❌ Patent ductus arteriosus:
Incorrect:  A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) occurs when the ductus arteriosus fails to involute after birth, resulting in a left to right shunt. Infants may present with signs of heart failure, failure to thrive, poor feeding, and respiratory distress; adults may have features of Eisenmenger syndrome, such as cyanosis and clubbing. A PDA is characterized as a “machine-like murmur” best heard over the left infraclavicular area.
❌ Coarctation of the aorta:
Incorrect: Coarctation of the aorta refers to the narrowing of the descending aorta, typically at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, distal to the left subclavian artery. A systolic murmur can sometimes be heard at the left paravertebral interscapular area, and the condition is often associated with conditions such as bicuspid aortic valve. Signs and symptoms include hypertension in upper extremities and weak and delayed pulses in lower extremities.
❌ Aortic stenosis:
 Incorrect:The murmur of aortic stenosis (AS) is characterized as a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur over the right 2nd intercostal space with radiation to the carotids. AS is the most common cause of left ventricular outflow obstruction, and the condition is commonly associated with age-related calcification of the aortic valve. Clinical findings of AS inclue exertional dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, and syncope. This patient presents with signs of acute right heart failure and deep vein thrombosis, suggesting tricuspid regurgitation.
✅ Aortic regurgitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mitral stenosis:
Incorrect: Mitral stenosis (MS) is heard as an opening snap followed by a rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur that is best heard at the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space (mitral area). Clinical features of MS include dyspnea, chest pain, hemoptysis, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve from left atrial enlargement.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider because of skin changes that began three-months ago. She has noticed increased bruising and the development of purple-red stretch marks on the abdomen. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which she intermittently uses a budesonide inhaler. She smokes half-a-pack of cigarettes per day. In the office, her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 142/85 mmHg. Physical exam confirms the presence of ecchymoses and abdominal striae. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  146 mmol/L 
 Potassium  3.9 mmol/L 
 Bicarbonate  26 mmol/L 
 Fasting glucose  137 mg/dL 
 24-hour urine cortisol*  72 µg/day 
 Serum ACTH**  35 pg/mL 

*Normal range: 4-40 µg/day
**Normal range: 5-20 pg/mL

The serum cortisol levels are significantly reduced in response to a high-dose of dexamethasone. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiology for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Excess ACTH production by lung tumor

questions.solution:
The clinical and laboratory findings in this patient are consistent with Cushing disease secondary to ACTH overproduction by a pituitary adenoma. Such patients can develop muscle weakness, weight gain, skin thinning and bruising, and fat redistribution. In addition, patients can develop hyperglycemia secondary to reduced glucose tolerance.

The first step in the work-up is to measure free cortisol in a 24-hour urine sample. Alternative methods include blood or saliva tests and a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test.

If any of the aforementioned tests yield abnormal results, the next step is to determine the exact cause of excess cortisol production. This evaluation involves measuring plasma ACTH levels. Low ACTH levels are seen in adrenal adenomas, adrenal carcinomas, and exogenous glucocorticoid use. High ACTH levels are seen in patients with Cushing disease (ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) and ectopic ACTH production.

In patients with high ACTH levels, the next step is to give a high-dose injection of dexamethasone. If there is no decline in ACTH/cortisol levels, it means there is an ectopic site of ACTH production. If ACTH/cortisol levels fall after the high-dose dexamethasone test, it means that an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma is the cause.

The patient in this vignette has elevated ACTH levels and reduced endogenous cortisol production after administration of high-dose dexamethasone, which is consistent with Cushing disease. Surgical resection is the first-line treatment option.



Option Analysis

❌ Glucocorticoid overproduction by adrenal tumor:
Incorrect: A cortisol-secreting adrenal adenoma can cause hypercortisolism. The condition will result in low ACTH levels due to the negative feedback that cortisol has on the pituitary gland. In contrast, this patient’s laboratory findings show an elevated ACTH level.
✅ ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Excess ACTH production by lung tumor:
Incorrect: Malignancies such as small cell lung cancer can secrete ACTH which, in turn, can cause increased glucocorticoid production. Patients with this condition are not expected to respond to a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. In contrast, this patient has reduced cortisol production after being administered a high dose of dexamethasone.
❌ Exogenous glucocorticoid intake:
Incorrect: Exogenous glucocorticoid intake can present with symptoms of hypercortisolism. In such instances, the body decreases (not increases) ACTH production in an attempt to reduce endogenous cortisol production and normalize blood cortisol levels. Moreover, intermittent use of inhaled corticosteroids (as in this patient) is not significant enough to cause hypercortisolism.
❌ Overactive posterior pituitary tumor:
 Incorrect: The clinical and laboratory findings in this patient are consistent with hypercortisolism. ACTH overproduction by the anterior pituitary can cause hypercortisolism However, none of the hormones produced by the posterior pituitary (vasopressin and oxytocin) can account for the patient’s symptoms.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a suspected generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The episode occurred an hour ago when she was with her roommate, who states the patient started uncontrollably flexing and extending her upper and lower limbs for 1 minute. She has a history of recurrent seizures for the past 2 years, and she lost partial vision due to occipital lobe infarction last year. Family history is not available because the patient was adopted as a child. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation and weakness of bilateral lower extremities. The patient is admitted for further evaluation. Serum lactate levels are 3.3 mmol/L. Skeletal muscle biopsy shows proliferation of mitochondria that appear bright red compared to the blue myofibers when stained with Gomori trichrome stain. This patient’s condition is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient’s neuromuscular lesions, ragged muscle fibers on biopsy, and elevated lactate levels are consistent with mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, most likely MELAS syndrome (mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes).

MELAS is a rare genetic disorder that occurs when there are mutated mitochondria in muscle cells, especially skeletal muscle cells. The diseased mitochondria proliferate in an attempt to compensate for poor energy production and appear bright red compared to the blue myofibers, and they are therefore called "ragged red fibers" when stained with Gomori trichrome stain.


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Mitochondria are cellular organelles that are responsible for ATP production via oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, mitochondrial defects tend to cause lactic acidosis and tend to affect tissues with highest metabolic rates (e.g., neural and muscular tissue). Although some mitochondrial proteins are encoded in the nuclear genome, mitochondria have their own mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) as well. Mutations of mtDNA result in failure of oxidative phosphorylation and are the underlying cause of mitochondrial myopathies.

Besides MELAS, other mitochondrial myopathies include Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, which results in cell death in the optic nerve neurons, leading to subacute bilateral vision loss in teens/young adults, which is usually permanent.

Option Analysis

❌ Myotonic dystrophy:
Incorrect: Myotonic dystrophy is a multisystem disorder most commonly caused by the expansion of CTG trinucleotide repeat, affecting the DMPK gene. It is characterized by skeletal muscle weakness and myotonia, cardiac conduction abnormalities, and cataracts. Stroke-like symptoms, lactic acidosis, seizures, and ragged red fibers on skeletal muscle biopsy are not usually seen.
❌ Inflammatory myopathy:
Incorrect: Inflammatory myopathies (e.g. polymyositis) results from lymphocytic inflammation of the skeletal muscle cells. Affected patients present with prominent proximal muscles weakness. Stroke-like symptoms, lactic acidosis, and seizures are not usually seen. “Ragged red fibers,” as indicated by the bright red mitochondria on biopsy, are also inconsistent with the diagnosis.
❌ Myasthenia gravis:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis is caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptors on the postsynaptic membrane. Affected individuals most commonly present with fluctuating weakness and fatigability of ocular muscles. Stroke-like symptoms, lactic acidosis, and seizures are not usually seen.
✅ Oxidative phosphorylation disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ion channel myopathy:
Incorrect: Ion channel myopathy manifests with episodes of myotonia and hypotonic paralysis, often after exercise. Intracytoplasmic, PAS-positive vacuoles can be seen on muscle biopsy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of testicular pain and fullness, which have been ongoing for the last 3 weeks. A physical examination is performed and reveals the presence of a mass on the left testicle that does not transilluminate with light. Imaging and tumor marker analysis are performed, confirming the diagnosis of testicular cancer. He subsequently undergoes a radical orchiectomy. Post-operative pathological analysis of the testicle reveals a 6-mm tumor containing strands of hair and keratinous material. Which of the statements is most likely to be true regarding this type of malignancy?

choices.text: The likelihood of metastases to other organs is high
The tumor consists primarily of well-differentiated cells
The patient likely had elevated ꞵ-hCG levels prior to tumor resection
The tumor consists of immature cells from all three germ layers
The patient will receive adjuvant radiation therapy

questions.solution:
This boy is presenting with a testicular mass that contains strands of hair and keratinous material. He most likely has a testicular teratoma, which, in prepubertal males, usually consists of well-differentiated cells.

Teratomas are a type of germ cell tumor that contain tissue from all three germinal layers, which are the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. The tumor is composed of somatic-type tissue in various stages of differentiation and maturation. Teratomas can be sub-classified into two groups: mature teratomas and immature teratomas.

Mature teratomas contain well-differentiated tissue (e.g., skin, hair, nails) and typically present in children. The tumors are usually benign, and there have been few, if any, cases of metastatic disease in prepubertal males. In contrast, immature teratomas contain undifferentiated tissue, typically present in adults, and are usually malignant. Of note, unlike those found in adult males, teratomas in adult females tend to be benign.



Option Analysis

❌ The likelihood of metastases to other organs is high:
Incorrect: Testicular teratomas can present in both children and adults. In general, testicular teratomas found in prepubertal children are benign, contain well-differentiated cells, and have a low risk of metastasizing to other organs.
✅ The tumor consists primarily of well-differentiated cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The patient likely had elevated ꞵ-hCG levels prior to tumor resection:
Incorrect: Post-operative analysis, which demonstrates the presence of keratinous material and strands of hair, is suggestive of a testicular teratoma. Teratomas do not typically cause elevations in ꞵ-hCG levels. In contrast, other testicular tumors, such as choriocarcinomas and embryonal carcinomas, are more likely to cause elevated ꞵ-hCG levels.
❌ The tumor consists of immature cells from all three germ layers:
Incorrect: Teratomas consist of cells from the three germ layers, which are the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. However, teratomas in pediatric patients typically consist of mature cells, whereas those in adult patients are more likely to contain immature cells.
❌ The patient will receive adjuvant radiation therapy:
Incorrect: Testicular teratomas in children consist of well-differentiated cells with low likelihood of metastases. As a result, patients are typically treated with orchiectomy without adjuvant radiation or chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to her physician complaining of a recent episode of vision loss in both eyes that lasted for several seconds. She has had diffuse headaches for the last several months but has never had changes in vision until now. Medical history is significant for moderate acne vulgaris that is being treated with topical benzoyl peroxide and oral doxycycline. She takes a multivitamin several times a day and claims it helps keep her “energized” throughout the day. Vital signs are within normal limits. BMI is 36 kg/m2. Physical examination shows few pustular acneiform lesions on her face. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes, but visual field testing shows loss of peripheral vision. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. Brain MRI is done, followed by a lumbar puncture which reveals an opening pressure of 270 mm H2O and immediate relief of her headache. Which of the following MRI findings is strongly associated with this patient’s underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Cerebrospinal fluid accumulation in the sella turcica
Enlargement of the lateral ventricles with no cortical atrophy
Extra-axial mass with a dural attachment

questions.solution:
This patient with episodic loss of vision, bilateral papilledema, and relief of headaches upon lumbar puncture, likely has idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), previously called pseudotumor cerebri.

The classic finding on MRI in IIH patients is an empty sella (indicated by the yellow circle), caused by excess cerebrospinal fluid displacing cerebral tissue in the sellar region. Although the pituitary gland is displaced, it rarely causes signs of hypopituitarism.

Empty sella syndrome can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to another condition. Primary empty sella syndrome occurs when cerebrospinal fluid enters the sella through a defect in the sellar diaphragm (which could be associated with increased intracranial pressure) and displaces cerebral tissue in the sellar region. Secondary empty sella syndrome is a result of an injury to the pituitary itself (e.g. pituitary apoplexy) or the consequence of surgical or radiation treatment. In adults, empty sells syndrome is most commonly found in older, obese, hypertensive, multiparous women and may be asymptomatic.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebrospinal fluid accumulation in the sella turcica:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Enlargement of the lateral ventricles with no cortical atrophy:
Incorrect: Enlargement of the lateral ventricles in the absence of cortical atrophy is a hallmark of normal pressure hydrocephalus, which can be idiopathic or secondary to impaired CSF resorption. It is classically characterized by the 3 W’s: Wet (urinary incontinence), Wobbly (gait dysfunction), and Wacky (cognitive impairment), none of which is seen in this patient.
❌ Extra-axial mass with a dural attachment:
Incorrect: Meningiomas arise as extra-axial mass with a dural attachment. These tumors are mostly asymptomatic but can sometimes present with seizures or focal neurologic signs, neither of which is seen in this patient.


❌ Cortical infarct:
Incorrect: Cortical infarct can be seen in patients with a stroke. Common clinical findings include focal neurologic deficits, weakness, or loss of sensation, none of which is seen in this patient.
❌ Periventricular plaques:
Incorrect: This finding is diagnostic of multiple sclerosis and is caused by the reactive gliosis that follows demyelination. Patients with multiple sclerosis typically have optic neuritis, which is characterized by painful eye movements and decreased visual acuity, neither of which is seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a first-time seizure. The patient attended the party with three of his friends who report that he used a drug to help him “be more social.” His friends state the patient seemed to be drinking “copious amounts of water” at the party. His temperature is 38.5C (101.3F), pulse is 110/minute, respirations are 16/minute, and blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. On physical examination the man is disoriented, the pupils are mydriatic, and he appears diaphoretic. Clonus is appreciated in the lower extremities bilaterally. Laboratory evaluation reveals hyponatremia. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with serotonin syndrome--a hyperadrenergic state with associated clonus. Of the agents listed, 3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine or MDMA is highly associated with this clinical syndrome. This drug is often consumed at parties to produce euphoria and social connection.

MDMA, when consumed in excess, can be life-threatening. High doses of MDMA result in agitation and increased blood pressure, heart rate and temperature. In addition, this increased sympathetic activity can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, and death.

 


One of the major causes of death is hyponatremia, which results from increased water intake and inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). Ultimately, severe hyponatremia can lead to seizures (like this patient) and cerebral edema. Rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria are common as well, secondary to increased sympathetic
 activity.


People who use MDMA frequently often develop tolerance and dependence, and they may have withdrawal symptoms when abstaining from use. Withdrawal symptoms are not life-threatening, but they can be bothersome. Withdrawal symptoms include irritability, depression, insomnia, and anxiety. In addition, decreased appetite is usually seen, which may lead to weight loss. 

Option Analysis

✅ 3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Heroin:
Incorrect: Heroin intoxication is characterized by miosis, respiratory depression, and somnolence. This presentation is in contrast to this patient’s evidence of increased sympathetic activity (e.g., hypertension, tachycardia).
❌ Lysergic acid diethylamide:
Incorrect: This patient presents with evidence of severe hypertension, hyperthermia, and hyponatremia, which are not typically observed with LSD intoxication.
❌ Marijuana:
Incorrect: Marijuana is associated with injected conjunctiva and normal pupil size--not mydriasis.
❌ Cocaine:
Incorrect: Cocaine use is associated with first time seizures; however, this patient has evidence of serotonin syndrome (clonus), which is not typically observed with cocaine intoxication.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is referred to an endocrinologist by his pediatrician due to concerns about the child’s development. The patient’s parents report that he has had pubic, axillary and chest hair growth over the past six months. They note that the child also gained several inches in height over the same period. Currently, the patient is at the 89th percentile for height and 76<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight. Physical examination reveals coarse pubic, chest and axillary hair. The testes are markedly enlarged without evidence of extra-seminal masses. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on further evaluation?

choices.text: Hypothalamic tumor on MRI of the brain

questions.solution:
Puberty encompasses a wide range of physical, mental and psychological changes that an individual undergoes in response to changes in the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis. Precocious puberty refers to a disorder in which puberty starts far earlier than expected. Specifically, precocious puberty is defined as starting puberty before the age of eight in females and nine in males. Broadly, precocious puberty gets divided into central precocious puberty and peripheral precocious puberty.

Central precocious puberty arises from large amounts of secreted gonadotropin release hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus (typically from a hypothalamic tumor). In contrast, peripheral precocious puberty is more often due to a tumor of the peripheral sex organs (namely the adrenal gland or gonads). The gold standard test to confirm a general diagnosis of precocious puberty is an x-ray of the hands or long bones; this should be done prior to pursuing radiographic or laboratory investigations for causes of central or peripheral precocious puberty. This test determines a patient’s bone age, and patients with precocious puberty are known to have advanced bone age. If the bone age is normal, other differentials should be considered including premature thelarche, premature adrenarche, or premature menarche.

Option Analysis

✅ Advanced bone age on radiography  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypothalamic tumor on MRI of the brain  :
Incorrect: While possible, patients with central precocious puberty (e.g. due to dysfunction hypothalamic-pituitary axis) often also present with symptoms of central nervous system dysfunction.  
❌ High circulating exogenous testosterone levels  :
Incorrect: Patients with exogenous testosterone use often present with extreme irritability, robust muscular build, severe acne, and male pattern baldness.  
❌ -1.0 T score on DEXA scan  :
Incorrect: DEXA scanning is used to evaluate bone density and is used frequently in evaluating for osteoporosis. A score of minus one reflects a normal bone density.  
❌ Testicular tumor on ultrasonography  :
Incorrect: A testicular ultrasound may better characterize a testicular tumor thought to be causing peripheral precocious puberty. While this patient has markedly enlarged testicles, evidence of an additional testicular mass is absent.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with a cough over the past week. He recently moved for college. Since beginning school, the patient has noticed a worsening runny nose with congestion, sneezing, and tearing over the past few days. He initially thought it was due to dust from moving into the dorm, but the symptoms have not improved with time. He does not have any pets. Physical examination shows edematous nasal mucosa. Bronchial breath sounds at the lung bases are heard on auscultation. Examination of the eyes reveals the findings shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with cough, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion in the setting of new environmental exposures (e.g. moving to a new city for college). He most likely has allergic rhinitis.   

Allergic rhinitis is characterized by paroxysms of sneezing, rhinorrhea, and nasal obstruction, often accompanied by itching of the eyes, nose, and palate. It is typically caused by hay, dust, pollen, animal dander, or mold spores. A high yield concept is that allergic rhinitis is a type 1 hypersensitivity mediated by immunoglobulin E antibody production and mast cell degranulation. This reaction leads to excess fluid build-up in the nasopharynx.    

On physical examination, one may see prominent creases below the inferior eyelid, referred to as Dennie-Morgan lines (see the image in the vignette). Additionally, the nasal mucosa can appear pale and boggy.    

The diagnosis is usually made clinically. However, diagnostic tests such as patch testing, in which allergens are applied to small patches and stuck onto the skin, can be performed. If the skin under a particular patch becomes irritated, it suggests an allergy to the substance. Blood tests may show elevated IgE and eosinophil levels.    

The best treatment option is to avoid the triggering allergen. However, allergic rhinitis is a persistent condition requiring ongoing therapy in most patients. Glucocorticoid nasal sprays are the most effective single-agent maintenance therapy for allergic rhinitis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Viral conjunctivitis :
Incorrect: Viral conjunctivitis often presents with erythematous eyes with copious tearing. This patient has no evidence of conjunctival injection.  
❌ Moderate asthma:
Incorrect: Moderate asthma can present with dyspnea, chest tightness, and persistent cough. Patients may also have increased respiratory rate, tachycardia, and wheezing audible throughout exhalation. 
✅ Allergic rhinitis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin-induced respiratory disease  :
Incorrect: Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) is characterized by a triad of nasal polyps, asthma, and aspirin sensitivity. This combination of symptoms is known as the Samter triad. This patient does not have any of the three components of this triad. 
❌ Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:
Incorrect: Nasopharyngeal angiofibromas are benign but locally aggressive tumors of the nasal mucosa composed of large blood vessels and fibrous tissues. They often present with profuse epistaxis, unilateral complaints of nasal obstruction, and trouble breathing. While they are most commonly seen in adolescent males, this patient’s presentation and physical exam do not correlate with a nasopharynx angiofibroma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the office with a two-month history of hoarseness and sore throat. He initially came to the office approximately two months ago with similar symptoms and was treated empirically for an upper respiratory infection. Since then, he has developed night sweats and experienced a 2 kg (4.4 lb) weight loss. He has not experienced heartburn, hearing loss, epistaxis, or nasal congestion. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and consumes 3 alcoholic beverages daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the left tonsil is enlarged, with an area of ulceration present on the mucosa. Overproduction of which of the following proteins is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has hoarseness, sore throat, night sweats, and weight loss in the setting of an ulcer on the oral mucosa. These factors, combined with a significant tobacco and alcohol use history, raise concern for oropharyngeal carcinoma.    

Oropharyngeal carcinoma is usually located on the soft palate, palatine tonsillar fossa and pillars, lateral and posterior pharyngeal wall, or tongue base. The leading causes of oropharyngeal carcinoma are chronic tobacco use, alcohol use, and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. HPV produces the proteins E6 and E7, which inhibit the tumor suppressor proteins p53 and Rb, respectively.  

Patients with oropharyngeal carcinoma are initially asymptomatic, and cervical lymphadenopathy is an early sign. As the tumor enlarges, it can cause persistent sore throat, dysphagia, and mucosal ulceration. In addition, patients can develop constitutional symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss.



Option Analysis

✅ E6 oncoprotein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CD21:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms and physical exam findings consistent with oropharyngeal carcinoma. CD21, also known as Epstein Barr virus receptor, is a receptor that EBV can bind with to infect B-cells. While EBV infection may contribute to the development of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, it does not play a role in the development of oropharyngeal carcinoma. 
❌ p53:
Incorrect: p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that regulates cell cycle and growth. Overproduction of p53 would protect against the development of oropharyngeal cancer. 
❌ CD4:
Incorrect: CD4 is a glycoprotein found on the surface of specific immune cells. HIV-1 uses CD4 to gain entry into host T-cells. However, overproduction of CD4 plays no role in the pathogenesis of oropharyngeal cancer. 
❌ Rb tumor suppressor:
Incorrect: Rb is a tumor suppressor protein that regulates the cell cycle and growth. Overproduction of Rb would protect against the development of oropharyngeal cancer.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient with Turner syndrome presents to the family physician for a routine annual checkup. They now work as a lawyer and have been undergoing routine checkups each year. They are feeling well and take no medications. Temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 72/min, and blood pressure 128/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck, short stature, curved thoracic spine, and cubitus valgus. Prior ECG and echocardiogram testing demonstrated no abnormalities. Which of the following is this patient at a greater risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with Turner syndrome and has several physical examination findings consistent with the diagnosis (e.g., scoliosis, short stature, cubitus valgus). Patients with Turner syndrome are at increased risk of developing a wide variety of symptoms and disorders (see below list).  

In particular, osteoporosis affects patients with Turner syndrome much earlier than average due to a lack of estrogen. Estrogen stimulates osteoblastic activity and is protective of bone development.
