In its absence, patients are susceptible to osteoporosis and fractures, similar to what is observed in postmenopausal females. This risk of osteoporosis and associated fractures can be reduced in patients with Turner syndrome via estrogen replacement therapy. 

Associated clinical findings with Turner syndrome:  
  • Short stature  
  • Cardiovascular abnormalities  
  • Learning disability  
  • Hearing loss  
  • Renal agenesis/horseshoe kidney  
  • Ovarian failure  
  • Osteoporosis  
  • Scoliosis  
  • Other comorbidities  
    • Celiac disease  
    • Autoimmune thyroiditis  
    • Liver disease  
    • Metabolic syndrome  
    • Gonadoblastoma  

Option Analysis

❌ Bicuspid aortic valve:
Incorrect: A bicuspid aortic valve is often associated with Turner syndrome. However, this patient has an unremarkable echocardiogram, hence making an underlying valvular abnormality unlikely.
❌ Alzheimer disease  :
Incorrect: Patients with trisomy 21 have three copies of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene, which is located on chromosome 21, and are subsequently at increased risk for developing Alzheimer disease. In contrast, this patient has Turner syndrome, which is not associated with Alzheimer disease.
✅ Osteoporosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypotension:
Incorrect: Patients with Turner syndrome are at increased risk for hypertension, not hypotension.
❌ Joint hypermobility  :
Incorrect: Joint hypermobility is a feature of Marfan syndrome. The condition arises due to a mutation of the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15. As a result, the body produces an abnormal form of the protein fibrillin, which is a key structure in the formation of elastic fibers in connective tissue. In contrast, this patient has Turner syndrome, which is not typically associated with joint hypermobility.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle crash in which he was the restrained driver and crashed into a standing car. In the ambulance, the patient is obtunded with a Glasgow scale of 4. Upon arrival at the emergency department, he is immediately intubated and taken for trauma CTs, which demonstrate multiple lesions at the gray-white junction. Vital signs are within normal limits. One day later, the patient remains in a coma and without a change in Glasgow scale, despite ventilator and sedation weaning strategies. Which of the following best explains this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery

questions.solution:
This patient most likely suffered a diffuse axonal injury (DAI) due to shearing of white matter tracts–a common and devastating form of traumatic brain injury. Patients with DAI often present in a deep coma without elevated intracranial pressure. DAI occurs as a result of traumatic shearing forces applied to the brain when the head is rapidly accelerated and/or decelerated. This injury typically affects the gray-white junction, but more severe injuries may involve the corpus callosum and/or midbrain. On imaging, multiple small lesions within the gray-white junction are typical. MRI is more sensitive than CT for detecting DAI.  



Option Analysis

❌ Cerebral hypoperfusion:
Incorrect: Hypoxic-ischemic brain injury is observed in conditions such as cardiac arrest, hypovolemic shock, poisoning, or head trauma. This condition typically affects cerebral watershed areas found between cerebral vascular territories. These territories include the junction between anterior and middle cerebral arteries, as well as the posterior and middle cerebral arteries. However, this patient’s presentation and imaging findings are more consistent with diffuse axonal injury.  
❌ Rupture of bridging veins:
Incorrect: Rupture of bridging veins is most commonly associated with subdural hematomas. CT findings of subdural hematomas show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines. In contrast, this patient’s presentation and imaging findings are more consistent with diffuse axonal injury.  
❌ Rupture of the middle meningeal artery:
Incorrect: Epidural hematoma is most commonly due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery from trauma to the pterion. Patients present with a “lucid interval” followed by rapid deterioration and death if left untreated. On a non-contrast head CT, a lens-shaped collection is typical. In contrast, this patient’s presentation and imaging findings are more consistent with diffuse axonal injury.  
✅ Shearing of white matter tracts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neurotransmitter-mediated excitotoxicity  :
Incorrect: Neurotransmitter-mediated excitotoxicity is a type of secondary brain injury where injured neurons release excessive glutamate, leading to overactivation injury in adjacent cells. This phenomenon is responsible for the worsening of cerebral edema, increased intracranial pressure, and clinical exacerbation of an initial brain injury. However, the CT findings in this case are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of exertional dyspnea and difficulty with ambulation. She has not experienced chest pain, syncope, or loss of consciousness but states she cannot climb a flight of stairs without feeling winded. She also reports gait instability and difficulty keeping her balance while standing. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes, untreated HIV, and chronic hepatitis C infection. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and glyburide. The patient is not sexually active and is post-menopausal. She lives in Connecticut with her niece and went on a camping trip six weeks ago. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/65 mmHg. Physical examination reveals granulomatous lesions with heaped borders on the patient’s lips, right leg, and arm. On cardiac auscultation, the apical impulse is displaced laterally and inferiorly with the presence of an early diastolic murmur over the left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals multiple wart-like lesions on the labia majora. Cervical motion tenderness is absent on bimanual examination. Neurological examination reveals a positive Romberg sign and loss of vibration perception with intact motor function. Ophthalmic examination is notable for an absent light reflex with a retained accommodation reflex. Which of the following historical features is the most likely etiology of this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Cohabitation with a person with a similar illness

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, a wide pulse pressure, and a new diastolic murmur–consistent with aortic regurgitation. In addition, the physical exam reveals evidence of gummatous lesions and neurological symptoms (positive Romberg sign, loss of proprioception, and sense of vibration) that suggest posterior column degeneration (tabes dorsalis). Lastly, the pupillary exam reveals a characteristically absent light reflex with a retained accommodation reflex (Argyll Robertson pupil). Together, these findings are highly concerning for tertiary syphilis, which is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.

Tertiary syphilis develops in patients with long-standing untreated syphilis and often presents with evidence of disseminated infection to multiple organ systems. Classically, tertiary syphilis presents with cardiovascular (aortitis), dermatologic (gumma), and neurologic symptoms (tabes dorsalis, Argyll Robertson pupil).

Classically, tertiary syphilis causes obliterative endarteritis of the vasa vasorum within the adventitia of the ascending thoracic aorta. Ultimately, this weakening of the aortic wall results in chronic aortitis, aortic root dilation, and subsequent aortic regurgitation. The associated skin lesions of tertiary syphilis are characterized by gummatous lesions, which are granulomatous, heaped lesions on the lips, skin of the extremities, bones, and viscera. Neurologically, infection of the posterior column of the spinal cord results in tabes dorsalis, with symptoms including the loss of proprioception and vibration sense due to posterior column degeneration.

Diagnostic investigations of tertiary syphilis include non-treponemal (VDRL, RPR) and treponemal (FTA-ABS, TP-EIA) antibody tests.  Specific investigations to confirm neurosyphilis include lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination and CSF-VDRL tests. A nonreactive CSF-VDRL test does not rule out a diagnosis of neurosyphilis; however, an elevated protein concentration and a CSF lymphocyte count of > 5 cells/microL are indicative of neurosyphilis in patients with high suspicion despite a negative CSF-VDRL test. The treatment of choice for neurosyphilis is ten to fourteen days of either intravenous penicillin or intramuscular penicillin plus probenecid.

Option Analysis

✅ Unprotected sexual intercourse:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Arthropod bite:
Incorrect: Lyme disease can cause myocarditis and subsequent symptoms of exertional dyspnea. Accompanying neurological symptoms include peripheral neuropathy and bilateral cranial nerve palsy. However, genital lesions and gummatous skin lesions would be atypical.
❌ Exposure to viral respiratory droplets:
Incorrect: A post-infectious viral myocarditis can cause exertional dyspnea; however, this diagnosis would not explain this patient’s genital lesions, gummatous skin lesions, or neurological manifestations.  
❌ Needlestick injury:
Incorrect: Chronic hepatitis can manifest with symptoms of malaise, myalgias, and dermatological conditions such as porphyria cutanea tarda and lichen planus. However, a history of hepatitis does not explain this patient's cardiorespiratory symptoms, genital lesions, or neurological symptoms.  
❌ Cohabitation with a person with a similar illness:
Incorrect: Neisseria meningitidis is transmitted among those in close contact and manifests with generalized malaise, headache, myalgia, confusion, and a diffuse erythematous rash. This patient does not have meningitis features, such neck pain or stiffness. Additionally, meningitis would not explain this patient’s cardiorespiratory symptoms, genital lesions or gummatous skin lesions.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right arm pain following a fall out of a tree. The patient’s parent states he was in his treehouse when he fell from the balcony directly onto an outstretched right arm. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination reveals a young male in acute distress who is holding his right arm against his body. There is tenderness and swelling of the right mid-forearm without visible deformity. A radiograph of the right forearm is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
A greenstick fracture is a partial thickness fracture in which the cortex and periosteum are disrupted on one side of the bone but remain unfractured on the opposite side. They commonly occur in long bones (e.g., fibula, tibia, ulna, radius, humerus) and most commonly occur in the radius, ulna, or humerus following a fall on an outstretched arm.

Prior to ossification, the majority of pediatric bone is compliant, calcified cartilage. Due to this increased compliance, pediatric bones will bow and bend under stress instead of fracture as in adult bone. This unique property of pediatric bone results in several distinctive fracture patterns:  

  •  Greenstick: partial-thickness fracture where cortex and periosteum are only interrupted on one side of the bone, while they remain uninterrupted on the opposite side 
  •  Torus: incomplete fractures of the shaft of a long bone characterized by bulging of the cortex 
  •  Spiral injuries: bending injuries rather than full-thickness cortical breaks
 

Greenstick fracture, Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Option Analysis

✅ Greenstick fracture of the radius   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Buckle fracture of the radius   :
Incorrect: Torus fractures, also known as buckle fractures, are incomplete fractures of the shaft of a long bone characterized by bulging of the cortex (as indicated by the yellow arrow). This patient has evidence of a cortical breach on one side of the bone, indicating a different diagnosis.
 
 
Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  
❌ Dietary vitamin D deficiency   :
Incorrect: Dietary vitamin D deficiency can lead to impaired bone mineralization, bowing of the long bones, and widening of the growth plate. These findings are not seen on this child’s x-ray.   
❌ Primary bone malignancy   :
Incorrect: Osteosarcomas are the most common primary bone malignancy in children. The tumor typically presents with localized bony pain and a palpable soft tissue mass. Characteristic findings on X-ray include a sunburst pattern and periosteal reaction.   
❌ Radial head subluxation   :
Incorrect: Radial head subluxation occurs when children are lifted or pulled by their wrist or arm causing the radial head to slip under the annular ligament. Radiographs of the affected arm are typically normal.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the primary care physician complaining of urinary urgency for the past week with occasional involuntary voiding, which has been causing the patient significant distress at work. She states this has never happened before, but that several months ago, she went to the emergency department for an episode of intense right eye pain with movement and loss of color vision. These symptoms gradually improved over 2 weeks. She has no other past medical history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination reveals no visual field defects. Physical examination reveals upgoing plantar reflexes bilaterally. A head MRI shows multiple hyperintense periventricular ovoid lesions. Which of the following best describes the likely disease course in this patient?

choices.text: Symptom exacerbations with near complete recovery between episodes
Continuous worsening from the onset of the disease
Symptom exacerbations with worsening of symptoms between episodes
Rapidly progressive disease course with neurologic disability in 5 years
Fully functional in all neurologic systems 15 years after the disease onset

questions.solution:
This woman is presenting with various neurologic symptoms (e.g., urgency incontinence, optic neuritis, positive Babinski sign) and has an MRI scan showing periventricular lesions. She most likely has multiple sclerosis (MS).

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease that results in oligodendrocyte damage and depletion. The previous episode of optic neuritis was likely caused by plaque formation around the optic nerve. The current urgency incontinence occurs due to detrusor overactivity secondary to cortical demyelinating lesions that impair the detrusor reflex at the level of the frontal cortex.  

There are various clinical courses that MS can follow, with relapsing-remitting MS (RR-MS) the most common; it is the clinical course of 90% of patients at the time of diagnosis. RR-MS describes a disease course characterized by clearly defined attacks (also called exacerbations or relapses) with full or near-full recovery in between. This patient had a prior episode of optic neuritis that resolved spontaneously and is now presenting with urgency incontinence that will also likely resolve spontaneously. As the plaques worsen, so too will the neurologic dysfunctions, and eventually RR-MS will become secondary progressive MS in 50% of patients, wherein there is continuous worsening of symptoms between exacerbations.    



Option Analysis

✅ Symptom exacerbations with near complete recovery between episodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Continuous worsening from the onset of the disease:
Incorrect: Primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PP-MS) describes a clinical course with no acute exacerbations but with continuous worsening of symptoms from the very onset of the disease. However, this patient’s history is notable for acute episodes of MS followed by complete resolution of symptoms, which is inconsistent with the presentation of PP-MS. 
❌ Symptom exacerbations with worsening of symptoms between episodes:
Incorrect: Secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (MS) describes a clinical course with continuous worsening of symptoms in between exacerbations. However, this is not the most common clinical course of MS. Moreover, although relapsing-remitting MS eventually becomes secondary progressive MS, this transition usually occurs 10 to 20 years after disease onset. 
❌ Rapidly progressive disease course with neurologic disability in 5 years:
Incorrect: Malignant multiple sclerosis (MS), also known as aggressive MS, describes a rapidly progressive disease course that leads to debilitating neurologic dysfunction within 5 to 10 years. This is not the most common disease course of MS. 
❌ Fully functional in all neurologic systems 15 years after the disease onset:
Incorrect: Benign multiple sclerosis describes a disease course wherein patients experience a single demyelinating event, but will never experience a second exacerbation. This is a rare type of multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the clinic for evaluation of a worsening productive cough. The symptoms have been worsening over the past week, and she has noticed increased production of foul-smelling, blood-tinged sputum. She has had multiple similar episodes in the past that mildly improved with antibiotics, but the cough has always persisted. The patient does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit substances. She takes pancreatic enzyme supplements for chronic diarrhea. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 124/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals digital clubbing. Lung auscultation demonstrates diffuse wheezes and crackles. Which of the following findings will most likely be present in this patient?

choices.text: Barrel chest with flattening of hemidiaphragms
Irregular thickening of the interlobular septa with honeycombing
Pleural thickening with multiple nodular pleural lesions
Dilated bronchi and bronchioles with signet-ring sign
Hilar lymphadenopathy with bilateral reticular opacities

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a productive cough in the setting of recurrent pulmonary infections and chronic diarrhea. She likely has bronchiectasis secondary to cystic fibrosis (CF).  

Patients with CF have thickened, viscous, and inspissated secretions at various mucosal surfaces, leading to lung injury, gastrointestinal malfunction, and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency. In the lungs, the abnormal secretions accumulate and predispose patients to superimposed infections. Recurrent infections cause permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles due to destruction of smooth muscle and the supporting elastic tissue, resulting in bronchiectasis.   

Bronchiectasis presents clinically as a persistent cough that produces copious amounts of purulent, foul-smelling sputum. Diagnosis can be made via CT scan, which will show dilated bronchi and bronchioles. The "signet-ring" sign is a classic imaging feature of bronchiectasis. It describes the cross-sectional appearance of a dilated, air-filled bronchus that is contiguous with a branch of the pulmonary artery (the jewel on the ring). Pulmonary function testing in patients with bronchiectasis will reveal findings consistent with obstructive pulmonary disease due to air trapping.  



Option Analysis

❌ Barrel chest with flattening of hemidiaphragms:
Incorrect: This finding is consistent with emphysema. Emphysema is characterized by chronic air-trapping that results in an increased anteroposterior chest diameter, bilateral hyperlucency, and flattening of the hemidiaphragms. However, patients with emphysema do not typically present with increased sputum production.
❌ Irregular thickening of the interlobular septa with honeycombing:
Incorrect: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a condition that causes irreversible fibrosis. Patients with IPF may also present with a chronic cough. However, this patient’s underlying cystic fibrosis would predispose her to another pulmonary condition.
❌ Pleural thickening with multiple nodular pleural lesions:
Incorrect: Chronic exposure to asbestos can result in asbestosis and potentially mesothelioma, which is characterized by pleural thickening. 
✅ Dilated bronchi and bronchioles with signet-ring sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hilar lymphadenopathy with bilateral reticular opacities:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem disorder characterized by non-caseating granulomatous inflammation that typically presents initially with dyspnea and a dry cough. However, this patient’s underlying cystic fibrosis would predispose her to another pulmonary condition.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with suicidal ideation. Today is the fourth day of hospitalization, and the course has been uncomplicated. The patient has been participating in therapy, taking medications, and eating daily. During rounds, the patient is noted to have altered mental status. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 102/74 mmHg, and BMI is 17 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. On physical exam, the patient appears thin and cachectic with several healing lacerations noted over the volar aspect of the wrists. Multiple calluses are present over the knuckles of the right hand. She has 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities bilaterally and faint bibasilar rales on pulmonary auscultation. She is having intermittent convulsions in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is most likely present?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of anorexia nervosa, including a cachectic state, low BMI, and positive Russell sign. The patient develops seizures and congestive heart failure after her nutritional intake is increased during the hospitalization, which raises concerns for refeeding syndrome. Of the listed electrolyte derangements, hypophosphatemia is most commonly seen with this condition.  

 Refeeding syndrome occurs in significantly malnourished patients during the initial stages of oral, enteral, or parenteral nutritional replenishment. The nutrition causes electrolyte and fluid shifts that may precipitate disabling or fatal medical complications including hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, congestive heart failure, peripheral edema, seizures, and hemolysis.  

Hypophosphatemia arises since in the starved state, cellular metabolism slows and blood glucose is low. When feeding is reinstituted, blood glucose increases, driving insulin upwards and shifting phosphate into cells for ATP synthesis, thus leading to hypophosphatemia.  

Other causes of hypophosphatemia include decreased intestinal absorption and increased urinary excretion of phosphate. Decreased intestinal absorption of phosphate can occur due to excess alcohol intake or antacid use. Increased urinary excretion of phosphate occurs due to conditions such as hyperparathyroidism or Fanconi syndrome. 

Acute symptoms of hypophosphatemia occur due to insufficient ATP formation and include metabolic encephalopathy, impaired myocardial contractility, respiratory failure due to weakness of the diaphragm, myopathy, dysphagia, and ileus. Chronically, hypophosphatemia results in weak bones, osteomalacia, and rickets in children.  

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

Option Analysis

✅ Hypophosphatemia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypermagnesemia:
Incorrect: Hypomagnesemia, as opposed to hypermagnesemia, is commonly observed in patients with refeeding syndrome. This phenomenon is due to increased uptake of magnesium from the bloodstream for intracellular processes. 
❌ Hyperchloremia:
Incorrect: Hyperchloremia is not commonly implicated in refeeding syndrome. In contrast, hyperchloremia is often seen in the setting of a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis or when large volumes of crystalloid are infused. 
❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: This thin and cachetic patient with signs of self-induced vomiting (e.g. calluses over the knuckles) likely has anorexia nervosa. She developed seizures and congestive heart failure after increasing her nutritional intake during hospitalization, which raises concerns for refeeding syndrome. Refeeding syndrome more commonly presents with hypokalemia, as opposed to hyperkalemia.
❌  Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: This patient has been having good daily nutritional intake since being admitted to the hospital. As a result, it is unlikely she has hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 1, presents to the office for evaluation of amenorrhea. Menarche was at age 13. Since then, she had a regular 28-day cycle with no dysmenorrhea that stopped 3 months ago. Past medical history is significant for two missed abortions, the last of which was 6 months ago, managed via dilation and curettage. She has a healthy 5-year-old daughter born via spontaneous vaginal delivery. The patient has not had any hot flashes or vaginal dryness. Family history is significant for hypothyroidism in her mother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 22 kg/m2. Speculum examination shows moist vaginal mucosa with no abnormalities. Urine beta-HCG is negative. FSH, TSH, and prolactin levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of amenorrhea in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of secondary amenorrhea, together with a history of an intrauterine procedure (dilation and curettage) makes the diagnosis of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome) most likely.  

Asherman syndrome is an acquired disorder that results from trauma to the basal layer of endometrium after which it fails to regenerate and undergoes fibrosis, replacing the normal tissue with multiple bands of collagen (adhesions) that stick to each other. The fibrosed endometrium becomes unresponsive to hormonal stimulation leading to amenorrhea, infertility and recurrent pregnancy loss. Common causes include dilation and curettage following spontaneous abortion (as seen in this patient), cesarean section and other intrauterine procedures like myomectomy or curettage in non-gravid uterus.  

Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosis, which can also be used therapeutically to cut the adhesions with a scissor or laser.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hypothalamic dysfunction:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is a disorder caused by hypothalamic dysfunction leading to disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Common risk factors include stress, anorexia nervosa and excessive exercise, and the condition can therefore be seen in young athletes. It is unlikely in this patient with normal lifestyle habits and body mass index. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels makes this cause less likely.
❌ Accelerated ovarian follicle depletion:
Incorrect: Accelerated follicular depletion can be due to primary ovarian insufficiency or secondary to follicular atresia due to other causes (radiation, chemotherapy, autoimmune). It commonly presents with irregular menstrual cycle, hot flashes and vaginal dryness, none of which are seen in this patient. Additionally, patients with premature ovarian failure typically have elevated FSH levels due to the loss of negative feedback from the lack of circulating estrogen.  
✅ Fibrosis of endometrial stratum basalis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ectopic implantation of endometrial tissue:
Incorrect: Endometriosis presents in women of reproductive age with pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, dysmenorrhea and deep dyspareunia (due to lesions in posterior cul-de-sac). This patient has had none of these complaints, making this diagnosis less likely. 
❌ Low levels of serum thyroxine:
Incorrect: Although amenorrhea can be seen in hypothyroidism, it is usually accompanied by fatigue, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance and other findings not seen in this patient. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels make this cause less likely.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2, presents to the clinic because of heavy and painful menstrual bleeding for the past 2 months. The pain starts with the onset of menstrual bleeding and has now become severe in intensity. Her last menstrual period was a week ago. Menarche was at age 11. Her menstrual cycle is regular, with 5-6 days of heavy bleeding. She is sexually active with her male partner and denies any pain during intercourse. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus for 2 years treated with metformin and Neisseria gonorrhoeae cervicitis as a teenager, for which she received appropriate treatment. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Bimanual examination shows a uniformly enlarged, mobile, tender and boggy uterus. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Hyperplastic overgrowth of tissue from endometrial surface
Subclinical infection of the upper genital tract

questions.solution:
The clinical findings of heavy and painful menstrual bleeding, together with the tender and uniformly enlarged (globular), boggy (soft) uterus on exam makes adenomyosis the most likely diagnosis in this case.  

Adenomyosis is defined as the presence of endometrial tissue in the myometrium. The exact pathophysiology is unknown, but it is thought to develop from invagination of endometrial basalis into the myometrium. The ectopic tissue is sensitive to hormonal stimulation throughout the menstrual cycle and mostly presents in multiparous women (between the age of 40 and 50 years) with heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain. Physical examination shows a mobile, uniformly enlarged, boggy uterus. It is important to contrast adenomyosis from leiomyomas, which may also present as an enlarged uterus; however, leiomyomas result in an irregularly enlarged, nontender uterus, rather than a uniformly enlarged, tender uterus in adenomyosis.  

Ultrasound and MRI are helpful in evaluation; however, the diagnosis is usually confirmed after hysterectomy, which is also the definitive treatment. For women who have not completed childbearing, hormonal treatment (e.g., levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine devices, estrogen-progestin contraceptives, aromatase inhibitors and oral GnRH antagonists) may be effective for reducing heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea, as in endometriosis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Ectopic endometrial tissue:
Incorrect: Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. It commonly presents with dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain, and deep dyspareunia. In endometriosis, the uterus is normal in size and often immobile (fixed).
❌ Hyperplastic overgrowth of tissue from endometrial surface:
Incorrect:  Endometrial polyps result from hyperplastic overgrowths of endometrial tissue. They typically present with abnormal uterine bleeding, most commonly intermenstrual bleeding (without dysmenorrhea). Tamoxifen therapy is a major risk factor. Physical examination is usually normal, in contrast to this patient’s findings.
❌ Benign myometrial smooth muscle proliferation:
Incorrect: Uterine leiomyoma (fibroids) result from benign myometrial smooth muscle proliferation. The condition usually presents with heavy and/or prolonged menses, pressure symptoms like constipation, noncyclic pelvic pain, and an irregularly enlarged uterus. This patient has a uniformly enlarged uterus and cyclic pelvic pain.
❌ Subclinical infection of the upper genital tract:
Incorrect: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can sometimes present as a subclinical infection of the upper genital tract. Although this patient is at high risk (given the history of N. gonorrhoeae cervicitis), subclinical PID is usually asymptomatic and presents with failure to conceive.
✅ Endometrial tissue in myometrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of excessive fatigue for the last 2 weeks. She states that 1 month ago, she had experienced episodes of palpitations and diarrhea, but those symptoms have now resolved. Past medical history is significant for type I diabetes mellitus, which is treated with insulin. She also has been taking a laxative several times a week to help with new-onset constipation, which started 3 weeks ago. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 48/min, blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg, and BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination shows cold, dry skin and thinning hair on the scalp. There is 1+ non-pitting edema on both lower extremities. Which of the following additional findings is likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Diffuse uptake of radioactive iodine on thyroid scintigraphy

questions.solution:
This middle-aged female is presenting with constipation, dry skin, thinning hair, and non-pitting edema in the lower extremities. She most likely has hypothyroidism. Taking into account the history of a previously diagnosed autoimmune condition (e.g. type I diabetes mellitus) as well as prior symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g. episodes of palpitations and diarrhea), she most likely has chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto thyroiditis).   

Hashimoto thyroiditis is the leading cause of hypothyroidism in the United States; it is autoimmune-mediated, and thus it tends to occur in patients with other underlying autoimmune conditions such as type I diabetes mellitus and vitiligo. Although the etiology is not fully understood, there is autoimmune-mediated lymphocytic inflammation and destruction of the thyroid tissue. This destruction of the follicular cells results in release of preformed thyroid hormones, which usually presents as an initial phase of hyperthyroidism. Patients subsequently progress to hypothyroidism as the thyroid parenchyma is destroyed and fibrosed.  

Diagnosis is based on thyroid function tests, as well as the presence of antibodies, such as anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-microsomal) and antithyroglobulin antibodies. Treatment is primarily with levothyroxine to replete the thyroid hormone deficiency.    



Option Analysis

✅ Positive antimicrosomal antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Human leukocyte antigen DQ8 positivity :
Incorrect: Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) DQ8 positivity is associated with celiac disease. Although this patient had episodes of diarrhea several weeks ago, the spontaneous resolution makes this diagnosis unlikely. This patient’s signs and symptoms make chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto thyroiditis) more likely, which is associated with HLA-DR5 positivity. 
❌ Decreased thyroid stimulating hormone levels:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., bradycardia, fatigue, hair thinning, non-pitting edema). The previous symptoms of palpitations and diarrhea were likely caused by autoimmune destruction of thyroid follicular cells and subsequent release of preformed T4 and T3. Therefore, the likely primary hypothyroidism seen in this patient would cause a resultant increase in thyroid stimulating hormone levels, not decrease. 
❌ Diffuse uptake of radioactive iodine on thyroid scintigraphy:
Incorrect: Thyroid scintigraphy is an imaging technique that demonstrates the structure and function of thyroid tissue based on the selective uptake of radioactive iodine (RAI). Normally, only the functional part of the thyroid gland takes up RAI. In patients with a hyperfunctioning thyroid gland (e.g. Graves disease), there would be an enlarged thyroid gland with diffuse uptake of RAI. However, in this patient currently presenting with hypothyroidism, there would be decreased uptake. 
❌ Positive TSH-receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: TSH-receptor antibodies are present in patients with Graves disease. The circulating TSH-receptor autoantibodies cause overstimulation of the thyroid gland, leading to excess production of thyroid hormone, resulting in signs of hyperthyroidism. In contrast, this patient is presenting with classical signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism, hence making Graves disease and the presence of TSH-receptor antibodies unlikely.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office escorted by his partner due to recent falls and confusion. Additionally, the partner states that multiple times throughout the night, the patient exhibits various movements in his sleep, such as throwing a ball and even accidentally kicking her one night. The patient states he is unaware of these activities, but he describes vivid dreams of playing football or fighting off home invaders. The patient’s partner mentions that the symptoms began a year ago, and since then, they have been getting worse, although some days are better than others. Medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals muscle rigidity in the upper extremities, and the patient walks slowly with small steps. On Mini-Mental State Examination the patient has difficulty with copying overlapping pentagons and drawing a clock but can repeat 3 objects after 1 and 5 minutes respectively. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy patient, who is presenting with parkinsonism (rigidity, shuffling gait), rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder, as well as fluctuating symptoms (good and bad days), most likely has dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB).  

 DLB is a common type of degenerative dementia. In addition to dementia, a patient with DLB must have at least two of the core features, including: 
  •  cognitive fluctuations 
  •  visual hallucinations 
  •  rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD) 
  •  parkinsonism    
Patients typically show an early decline in executive function (e.g. calculations), and visuoperceptual ability (e.g. missing traffic signs). On the Mini-Mental Exam, although not diagnostic, patients with DLB have impaired figure copying, clock drawing, and serial sevens, compared to Alzheimer disease, which shows impaired short-term memory and orientation. The diagnosis of DLB is based upon the presence of core clinical features, history, and physical examination. MRI will likely show nonspecific diffuse cortical atrophy. The hallmark of the disease is the presence of Lewy bodies on pathological examination of the brain, which are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions containing aggregated alpha-synuclein in the deep cortical layers.  

The differentiation of Parkinson disease from DLB is based on the timeline of which symptoms occur. If the parkinsonism symptoms are present for more than a year before the onset of dementia, the diagnosis is instead classified as Parkinson disease dementia.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Alzheimer disease:
Incorrect: Alzheimer disease (AD) is an idiopathic neurodegenerative disorder which typically presents after 60 years of age; it is the most common cause of dementia. Declarative episodic memory, vocabulary, and concepts are typically impaired while procedural memory and motor learning are spared. This patient shows intact short term memory and parkinsonism, which favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Frontotemporal dementia:
Incorrect: Frontotemporal dementia, formerly known as Pick disease, is characterized by early personality and behavior changes or aphasia. Patients with frontotemporal dementia may also have associated movement disorders (e.g. parkinsonism). However, the REM-sleep disturbances and the order of the progression of this patient’s presentation favor another diagnosis.
❌ Normal-pressure hydrocephalus:
Incorrect: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is an idiopathic condition characterized by expansion of the ventricles and distortion of the corona radiata fibers. Patients typically present with a classic triad of urinary incontinence, gait apraxia (magnetic gait), and cognitive dysfunction. This patient’s clinical symptoms favors another diagnosis. 
✅ Dementia with Lewy bodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vascular dementia:
Incorrect:  Vascular dementia is caused as a result of multiple arterial infarcts. It is typically seen in patients with longstanding cardiovascular conditions (e.g., hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes) and characterized by a stepwise decline in cognitive ability with late-onset memory impairment; it does not cause parkinsonism symptoms as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the office because of increased frequency of falls, loss of balance, and blurry vision for the past several months. His partner mentions that the patient has been moodier, has difficulty coming up with names of places, and “gets aggravated easily if he does not get his way.” Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient moves slowly and walks with small steps. There is rigidity noted in the extremities, and a fine tremor in the bilateral hands. Eye examination shows a limited upward and downward gaze with slowing of vertical saccades bilaterally. The fundal margins are clear without edema. A therapeutic dose of levodopa is administered and does not result in improvement of the patient’s rigidity or tremors. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, personality and behavior changes, parkinsonism (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability with unexplained falls), and cognitive dysfunction, most likely has progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP).  

Symptoms and signs of parkinsonism (i.e., tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability) are also present in other neurodegenerative disorders aside from idiopathic Parkinson disease, known as “Parkinson-Plus syndromes.” These include corticobasal degeneration, multiple system atrophy, and progressive supranuclear palsy.  

PSP is characterized by progressive supranuclear ophthalmoplegia, gait disorder, postural instability, dysarthria, dysphagia, rigidity, and frontal cognitive disturbance (personality and behavior changes). Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia is the hallmark of PSP; it typically begins with slowing of vertical saccades, followed by a limitation of saccadic range. Patients often present with downgaze palsy and later, an upgaze palsy.

The cause of the condition is unknown, but it is associated with the accumulation of tau protein within the brain. The pathological correlates associated with this syndrome are atrophy of the dorsal midbrain, subthalamic nucleus, basal ganglia, and frontal lobes. Neurofibrillary tangles, neuronal loss, and gliosis are also seen.  

Parkinson disease (PD) is a common differential diagnosis for PSP; however, PD does not normally present with symmetrical onset. Additionally, PSP patients have a poor response to levodopa therapy, in contrast to idiopathic PD.  



Option Analysis

❌ Alzheimer disease:
Incorrect: Alzheimer disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. AD typically presents with early memory loss and dementia. While motor signs (e.g., pyramidal, extrapyramidal) do occur in patients with AD, these are usually late-stage findings. The timing of this patient’s symptoms and the abnormal eye findings are suggestive of a different, specific diagnosis.
❌ Lewy body dementia:
Incorrect: Dementia with Lewy bodies is characterized by dementia with fluctuating cognition and alertness, visual hallucinations, and late parkinsonism. This patient's abnormal eye movements are suggestive of a different, specific diagnosis.
❌ Parkinson disease :
Incorrect: Parkinson disease (PD) and progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) share bradykinesia, rigidity of muscles, and late-onset dementia. However, abnormal eye movements are rare in PD, while the finding is considered a disease hallmark in PSP patients. 
❌ Multisystem atrophy:
Incorrect: Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a neurodegenerative condition characterized by autonomic dysfunction, ataxia, and parkinsonism (slow movement, muscle rigidity, tremors, and postural instability). Cognitive function is relatively preserved in MSA compared with Parkinson disease. Although cerebellar disturbances of eye movements can be seen, vertical gaze palsy is not expected in MSA. 
✅ Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician office due decreased vision, progressive fatigue and swelling around the ankles for the past 4 weeks. Medical history is significant for myocardial infarction 2 years ago, diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension. Current medications include aspirin, captopril, metformin and lovastatin. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 144/90 mmHg.  Physical examination shows 2+ edema around the ankles bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination reveals retinal arteriolar narrowing, arteriovenous nicking, and flame-shaped hemorrhages. Laboratories studies are shown: 




Which of the following is likely responsible for this patient’s eye examination findings?
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic, uncontrolled hypertension is presenting with decreased vision, lower extremity edema, and fatigue; in conjunction with the laboratory results and eye examination findings, he most likely has chronic kidney disease and coexisting hypertensive retinopathy. The laboratory results show high creatinine, high BUN and anemia, which support the diagnosis of chronic kidney disease (CKD), likely secondary to chronic hypertension.  

Hypertension is defined as persistent systolic BP ≥ 130 mm Hg and/or diastolic BP ≥ 80 mm Hg, which can be primary (essential) or secondary to other causes (e.g., hyperaldosteronism, fibromuscular dysplasia). Hypertension increases the risk for various complications, including:

  •  Neurologic: Stroke, retinopathy 
  •  Cardiopulmonary: Coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, atrial fibrillation, left ventricular hypertrophy 
  •  Vascular: Aortic dissection 
  •  Renal: Chronic kidney disease 
In the kidneys, chronic hypertension causes hypertensive nephrosclerosis, which is characterized by damage to various components of the kidneys, including small blood vessels, glomeruli, renal tubules, and interstitial tissues. Chronic hypertension causes medial and intimal hypertrophy of blood vessels, resulting in narrowed vessels and ischemic damage to the kidneys. Additionally, vessel walls are further damaged by hyaline-like material deposition. Patients with nephrosclerosis typically present with a history of hypertension, progressive elevations of BUN and plasma creatinine concentration, and mild proteinuria.  

Chronic hypertension also damages the eyes, leading to retinal damage. Eye examination may show flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages, arteriovenous nicking, microaneurysms and a macular star (exudate). Depending on the severity and chronicity of the hypertension, these findings typically vary.

Option Analysis

❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Retinal damage can occur in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus due to chronic hyperglycemia. It can present in two forms, proliferative and nonproliferative retinopathy. Nonproliferative retinopathy is characterized by damage to the capillaries and leaking of lipids and fluids into the retina. Eye examination will show hemorrhages and macular edema. Proliferative retinopathy, on the other hand, is caused by chronic hypoxia, which results in new blood vessel formation (neovascularization) that can lead to vitreous hemorrhage, fibrosis, and subsequent retinal detachment. However, this patient’s diabetes is likely well-controlled, as indicated by a normal HbA1c level. Additionally, the eye examination findings favor another diagnosis. 
❌ Atherosclerosis:
Incorrect: Atherosclerotic disease of the ipsilateral carotid artery is the most common overall cause of central retinal artery occlusion in elderly individuals; it presents with acute, painless monocular vision loss. Fundoscopic examination, however, would reveal a pale retina due to ischemia, as opposed to this patient’s exam, which revealed retinal arteriolar narrowing, arteriovenous nicking, and flame-shaped hemorrhages. 
❌ Multiple myeloma:
Incorrect: Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell cancer that arises in the bone marrow and produces large amounts of monoclonal immunoglobulins (IgG or IgA). It typically presents with hypercalcemia, renal involvement, anemia and back pain from lytic bone lesions. The massive amounts of circulating immunoglobulins can result in hyperviscosity of the patient’s blood. This hyperviscosity can affect the retinal vessels, resulting in dilated, segmented, and tortuous retinal veins, giving a "sausage link" appearance. However, this patient’s calcium level is normal, and the eye examination and laboratory results favor another diagnosis.
✅ Hypertension:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thromboembolism:
Incorrect: Thromboembolism is a potential cause of central retinal artery occlusion, which presents as acute, painless monocular vision loss. Embolic sources include carotid artery atherosclerosis, cardiac vegetations, and patent foramen ovale. Eye examination will show retinal cloudiness with attenuated vessels and “cherry-red” spot at the fovea. This patient’s eye examination and laboratory results favor another diagnosis. 
❌ Age-related macular degeneration:
Incorrect: Age-related macular degeneration usually presents with distortion of straight lines (metamorphopsia) and eventual loss of central vision (scotomas). It can be further divided into dry (nonexudative) or wet (exudative). Dry macular degeneration is characterized by deposition of yellow material (drusen) in the retina, while wet causes neovascularization. This patient’s eye examination and laboratory results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her provider’s office for evaluation of fatigue and exercise intolerance that began two months ago. Past medical history is notable for Crohn disease diagnosed eight-years ago. She is taking mesalamine but reports frequent “flare-ups.” The patient consumes 3-4 glasses of wine per week. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 123/76 mmHg, pulse is 75/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. The patient has conjunctival pallor. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are non-contributory. Neurological examination reveals decreased proprioception and vibratory sensation in the lower extremities. Complete blood count reveals a hemoglobin of 8.8 g/dL and a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 115 µm3. Which of the following findings would be most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Homocysteine   Methylmalonic Acid   Findings on Colonoscopy  ↑  Unchanged  Transmural inflammation of the jejunum
Homocysteine   Methylmalonic Acid   Findings on Colonoscopy  ↑  Unchanged Transmural inflammation of the ileum
Homocysteine   Methylmalonic Acid   Findings on Colonoscopy  ↑  ↑ Transmural inflammation of the jejunum
Homocysteine   Methylmalonic Acid   Findings on Colonoscopy  ↑  ↑Transmural inflammation of the ileum
Homocysteine   Methylmalonic Acid   Findings on Colonoscopy Unchanged  Unchanged  Transmural inflammation of the ileum

questions.solution:
This patient has macrocytic anemia secondary to vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 is obtained by consuming animal-derived products. After being absorbed, vitamin B12 plays a crucial role in two biochemical reactions. First, it is involved in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. Second, it is involved in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA (a derivative of methylmalonic acid) to succinyl-CoA/conversion of THF-CH3 to THF. The latter reaction helps produce DNA nucleotides.  

Potential causes of vitamin B12 deficiency include atrophic gastritis, pernicious anemia, and Crohn disease, all of which impair B12 uptake. Patients who consume a vegan diet are also at risk for vitamin B12 deficiency.  

Patients with the condition have anemia due to impaired DNA synthesis. Red blood cell (RBC) replication and maturation are disrupted, resulting in large (macrocytic) and immature (megaloblastic) RBCs. In addition, elevated methylmalonic acid levels lead to myelin sheath degeneration, resulting in the classic neurological symptoms (decreased vibratory sensation and proprioception).  

Diagnosis of vitamin B12 deficiency relies on a peripheral blood smear, which shows large red blood cells and hypersegmented neutrophils. On a blood sample, the mean corpuscular volume (MCV) will exceed 100 mm3. Bone marrow study can be done to look for the megaloblastic changes in RBC precursors. Homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels are also elevated, in contrast to folate deficiency which presents with elevated homocysteine but normal methylmalonic acid levels. Finally, the condition can be confirmed by low total vitamin B12 levels in the blood.    

Option Analysis

❌   Homocysteine   Methylmalonic Acid   Findings on Colonoscopy  ↑  Unchanged  Transmural inflammation of the jejunum :
Incorrect: An elevated homocysteine but normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) level is seen in patients with folate deficiency, and inflammation of the jejunum can impair folate absorption. Folate deficiency does present with a macrocytic anemia; however, it would be atypical for folate deficiency to cause the neurological symptoms observed in this patient.
❌   Homocysteine   Methylmalonic Acid   Findings on Colonoscopy  ↑  Unchanged Transmural inflammation of the ileum:
Incorrect: Patients with folate deficiency present with elevated homocysteine levels but normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels. However, Crohn disease lesions in the ileum would not affect folate absorption, which takes place in the jejunum. Moreover, folate deficiency would not cause the lower extremity neuropathy observed in this patient.
❌   Homocysteine   Methylmalonic Acid   Findings on Colonoscopy  ↑  ↑ Transmural inflammation of the jejunum :
Incorrect: The elevated homocysteine and MMA levels are consistent with the presentation of vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to the degeneration of the dorsal columns and account for the sensory deficits found on physical examination. However, vitamin B12 absorption would be imapired only if the Crohn disease affected the distal ileum (site of B12 absorption).
✅   Homocysteine   Methylmalonic Acid   Findings on Colonoscopy  ↑  ↑Transmural inflammation of the ileum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Homocysteine   Methylmalonic Acid   Findings on Colonoscopy Unchanged  Unchanged  Transmural inflammation of the ileum:
Incorrect: Crohn disease can lead to gastrointestinal tract blood loss, which would in turn explain the patient’s anemia and symptoms. In this scenario, blood homocysteine and MMA levels would be within normal range. However, anemia secondary to blood loss/iron deficiency presents with either normocytic or microcytic RBCs. In addition, this mechanism would fail to account for the patient’s neurological symptoms.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man comes to the office because of weak urinary stream. He has been experiencing this for the past year, but it has been gradually worsening, and he now has to strain to urinate. He also complains of urinary frequency and urgency but denies incontinence or pain with micturition. He was recently treated for a presumed urinary tract infection with antibiotics for 2 weeks. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Medications include metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Vitals are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, non-tender prostate with a rubbery texture. The rest of the examination is noncontributory. The most recent HbA1c 2 months ago was 5.6%. Urinalysis at this visit is as follows:  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Urinalysis 
 Specific gravity  1.013 
 Glucose  Negative 
 Blood  Negative 
 Leukocyte esterase  Negative 
 Nitrites  Negative 
 Leukocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Erythrocytes  1-2/hpf 

Prostate specific antigen is 5.5 ng/mL. Which of the following factors in the patient’s history is the strongest predisposing factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) refers to the benign enlargement of the prostate gland. The overall risk of developing BPH increases with age and is most common in men between the ages of 60 and 69 years.   

BPH is a histologic diagnosis that is characterized by nodular hyperplasia of stromal and epithelial cells in the periurethral zone of the prostate gland. As the prostatic cells proliferate in the periurethral zone, they impinge on the urethra, resulting in the lower urinary tract symptoms seen in patients. There is some evidence that the hyperplasia results from prostatic cell proliferation and impaired cell death mediated by androgens, mainly dihydrotestosterone (DHT). DHT is produced from testosterone via 5α-reductase activity (which increases with age), and this theory explains why 5α-reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride, are effective in management of BPH.  

The enlargement and increased smooth muscle tone lead to the development of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) over time which can be:

  •  Storage (or irritative) symptoms: Urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia and incontinence. 
  •  Voiding (or obstructive) symptoms: Weak urinary stream, straining to void, hesitancy, dribbling and splitting of the stream. 
 

Option Analysis

✅ Advanced age:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cigarette smoking:
Incorrect: Cigarette smoking is associated with increased risk of transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder, which usually presents with gross or microscopic hematuria. Bladder cancer does not usually cause irritative symptoms such as frequency or urgency. 
❌ Recent urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Although an inadequately treated urinary infection may present with urinary frequency and urgency, this patient was treated with antibiotics for 2 weeks, and the urinalysis is normal.
❌ Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus may present with urinary frequency (polyuria) and, in the long-term, can lead to neurogenic bladder, which presents with continuous dribbling of urine and a sense of incomplete bladder emptying. This patient’s HbA1c is normal, indicating that the diabetes is well-controlled.
❌ Diuretic use:
Incorrect: Excessive diuretic use can sometimes cause urinary frequency but obstructive symptoms (straining, weak urinary stream) are not observed. A firm prostate with a smooth, rubbery texture would be atypical.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old male presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. According to the paramedics, the patient was found obtunded in an alley with empty beer cans at his side. While nursing staff attempt to establish an IV, the patient begins seizing. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 11/min, blood pressure is 152/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. On physical exam, the patient appears disheveled with tetany in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. The patient’s laboratory findings are demonstrated below:  
 
 Laboratory Value, Serum  Result 
 Sodium   105 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   92 mEq/L 
 HCO3-  20 mEq/L 
 BUN  12 mg/dL 
 Creatinine   1.1 mg/dL 

Which of the following clinical findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Pitting edema of the lower extremities

questions.solution:
This patient with a presumed episode of binge drinking presents with severe hyponatremia and associated seizures. Given the patient’s history, beer potomania (a subset of euvolemic hyponatremia) is the most likely cause. The condition occurs secondary to overconsumption of electrolyte-poor liquid, such as beer, with little other sources of nutrition. Poor electrolyte intake limits the formation of a normal renal urea gradient, leading to an inability to excrete sufficient free water and subsequent development of hyponatremia.  

Hyponatremia is classified based on the patient's volume status (e.g., hypovolemic, euvolemic, hypervolemic). It is important to not confuse true hyponatremia with pseudohyponatremia or false hyponatremia, which arises due to increased serum lipids and protein or instrumental error.  

Hypervolemic hyponatremia occurs due to an enormous increase in total body water and less significant increase in total body sodium. Etiologies include congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome. In contrast, hypovolemic hyponatremia occurs when there is significant sodium loss in comparison to a smaller water volume loss. Etiologies include cerebral salt wasting, diarrhea, and vomiting. Euvolemic hyponatremia occurs when there is normal total body sodium but an increase in total body water. The condition is termed “euvolemic” since no edema is present. Etiologies include primary polydipsia, beer potomania, and SIADH.  

Regardless of etiology, the symptoms of hyponatremia are primarily neurologic in nature. Mild symptoms including nausea and malaise may occur as serum levels fall below 120 mEq/L. As levels fall below 110 mEq/L, stupor, coma, and seizures may occur. At this level, correction of sodium levels should occur with hypertonic saline, though hyponatremia should not be corrected too quickly to avoid central pontine myelinolysis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Normal extracellular fluid status :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pitting edema of the lower extremities :
Incorrect: The presence of pitting edema and hyponatremia is suggestive of volume overload or increased extracellular fluid. It can arise in the setting of congestive heart failure, liver failure, or renal failure. In contrast, this patient more likely has beer potomania, which manifests as a euvolemic state.
❌ Bibasilar rales:
Incorrect: Bibasilar rales lend towards evidence of hyponatremia in the setting of increased extracellular fluid. This patient presents with hyponatremia likely after consuming large quantities of beer, which is concerning for beer potomania. Beer potomania typically manifests as an euvolemic state.
❌ Jaundice :
Incorrect: Although this patient’s history is concerning for chronic alcoholism, he has no evidence of liver cirrhosis (e.g., hepatomegaly, ascites, spider angiomata). As a result, it would be unlikely that this patient presents with jaundice.
❌ Dry mucous membranes:
Incorrect: Hypovolemic hyponatremia can arise in the setting of excess sodium and water loss (e.g., vomiting, diuretic use, hypoaldosteronism). In contrast, this patient’s history is more consistent with beer potomania, which manifests as a euvolemic state.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 30 weeks gestation comes to the labor and delivery unit due to painful contractions for the past several hours. She did not receive any prenatal care. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 135/84 mmHg. The fetal ultrasound shows an amniotic fluid index of 24 cm (normal 8-18) with the single deepest pocket measuring 9 cm. She denies any gush of fluid. Pelvic examination reveals a uterus size consistent with 34 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with minimal prenatal care is presenting with preterm labor and size-date discrepancy, most likely due to high amniotic fluid levels. Among the answers above, only esophageal atresia, which impairs the fetus' ability to swallow fluid, will result in a high amniotic fluid index.

During the first trimester, the amniotic fluid volume is derived from the maternal compartment, fetal secretions, and the placenta. During the second trimester, fetal urine becomes the primary source of amniotic fluid. The amniotic fluid volume reflects the balance between fluid production and absorption. Therefore, any condition that results in an increase in fetal urine production or a decrease in fetal swallowing can result in polyhydramnios, which is defined as an excessive volume of amniotic fluid. Polyhydramnios should be suspected when uterine size is large for gestational age. The diagnosis is made prenatally by ultrasound examination showing an amniotic fluid index ≥24 cm or a single deepest pocket of ≥8 cm.



Option Analysis

❌ Uteroplacental insufficiency:
Incorrect: Uteroplacental insufficiency results in oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid index) and uterine size that is less than expected for gestational age. Low amniotic fluid is associated with Potter sequence, which includes severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia.
❌ Posterior urethral valve :
Incorrect: Posterior urethral valves, obstructions of the lower urinary tract (e.g. urethral atresia), and intrinsic renal disorders (e.g., renal agenesis, polycystic renal disease) will result in reduced amniotic fluid production. Low amniotic fluid is associated with Potter sequence, which includes severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia.
✅ Esophageal atresia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Renal agenesis:
Incorrect: Renal agenesis, intrinsic renal disorders, and obstruction of the lower urinary tract (e.g., posterior urethral valve, urethral atresia) result in reduced amniotic fluid production. Low amniotic fluid is associated with Potter sequence, which includes severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia.
❌ Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use :
Incorrect: NSAIDs, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, and trastuzumab use during pregnancy is associated with oligohydramnios, not polyhydramnios. It is thought that NSAIDs induce renal antidiuretic responses, reduce renal blood flow, and are therefore associated with decreased fetal urine flow.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of a painless nodule on the back of the left heel. He has had several episodes of joint pain in the last 2 years, involving the toes and knees, that would often resolve after taking ibuprofen. He has not had any fevers, recent joint trauma, or weight loss. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is currently on hydrochlorothiazide and pravastatin. He has been drinking 5-6 beers daily for the last 13 years. He denies tobacco or illicit substance use. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 138/95 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a nontender, hard, chalky nodule on the left Achilles tendon, as seen in the image below:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Similar nodules are present on the left elbow and right external pinna of the ear. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Chronic deposition of monosodium urate in joints

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with hardened nodules on the Achilles tendon and external pinna of the ear; taking into account the history of recurrent joint pains, he likely has tophi formation secondary to chronic gout. Tophaceous gout is characterized by deposition of solid urate followed by chronic inflammation and destructive changes in the nearby connective tissue. Tophi often form on cartilage (e.g. external pinna of the ear), tendons, ligaments, and articular bone. Since tophi form secondary to urate deposition, treatment consists primarily of achieving and maintaining low levels of serum urate. 

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic deposition of monosodium urate in joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Presence of rheumatoid factor antibodies:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with persistent pain in the joints, especially at the hands and wrists, that is typically worse in the morning. Rheumatoid nodules are subcutaneous lesions formed by necrosis and palisading macrophages and lymphocytes. This patient’s acute episodes of pain in the toes and knees are characteristic of gout attacks and not rheumatoid arthritis. 
❌ Mutation in the HFE gene:
Incorrect: Hemochromatosis is caused by a mutation in the HFE gene resulting in uncontrolled iron absorption from the intestines. Patients with hemochromatosis may suffer from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition (CPPD) disease, which may present similarly to acute gout attacks. However, this patient’s subsequent tophi formation is not seen in hemochromatosis, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Positive human leukocyte antigen-B27 :
Incorrect: Human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-B27 positivity is associated with seronegative spondyloarthropathies, such as psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, inflammatory bowel disease, reactive arthritis (remembered with the mnemonic PAIR). Common findings include arthritis, dactylitis, and enthesitis (inflammation at the insertion of tendon sites). However, none of the aforementioned conditions would result in the tophi formation seen in this patient. 
❌ Positive gram-staining of bone biopsy:
Incorrect: A positive gram-stain of a bone biopsy is indicative of osteomyelitis. Osteomyelitis can cause chronic bone pain localized to a single joint. The pain would not be migratory, as seen in this patient. Moreover, osteomyelitis is usually associated with a fever.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with rapid, shallow breathing and rapid heart rate. He recently came back from a trip to Nepal where he went mountain climbing. The patient has no past medical history, and he has recently been taking acetazolamide for altitude sickness. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 102/70 mmHg. Arterial blood gas and laboratory testing are obtained, and the results are shown below.


Which of the following parts of the nephron is most likely affected by this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with hyperventilation, history of acetazolamide (carbonic anhydrase inhibitor) use, hypokalemia, urine pH below 5.5, and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis has a proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis (RTA). 



Proximal RTA is caused by a genetic or acquired defect of the brush border cells of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) that prevents bicarbonate reabsorption. The increased bicarbonate excretion via urine leads to an overabundance of hydrogen ions in the blood and metabolic acidosis. Also, the high urine bicarbonate concentration leads to osmotic diuresis and mild hypovolemia. This fluid shift leads to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), increased sodium reabsorption, and increased potassium excretion. As a result, patients develop hypokalemia. Unlike in distal (type 1) RTA, however, the distal intercalated cells are still functional in patients with proximal RTA and can secrete hydrogen ions, so urine pH is below 5.5.  





The most common cause of proximal RTA is Fanconi syndrome, which is defined as generalized proximal tubule dysfunction. Other causes include carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g. acetazolamide) and hypergammaglobulinemic states (e.g., monoclonal gammopathy, multiple myeloma).    

In this patient, acetazolamide led to development of a proximal RTA. Discontinuing the offending agent would lead to symptom resolution.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the glomerulus. Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes affect the glomerulus. However, this patient has findings consistent with a proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which is due to defective bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule. 
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This patient with proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis (RTA) has defective bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule.  
❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). However, this patient has a low serum pH, hypokalemia, and urine pH < 5.5, which is consistent with a proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis (RTA). Type 2 RTA affects the proximal convoluted tubule.
❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the collecting duct, which is affected in distal (type 1) renal tubular acidosis (RTA). Potential causes of type 1 RTA include medications (e.g., amphotericin B analgesics), congenital urinary tract anomalies, and autoimmune diseases (e.g. SLE). However, type I RTA would present with a urine pH greater than 5.5.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting this morning. He states he has had abdominal pain for the past several weeks, with the pain acutely worsening today with radiation to the left shoulder. He reports the vomit was dark brown and had a granular consistency. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He was also admitted for alcoholic pancreatitis approximately six weeks ago.The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He reports drinking 3-4 beers daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6 °F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 92/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows a pale man in acute distress. Abdominal examination is notable for diffuse tenderness to palpation, with rebound and rigidity. Laboratory results are shown below:

 
Laboratory value  Result 
 CBC, Serum 
 Hemoglobin  10.1  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  30% 
 Leukocyte count  14,000 /mm3 
 Platelet count  160,000/mm3 
 Serum 
               Sodium  132 mEq/L 
           Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
              Chloride  95 mEq/L 
                 BUN                    67 mg/dL  
             Creatinine  2.6 mg/dL 
              Albumin  3.7  g/dL 
                 AST  60 U/L 
                 ALT  30 U/L 
    Alkaline Phosphatase  110 U/L 
           Bilirubin, total  .7 mg/dL 
              Lipase  100 U/L 
Abdominal imaging is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Pericholecystic fluid and common bile duct dilatation
Dilation of the abdominal aorta >5 cm

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a peritonitis, coffee ground emesis, and signs of hemodynamic instability concerning for a perforated ulcer. In the setting of peritonitis, an upright chest x-ray should be performed on all patients to rule out free air under the diaphragm from a perforated viscus. If free air is discovered, urgent surgical consultation should be obtained for exploration and repair.  

Peptic ulcer disease is the most common cause of gastric and duodenal perforations, and they are typically located on the anterior or superior portions of the duodenum. Most patients will describe acute on chronic onset of abdominal pain with referred pain to the shoulder via irritation of the phrenic nerve. The majority of perforations due to peptic ulcer disease require repair with either an open or laparoscopic approach.  

Option Analysis

✅ Subdiaphragmatic air :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pericholecystic fluid and common bile duct dilatation:
Incorrect: Acute cholecystitis may manifest with signs and symptoms of peritonitis in the setting of perforation. The absence of focal right upper quadrant tenderness makes this diagnosis less likely. 
❌ Mediastinal emphysema:
Incorrect: Boerhaave syndrome or esophageal rupture typically presents with forceful retching and vomiting followed by severe retrosternal chest pain. Typical physical exam findings include crepitus over the chest wall and Hamman’s sign, where mediastinal crackling with each heartbeat may be heard on auscultation. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with an abdominal pathology.
❌ Dilation of the abdominal aorta >5 cm:
Incorrect: Patients with an aortic rupture typically present with lower back pain, a pulsatile abdominal mass, and a bruit on auscultation. With the absence of these clinical signs, this patient is less likely to be suffering from an abdominal aortic aneurysm.
❌ Pseudocyst surrounding the pancreas :
Incorrect: Pancreatic pseudocysts may manifest four to six weeks after an episode of pancreatitis. Typically, these present with persistent abdominal pain and indigestion after a bout of pancreatitis. Rarely do these present with peritonitis or hemodynamic instability, unless there is severe co-existing necrosis or hemorrhage. Additionally, pancreatic pseudocysts tend to present with persistently elevated lipase.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to fatigue and difficulty breathing. The patient is generally healthy, but over the past few months, she has experienced progressive fatigue and dyspnea. She also has noticed an increase in her weight without changes in her diet. Her last menstrual cycle was 2 years ago; since then, she has had some mild hot flashes that have resolved without treatment. The patient’s last Pap smear 2 years ago was normal, and she has no history of a sexually transmitted disease or abnormal uterine bleeding. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, heart sounds are normal. There are decreased breath sounds at the lung bases bilaterally and dullness to percussion. Abdominal examination reveals shifting dullness but no peritoneal signs. On pelvic examination, a right-sided, non-tender adnexal mass is noted but the rest of the exam is within normal limits. On ultrasound examination, a calcified hypoechoic mass is observed. Based on these features alone, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient is presenting with a triad of pleural effusion, ascites, and an adnexal mass, a classic presentation of Meigs syndrome, which is associated with a fibroma.  

Fibromas are the most common amongst sex cord-stromal tumors. Pure fibromas are benign solid tumors, usually unilateral, and are not hormonally active. They occur primarily in postmenopausal women. The fluid accumulation is thought to occur due to substances such as VEGF that increase capillary permeability. Removal of the fibroma results in resolution of the ascites and pleural effusion. Occasionally, the tumor can compress the round ligament of the uterus which produces a pulling sensation in the groin. Histology shows nests of spindle-shaped fibroblasts. On ultrasound examination, fibromas appear as a mass that may be hyper/hypoechoic, and they are often calcified and/or exhibit cystic degeneration. Treatment usually involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy or an ovarian cystectomy for women who desire preservation of the ovary.  



Option Analysis

✅ Fibroma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thecoma:
Incorrect: Thecomas are benign, solid, and fibromatous neoplasms, composed of theca cells arising from the ovarian stroma. They are usually seen in postmenopausal women.
