Thecomas may produce estrogen, and therefore often present with abnormal uterine bleeding; up to 20% of patients have concomitant endometrial cancer. Grossly, the tumors appear yellow from accumulated lipids. Histologically, they are primarily composed of theca cells. Thecomas are not associated with Meigs syndrome, as seen in this patient.
❌ Choriocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Choriocarcinoma is an invasive trophoblastic neoplasia composed of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts without villi. The most common presentation is antepartum vaginal bleeding. Other signs and symptoms include respiratory symptoms due to lung metastases, neurologic symptoms due to brain metastases, and acute abdominal pain due to bleeding intra-abdominal metastases. Choriocarcinoma can develop after any type of pregnancy (e.g., molar, abortion, etc.), though it rarely occurs coexistent with a normal intrauterine pregnancy. Since this patient is postmenopausal, this diagnosis is unlikely.
❌ Mature cystic teratoma:
Incorrect: A mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is a benign germ cell tumor that often contains elements of differentiated germ cell layers including ectoderm (e.g. hair follicles), mesoderm (e.g. muscle), and endoderm (e.g. lung). On imaging, it appears as a complex mass with hyperechoic contents and areas of acoustic shadowing. 
❌ Granulosa cell tumor:
Incorrect: Granulosa cell tumors are a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumors. These include 2 subtypes, adult and juvenile. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. These tumors often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, breast tenderness) and sexual precocity in children. Inhibin is the most common serum marker of these tumors. This patient, however, shows none of these features.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic due to back pain for the past 2 months. The patient reports dull, low back pain that is 3/10 in severity and managed with pain medications. He has not had any similar pain in the past or any recent trauma. He has tried ibuprofen, which provided partial relief. The pain often awakes the patient at night, but he is able to go back to sleep. He did not notice any specific aggravating or relieving factors. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, obesity, and osteoarthritis. Medication includes metformin and ibuprofen as needed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is within normal limits, except mild pain upon palpation at the lumbar area. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s back pain?
questions.solution:
This patient has new onset non-mechanical back pain (not related to movement) that is present at night and does not respond to pain medication, which raises concerns for an underlying malignancy (e.g. prostate cancer with metastases to the back).  

Approximately 85% of adults will experience low back pain at some time in their lives. Most cases are self-limited. The vast majority of cases are defined as nonspecific low back pain (85%), meaning that no specific underlying condition has been identified. Less than 10% of individuals who present to a primary care provider for low back pain will have mild but specific etiologies (e.g. disc herniation) and less than 1% will have serious etiologies (e.g., metastatic cancer, cauda equina syndrome). Due to these statistics, imaging for low back pain without associated symptoms is not recommended since it does not change outcomes and increases the use of invasive procedures. That being said, the clinician must recognize the patients who present with red flag symptoms and pursue appropriate investigations.



Option Analysis

❌ Inflammatory:
Incorrect: Inflammatory back pain includes spondyloarthropathies (e.g. ankylosing spondylitis) and is characterized by morning stiffness, improvement with activity, and pain at night. However, this patient did not report any alleviating factors, and patients with ankylosing spondylitis are typically between the age of 30-50 years.
❌ Degenerative:
Incorrect: Spondylosis (degenerative changes of the spine) is a common cause of back pain in individuals over 60 years. Pain due to degenerative changes is often mechanical, meaning it worsens with activity and improves with rest. The pain usually responds to medications. This patient has a new onset of back pain which is not mechanical and does not respond to medications.
✅ Neoplastic:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Infectious:
Incorrect: Vertebral osteomyelitis may occur due to hematogenous spread of an infection, trauma, or contiguous spread from an adjacent infection. Patients often present with insidious onset of back pain and possibly fever over weeks to months. CRP and ESR are usually elevated, whereas WBC count may be elevated or normal. Although further testing should be performed to exclude osteomyelitis, this patient lacks risk factors, such as IV drug use or trauma, making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Nonorganic:
Incorrect: Nonorganic findings are those that do not have a direct anatomical cause. Psychological conditions, such as depression, somatization disorder, and anxiety, can contribute to the severity of low back pain or cause nonorganic back pain. This patient has no history of psychological conditions, and a nonorganic etiology would not explain the night pain he is experiencing.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter due to persistent confusion at home. Over the past several days, the patient has appeared more sleepy and is harder to arouse. He has also experienced urinary incontinence more frequently, and he moans when his abdomen is palpated. His daughter had to call an ambulance to bring him to the hospital because he was too weak to stand on his own. The patient has a history of Alzheimer dementia, type 2 diabetes, and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Medications include aspirin, insulin glargine, lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and metformin. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows an ill-appearing, lethargic man with dry mucous membranes and an absent jugular venous pulsation. The abdomen is mildly tender just proximal to the pubic symphysis. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  12 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  36 % 
 Leukocyte count  14,000/mm3 
 Platelet count  400,000/mm3 
 Sodium  127 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.5 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  20 mEq/L 
 Blood urea nitrogen  45 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  3.0 mg/dL 
 Glucose  800 mg/dL 
 Serum osmolality  340 mOsm/kg 
Which of the following processes is most likely contributing to this patient’s acute illness?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a urinary tract infection given his suprabpubic pain, fever, and leukocytosis. However, his lethargic state and laboratory results suggest a second process: hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS). This pathologic state happens in type 2 diabetes when glucose levels get high, usually from a trigger, such as an underlying infection, leading to profound dehydration. The mechanisms that cause hyperglycemia overlap between diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and HHS. Both result in increased lysosomal activity, leading to protein degradation (proteolysis) to create building blocks (amino acids) for gluconeogenesis. Without insulin, the glucose that is synthesized cannot be used by cells, causing a massive glucose elevation.


Glucose is a polar molecule that cannot passively diffuse across cell membranes, which means that it acts as a solute. Therefore, when levels of glucose become elevated in the blood, the patient is in a hyperosmolar state, which causes water to leave the body’s cells. This extravasation of intracellular fluid leads to polyuria and dehydration, ultimately causing neurologic symptoms like lethargy and seizures, which can progress to coma and death if left untreated. Laboratory results in these patients show hyperglycemia, often over 600 mg/dL, high serum osmolality, often over 320 mOsm/kg and, unlike DKA, there is no acidosis, because ketone production is limited by the endogenous insulin. Treatment relies on aggressive IV fluids and insulin therapy.      

Option Analysis

❌ Glycolysis:
Incorrect: Glycolysis is the metabolic pathway that converts glucose into cellular energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). Without adequate insulin, intracellular glucose levels decrease and glycolysis is stunted.  
❌ Glycogenesis:
Incorrect: Glycogenesis is the process of glycogen synthesis whereby glucose molecules are added to chains of glycogen for storage. Insulin deficiency instead increases the breakdown of glycogen, known as glycogenolysis.   
❌ Lipogenesis:
Incorrect: Lipogenesis is the metabolic process that converts acetyl-CoA into triglycerides for energy storage in fat. The presence of insulin stimulates lipogenesis by activating the pyruvate dehydrogenase and acetyl-CoA pathways, leading to malonyl-CoA formation for use in fatty acid chains. However, this patient instead has a relative insulin deficiency.  
❌ Lipolysis:
Incorrect:  In type 1 diabetes, the absolute insulin deficiency leads to lipolysis, which is the breakdown of lipid triglycerides into a glycerol and three fatty acids. These fatty acids are then turned into ketones, causing diabetic ketoacidosis. In type 2 diabetes, there is enough endogenous insulin still produced to prevent lipolysis and ketogenesis.   
✅ Gluconeogenesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the primary care office complaining of mild fatigue and shortness of breath. The patient has a past medical history significant for episodes of jaundice and intermittent right upper quadrant abdominal pain, which he has never been to the doctor for before. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/88 mmHg. Physical examination shows splenomegaly. Laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below.  


Peripheral blood smear shows hexagonal crystals and target cells. This patient’s disease is most likely caused by a substitution of glutamic acid with which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
This patient with anemia, extramedullary hematopoiesis, and hexagonal crystals and target cells on peripheral blood smear has hemoglobin C (HbC) disease. HbC disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutated genes that encode for an abnormal adult hemoglobin called hemoglobin C (HbC). This mutation leads to a substitution of glutamic acid in the sixth position of the beta globin chain with lysine, and a mutation in both copies of the gene is needed to get the disease. If the person has just one copy of the mutation and one normal hemoglobin A gene (HbA), then he or she has HbC trait and is said to be a carrier of the disease. HbC carriers are also protected against malaria, because infected erythrocytes are removed by the spleen.  

HbC is less soluble than normal HbA, so it aggregates into crystals, which build up inside erythrocytes and make them more rigid. As a result of the decreased solubility of the hemoglobin, there is a relative membrane excess, and the erythrocytes start resembling a shooting target with a bullseye, seen as a dark center of hemoglobin, a ring of pallor, and an outer band of hemoglobin. These cells are known as target cells or codocytes. Erythrocytes do not appear sickled like in sickle cell disease, because unlike valine, lysine is positively charged. Therefore, there is no hydrophobic effect seen in HbC disease. Additionally, HbC, either in the homozygous state (HbCC) or in heterozygous states, induces red cell dehydration, resulting in red cells with an increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC).  


Reproduced from:

Hemoglobin C disease leads to both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis, resulting in increased RBC breakdown, causing jaundice and gallstones (intermittent RUQ abdominal pain), as well as anemia. There is also increased compensatory erythropoiesis in the bone marrow, leading to new bone formation, and extramedullary hematopoiesis and hepatomegaly.  

Definitive diagnosis is achieved via hemoglobin electrophoresis. Patients with hemoglobin C disease typically do not need treatment.


Option Analysis

❌ Glutamine:
Incorrect: This patient with anemia, extramedullary hematopoiesis, and hexagonal crystals on peripheral blood smear has hemoglobin C (HbC) disease. HbC disease is caused by a substitution of glutamic acid for lysine in the sixth position of the beta globin chain. Hexagonal crystals are formed due to lysine’s positively charged side chain. Glutamine’s side chain is polar but uncharged.
❌ Valine:
Incorrect: Glutamic acid is substituted for valine in sickle cell disease. However, this patient with hexagonal crystals on peripheral blood smear has hemoglobin C (HbC) disease. HbC disease is caused by a substitution of glutamic acid for lysine in the sixth position of the beta globin chain. Hexagonal crystals are formed due to lysine’s positively charged side chain. Valine’s side chain is hydrophobic.
✅ Lysine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Leucine:
Incorrect: This patient with anemia, extramedullary hematopoiesis, and hexagonal crystals on peripheral blood smear has hemoglobin C (HbC) disease. HbC disease is caused by a substitution of glutamic acid for lysine in the sixth position of the beta globin chain. Hexagonal crystals are formed due to lysine’s positively charged side chain. Leucine’s side chain is hydrophobic.
❌ Aspartic acid:
Incorrect: This patient with anemia, extramedullary hematopoiesis, and hexagonal crystals on peripheral blood smear has hemoglobin C (HbC) disease. HbC disease is caused by a substitution of glutamic acid for lysine in the sixth position of the beta globin chain. Hexagonal crystals are formed due to lysine’s positively charged side chain. Aspartic acid’s side chain is negatively charged.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of generalized body swelling. The swelling started 2 days ago when his parent noticed swelling around the patient’s eyes. Review of systems reveals mild shortness of breath after climbing a flight of stairs. The patient experienced an episode of flu-like symptoms and throat pain 2 weeks ago that responded to over-the-counter medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 155/92 mmHg. Physical examination shows periorbital pitting edema and 1+ generalized pitting edema. Pulmonary exam reveals bilateral fine expiratory crackles in the lower lobes. Complete blood count is normal. Serum chemistries and urinalysis findings are as follows:


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient with generalized edema, dyspnea, and hypertension, as well as hematuria, red blood cell casts, and mild proteinuria on urinalysis most likely has poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).  

PSGN is a result of a type III hypersensitivity reaction in response to bacterial M protein (virulence factor) that results in the formation of antigen-antibody complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, which then leads to complement activation and inflammation, resulting in nephritic syndrome. It usually occurs 2-4 weeks after a streptococcal pharyngeal (as in this patient) or skin (e.g. impetigo) infection. Clinical features and laboratory findings are described in the table below.


The prognosis is good, and renal biopsy is usually not indicated except for refractory cases. If a biopsy is performed, the histology reveals diffusely enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli, RBC casts in nephron tubules, and interstitial edema and inflammation. Electron microscopy shows antigen-antibody complexes as subepithelial deposits or “humps” along the glomerular basement membrane. These complexes can also be seen on immunofluorescence microscopy as granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3.  


Reproduced from:




Option Analysis

❌ Type II hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type II hypersensitivity reaction involves antibodies binding to cell-surface antigens, resulting in cellular destruction and inflammation. Goodpasture syndrome is a notable example of type II HSR that causes rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. However, it instead presents in the third decade of life with hematuria and hemoptysis, and it would not be associated with high ASO titers, such as in this patient.
✅ Type III hypersensitivity reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Type IV hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: In type IV hypersensitivity reaction, CD8+ T cells are involved in direct cell cytotoxicity and inflammation. Examples include contact dermatitis with poison ivy, PPD-induced skin induration and graft-versus-host disease. It does not involve antibodies, as seen in this patient with elevated ASO titers.
❌ Leukemoid reaction:
Incorrect: A leukemoid reaction is an increase in the leukocyte count which can mimic leukemia. The reaction is typically due to an infection or another disease. This patient’s body temperature and leukocyte count is normal.
❌ Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction:
Incorrect: This is a reaction whereby endotoxin-like molecules are released by the death of microorganisms, inducing an inflammatory response. It is uncommon and is observed during antibiotic treatment for spirochetal infection (e.g. syphilis). It usually manifests as fever, rigors, hypotension and tachycardia, not dyspnea and hematuria.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the office because of a cough and bloody sputum for 3 weeks. The onset of symptoms was preceded by sore throat and mild nasal congestion. He has no fever, weight loss, night sweats, or complaints of recurrent infections, but he does describe several episodes of red-colored urine. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 152/88 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral inspiratory crackles. There is 1+ peripheral pitting edema. Chest x-ray reveals bilateral infiltrates. Serum creatinine is 3.2 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows mild proteinuria, hematuria, and red blood cell casts. Renal biopsy specimen under immunofluorescence microscopy is shown:


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has nephritic syndrome (hematuria, hypertension, mild proteinuria), accompanied by hemoptysis and immunofluorescence findings of linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), which suggests a diagnosis of anti-GBM disease, previously called Goodpasture syndrome.  

Anti-GBM disease is an uncommon cause of glomerulonephritis that is caused by autoimmune antibodies directed against the components of the GBM (e.g. alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen). Antibody formation may be triggered by an antecedent viral upper respiratory infection but can be idiopathic. The antibodies induce a type II hypersensitivity reaction resulting in basement membrane damage of glomeruli and alveoli, leading to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) and alveolar hemorrhage.  

RPGN presents with nephritic syndrome. On renal biopsy, light microscopy reveals crescent-shaped deposits of fibrin, C3, and mononuclear cells. Immunofluorescence microscopy is characterized by linear deposits of IgG and complement along the GBM, a finding specific to anti-GBM disease. Alveolar hemorrhage presents with hemoptysis, cough, and dyspnea with infiltrates seen on chest x-ray.  

Treatment of anti-GBM disease includes plasmapheresis accompanied by immunosuppressants, such as glucocorticoids and cyclophosphamide. Plasmapheresis removes circulating anti-GBM antibodies and other mediators of inflammation, and the immunosuppressive agents minimize new antibody formation.

Option Analysis

❌ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Although granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) may also present with hemoptysis and nephritic syndrome, it is usually accompanied by fatigue, fever, weight loss, and history of recurrent rhinosinusitis. Chest x-ray shows necrotizing nodular or cavitary lesions, not interstitial infiltrates. Moreover, renal biopsy specimen under immunofluorescence microscopy reveals no deposits (pauci-immune), as opposed to this patient’s linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane.
✅ Anti-glomerular basement membrane syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a granulomatous, necrotizing, small vessel vasculitis that is associated with atopy, sinusitis, purpura, peripheral neuropathy and/or eosinophilia. When it involves the kidneys, it causes pauci-immune glomerulonephritis, in which no deposition is seen on immunofluorescence microscopy, as opposed to this patient’s linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane.
❌ Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is usually associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and often presents with findings of both nephritic and nephrotic syndromes. Renal biopsy findings include wire looping of capillaries on light microscopy. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals granular immune complex deposits, as opposed to this patient’s linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane. Additionally, pulmonary symptoms would be atypical.
❌ Amyloidosis:
Incorrect: Pulmonary findings in amyloidosis are limited to pleural effusions and parenchymal nodules, while renal involvement usually presents with asymptomatic proteinuria or clinically apparent nephrotic (not nephritic) syndrome. Renal biopsy findings include mesangial deposits of amyloid that are observed in Congo red staining as apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman comes to the office because of several episodes of dark brown urine. The episodes started 3 weeks ago. She has no recent history of skin infection, flu or diarrhea. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for deafness in her mother and renal failure in her maternal grandfather. She has a 26-year-old brother who is healthy. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 142/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals 1+ generalized pitting edema. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral yellow granulations in the retina suggestive of retinopathy. Complete blood count is normal. Urinalysis is shown below:


Renal biopsy findings reveal thinning and splitting of glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
The findings of retinopathy, nephritic syndrome (hematuria, periorbital edema, dysmorphic RBCs), and a family history of deafness and renal failure are classic for Alport syndrome.  

Alport syndrome (also known as hereditary nephritis) is a hereditary disorder that is caused by mutations in genes encoding members of the type IV collagen family which are found in the basement membranes of glomerulus (GBM) and cochlea, in addition to the lens capsule. It is mostly inherited in an X-linked dominant fashion, in which transmission can occur through both sexes. Mothers with a disease-causing X chromosome (XnX) can transmit it to both sons and daughters, while fathers can only transmit to daughters but not sons.  



The abnormal collagen results in progressive glomerular disease that is often associated with sensorineural hearing loss and ocular manifestations (anterior lenticonus, retinopathy). The condition is diagnosed on molecular genetic testing or renal biopsy. The latter reveals the characteristic finding of longitudinal splitting of the lamina densa of the GBM, making its appearance as a basket-weave under electron microscopy. Immunostaining for type IV collagen shows absence or discontinuous distribution of the alpha chains.

Option Analysis

❌ X-linked recessive:
Incorrect: Phenotypic expression of an X-linked recessive disorder is dependent on the sex of the child. All the males who inherit the defective X-chromosome display the phenotype whereas only homozygous females do (which is a very rare occurrence). As a result, the disorder cannot manifest in females in two consecutive generations.
✅ X-linked dominant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mitochondrial:
Incorrect: Mitochondrial DNA is only inherited from the mother, and disorders transmitted by mitochondrial inheritance are seen in all the progeny with variable expressivity. This patient’s maternal grandfather transmitted the disease to her mother, making this inheritance pattern very unlikely. Moreover, the patient’s brother is unaffected. Examples of mitochondrial diseases are Leber hereditary optic neuropathy and myoclonic epilepsy.
❌ Multifactorial:
Incorrect: Multifactorial inheritance involves numerous genetic and environmental factors that interact to determine phenotypic expression. Examples include neural tube defects, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. In general, these conditions have a lower risk of recurrence as compared to single-gene disorders.
❌ Autosomal recessive:
Incorrect: Phenotypic expression of autosomal recessive disorders require both parents to be carriers of the disease. It is usually observed in disorders with enzyme deficiencies like cystic fibrosis and glycogen storage diseases. This patient’s mother and maternal grandfather variably expressed the disease manifestations, making this mode of inheritance unlikely.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a cough and shortness of breath. His partner stated that overnight, the patient started “shaking” and had audible wheezing. Past medical history includes hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 134/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg. On physical exam, he is in respiratory distress, with use of accessory muscles of respiration and audible wheezing. Cardiopulmonary examination is notable for rales at the right lung base. Initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following arrhythmias is demonstrated on this patient’s electrocardiogram?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of a COPD exacerbation likely due to community acquired pneumonia. The electrocardiogram demonstrates a regular rhythm, tachycardia, and narrow QRS complexes with the presence of P-waves and T-waves, which is consistent with sinus tachycardia.   

Sinus tachycardia is a type of sinus rhythm defined as a rate greater than 100 beats per minute. On electrocardiogram, it appears as a regular rhythm with P-waves identified before each QRS complex.  The causes of sinus tachycardia are generally divided into non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic causes. Non-pharmacologic etiologies include exercise, sepsis, hyperthyroidism, pain, anxiety, volume loss, pulmonary embolism, and cardiogenic shock. Pharmacologic etiologies include ꞵ-agonists, sympathomimetics, caffeine, and antimuscarinics.  

In severe cases, sinus tachycardia actually decreases diastolic filling time, resulting in decreased cardiac output and tissue perfusion. Treatment is aimed at correcting the underlying etiology, such as via fluid repletion in low volume states.  



Option Analysis

✅ Sinus tachycardia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atrial flutter  :
Incorrect: Atrial flutter is defined by atrial depolarization occurring at a rate of 250 to 350 beats/min. It is usually caused by an atrial reentry circuit that runs around the tricuspid annulus. The condition is characterized by "flutter waves,” which have a sawtooth appearance, and the presence of multiple P-waves between QRS complexes. 
❌ Multifocal atrial tachycardia :
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying R-R intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. Patients with underlying pulmonary disease are predisposed to this tachyarrhythmia. In contrast, this patient’s rhythm is regular, and the P-waves are of similar morphology.   
❌ Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) is defined as an abnormally fast heart rate with irregularly irregular QRS complexes and absent P-waves. In contrast, this patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates regular rhythm and normal P-waves.  
❌ Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia :
Incorrect: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia, also referred to AV-nodal reentrant tachycardia, manifests with a regular rate, narrow QRS complexes, and absent P-waves. The presence of P-waves in this patient’s electrocardiogram precludes this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old female presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and lightheadedness. The patient’s symptoms started an hour ago while she was watching television at home. She had a similar episode that occurred several weeks ago and resolved without medical intervention. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is a non-smoker and drinks a glass of wine during the weekend. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 122/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam is otherwise unremarkable, and initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lightheadedness, shortness of breath, and an electrocardiogram demonstrating an irregularly irregular fast rhythm, without identifiable P-waves. These findings are consistent with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Of the sequelae listed, patients with atrial fibrillation are at highest risk of thromboembolic events.   

Patients with atrial fibrillation are at risk for several complications. Most notably, prolonged atrial fibrillation results in hemostasis, as blood is no longer pumped effectively throughout the body. Thrombi can then form (most commonly on the left atrial appendage), dislodge, and then travel to the brain resulting in embolic stroke. Prolonged atrial fibrillation also places patients at risk for high output cardiac failure and dilated cardiomyopathy. Additional complications include chronic kidney disease, myocardial infarction, and silent ischemia of other organ systems.

Management of atrial fibrillation is targeted at identifying the underlying etiology, achieving rate and rhythm control, and starting anticoagulation. Rate and rhythm control is achieved through the use of calcium channel blockers (e.g. diltiazem) or beta blockers (e.g. metoprolol). The need for anticoagulation is evaluated by calculating a patient's CHADs-VASc score, which takes into account a patient's history of hypertension, congestive heart failure, diabetes, stroke, as well as sex and age. Patients with appropriate risk factors should be started on an anticoagulation regimen.    



Option Analysis

✅ Thromboembolic stroke :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ischemic stroke :
Incorrect: Cerebral ischemia can result from atrial fibrillation due to decreased cardiac output during episodes with rapid ventricular response. However, the risk associated with thromboembolic stroke is higher. 
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy :
Incorrect: High output congestive heart failure and dilated cardiomyopathy may occur in patients with long-standing atrial fibrillation. However, the risk of developing these conditions is not as high as that of developing a thromboembolic stroke. 
❌ Chronic kidney disease :
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation can cause emboli to be released from the heart, potentially leading to renal infarction. Overtime, these infarctions can progress to chronic kidney disease. However, the risk of this complication is overall less than that of thromboembolic stroke.
❌ Myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Demand ischemia and myocardial infarction may result from prolonged episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. In contrast, this complication is less likely to occur during paroxysmal atrial fibrillation or atrial fibrillation without rapid ventricular response. Overall, amongst patients with atrial fibrillation, the risk of myocardial infarction is less than that of thromboembolic stroke.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the primary care physician after sustaining a needle stick injury at work. He works as a nurse in the emergency department and reports he sustained an accidental needlestick injury in the emergency department several weeks ago while placing an IV line. He did not initially seek treatment as he was asymptomatic, but he became concerned after he developed fatigue, malaise, and a low-grade fever several days ago. His laboratory findings are demonstrated below:

If left untreated which of the following is the most likely clinical course of this disease process?
questions.solution:
This healthcare worker presents after sustaining a needlestick injury at work, and his laboratory findings are consistent with chronic hepatitis C infection and previous hepatitis B vaccination. Of the clinical courses listed, most patients with hepatitis C go on to develop a chronic infection and carrier state.  

Hepatitis C is an enveloped single-stranded RNA flavivirus that is primarily transmitted parenterally—e.g. through needlestick injury, intravenous drug use, dialysis, or blood transfusions. Most patients who become infected undergo a long incubation period (2 weeks to 6 months) before symptoms, if any, develop. After acute symptoms, which are usually non-specific viral symptoms, the majority of patients (50-85%) go on to be chronic carriers of hepatitis C, while a minority spontaneously clear the infection.  

Around 5-30% of patients who are chronic carriers develop cirrhosis and end-stage liver disease, which may ultimately be the only signs of infection, even after 20-30 years of viral incubation. Of the patients who develop cirrhosis, a small percentage—approximately 5%—will go on to develop hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic infection and carrier state:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Complete resolution:
Incorrect: Approximately 20-30% of patients will completely clear hepatitis C following acute infection. In contrast, approximately 95% of primary hepatitis B infections in immunocompetent adults are self-limited, with elimination of the virus from blood and general immunity to reinfection.
❌ Cirrhosis:
Incorrect: Of patients who develop chronic hepatitis C, approximately 10-20% will go on to develop cirrhosis after 20-30 years of active infection.
❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma:
Incorrect: There is an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with hepatitis C infection; however, it is not the most common clinical course.
❌ Superinfection:
Incorrect: Superinfection occurs when a patient who is a chronic carrier of hepatitis B becomes infected with hepatitis D. This patient’s viral hepatitis panel shows immunity against hepatitis B (positive anti-HBs), with a current hepatitis C infection.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. She currently lives in a rehabilitation facility, where she is undergoing rehabilitation after having a total hip replacement. Past medical history is notable for COPD, type II diabetes mellitus, osteoarthritis, and hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 84/60 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 76% on room air. On physical exam, the patient is in respiratory distress with clammy and cool extremities. Cardiopulmonary exam is notable for jugular venous distension but is otherwise unremarkable. ECG is demonstrated below:

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Systemic release of histamine and associated inflammatory mediators
Occlusion of the right coronary artery

questions.solution:
This patient has profound hypotension, hypoxemia, and cool clammy extremities in the setting of a recent surgery and prolonged immobilization. Her overall clinical presentation is consistent with a massive pulmonary embolism resulting in obstructive shock and ventilation perfusion mismatch. Her presentation warrants consideration for treatment with thrombolytic therapy, which will break down the thrombus.  

Obstructive shock described impaired end-organ perfusion due to physical obstruction of circulation either into or out of the heart. It falls under the umbrella of “cold shock”, which manifests with clammy and cool extremities due to decreased cardiac output and increased systemic vascular resistance to shunt blood towards vital organs.  

There are three primary causes of obstructive shock: pulmonary embolism, pericardial tamponade, and tension pneumothorax. A pulmonary embolism manifests with obstructive shock due to the right heart's inability to pump blood through the pulmonary vasculature, causing profound V/Q mismatch, jugular venous distension, hypoxemia, and compromised left ventricular cardiac output. Pericardial tamponade refers to accumulation of blood or fluid in the pericardial sac, of which there are numerous causes including trauma, uremia, and pericarditis. When the amount of pericardial fluid reaches a critical threshold, ventricular filling and outflow becomes compromised, warranting pericardiocentesis. Lastly, a tension pneumothorax results in compression of mediastinal structures and causes decreased venous return and stroke volume. Treatment involves rapid decompression with needle thoracostomy followed by chest tube placement.



Option Analysis

✅ V/Q mismatch:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased venous return:
Incorrect: Hypovolemic shock is associated with decreased venous return to the heart. This patient’s clinical presentation of chest pain and shortness of breath in the setting of a recent surgery is more consistent with pulmonary embolism, which results in a ventilation perfusion deficit.
❌ Systemic release of histamine and associated inflammatory mediators:
Incorrect: Anaphylaxis falls under the category of distributive or “warm” shock and is due to systemic release of histamine as well as other inflammatory mediators. Unlike obstructive shock, which is associated with cool extremities, anaphylaxis is associated with warm extremities. Additional clues for anaphylactic shock include a history of exposure to an allergen (e.g. bee sting) or presence of a diffuse erythematous rash.
❌ Occlusion of the right coronary artery:
Incorrect: Cardiogenic shock can result from occlusion of the right coronary artery. This type of shock may manifest with right ventricular failure, jugular venous distension, and lethal arrhythmias resulting in compromised cardiac output. Occlusion of the right coronary artery manifests with ST-elevations in leads II, III, and aVF. This patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates sinus tachycardia, making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Left ventricular outflow obstruction:
Incorrect: Pericardial tamponade is a type of obstructive shock that can cause left ventricular outflow obstruction. Clues to this diagnosis include a history of penetrating trauma to the chest, uremia, malignancy, and presence of Beck triad (muffled heart tones, jugular venous distension, and hypotension). An ECG will typically demonstrate “electrical alternans” due to the oscillations of the heart within the pericardium.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with shortness of breath and cough. She reports her symptoms started after she began working in a coal mine several months ago, and they have increased in severity. She also reports diffuse arthralgias in her hands which is worse in the morning and improves after about two-hours of working. Temperature 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 138/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination is notable for diffuse pulmonary rales as well as the finding depicted below:  


Reproduced from: wikipedia    

Laboratory studies reveal rheumatoid factor is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This coal miner presents with findings of interstitial lung disease and rheumatoid arthritis (ulnar deviation depicted above) consistent with Caplan syndrome, a type of pneumoconiosis.  

Caplan syndrome refers to a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis that manifests with intrapulmonary nodules on chest x-ray. Patients with this disorder will have typical features of rheumatoid arthritis including painful joints and morning stiffness, as well as tender, swollen metacarpophalangeal joints and rheumatoid nodules. In addition, patients will have a history of exposure to inorganic particulate matter such as asbestos, silicosis, or coal dust and subsequent decline in pulmonary function.    

Rheumatoid arthritis alters how the immune system responds to these foreign particles, resulting in accelerated development of multiple peripheral basilar nodules and lung fibrosis. There is immune hyperactivity that is initiated by silica exposure in which monocytes and macrophages release cytokines such as interleukin-1 and tumor necrosis factor alpha. Lymphocytes are subsequently activated by the cytokines released by macrophages, leading to an autoimmune phenomenon in genetically predisposed individuals who have RA. Ultimately, this leads to the development of impaired diffusion interface for gas exchange, decreased lung compliance, and a restrictive lung disease pattern.  

Option Analysis

✅ Caplan syndrome :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emphysema :
Incorrect: Emphysema describes permanent alveoli enlargement and loss of alveolar wall elasticity. It is most commonly caused by an irritant, such as tobacco smoke, which triggers inflammation in the alveoli. Inflammatory cells (e.g. neutrophils) gather in the lungs and release destructive proteases, which degrade connective tissue in the alveolar walls.  
❌ Asthma :
Incorrect: Asthma is an obstructive lung disease that presents with wheezing in response to inhaled particulate matter. This patient has evidence of rales, which is instead concerning for an interstitial pulmonary inflammatory process.  
❌ Anthracosis :
Incorrect: Anthracosis is an asymptomatic condition found in many urban dwellers exposed to sooty air. It is characterized by small areas of blackened lung tissue, reflective of inhaled carbon.   
❌ Sarcoidosis :
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis can present with findings consistent with interstitial lung disease and polyarthropathy; however, it is usually associated with additional clinical features such as lymphadenopathy, uveitis, or Bell's palsy. Additionally, sarcoidosis is not classically associated with a positive rheumatoid factor.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with a dry cough and shortness of breath. He reports worsening symptoms for months and states he is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. He usually drinks two beers everyday after he finishes his work as a sandblaster for the city government. Vitals are within normal limits. His physical examination is unremarkable. He undergoes spirometry which demonstrates an increased FEV1/FVC ratio. Which of the following radiographic features is most likely to be observed based on this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Nodular opacities and hilar lymph node calcification of the upper lobes
Small, rounded nodular opacities of the upper lobes
Reticular bilateral opacities of the lower lobes
Small bilateral opacities throughout both lungs sparring the apices and the bases
Honeycombing pattern of the upper lobes

questions.solution:
This patient who works as a sandblaster presents with worsening shortness of breath and a dry cough, concerning silicosis. Of the choices listed, nodular opacities and hilar lymph node calcification of the upper lobes (also referred to as egg shell calcification) is most commonly associated with silicosis.  

Clues to the etiology of a restrictive lung disease can often be elicited from the anatomic location of disease on chest radiographic or chest CT. Diseases that tend to affect the upper lobes of the lung include: sarcoidosis (late), silicosis, berylliosis, and coal workers pneumoconiosis.   

Diseases that tend to affect the lower lobes include asbestosis and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Diseases that tend to have a diffuse or non-specific pattern include sarcoidosis, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and medication toxicities.    



Option Analysis

✅ Nodular opacities and hilar lymph node calcification of the upper lobes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Small, rounded nodular opacities of the upper lobes :
Incorrect: Coal workers pneumoconiosis manifests with nodular opacities of the upper lobes and is most commonly asymptomatic. Patients at risk for this disease include those who work in coal mines. 
❌ Reticular bilateral opacities of the lower lobes :
Incorrect: Asbestosis predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung and is more prominent in those who work in shipbuilding, roofing, plumbing, and manufacturing.  
❌ Small bilateral opacities throughout both lungs sparring the apices and the bases:
Incorrect: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis results in a diffuse reticular pattern that does not predominantly affect the upper or lower lobes. Clinically, patients with this disease have repeated exposure to an offending antigen—such as bird breeders. 
❌ Honeycombing pattern of the upper lobes :
Incorrect: Late stage sarcoidosis tends to present with a honeycombing pattern affecting the upper lobes of the lung. This patient has no other associated clinical features of sarcoidosis (e.g. erythema nodosum).

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman presents for evaluation of recurrent diarrhea and lower abdominal pain of several years duration. The patient has not been previously evaluated for this issue. Past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medication. Her temperature is 38.2 °C (100.8°F), pulse is 80/minute, respirations are 16/minute, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Stool culture is negative for growth. Colonoscopy demonstrates cobblestone mucosa and transmural inflammation. Biopsy of the ileum is shown below.  


Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons  

Which of the following clinical features is most likely to be associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with episodic diarrhea and abdominal pain, with colonoscopy findings of cobblestone mucosa and transmural inflammation, is strongly suggestive of Crohn disease, a type of inflammatory bowel disease. Biopsy reveals a non-caseating granuloma and lymphoid aggregates, confirming the diagnosis. Of the answer choices listed, only sacroiliitis is associated with this condition.  

Multiple extra-intestinal manifestations are associated with IBD including pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum, episcleritis, uveitis, oral ulcerations and spondyloarthropathy (SpA). IBD-associated SpA usually manifests with sacroiliitis and spondylitis (low back pain with stiffness that improves with movement), peripheral arthritis (most commonly involving the knee), enthesitis (inflammation and tenderness where tendons insert on joint) and dactylitis (sausage fingers). Most of the affected patients are HLA-B27 positive (characteristic of seronegative arthropathy). Treating IBD adequately also improves the symptoms of IBD-associated SpA.  

Option Analysis

✅ Sacroiliitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Esophageal dysmotility:
Incorrect: Esophageal dysmotility is associated with systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome), which manifests with puffy taut skin and finger pitting without wrinkles. This condition presents with dysphagia and/or heartburn--diarrhea and abdominal pain are atypical. 
❌ Optic neuritis:
Incorrect: Optic neuritis is strongly associated with multiple sclerosis (MS), an inflammatory demyelinating condition which presents with recurrent ocular symptoms (e.g., diplopia, internuclear ophthalmoplegia), numbness, and paresthesias. Gastrointestinal involvement is atypical. Moreover, anterior uveitis, not optic neuritis, is associated with IBD. 
❌ Keratoconjunctivitis sicca:
Incorrect: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca refers to decreased tear production resulting in corneal damage. It is associated with Sjögren syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by exocrine gland destruction. Xerostomia (decreased saliva production) is commonly found. Lower gastrointestinal tract involvement, however, is atypical. 
❌ Oral and genital ulcerations:
Incorrect: Oral and genital ulcerations in conjunction with iritis and occasional central nervous system involvement  are characteristically found in Behçet syndrome. Abdominal pain and diarrhea can be seen in Behçet syndrome; however, endoscopy shows discrete ulcerations rather than transmural inflammation.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old female comes to her primary care provider due to fatigue and intense pruritus for the last 2 months. She works as a schoolteacher and has felt excessive daytime somnolence that is interfering with her job. Past medical history is significant for chronic autoimmune (Hashimoto) thyroiditis, for which she has been taking daily levothyroxine. She drinks 1-2 glasses of wine on the weekends and denies smoking tobacco or using illicit substances. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals multiple excoriations on her trunk and extremities. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the costal margin and is not tender to palpation. Laboratory results are as follows:



Which of the following complications is associated with this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with pruritus, fatigue, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory testing reveals an elevated alkaline phosphatase, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and anti-mitochondrial antibodies. These findings are suggestive of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), which predisposes patients to osteoporosis and pathologic fractures.  

PBC is an autoimmune disease that results in inflammatory destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts. Unlike primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), the extrahepatic biliary tree is unaffected. PBC primarily affects middle-aged women, with a peak incidence between 40-50 years of age.  

Most patients are diagnosed while asymptomatic because of abnormalities in routine liver biochemical tests, such as elevated serum alkaline phosphatase or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Patients are also positive for anti-mitochondrial antibodies.  

Common clinical symptoms arise from cholestasis, such as fatigue and pruritus. Early treatment with oral ursodeoxycholic acid has been shown to significantly slow disease progression, likely due to its ability to enter the bile acid pool and alter the biochemical composition of bile. However, even with treatment, patients are at increased risk of osteomalacia and osteoporosis. The exact mechanism behind this association is unclear, but is thought to be a result of several factors, including 1) malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins secondary to decreased bile acid secretion and 2) reduced new bone formation.



Option Analysis

✅ Femoral neck fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pretibial and periorbital edema:
Incorrect: Generalized myxedema can be seen in patients with hypothyroidism due to increased deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the dermis and mucous membranes. This patient has a normal TSH level, suggesting that her hypothyroidism is well managed.
❌ Inflammatory bowel disease:
Incorrect: Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), such as Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis, can be seen in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC can present similarly to primary biliary cholangitis; however, patients with PSC will typically be positive for p-ANCA antibodies, not anti-mitochondrial antibodies.
❌ Cholangiocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Cholangiocarcinoma is a complication of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), which may present similarly to PBC. The risk for cholangiocarcinoma may be slightly increased in patients with PBC, but the association is still unclear.
❌ Vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels:
Incorrect: Polyarteritis nodosa, a systemic vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels, can be seen in patients with hepatitis B infection. This patient’s laboratory results are positive for anti-HBsAg antibodies, which indicates the patient is immune to hepatitis B and does not have a chronic infection.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the clinic due to worsening fatigue and abdominal distension. The patient has lost 11 pounds in the last 2 months with minimal change in appetite. Past medical history is notable for chronic liver disease due to hepatitis B infection that was diagnosed 15 years ago. His most recent colonoscopy 1 year ago showed no abnormalities. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 154/89 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals temporal wasting and scleral icterus. Palmar erythema and multiple spider angiomas are present. The abdomen is distended with shifting dullness to percussion. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Ultrasound shows a single homogenous liver mass with irregular borders. Which of the following best describes the tumor marker that is likely elevated in this patient?

choices.text: Glycoprotein normally produced by the fetal yolk sac
Hormone produced by the placenta after embryonal implantation
Cell-surface glycoprotein found on Müllerian-type epithelium
Protein normally present in cells derived from the neural crest

questions.solution:
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a malignant, usually solitary, tumor of the liver that primarily occurs in patients with preexisting liver cirrhosis or chronic hepatitis. The most important underlying factors in HCC are viral infections (e.g., hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus) and toxin-mediated injuries (e.g., aflatoxin, alcohol). These factors cause the liver to be in a constant cycle of damage and repair, which raise the chances of genetic mutations, potentially leading to carcinogenesis and development of HCC. Therefore, in regions where HBV and HCV (and therefore, cirrhosis) are common, there is a high incidence of HCC.  

Clinical manifestations of HCC are typically due to underlying cirrhosis (e.g., ascites, pitting edema), but patients may also present with systemic signs such as weight loss, malaise, and fatigue. As the tumor grows, abdominal distension and anorexia (due to compression of the stomach) may occur. Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is a tumor marker associated with HCC. AFP is a glycoprotein normally produced by the fetal yolk sac, and is therefore also elevated in yolk sac tumors. Additional diagnostic studies involve liver imaging (e.g., ultrasound, CT, MRI) and would typically show a hypodense lesion with irregular borders.  




Image reproduced from

Option Analysis

✅ Glycoprotein normally produced by the fetal yolk sac:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hormone produced by the placenta after embryonal implantation:
Incorrect: ꞵ-hCG is a hormone produced by the placenta after implantation. It can be used as a tumor-marker to detect recurrence and response to treatment for seminomas, choriocarcinomas, germ cell tumors, and teratomas; however, it is not typically elevated in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.
❌ Glycoprotein involved in cell adhesion:
Incorrect: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a group of proteins involved in cell adhesion and is normally produced during embryonic development by cells of the gastrointestinal tract; therefore, it is commonly elevated in patients with colorectal cancer. However, it would not be elevated in this patient with hepatocellular carcinoma.
❌ Cell-surface glycoprotein found on Müllerian-type epithelium:
Incorrect: Carcinoembryonic antigen-125 (CA-125) is a cell-surface glycoprotein found on cells derived from the Müllerian ducts. The Müllerian ducts form the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper ⅓ of the vagina. CA-125 is used as a marker for epithelial ovarian tumors and other tumors arising from the Müllerian ducts. However, it is unlikely to be elevated in this patient with hepatocellular carcinoma.
❌ Protein normally present in cells derived from the neural crest:
Incorrect: S-100 is a cytoplasmic protein that can be used as a tumor marker on immunohistochemical staining, especially in cells derived from the neural crest. It is usually associated with malignant melanoma, neurofibromas, and peripheral sheath tumors. It would not be elevated in this patient with hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a two-day history of nausea, vomiting, and confusion. According to the patient's partner, she has lost 5 lbs (2.2 kg) in the past three months and often wakes up at night soaked in sweat. Medical history is unremarkable. The patient has a 50-pack-year smoking history. At the time of arrival, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Physical examination shows a somnolent female with moist mucous membranes and no jugular venous distention. Serum osmolality is 245 mOsm/kg and urine osmolality is 450 mOsm/kg. A chest X-ray is obtained (see image below).  


Reproduced from: Radiopedia     

Additional work-up would most likely show which of the following set of findings?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of unintentional weight loss and night sweats, together with a history of smoking and chest x-ray findings of a left upper lobe mass, are all suggestive of a lung malignancy. In addition, this patient has syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), most likely due to ectopic ADH production by the lung mass.  

In SIADH, excess ADH secretion increases water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules, resulting in mild water retention, hyponatremia, low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality. In turn, the body reduces aldosterone production, which increases urinary sodium excretion and eliminates some of the excess water. The net result is euvolemic hyponatremia.

Mild and moderate hyponatremia may present symptomatically as headaches, nausea, vomiting, and muscle cramps. In cases of severe hyponatremia, patients can also present with confusion, seizures and coma.  

Option Analysis

❌   Serum sodium Aldosterone level Volume status 145 mEq/dL  ↓  Hypervolemic :
Incorrect: The patient’s symptoms of nausea, vomiting and altered mental status are more consistent with those of hyponatremia. Moreover, the patient has no signs of hypervolemia (e.g., peripheral edema, ascites, jugular venous distention) on physical examination.  
❌   Serum sodium Aldosterone level Volume status 152 mEq/dL  ↑ Euvolemic:
Incorrect: This answer describes euvolemic hypernatremia. However, the patient’s symptoms are more consistent with that of hyponatremia. In addition, it would be atypical to observe elevated aldosterone levels (which increase sodium and fluid reuptake) in patients with adequate volume status and elevated sodium levels.
❌   Serum sodium Aldosterone level Volume status  120 mEq/dL ↑ Hypervolemic :
Incorrect: Conditions such as congestive heart failure and liver cirrhosis can present with hypervolemic hyponatremia. Patients with these conditions often have reduced effective arterial blood volume (due to reduced cardiac output or splanchnic vasodilation), which activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. The patient in this vignette has none of the aforementioned conditions.
✅   Serum sodium Aldosterone level Volume status  120 mEq/dL ↓ Euvolemic :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌   Serum sodium Aldosterone level Volume status 120 mEq/dL ↑ Euvolemic :
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette has SIADH, which presents with euvolemic hyponatremia. However, such patients generally have reduced aldosterone production because the increased ADH causes water retention. By reducing aldosterone production, the body is able to increase urinary sodium excretion, thereby eliminating some of the excess water via urine.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with fatigue, abdominal pain, and frequent “muscle twitching.” She describes that her muscles spasm easily, and she is constantly craving salty foods. The patient has had irregular menstrual cycles and an inability to become pregnant despite having unprotected intercourse with her husband for five months. Her vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination reveals hyperpigmented palmar creases and carpo-pedal spasm. Genetic analysis demonstrates an autosomal recessive condition due to mutations in the AIRE gene. Which of the following findings is most often associated with this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of primary adrenal insufficiency, hypogonadism, and hypoparathyroidism. In addition, her work-up reveals mutations in the AIRE gene, which is consistent with polyglandular autoimmune syndrome(PGAS)type I. Of the clinical features listed, these patients are most susceptible to recurrent mucocutaneous candida infections.  

Two important causes of autoimmune adrenalitis are polyglandular autoimmune syndrome types I and II. Type I is due to mutations in the AIRE gene, which serves important immunological tolerance roles. Mutations in this gene result in autoimmune dysfunction of multiple organs, leading to primary adrenal insufficiency, hypogonadism, hypoparathyroidism, and recurrent infections with commensal organisms such as candida.  

Polyglandular autoimmune syndrome type II is associated with mutations in multiple genes affecting immune tolerance, and it is also associated with primary adrenal insufficiency and hypogonadism. However, this disease is further characterized by the presence of type I diabetes and autoimmune thyroiditis.  

In either condition, the presence of autoimmune adrenalitis can be diagnosed by identifying elevated titers of anti-adrenal antibodies.  



Option Analysis

✅ White plaques on the tongue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fasting blood glucose >126 mg/dL:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus, especially type I, is often found in patients with polyglandular autoimmune syndrome (PGAS) type II. However, PGAS type II would not account for this patient’s symptoms of hypocalcemia (muscle spasms).
❌ Antithyroglobulin antibodies:
Incorrect: Antithyroglobulin antibodies are found in patients with polyglandular autoimmune syndrome type II, not type I.  
❌ Anticardiolipin antibodies:
Incorrect: Anticardiolipin antibodies are sometimes found in patients with polyglandular autoimmune syndrome (PGAS) type II. They are more commonly found in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or antiphospholipid syndrome. However, this patient’s presentation is not consistent with any of the aforementioned conditions.
❌ Mutation in the RET gene:
Incorrect: Mutation of the RET gene, which codes for a receptor tyrosine kinase, can cause multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A. MEN 2A is associated with conditions including parathyroid hyperplasia, pheochromocytoma, and medullary thyroid cancer.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of worsening productive cough and fevers over the last few days. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension that is well-controlled with metoprolol. He recently completed a course of antibiotics for cellulitis of the left shin. He actively smokes, has a 15-pack-year smoking history, and drinks 2-3 beers on the weekends. He rarely exercises. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals dullness to percussion and bronchial breath sounds over the left lung. Chest radiograph demonstrates a left lower lobe consolidation. Sputum microscopy shows Gram-positive diplococci. Which of the following is the most important risk factor for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fevers, productive cough, and lobar consolidation, which are all suggestive of pneumonia. The presence of Gram-positive diplococci in the sputum indicates the underlying pathogen is most likely Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is one of the most common causes of community-acquired pneumonia. 

The innate defense mechanisms of the airways and lungs include the cough reflex, gag reflex (also termed pharyngeal reflex), mucociliary clearance, as well as the epithelial barrier itself. Therefore, alterations in the function of these protective factors can predispose individuals to developing pneumonia and other respiratory infections. For instance, mucociliary clearance occurs by organized ciliary movements that facilitate removal of inhaled pathogens and particulate material from the distal airway toward the pharynx. Smoking can impair mucociliary clearance by causing mucus overproduction and decreased ciliary beat frequency. Additionally, alcohol abuse can cause decreased cough and gag reflexes, thereby increasing the risk for pathogen aspiration or inhalation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Alcohol use :
Incorrect: Chronic alcohol use is a risk factor for developing aspiration pneumonia since alcohol intoxication can lead to impaired cough and gag reflexes. However, this patient consumes 2-3 beers/week, which would not be enough to cause significant intoxication. Furthermore, aspiration pneumonia is typically caused by the mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacteria that are found in the oral flora. 
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension has not been demonstrated to be a significant risk factor for developing pneumonia. 
❌ Sedentary lifestyle:
Incorrect: Although a sedentary lifestyle can predispose patients to more severe forms of cardiovascular disease, it is not a significant risk factor for developing pneumonia. 
✅ Cigarette smoking :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent antibiotic use:
Incorrect: Recent antibiotic use can increase a patient's risk for Clostridium difficile diarrhea. However, it is not known to be a risk factor for developing pneumonia.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of a mole on the left arm. The patient first noticed the mole 3 years ago and reports that it has not changed in size. The lesion is neither painful nor pruritic. Medical history is notable for asthma, for which she intermittently uses an albuterol inhaler. Her father was recently diagnosed with melanoma. She is part of her university’s cross-country team and has had several episodes of sunburn over the past year. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 115/71 mmHg, and pulse is 67/min. Examination of the patient’s left upper arm reveals the following finding:

 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

 The lesion is flat and soft to palpation. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of the patient’s skin finding?

choices.text: Benign proliferation of melanocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction
Benign proliferation of melanocytes in the dermis
Infiltration of lymphocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction

questions.solution:
This patient has a nevus (also termed mole), which occurs due to melanocyteproliferation.  

Nevi can broadly be classified into congenital versus acquired. Congenital melanocytic nevi are present at birth or appear within the first few months of life. They usually have hair growing out of them. On the other hand, acquired melanocytic nevi appear later in life. Patients with familial predisposition, sun exposure, and lightly pigmented skin are at increased risk of developing acquired nevi.  

Acquired nevi can further be classified as common or atypical. Common nevi are benign tumors of melanocytes. They are symmetrical, evenly pigmented, have well-demarcated borders, and small (diameter < 5 mm). Common nevi can then be divided into junctional and intradermal nevi. Junctional nevi, which are characterized by the proliferation of melanocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction, typically manifest as flat macules. Intradermal nevi, which are characterized by the proliferation of melanocytes within the dermis, typically manifest as elevated papules.    

Lastly, there are atypical nevi, which are asymmetrical, inconsistently pigmented, and large (diameter > 5 mm) with irregular borders. Although almost all nevi technically bear the risk of turning into malignant melanoma, atypical nevi carry a higher risk and hence are considered precursors to melanoma.

Figure 1: Classification of melanocytic nevi

Option Analysis

✅ Benign proliferation of melanocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Benign proliferation of melanocytes in the dermis :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes an intradermal nevus, which are often elevated and fibrotic. In contrast, this patient’s nevus is flat and soft.   
❌ Malignant proliferation of melanocytes :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes malignant melanoma. The ABCDE rule (Asymmetrical, Border irregularities, Color inconsistency, Diameter enlarges, Evolving lesion) can be used to distinguish malignant melanoma from benign lesions. This patient’s lesion is symmetrical, has well-defined borders, is of uniform color, and has not changed in size, making melanoma unlikely. 
❌ Benign proliferation of keratinocytes:
Incorrect: Seborrheic keratosis occurs secondary to the benign proliferation of keratinocytes. The condition manifests with darkly pigmented, greasy, “stuck-on” lesions. The condition most often affects the elderly. In contrast, it would be atypical for seborrheic keratosis to affect a patient in her 20s.
❌ Infiltration of lymphocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction :
Incorrect: Lichen planus is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration at the dermal-epidermal junction. The condition causes the development of purple, pruritic, papules and plaques. In contrast, this patient’s lesion is brownish-black in color and non-pruritic.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of facial muscle weakness that started two months ago. He complains of difficulty chewing halfway through a meal that is associated with difficulty swallowing. He also reports “seeing-double,” usually at the end of the day. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He takes hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history. In the office, his temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 148/83 mmHg. During the physical examination, the patient is asked to look upwards toward the ceiling for 60 seconds. This maneuver elicits bilateral diplopia, which resolves after several minutes of rest. Neck and cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals a serum creatinine kinase of 65 U/L. Work-up should be initiated for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient with fatigable chewing, dysphagia and diplopia that is exacerbated with activity most likely has myasthenia gravis (MG), an autoimmune condition that causes varying degrees of skeletal muscle weakness. The condition has a bimodal distribution, most commonly affecting women in their 20s and 30s and men in their 60s and 70s. It occurs due to the formation of autoantibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on muscle cells.  

The hallmark symptom is muscle weakness that worsens after repeated activity and improves after rest. Patients may complain of ptosis and diplopia secondary to extraocular muscle weakness early in the course of the disease. Later on, bulbar muscles involvement can result in slurred speech, difficulty chewing, and choking. Neck muscles involvement can cause patients to feel that their head is heavy and difficult to keep upright. Lastly, involvement of the proximal limb muscles can result in difficulty climbing stairs, combing hair, or brushing teeth.    

Approximately 75% of patients with MG have associated thymic abnormalities (e.g., thymic hyperplasia, thymoma), and mediastinal imaging should be performed in every patient to actively rule them out. Other less common associations of MG include bronchogenic carcinoma, hyperthyroidism, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Thymoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Polymyositis:
Incorrect: Polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that most often affects proximal muscles, such as those in the hip and shoulder. In contrast, it would be atypical for polymyositis to predominantly affect the extraocular muscles. Moreover, patients with polymyositis will generally have elevated creatinine kinase levels, whereas this patient’s level is normal.
❌ Small cell lung cancer:
Incorrect: Patients with small cell lung cancer can develop Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which occurs when auto-antibodies develop against presynaptic calcium channels. LEMS manifests with muscle weakness that improves with activity. In contrast, this patient has muscle weakness that is exacerbated by activity, which is more consistent with myasthenia gravis.
❌ Cushing disease:
Incorrect: Cushing disease is a state of hypercortisolism secondary to ACTH overproduction by a pituitary adenoma. Patients may experience muscle atrophy and weakness, but these symptoms are usually accompanied by thin extremities/truncal obesity due to fat redistribution, abdominal striae, and headaches, none of which are seen in this patient.
❌ Multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Common ocular findings in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) include optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia (which can cause diplopia) and nystagmus, though extraocular muscle weakness can sometimes occur. The condition is usually associated with sensory abnormalities (e.g. numbness), cognitive impairment, and autonomic dysfunction, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, MS most often affects young females.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for skin lesions most prominent at the armpits and neck. In addition, the patient has a history of irregular menstrual cycles that occur every 2-3 months. She has not had any recent weight loss, fatigue, nausea, or weakness. Family history is notable for Addison disease in her mother. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 130/74 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. BMI is 31 kg/m2. Examination of the patient’s bilateral axillae reveals the following finding:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

 Similar lesions are found in the neck folds. They are neither painful nor pruritic. Examination of the face reveals hair growth on the upper lip and chin. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings are consistent with acanthosis nigricans, which is characterized by the development of velvet-like, gray to brown hyperpigmented plaques. Typically, acanthosis nigricans appears on the skin of intertriginous sites, such as the neck, groin, and axillae. In rare cases, it can appear in other skin sites or on mucosal surfaces. The condition is due to epidermal hyperplasia of the stratum spinosum.  

Acanthosis nigricans is associated with a variety of underlying systemic disorders that are characterized by insulin resistance, such as obesity, diabetes mellitus, Cushing syndrome, and polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). In the case of this patient, her history of irregular menstrual cycles and physical examination findings of hirsutism are most consistent with PCOS.    

In rare cases, acanthosis nigricans can be associated with internal malignancy, especially gastric adenocarcinoma. Therefore, if an elderly, non-obese individual presents with new onset acanthosis nigricans, it is important to consider the possibility of an occult malignancy.    

Diagnosis is clinical, and individuals should be screened for underlying disorders. Treatment involves addressing the underlying disorder, as well as topical treatments, such as retinoids or laser therapy.



Option Analysis

✅ Insulin resistance :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Occult malignancy:
Incorrect: Malignancies, such as gastric, uterine, or lung cancer, can cause acanthosis nigricans as a paraneoplastic phenomenon. However, this patient has no symptoms that are concerning for cancer (e.g., weight loss, night sweats). In contrast, the patient’s history of irregular menstrual periods and hirsutism are more consistent with polycystic ovarian syndrome.  
❌ Cortisol deficiency :
Incorrect: Addison disease is characterized by the loss of adrenal gland function. Patients develop hypocortisolism, and the body attempts to compensate by increased ACTH production. Melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) is cleaved from the same precursor as ACTH; therefore, increased ACTH production would also lead to increased MSH production, with resultant hyperpigementation. However, in patients with Addison disease, the hyperpigmentation tends to be generalized. In contrast, this patient’s lesions are localized to the neck and axillae. Additionally, most patients present with weakness, weight loss, and fatigue, none of which are seen in this patient.  
❌ Melanocyte proliferation:
Incorrect: Benign melanocyte proliferation can result in the formation of nevi, whereas malignant melanocyte proliferation can result in melanoma. However, it would be atypical for either condition to manifest as a greyish-brown hyperpigmented plaque. 
❌ Fungal infection :
Incorrect: Infection by fungi from the Malassezia species can result in changes to skin pigmentation. Patients can develop either hypo- or hyperpigmentation. However, lesions secondary to fungal infection tend to be pruritic. Moreover, this patient’s history of irregular menstrual periods and hirsutism are more consistent with polycystic ovarian syndrome, which can cause insulin resistance and the subsequent development of acanthosis nigricans.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider because of a chronic cough for the past 3 months. It is occasionally accompanied by flecks of blood-tinged sputum.
