Review of systems is significant for weakness in the hips and thighs bilaterally and 15 lbs (6.8 kg) weight loss. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. He only takes hydrochlorothiazide. Social history is notable for a 50-pack-year smoking history. In the office, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min and blood pressure is 157/85 mmHg. Pulmonary examination reveals expiratory wheezing on the left side in 5th intercostal space. A chest radiograph is ordered and reveals the following:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia.org   

Laboratory testing reveals a creatinine kinase level of 75 U/L. Which of the following additional examination findings will most likely be present in this patient?

choices.text: Reduced deep tendon reflexes that transiently improve with repeated activity
Presence of multiple newly-erupted seborrheic keratoses
Hallux dorsiflexion with stimulation of the sole of the foot
Tenderness of the shoulder and hip muscles

questions.solution:
This patient with chronic cough that is occasionally productive of blood-tinged sputum, and weight loss, together with radiographic evidence of a left-sided central hilar mass is highly suspicious of a lung malignancy. His proximal lower extremity weakness is most likely secondary to Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is associated with small cell lung cancer.

Although LEMS is a clinical diagnosis, it can be confirmed via laboratory testing, which may reveal the presence of antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels. Repeated nerve stimulation will reveal an incremental increase in the muscle action potential. Once the diagnosis has been made, a chest CT should be performed to evaluate for underlying small cell lung cancer, with which it is most commonly associated.

Treatment depends on the underlying cause. If there is small cell lung cancer, treatment of the cancer is the main goal. When there is no underlying malignancy, amifampridine (3,4-diaminopyridine) can be used to block neuronal potassium channels, prolong the depolarization phase, and increase the amount of acetylcholine release into the neuromuscular junction. Guanidine can also be used as a second line agent. In severe cases, immunosuppressants, intravenous immunoglobulin therapy (IVIG) and plasma exchange can be used to remove the autoantibodies.



Option Analysis

✅ Reduced deep tendon reflexes that transiently improve with repeated activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Presence of multiple newly-erupted seborrheic keratoses:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the Leser-Trelat sign. The condition is associated with malignancies of the gastrointestinal tract, such as stomach or colorectal cancer. It would be atypical for this condition to manifest in a patient with lung cancer and would not account for the patient’s muscle weakness.  
❌ Hallux dorsiflexion with stimulation of the sole of the foot:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a positive Babinski sign. It is seen in conditions affecting the upper motor neurons, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). However, ALS manifests with asymmetrical limb weakness. Moreover, this patient’s history of bloody sputum and imaging findings are consistent with lung cancer, making LEMS aore likely explanation for the muscle weakness.  
❌ Tenderness of the shoulder and hip muscles:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis and polymyositis are inflammatory myopathies that can manifest with tenderness in the proximal muscles. Dermatomyositis in particular is associated with many malignancies, such as lung, ovarian, and stomach cancer. However, patients with inflammatory myopathies will likely have elevated creatinine kinase levels secondary to muscle injury, which is not seen in this patient.
❌ Jaw pain exacerbated by chewing:
Incorrect: This is seen in patients with temporal arteritis. Patients with this condition can also develop polymyalgia rheumatica, which manifests with muscle pain, stiffness, and subjective weakness that is most prominent at the shoulder and hip joints. However, neither temporal arteritis nor polymyalgia rheumatica is associated with lung cancer.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male comes to the emergency room because of severe lower-extremity cramping. The symptoms started three days ago. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, and he recently underwent surgery for a “thyroid problem.” He currently takes propranolol. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 141/78 mmHg. While the blood pressure is being measured in the left arm, spasms are noted in the patient’s left hand. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Blood tests and an electrocardiogram (ECG) are ordered. Which of the following findings will most like be observed on the patient’s ECG?

choices.text: Positive deflection at the J point

questions.solution:
This patient with severe lower extremity cramping after a recent thyroid surgery is most likely having hypocalcemia secondary to iatrogenic hypoparathyroidism. It is the most common cause of hypoparathyroidism, as thyroid surgery often leads to the damage and/or removal of the parathyroid glands. Another common cause is autoimmune destruction of the parathyroid glands.  

Hypoparathyroidism causes hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. These electrolyte derangements make neurons more excitable, which can trigger tetany and muscle spasms. Other findings include paresthesias, the Chvostek sign, which is when facial muscles twitch after the facial nerve is lightly tapped below the zygomatic process, and the Trousseau sign, which is when tightening of a blood pressure cuff causes muscle spasm in the wrist and hand (as seen in this patient). If the hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia are severe, life-threatening complications like seizures and cardiac arrhythmias can occur.  

Diagnosis is based on blood tests for parathyroid hormone, calcium, vitamin D, albumin, phosphorus, and magnesium. Also, an electrocardiogram might have changes such as a prolongedQT (see EKG below), prolonged ST segment, and arrhythmias, like torsade de pointes and atrial fibrillation.

 Figure 1: EKG with prolonged QT interval


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Flattened T waves:
Incorrect: Flattened T waves are observed in patients with hypokalemia. Hypokalemia can also present with muscle spasms and cramping. However, the patient’s history of recent thyroid surgery is concerning for hypocalcemia since the operation may damage or remove the parathyroid glands. Hypocalcemia does not typically present with flattened T waves. 
✅  QT-interval prolongation :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Peaked T waves:
Incorrect: Peaked T waves are observed in patients with hyperkalemia. The condition can present with arrhythmias and muscle weakness. However, it would be atypical for hyperkalemia to present with muscle spasms, and there are no conditions in the patient’s history (e.g., kidney disease, hypoaldosteronism, etc.) that would increase the risk of hyperkalemia. 
❌ Positive deflection at the J point :
Incorrect: An Osborn wave (a positive deflection at the J point) may be observed in patients with hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemia can present with bone pain, constipation, kidney stones, and altered mental status. However, the patient’s history of recent thyroid surgery is more concerning for hypocalcemia. 
❌ ST segment depression:
Incorrect: ST segment depression can be seen in conditions such as subendocardial ischemia, digoxin toxicity or hypokalemia. However, these conditions would not present with muscle spasms and cramps as observed in this patient.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with worsening hand and leg weakness. He often feels as if his left leg is “dragging” and experiences “spasms” while running. He additionally has difficulty holding a pen as firmly as he used to. Past medical history is notable for Graves disease. The patient does not smoke, use alcohol or other illicit substances. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 125/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for 4/5 strength in the right hand, with thenar muscle atrophy, as well as 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity. He has upgoing toes when the inner sole of the left foot is stroked. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this disease?

choices.text: Combined upper motor and lower motor neuron degeneration
Congenital degeneration of the anterior horns of the spinal cord
Degeneration of the dorsal columns and roots
Disruption of the dystrophin-associated protein complex

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of both upper and lower motor neuron disease including spasticity, a positive Babinski sign, and thenar wasting. These findings raise concern for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).   

ALS is a combined upper and lower motor neuron disease that results in degeneration of the corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts. The etiology of ALS is unknown, and current research proposes a number of potential mechanisms including abnormal RNA processing, excitotoxicity, cytoskeletal derangements, mitochondrial dysfunction, and growth factor abnormalities. Mutations in the superoxide dismutase type 1 (SOD-1) gene are thought to be implicated.    

Regardless, neuronal degeneration in these spinal tracts results in symptoms of both upper (e.g., spasticity, positive Babinski sign) and lower (e.g., fasciculations, atrophy) motor neuron disease. Additional symptoms include dysarthria, dysphagia, and asymmetric limb weakness. Most patients with ALS lack sensory deficits or deficits in bowel or bladder function.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Combined upper motor and lower motor neuron degeneration:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Congenital degeneration of the anterior horns of the spinal cord:
Incorrect: Werdnig-Hoffman disease is due to an autosomal recessive mutation in the SMN1 gene that results in congenital degeneration of the anterior horns of the spinal cord. This disease presents with signs of lower motor neuron disease, and symptoms manifest early in childhood.  
❌   Degeneration of the dorsal columns and roots  :
Incorrect: Tabes dorsalis is a manifestation of tertiary neurosyphilis and is caused by degenerative changes of the dorsal column of the spinal cord. However, tabes dorsalis would not typically present with the signs of muscle weakness seen in this patient. 
❌ Antibodies against postsynaptic ACh receptors:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease characterized by progressive muscle weakness. Unlike amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, myasthenia gravis will demonstrate worsening fatigability with repetitive muscle movements and subsequent improvement with rest. Furthermore, myasthenia gravis does not present with features of upper motor neuron disease (e.g., muscle spasm, positive Babinski reflex).  
❌ Disruption of the dystrophin-associated protein complex :
Incorrect: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies are associated with mutations in the dystrophin gene, which anchors myofilaments to the extracellular matrix. These disorders can present with muscle weakness. However, symptoms will develop during childhood in Duchenne muscular dystrophy and by early adulthood in Becker muscular dystrophy. It would be unusual for either of these conditions to first manifest with symptoms in a middle-aged individual.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the office because of non-radiating lower back pain. The pain has been present for the past 5 months and has progressively worsened. He has tried ibuprofen, which was initially able to control the pain but is no longer able to do so. He has no history of back trauma and does not perform any heavy lifting. Physical examination is notable for a decrease in height of 3 inches when compared with measurements taken one year ago and tenderness over the lumbar spine. Examination also reveals a slightly abnormal spine curvature. Radiographic studies are ordered, revealing anterior vertebral wedging and vertebral end-plate irregularity. What is the most likely underlying pathology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Decreased osteoblast activity, normal osteoclast activity
Increased osteoblast activity, decreased osteoclast activity
Decreased osteoblast activity, increased osteoclast activity

questions.solution:
This patient’s age, progressive back pain, height loss, and tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine raise concerns for a non-traumatic compression fracture. This diagnosis is confirmed by radiographic findings. In this patient, the condition is most likely due to osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is defined clinically as bone density that is less than 2.5 standard deviations below peak bone mass.

Osteoporosis can be divided into type I and type II. Type I osteoporosis affects postmenopausal females who have reduced estrogen production. Estrogen normally inhibits osteoclast resorption of bone; therefore, decreased estrogen levels leave the patient vulnerable to increased osteoclast breakdown of bone. Although osteoblast activity does increase to compensate, it ultimately cannot keep up with the resorptive process. For this reason, type I osteoporosis is also termed ‘high-turnover’ and ‘postmenopausal’ osteoporosis.

Type II osteoporosis affects both men and women. With age, osteoblasts lose their ability to proliferate and form new bone. Thus, after reaching a peak bone mass around age 30, decreased osteoblast activity will result in an overall decrease in bone density. This condition is also termed ‘low-turnover’ osteoporosis, since osteoclast activity is normal, and ‘senile’ osteoporosis, since it occurs universally with age in both genders. It is the most likely etiology of osteoporosis in this elderly male patient.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased osteoblast activity, normal osteoclast activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased osteoblast activity, decreased osteoclast activity:
Incorrect: Increased osteoblast activity with decreased osteoclast activity will result in an overall increase in bone mineral density, as seen in osteopetrosis. In contrast, this patient has a vertebral compression fracture, which is often due to bone weakness secondary to low mineral density.
❌ Intervertebral disc degeneration:
Incorrect: Intervertebral disc degeneration leads to disc herniation. Disc herniation can cause lower back pain secondary to nerve root compression, classically radiating to the lower extremities. This set of symptoms is termed sciatica. In contrast, this patient’s back pain is non-radiating, and the radiographic findings make a spinal compression fracture more likely.
❌ Intervertebral disc space calcification:
Incorrect: Intervertebral disc space calcification is a cause of pediatric spinal pain. The condition most often affects preadolescent children and self-resolves within 6 months.
❌ Decreased osteoblast activity, increased osteoclast activity:
Incorrect: Decreased osteoblast activity with increased osteoclast activity causes an overall decrease in bone density. It may lead to a vertebral compression fracture. However, this process occurs in type I 'postmenopausal’ osteoporosis, which is six times more common in women. In contrast, this man is more likely to have type II ‘senile’ osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to his primary care physician seeking evaluation for worsening pelvic pain. The pain is dull and constant, is present throughout the day, and is sometimes worse with weight-bearing. In addition, the patient complains of progressive hearing loss in both ears. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for warmth over the lateral pelvic walls and reduced sensorineural hearing loss in both ears. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. A plain film radiograph of the pelvis is ordered and reveals significant sclerosis, with evidence of osteolytic lesions and cortical thickening. Which of the following set of serum laboratory findings will be most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has Paget disease of the bone (also termed osteitis deformans), a disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling. The condition most often involves the skull, lumbar vertebrae, pelvis, and femur.  

 The disease has four phases: 
  1.  Phase 1 is the lytic phase, wherein osteoclasts start to aggressively demineralize the bone up to 20 times more than normal.  
  2.  Phase 2 is the mixed phase, wherein there is rapid breakdown of existing bone and rapid deposition of new bone.  
  3.  Phase 3 is the sclerotic phase, which is when new bone formation exceeds bone resorption.  
  4.  Phase 4 is the quiescent phase, wherein both osteoblast and osteoclast activity is reduced. The net result is production of disorganized bone that is weaker than normal bone.  
Patients present with bone pain due to microfractures, erythema/warmth over affected areas, and increased shoe/hat size after puberty. In addition, changes in the shape of the skull can cause facial changes and cranial nerve impingement, which can present with sensorineural hearing loss. Laboratory findings, which reflect increased bone turnover, include elevated levels of serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP). In contrast, serum calcium and phosphorus are normal in most patients.  
 


Option Analysis

❌   Calcium  Phosphate Alkaline Phosphatase  ↓  Normal  Normal :
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with osteopetrosis. The condition manifests during infancy or young adulthood. In patients with osteopetrosis, radiographic imaging will reveal diffuse bone sclerosis without osteolytic lesions.
✅   Calcium  Phosphate Alkaline Phosphatase  Normal Normal  ↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Calcium  Phosphate  Alkaline Phosphatase ↑↓ ↑ :
Incorrect: Hyperparathyroidism will cause elevated serum calcium and reduced serum phosphate levels. Bone turnover due to high parathyroid hormone levels will result in an elevated alkaline phosphatase. Although hyperparathyroidism can cause bony pain, the condition presents with cortical thinning on radiographic imaging. In contrast, this patient has cortical thickening.
❌   Calcium  Phosphate  Alkaline Phosphatase  ↓  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: Osteomalacia will present with these findings. In these patients, osteoblasts will deposit significant quantities of osteoid seam, explaining the elevated alkaline phosphatase level. However, not enough calcium or phosphate is available for the osteoid to mineralize and form mature bone. 
❌   Calcium  Phosphate Alkaline Phosphatase Normal  Normal  Normal :
Incorrect: These findings are seen in patients with osteoporosis. Osteoporosis can cause pathological fractures, which may present with skeletal pain. However, it would be atypical for osteoporosis to cause bilateral hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 72 year-old man comes to his outpatient provider’s office because of lower back pain and fatigue. The symptoms started two months ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which he is taking hydrochlorothiazide and carvedilol. Review of systems is significant for 5 kg (11 lb) unintentional weight loss. The patient’s temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 136/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination is noncontributory. There is tenderness to palpation of the lumbar spine at the L2 to L4 level. Laboratory results are as follows:  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  8.7 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  85 fL 
 Leukocyte count  3400/mm3 
 Creatinine  2.4 mg/dL 
 Calcium  11.5 mg/dL 
 Total protein  9.2 g/dL 
 Albumin  3.9 g/dL 
   
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Hypercalcemia secondary to thiazide diuretic use
Replacement of bone marrow with fibrous scar tissue
Neoplastic proliferation of IgM-secreting plasma cells

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has multiple myeloma, a hematologic malignancy characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of monoclonal plasma cells. These plasma cells produce large amounts of non-functional IgG and IgA antibodies. Multiple myeloma is most frequently diagnosed in elderly males.  

The condition classically manifests with the CRAB symptoms (hyperCalcemia, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, and Bone lesions). The renal insufficiency is secondary to deposition of immunoglobulin light chains (called Bence Jones proteins) in the kidneys. The patient’s laboratory findings provide evidence of hypercalcemia, kidney injury as reflected via the elevated creatinine level, and anemia. Moreover, the patient’s history of lower back pain is likely due to bone breakdown by osteoclasts/lytic lesions.  

Overtime, the neoplastic plasma cells will fill the bone marrow and impede the production of other cell lines, resulting in anemia, leukopenia, and/or thrombocytopenia.
 

Option Analysis

❌  Elevated parathyroid hormone level :
Incorrect: Hyperparathyroidism can cause hypercalcemia, which may present with symptoms including bone pain, muscle weakness, and confusion. However, it would not explain the leukopenia, anemia or the elevated serum protein seen in this patient’s laboratory results. 
❌ Hypercalcemia secondary to thiazide diuretic use :
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics can cause hypercalcemia and present with symptoms such as bone pain, constipation, and confusion. Moreover, if patients become significantly volume-depleted, kidney injury can occur and result in an elevated serum creatinine. However, anemia and leukopenia are not usually seen in patients taking thiazide diuretics. 
❌ Replacement of bone marrow with fibrous scar tissue:
Incorrect: Primary myelofibrosis can result in the fibrotic obliteration of the bone marrow. This condition can present with symptoms including weight loss, fatigue, splenomegaly, and pancytopenia. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has a normal abdominal exam. Moreover, primary myelofibrosis would not account for the patient's hypercalcemia, elevated serum protein, and elevated creatinine, which suggests renal injury. 
❌ Neoplastic proliferation of IgM-secreting plasma cells:
Incorrect: This answer describes Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. The excess IgM produced in this condition increases blood viscosity, resulting in symptoms including headache, vision impairment, epistaxis, and cramping. Around 3% of patients with this condition also have renal insufficiency. However, it would be uncommon for Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia to present with the hypercalcemia or bony pain observed in this patient. 
✅  Neoplastic proliferation of IgG-secreting plasma cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of joint pain and stiffness. Her symptoms are most prominent in the hands, worse in the morning and gradually improve after two-hours of physical activity. In addition, she complains of malaise and decreased appetite for the past several months. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals swelling of the bilateral proximal interphalangeal joints. Ulnar deviation is observed at the bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints. Serology testing is notable for elevated anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has elevated cyclic-citrullinated peptide levels, involvement of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints, and constitutional symptoms. She most likely has rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by autoimmune destruction of the joints.  

Cytokines released secondary to joint inflammation can travel to other parts of the body, causing extra-articular symptoms. In the blood vessels, the cytokines can cause wall inflammation and result in various forms of vasculitis, which can make blood vessels more prone to developing atheromatous or fibrofatty plaques. These plaques can lead to cardiovascular conditions such as myocardial infarction and stroke. In fact, cardiovascular disease is the primary cause of mortality in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

 
   

Option Analysis

❌ Spinal cord compression:
Incorrect: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis can develop atlantoaxial instability, which can cause acute compression of the spinal cord and/or vertebral arteries during forceful extension of the neck (e.g., orotracheal intubation, trauma). However, spinal cord compression is not the most common cause of mortality in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis can affect the lungs, causing pleural effusions, pulmonary fibrosis, and other interstitial lung diseases. However, it is not the most common cause of mortality in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Kidney failure:
Incorrect: Historically, renal failure has been the most common cause of death in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although SLE can also cause arthritis, it would be atypical for the condition to manifest with elevated anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody levels.
✅ Cardiovascular disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Septic shock:
Incorrect: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis can develop Felty syndrome, a serious disorder characterized by the presence of three conditions: rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia. As a result, patients are at increased risk of infection and sepsis. However, sepsis is not the most common cause of mortality in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old young man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of exertional shortness of breath. It worsens with exercise and improves with rest. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which he uses an albuterol inhaler occasionally. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 115/74 mmHg, and pulse is 67/min. Physical exam is notable for a systolic murmur most prominent at the left upper sternal border, as well as fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Incomplete fusion of the septum primum with endocardial cushions
Incomplete fusion of the septum primum with septum secundum
Impaired growth of the septum secundum
Impaired development of the membranous interventricular septum

questions.solution:
This patient with exertional dyspnea and examination findings of a systolic murmur that is most prominent at the left upper sternal border as well as fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound most likely has an atrial septal defect (ASD). Although most patients are asymptomatic, some can exhibit poor weight gain and exercise intolerance.  

ASDs can be subdivided into ostium secundum defects and ostium primum defects. Ostium secundum defects occur due to impaired growth of the septum secundum. This type is more common and is usually an isolated finding. In contrast, ostium primum defects occur due to incomplete fusion of the septum primum with the endocardial cushion. This type is uncommon and is associated with conditions such as trisomy 21.  

Option Analysis

❌ Incomplete fusion of the septum primum with endocardial cushions :
Incorrect: This patient has a fixed-split S2 heart sound, which is suggestive of an atrial septal defect. Ostium primum defects, wherein there is incomplete fusion of the septum primum with the endocardial cushions, can result in an ASD. However, ASDs are more frequently due to ostium secundum defects. 
❌ Incomplete fusion of the septum primum with septum secundum :
Incorrect: A patent foramen ovale (PFO) results from the incomplete fusion of the ostium primum and secundum. The condition is mostly asymptomatic. Patients may have a faint systolic murmur on auscultation. However, fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound would be an atypical presentation of PFO. 
✅ Impaired growth of the septum secundum :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Calcification of the aortic valve :
Incorrect: Calcification of the aortic valve can sometimes lead to aortic stenosis (AS). Because the left ventricle has to eject blood against greater resistance, patients with AS may develop paradoxical splitting, wherein the A2 sound occurs after the P2 sound. However, the condition would not cause fixed-splitting. In addition, the systolic murmur would be more prominent in the right second intercostal space. 
❌ Impaired development of the membranous interventricular septum :
Incorrect: This answer describes a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Wide-splitting of the S2 heart sound may be heard in patients with VSD because blood from the left ventricle can pass through the defect, enter the right ventricle, increase right ventricular volume, and prolong systole. However, VSD would not cause fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter due to worsening irritability and aggression. Over the past year, the patient has been having trouble recalling the names of her children. She has even gotten lost walking back from the park, which she has done nearly everyday without difficulty for 30 years. According to the daughter, the patient also seems more withdrawn and becomes irritated when asked simple questions. She has not had any hallucinations or changes in urinary frequency or gait. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. She says her mood is “annoyed” and scores 19/30 on the Mini-Mental State Examination (normal: ≥ 24). She is oriented to person and place but not time. Which of the following clinical features in this patient’s history is indicative of dementia, as opposed to delirium?
questions.solution:
Major neurocognitive disorder (formerly called dementia) is a condition that affects cognitive functioning and is characterized by impairments in memory, language, executive function, and/or spatial-temporal awareness to the point of restricting a patient’s daily routine. Although normal aging may present with a similar decline in some cognitive areas (e.g. episodic memories), procedural and semantic memories are typically preserved well enough to allow for independence when carrying out daily activities.

There are various causes of dementia, with most cases originating from neurodegenerative conditions (e.g., Alzheimer disease, Parkinson disease), which are therefore irreversible. A crucial aspect of dementia is that the cognitive impairment is gradual and progresses over time.

Delirium, on the other hand, may present with similar impairments in cognitive functioning, but the symptoms develop acutely and fluctuate throughout the day. Delirium can occur as a result of a variety of medical conditions and is often a complication of various medications in the elderly. Delirium is a reversible state, and treatment focuses on addressing the underlying condition.



Option Analysis

✅ Progressive course of condition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lack of orientation:
Incorrect: This patient is currently oriented to person and place, but not time. Disorientation can occur in both delirium and dementia.
❌ Mini-Mental State Examination score:
Incorrect: The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) is a widely used screening tool for delirium and dementia. Patients with dementia will likely have persistently reduced scores, whereas patients with delirium will likely have a transiently reduced score but normal baseline scores. However, a single score would not be enough to distinguish between the two conditions.
❌ Memory deficit:
Incorrect: Both delirium and dementia (e.g. Alzheimer disease) can present with impaired memory. As a result, this clinical feature is specific to neither condition.
❌ Agitation and irritability:
Incorrect: Neuropsychiatric symptoms, such as irritability, agitation, and apathy, are common in Alzheimer disease. These symptoms become more prominent in the middle and later course of the disease. However, patients with delirium (e.g. substance intoxication) can also exhibit these symptoms. As a result, the presence of agitation and irritability is not specific to either delirium or dementia.

questions.text:
A pathologist is examining various brain biopsies obtained from patients who died of neurodegenerative conditions. A particular slide she is examining is from the frontal lobe and shown below.  

 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Further testing reveals round cytoplasmic inclusions containing aggregates of tau proteins that stain with silver. Which of the following symptoms did this patient most likely exhibit before his death?

choices.text: Fabricated stories to fill memory lapses
Vivid visual hallucinations of deceased family members

questions.solution:
Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a neurodegenerative condition characterized by neuronal cell loss in the frontal and temporal regions of the brain. Microscopic examination will likely reveal neuronal loss, swollen neurons, and astrocytic glial cell proliferation (gliosis). Moreover, two types of abnormal protein inclusions are typically seen in the cytoplasm of neurons:  

  •  Pick bodies are round silver-staining inclusions that consist of hyperphosphorylated tau protein. Pick bodies are seen in many patients with FTD (hence why the condition was previously called Pick syndrome).  
  • TDP-43 protein is an RNA binding protein normally present in the nucleus and involved in the regulation of transcription. Improperly phosphorylated and ubiquitinated TDP-43 can be seen as intracellular inclusions. 
Clinically, FTD is characterized by early behavioral changes (due to frontal lobe degeneration) that can present as disinhibition (e.g., kissing strangers, public urination), apathy, and hyperorality (which can manifest as increased smoking habits). Most patients typically lack insight into their behavioral changes, and they are often brought in for evaluation by concerned and/or embarrassed family members. Another prominent early finding in FTD is progressive aphasia, which can present as deficits in word finding and word comprehension. As the disease progresses, however, patients can begin developing memory loss.  



Option Analysis

✅ Socially inappropriate behavior:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fabricated stories to fill memory lapses:
Incorrect: Korsakoff syndrome is seen in patients with chronic alcohol use and is caused by a thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine deficiency results in decreased cerebral glucose metabolism and injury to neurons, especially those in the mammillary bodies. Patients with Korsakoff syndrome typically exhibit anterograde and retrograde amnesia and confabulation, wherein they fabricate stories to fill lapses in memory. However, Korsakoff syndrome would not present with the silver-staining Pick bodies seen in the above image.
❌ Vivid visual hallucinations of deceased family members:
Incorrect: Patients with Lewy body dementia can present with vivid hallucinations of animals or people. The condition is characterized by the presence of Lewy bodies, which are alpha-synuclein positive cytoplasmic inclusions. These structures appear as hyaline eosinophilic globules found within neurons.
❌ Bradykinesia and tremors:
Incorrect: Lewy bodies are also seen in patients with Parkinson disease, who initially present with bradykinesia and a resting tremor. However, no Lewy bodies are seen in the above image.
❌ Writhing movements and depression:
Incorrect: Huntington disease manifests with choreiform movements, psychiatric illnesses (e.g., depression, psychosis), and dementia. Microscopic examination would reveal severe loss of neurons and gliosis in the striatum, as well as intranuclear inclusions containing aggregates of ubiquitinated huntingtin protein.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman goes to her primary care physician because of progressive right sided hearing loss over the past three months. The patient states, “I cannot hear conversations out of this ear anymore; it feels like my ear is all plugged up.” She also has had tinnitus and balance issues during this time period. During the physical exam, the physician strikes a tuning fork and places it on the patient’s forehead. The abnormal finding from this test prompts the physician to order MRI imaging of the brain, which reveals the following:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following combinations of Weber and Rinne test results are most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  Lateralization to the left ear  Air conduction greater than bone conduction
Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  Lateralization to the left ear Bone conduction greater than air conduction
Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result Lateralization to the right ear Air conduction greater than bone conduction
Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result Lateralization to the right earBone conduction greater than air conduction
Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  No lateralization will be presentAir conduction greater than bone conduction

questions.solution:
This patient’s history and MRI findings are consistent with those of an acoustic neuroma (also termed vestibular schwannoma). Vestibular schwannomas can result in sensorineural hearing loss, which on Weber testing would demonstrate lateralization of sound to the unaffected ear.   

Two tests, the Weber test and Rinne test, can help determine if a patient has conductive or sensorineural hearing loss. The Weber test is performed by placing a struck tuning fork on the bridge of the forehead, and in a healthy individual, there would be no lateralization of sound. With unilateral conductive hearing loss, sound lateralizes to the affected ear, whereas with sensorineural hearing loss, sound lateralizes to the normal ear.  

The Rinne test is performed by placing the base of a struck tuning fork on the mastoid bone until the patient no longer hears sound. Next, the fork is moved beside the ear and the patient is asked if they can still hear sound. In a normal test, air conduction is greater than bone conduction. However, in patients with conductive hearing loss, bone conduction is greater than air conduction. Unfortunately, the Rinne test cannot differentiate between healthy individuals and those with sensorineural hearing loss, as both present with air conduction greater than bone conduction.  

Option Analysis

✅   Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  Lateralization to the left ear  Air conduction greater than bone conduction :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  Lateralization to the left ear Bone conduction greater than air conduction:
Incorrect: This patient's right ear hearing loss is primarily sensorineural, given the findings of a vestibular schwannoma (also termed acoustic neuroma) on MRI. A Weber test will demonstrate lateralization of sound to the unaffected (left) ear. However, in sensorineural hearing loss, the Rinne test will reveal air conduction that is greater than bone conduction.
❌   Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result Lateralization to the right ear Air conduction greater than bone conduction:
Incorrect: This patient's right ear hearing loss is primarily sensorineural, given the findings of a vestibular schwannoma (also termed acoustic neuroma) on MRI. With sensorineural hearing loss, a Weber test will demonstrate sound lateralization to the unaffected (left) ear.
❌   Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result Lateralization to the right earBone conduction greater than air conduction:
Incorrect: A Rinne test revealing bone conduction greater than air conduction is suggestive of conductive hearing loss. The Weber test demonstrates lateralization of sound to the right ear. In combination, these findings are suggestive of right-sided conductive hearing loss. In contrast, this patient has a right vestibular schwannoma, which would more likely cause sensorineural hearing loss.
❌   Weber Test Result  Rinne Test Result  No lateralization will be presentAir conduction greater than bone conduction:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the Weber and Rinne test findings in a healthy individual. In contrast, this patient has a right-sided vestibular schwannoma, which would cause sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of ear drainage. The patient has had intermittent, foul-smelling drainage coming from the left ear over the past two weeks. In addition, she has noticed difficulty hearing out of the left ear. On physical exam, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 118/77 mmHg, and pulse is 64/min. An otoscopic evaluation of the affected ear is performed and demonstrates the following:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons   

Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Benign trabecular bone and fibrofatty marrow

questions.solution:
This patient has left ear drainage, hearing loss, and an otoscopic examination that demonstrates collection of keratin debris and a retraction pocket in the tympanic membrane. These findings are suggestive of a cholesteatoma, which is a benign lesion caused by overgrowth of keratinized squamous epithelium.  

Cholesteatoma refers to an abnormal accumulation of squamous epithelium that most commonly develops behind the tympanic membrane. This condition has both congenital and acquired forms, with the latter being more common. Congenital cholesteatomas are present at birth and are a result of embryonic nests of squamous cells that remain in the middle ear after birth. Acquired cholesteatomas often occur due to eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent formation of a retraction pocket that allows desquamating skin cells to accumulate into a slowly expanding mass.  

Clinically, cholesteatomas present with painless ear drainage, which may be foul-smelling, and conductive hearing loss. Otoscopic evaluation will often demonstrate retraction of the tympanic membrane around ossicles as well as a mass behind the tympanic membrane. If left untreated, these lesions can erode the ossicles or mastoid bone.  

Option Analysis

✅ Accumulation of keratinized squamous epithelium:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Infiltrating polygonal squamous cells :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the histopathology of squamous cell cancer of the ear, which is overall a rare neoplasm. Physical examination could also demonstrate associated lymphadenopathy, nerve palsy, and significant ear pain. 
❌ Benign trabecular bone and fibrofatty marrow:
Incorrect: External auditory osteomas are a rare type of tumor composed of benign bone and marrow tissue. Osteomas typically present as a smooth mass growing from the walls of the ear canal.   
❌ Growth of malignant melanocytes :
Incorrect: Melanoma presents as an area of skin characterized by irregular borders, variations in color (e.g., brown, black, tan), and asymmetry. It most often affects sun-exposed areas of skin. In contrast, melanoma of the tympanic membrane would be an extremely rare condition.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of worsening headaches and dizziness. The headaches tend to occur during periods of stress and are usually associated with blurry vision and tremors. In the office, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 154/96 mmHg. Physical examination reveals brownish macules spread over his body, as well as numerous cutaneous nodules. The lesions are shown in the below image:

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Given the patient’s history and physical exam findings, he should be assessed for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypertension, intermittent headaches, and visual disturbances. In addition, physical examination reveals brownish macules (cafe-au-lait spots) and numerous pedunculated lesions (cutaneous neurofibromas). In combination, these findings are concerning for an underlying pheochromocytoma due to neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1).

Most pheochromocytomas arise sporadically. However, 10% are associated with inherited syndromes such as NF-1, which occurs due to an autosomal dominant mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17. Other conditions associated with pheochromocytomas include von Hippel-Lindau disease, multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A, and MEN 2B.

Pheochromocytomas typically arise in the adrenal medulla and are composed of chromaffin cells. These cells synthesize and release catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine, norepinephrine). As a result, patients with pheochromocytomas will have catecholamine overproduction and oversecretion. This increase in serum catecholamines can manifest as paroxysmal episodes of hypertension, tachycardia, palpitations, headache, diaphoresis, and tremors due to the sudden release of catecholamines. Some patients, such as the one in this vignette, can demonstrate a chronic sustained elevation in blood pressure.

The characteristics of pheochromocytomas can be remembered with the “rule of tens,” which states that 10% are malignant, bilateral, extra-adrenal (e.g. bladder), calcified, and manifest in kids. Furthermore, 10% of cases are associated with genetic syndromes such as NF-1.





Option Analysis

✅ Adrenal medulla neoplasm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bilateral vestibular schwannomas:
Incorrect: Bilateral vestibular schwannomas, also termed acoustic neuromas, are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells. Bilateral neuromas are characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 2. In contrast, this patient likely has neurofibromatosis type 1, which is not associated with bilateral vestibular schwannomas.
❌ Parathyroid hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Parathyroid hyperplasia can be seen in multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1 and type 2A. Patients typically present with signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia (e.g., constipation, kidney stones, polyuria). However, this patient has multiple neurofibromas over his back, which is more concerning for neurofibromatosis type 1. Neurofibromatosis type 1 is not associated with parathyroid hyperplasia.
❌ Pancreatic neoplasm:
Incorrect: Pancreatic neoplasms, such as insulinomas and gastrinomas, are strongly associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1. Although an increased incidence of pancreatic endocrine tumors has also been linked with neurofibromatosis type 1, another condition is more likely in this patient, especially given his current symptoms.
❌ Pituitary neoplasm:
Incorrect: Pituitary tumors can be seen in multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1. Although these masses can also present with headaches and changes in vision, the visual changes are typically described as loss of temporal visual fields. Additionally, this patient’s cutaneous lesions are more suggestive of a different underlying condition.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of loss of sensation in the right upper and right lower extremity of one hour duration. The patient was working in his basement when he began losing feeling in his right arm and leg throughout the morning. He became more concerned when he developed a headache with associated non-bilious non-bloody vomiting. The patient has a history of untreated hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He does not take any medications. He drinks 6-8 beers on the weekends and has a 30-pack year smoking history. Current temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 225/108 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates an obese, ill appearing male with 2/5 weakness in the right upper and right lower extremities. There is decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick of the right upper and lower extremities. A non-contrast CT of the head is shown below:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Which of the following risk factors is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an intraparenchymal hemorrhage (IPH), which often occurs secondary to long-standing untreated hypertension. The imaging findings demonstrate a hemorrhage within the  internal capsule, as seen by the hyperdensity (blood) in the left basal ganglia. Internal capsule hemorrhage may present with dysarthria, contralateral hemiparesis, sensory deficit, or both. Neurologic symptoms typically increase gradually over minutes to hours as the hemorrhage expands. In contrast, the neurologic findings of a large vessel embolic stroke are often maximal at onset. If the hemorrhage becomes large, signs of increased intracranial pressure may arise including headache, vomiting, and a decreased level of consciousness.

Hypertension is the primary risk factor for IPH, and hypertension-induced degenerative changes in small, perforating arteries increase the likelihood of rupture through the formation of Charcot–Bouchard aneurysms. These small aneurysms, undetectable by angiography, supply deep grey matter structures including the basal ganglia, thalamus, brainstem, and cerebellum. 

Option Analysis

❌ Alcohol use:
Incorrect: High alcohol intake is associated with an increased risk of intraparenchymal hemorrhage; however, is not the most significant risk factor.
✅ Hypertension:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperlipidemia:
Incorrect: Hyperlipidemia is associated with an increased risk of intraparenchymal hemorrhage; however, uncontrolled hypertension is a more significant risk factor.
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Obesity is associated with various adverse outcomes; however, it is not a direct risk factor in the development of this patient’s intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: Smoking is associated with various adverse outcomes, and it also increases the risk of developing an intraparenchymal hemorrhage; however, it is not the most significant risk factor.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset numbness affecting the right upper and lower extremity as well as right sided visual deficit. The patient was playing golf with his son when he suddenly lost the ability to sense holding the golf club with his right hand. He was then unable to get into the golf cart due to “blurry vision.” The patient has a history of poorly controlled hypertension. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 188/104 mmHg. The patient is alert and oriented. Sensation is decreased in the right arm and leg. Strength testing is intact throughout. A noncontrast head CT is demonstrated below:

 

 Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following visual deficits is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hemisensory loss, associated visual deficits, and a noncontrast head CT demonstrating a left occipital lobe infarct. Given these findings, he likely suffered a left posterior cerebral artery stroke, resulting in right sided homonymous hemianopia.

Homonymous hemianopia refers to a loss of vision in either the left or right halves of the visual fields of both eyes. In the setting of stroke to the posterior cerebral artery, the vision lost reflects the side contralateral to the posterior cerebral artery affected. Although these patients suffer partial vision loss, macular sparing occurs, since the portion of the occipital lobe regulating this function receives dual blood supply from both the posterior cerebral artery as well as the middle cerebral artery.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Non-homonymous bitemporal hemianopia often occurs due to a large pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasm, not a stroke of the left occipital lobe.
❌ :
Incorrect: Damage to the right temporal lobe (containing the Meyer loop) can result in superior left homonymous quadrantanopia, or “pie-in-the-sky” visual disturbances.
❌ :
Incorrect: Damage to the right parietal lobe can manifest with contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia, or “pie-on-the-floor” visual disorder. These lesions may be caused by vascular occlusion of the middle cerebral artery.
❌ :
Incorrect: Left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing can be seen in patients with occlusion of the right posterior cerebral artery. Macular sparing results from a dual blood supply to the visual cortex.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl was brought to the clinic by her mother due to abdominal and back pain over the past few months. The pain started approximately 6 months ago and since then has progressively worsened. Each month, the patient experiences a few days of severe pain that cause her to miss school. She also discloses pain with defecation and difficulty urinating. The patient had not yet had a menstrual period and is not sexually active. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 121/73 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is Tanner stage 5 with fully developed female secondary sex characteristics. Suprapubic fullness and tenderness are noted. β-hCG is negative. Which of the following is most likely the cause of this condition?

choices.text: Endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity
Penetration of glandular tissue into the myometrium

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with primary amenorrhea, cyclic pelvic pain, back pain, dyschezia, and difficulty urinating, as well as suprapubic fullness, all favoring the diagnosis of outlet obstruction due to imperforate hymen.    

The vaginal lumen is parted from the urogenital sinus by the hymenal membrane. Normally, the hymen ruptures before birth due to degeneration of the central portion. Hymenal anomalies occur due to incomplete degeneration of the central portion and include imperforate, microperforate, septate, and cribriform hymens.    

Imperforate hymen results in complete outflow obstruction. At the age of menarche, adolescent girls present with amenorrhea and cyclic abdominal or pelvic pain. Significant distention from blood accumulation (hematocolpos) may result in back pain, dyschezia, and difficulty urinating. On physical examination, a bluish membrane is often observed bulging from the vagina. The diagnosis can be confirmed with translabial or transperitoneal ultrasound. Treatment involves surgical opening of the hymen and evacuation of accumulated material.   

Option Analysis

❌  Endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity :
Incorrect: These findings describe endometriosis, which commonly occurs in the ovary, pelvis, and peritoneum. Common presenting symptoms include cyclic pelvic pain, bleeding, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dyschezia, and infertility. While some of this patient’s symptoms overlap with endometriosis, it does not explain the patient’s suprapubic fullness. Findings suggestive of endometriosis are tenderness on vaginal examination, posterior fornix nodularity, adnexal masses, and immobility of cervix or uterus.   
✅ Outlet obstruction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Uterine adhesions :
Incorrect: Uterine adhesions and/or fibrosis of the endometrium, also known as Asherman syndrome, are associated with intrauterine procedures such as dilation and curettage. Patients may present with decreased fertility, abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, and recurrent pregnancy loss. This patient has not reached menarche and did not undergo any intrauterine procedures.  
❌ Penetration of glandular tissue into the myometrium :
Incorrect: Penetration of glandular tissue (endometrial tissue) into the myometrium describes adenomyosis. Patients with adenomyosis often present with uterine enlargement, abnormal uterine bleeding, and painful and heavy menses. It is more common in women after 40 years of age. This patient has not yet reached menarche. 
❌ Defect in the androgen receptor:
Incorrect: Androgen-insensitivity syndrome (AIS) is a condition in which a defect in the androgen receptor results in a patient who is phenotypically female (despite 46,XY karyotype), with normal female external genitalia, scant axillary and pubic hair, rudimentary vagina, and absence of the uterus and fallopian tubes. This phenotype is due to the production of anti-Müllerian hormone from normally functioning testes which are often found in the labia majora. While primary amenorrhea also occurs in AIS, it would not explain the patient’s cyclic symptoms and abdominal fullness.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the office for recurrent episodes of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. He has had several episodes of watery diarrhea in the past 2 years. Review of systems reveals a 9-kg (20-lbs) weight loss over this time period, fatigue, and loss of appetite. Past medical history is significant for ischemic heart disease and diabetes mellitus type II. He takes aspirin and glyburide regularly. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 19 kg/m2. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Colonoscopy shows erythematous and edematous bowel wall mucosa involving the whole colon. After appropriate workup, a colectomy is performed; findings of the involved regions are shown.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who has constitutional symptoms (fatigue, loss of appetite, weight loss), recurrent bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain with gross morphological findings of pancolitis likely has ulcerative colitis (UC).

UC is an immune-mediated inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon. Unlike Crohn disease (which can involve any part of the gastrointestinal tract with relative rectal sparing), UC mostly involves the rectum and may extend in a proximal and continuous fashion to involve other parts of the colon. Clinically, it presents with recurrent episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Patients may have systemic symptoms including fever, fatigue, and weight loss.



Though nonspecific, colonoscopy findings in UC include loss of vascular markings due to engorgement of the mucosa, giving the colon an erythematous appearance. In addition, pseudopolyps, edema, erosions, friability, and spontaneous bleeding may be observed. Histological features include crypt abscesses, mucin depletion and basal lymphoidaggregates. UC is associated with increased risk of development of colorectal cancer, and thus colectomy is both therapeutic and preventative.  

Option Analysis

❌ Crohn disease:
Incorrect: Clinically, Crohn disease can present similarly; however, gross morphology usually reveals skip lesions (focal ulcerations adjacent to areas of normal appearing mucosa) that result in a cobblestone appearance. Moreover, grossly bloody stools are uncommon until late in the disease course.
❌ Pseudomembranous colitis:
Incorrect: Pseudomembranous colitis is a manifestation of C. difficile infection, which clinically presents with watery diarrhea and low-grade fever. The infection is associated with antibiotic therapy (e.g., clindamycin, quinolones, penicillins), and typical colonoscopy findings include pseudomembranes on the inflamed colonic mucosa. Bloody diarrhea and pancolitis are unlikely.
❌ Collagenous colitis:
Incorrect: Collagenous colitis is characterized by chronic, watery, non-bloody diarrhea with normal appearance of the colon on endoscopy. Macroscopic features can include slight edema, erythema, friability, exudative lesions, and scars, but these findings are uncommon. Diagnosis is made on biopsy findings of subepithelial collagen band >10 micrometers in diameter.
❌ Ischemic colitis:
Incorrect: Ischemic colitis can be secondary to embolic or thrombotic occlusion of mesenteric vessels; it typically presents with postprandial pain or the classic finding of abdominal pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings. Instead, this patient with long-standing diarrhea, abdominal tenderness, and continuous inflammation of colon most likely has UC.
✅ Ulcerative colitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man comes to the office due to 6 days of eye redness and pain in both eyes. Medical history is significant for recurrent painful oral ulcers and ankylosing spondylitis. He currently takes aspirin and sulfasalazine. The patient is in a monogamous relationship but is unsure sure if his partner is monogamous. The patient immigrated from Turkey when he was a child. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows warm and tender nodules over bilateral shins as well as his left ankle, as shown in the image below:

Reproduced from: Wikipedia

 On ophthalmological examination, decreased visual acuity, conjunctival redness, and hypopyon are noted bilaterally. Genital exam reveals an incipient genital ulceration over the scrotal raphe. Laboratory studies show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. This patient most likely has which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient who developed signs and symptoms of anterior uveitis (i.e., decreased visual acuity, conjunctival redness, hypopyon), genital ulceration, painful aphthous ulcers, and erythema nodosum (i.e. tender nodules over the shins and left ankle) likely has Behçet disease.    

The underlying cause of Behçet syndrome is unknown, and several mechanisms have been suggested, including immune complexes from antibodies production and vascular endothelial activation with subsequent hypercoagulability. The condition involves blood vessels of all sizes (small, medium, and large), including both the arterial and venous circulation. This condition has a high incidence among eastern Asia and Mediterranean countries. Behçet disease is strongly associated with HLA-B51 antigens, and it may be precipitated by certain pathogens such as herpes simplex virus, parvovirus infections, and streptococcal infections.  

Obtaining medical history is an important aspect of the diagnosis of Behçet disease. Common clinical findings include (1) recurrent aphthous ulcers or genital ulcerations, (2) uveitis, and (3) erythema nodosum. Other systems may be involved, including CNS, renal, pulmonary, cardiac, musculoskeletal, and gastrointestinal. Patients often present with pathergy, a skin condition in which a minor trauma leads to the development of skin lesions or ulcers resistant to healing.  

Behçet disease attacks generally last 1-4 weeks, and if left untreated, patients may progress to develop permanent vision loss. Medical treatment for Behçet disease includes anti-inflammatory medications, high-dose corticosteroids, and TNF inhibitors (e.g., infliximab, etanercept).    


Option Analysis

❌  Ankylosing spondylitis relapse :
Incorrect: Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of systemic inflammatory arthritis in which there is long-term inflammation of the joints of the spine. It may also be associated with nonarticular features including uveitis, psoriasis, and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). A relapse is characterized by the deterioration of initial symptoms, such as dull pain in the lower back combined with lower back stiffness, none of which is present in this patient.  
❌ Aphthous stomatitis:
Incorrect: Aphthous stomatitis (or "canker sore") is a common condition characterized by the repeated formation of benign and non-contagious mouth ulcers in healthy individuals. In this case, the patient has additional signs and symptoms (genital ulcers, uveitis) which are indicative of another condition.   
✅ Behçet disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Primary syphilis:
Incorrect: Primary syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Treponema pallidum. Primary syphilis is particularly characterized by a syphilitic chancre (single, firm, painless, non-itchy skin ulceration), which normally appears at the point of contact. However, the presence of multiple aphthous ulcers in the oral cavity and eye inflammation is not present in syphilis. 
❌ Reactive arthritis:
Incorrect: Reactive arthritis (or Reiter syndrome) is an autoimmune condition characterized by conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis. This condition is strongly associated with HLA-B27 serology and is usually seen after infection with Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, and Chlamydia trachomatis species. Reactive arthritis can present with many similar features seen in Behçet disease; however, the oral lesions in reactive arthritis are not painful, and erythema nodosum is very rare in patients with reactive arthritis.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the clinic due to fatigue, joint pain, and recent appearance of skin lesions on his legs. His medical history is noncontributory except for a car accident as a child which required hospitalization and multiple blood transfusions. He has not seen a physician in more than 10 years. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. He is monogamous with one sexual partner. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical exam shows purpuric papules covering the lower extremities that do not blanch with pressure. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory tests are obtained and shown below:  

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin   15 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count   7,000/mm3 
 Platelets    250,000/mm3 
 ALT  110 U/L 
 AST  75 U/L 
 Rheumatoid factor   Positive   
 Antinuclear antibodies  Negative  
 
 Urinalysis is unremarkable. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation reveals polyclonal IgG and monoclonal IgM bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitation after 24 hours. Which of the following tests is most likely to reveal this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with purpura, arthralgias, and weakness (Meltzer triad) in association with positive rheumatoid factor test and confirmatory electrophoresis results, has cryoglobulinemia (type II). Mixed cryoglobulinemia syndrome is most often due to chronic hepatitis C infection. The patient's age and history of blood transfusions as a child put him at increased risk for hepatitis C infection. An additional clue is this patient’s elevated liver enzymes, suggesting a chronic liver condition.  

Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in the cold temperatures and dissolve on rewarming. Cryoglobulins that contain more than one type of immunoglobulin component are called mixed cryoglobulins (e.g., monoclonal/polyclonal IgM, IgG, IgA antibodies, monoclonal κ or λ free light chain portions of these antibodies, and proteins of the blood complement system). The pathogenesis of the condition is poorly understood and assumed to be related to higher production of immunoglobulin, increased precipitation of immune complexes, and insufficient clearance. In type I cryoglobulinemia, precipitates are often seen within 24 hours. However, 3-5 days are usually needed in patients with mixed cryoglobulins, as well as type II cryoglobulins, which requires up to 7 days for precipitation.  

Clinical manifestations commonly include purpura, arthralgias, weakness and possibly peripheral neuropathy, and renal involvement (e.g. glomerulonephritis).

Option Analysis

✅  Hepatitis C serology  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ PCR for N. gonorrhea:
Incorrect: The classic presentation of disseminated N. gonorrhoea infection includes tenosynovitis, dermatitis, and polyarthralgia. Skin lesions are usually pustular or vesiculopustular (although papules can also occur). Moreover, this patient had no history of unprotected sex or sexually transmitted disease, and the urinalysis was normal.   
❌ Serum anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA):
Incorrect: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)-associated vasculitis is a group of diseases which includes granulomatosis with polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and microscopic polyangiitis. Although (ANCA)-associated vasculitis can present with similar symptoms, other characteristics would be expected, such as nasopharyngeal involvement (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) or atopic history with eosinophilia (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). Moreover, the patient’s electrophoresis results favor another diagnosis.  
❌  Rapid plasma reagin test (RPR) :
Incorrect: Rapid plasma reagin test is a screening test for syphilis. Secondary syphilis can present with fever, lymphadenopathy, skin rashes and condylomata lata. Although the rash seen in secondary syphilis can be papular, this patient has no history of unprotected sex or sexually transmitted diseases. 
❌ Antibodies to rickettsiae:
Incorrect: Rickettsiae infection is caused by fleas or ticks and usually presents with a classic triad of headache, fever, and rash (vasculitis). The rash seen in rickettsiae is not limited to the lower extremities. This patient’s rash pattern, symptoms, and laboratory findings favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Bone marrow biopsy:
Incorrect: Bone marrow biopsy can help establish the underlying diagnosis in patients with type I cryoglobulinemia. Type I cryoglobulinemia is associated with monoclonal gammopathies (e.g., MGUS, multiple myeloma) or hematologic malignancies (e.g. chronic lymphocytic leukemia). This patient blood count is normal, and his electrophoresis and precipitation test supports the diagnosis of type II cryoglobulinemia (See Main Explanation). 
❌ Antibodies to citrullinated peptide antigens:
Incorrect: This patient is found positive for rheumatoid factor (IgM antibody that targets IgG Fc region), which is not specific and can be found in many diseases, including cryoglobulinemia. In patients with suspected rheumatoid arthritis, positive test for rheumatoid factor will be followed by testing for anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody (more specific) to confirm the diagnosis. Rheumatoid arthritis does not present with palpable purpura on the lower extremities, and other symptoms would be expected.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with Crohn ileocolitis presents to the office because of urinary burning, urgency and frequency since yesterday. She also reports passage of air at the end of urination. Review of systems reveals fatigue, weight loss, and intermittent diarrhea. Past medical history is significant for 3 urinary tract infections in the past 6 months treated with antibiotics, as well as Crohn disease, for which she is currently taking 5-aminosalicylic acid. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows multiple aphthous ulcers on the oral mucosa and a mildly distended lower abdomen with tenderness. Urinalysis reveals brown-colored urine with positive nitrites. Serum creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with irritative symptoms (urgency and frequency) and pneumaturia, together with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTI), is consistent with colovesical fistula (CVF) secondary to Crohn disease.

A CVF is described as an atypical connection between the colon and urinary bladder. It most commonly develops as a complication of diverticulitis, malignancy, or Crohn disease (as in this patient). In the case of Crohn disease, long-standing transmural inflammation of the bowel wall can lead to erosion into the adjacent organ(s), resulting in fistula formation. If such erosion involves the bladder, it presents with irritative lower urinary tract symptoms (e.g., dysuria, frequency, urgency), pneumaturia (air in urine) and/or fecaluria (feces in urine). A history of recurrent UTI secondary to anaerobic organisms (e.g. E. coli) can also be seen. Diagnosis is confirmed on abdominopelvic computed tomography (CT) scan with oral or rectal contrast, and the imaging will illustrate air or contrast in the bladder with adjacent colonic wall thickening.



Other common complications of Crohn disease include malabsorption (due to associated ileitis), increased risk of colorectal cancer, abscess formation, strictures and perianal disease.



Option Analysis

❌ Bladder cancer:
Incorrect: Bladder cancer usually presents with gross hematuria. Long-term smoking is the major risk factor. Storage (irritative) urinary symptoms can sometimes be present due to secondary urinary infection, but pneumaturia is unlikely.
✅ Colovesical fistula:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emphysematous pyelonephritis :
Incorrect: Emphysematous pyelonephritis is a necrotizing infection of renal parenchyma that usually presents with fever, chills, flank pain, nausea and vomiting. A normal serum creatinine would be atypical.
❌ Toxic megacolon:
Incorrect: Toxic megacolon, which is a nonobstructive colonic dilatation, is a potentially lethal complication. It is a surgical emergency that commonly presents with severe bloody diarrhea, abdominal distension, and hemodynamic instability (fever, tachycardia, and hypotension). Long-standing intermittent watery diarrhea with urinary frequency and pneumaturia are unlikely.
❌ Urethral diverticulum:
Incorrect: Urethral diverticulum refers to the out-pouching of urethral mucosa into the mid-to-distal urethra. It usually presents with post-void dribbling, dyspareunia or dysuria. Gastrointestinal symptoms with pneumaturia are atypical.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided flank pain and dark urine for the past few hours. The patient states, “I thought my back was acting up again so I took two extra naproxen today. I decided to come get checked out once my urine appeared dark.” The patient denies dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, fever or chills. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic lumbosacral back pain and migraine headaches. Current medications include phenacetin, acetaminophen, ibuprofen, naproxen and insulin. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8° F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Serum creatinine is 1.9 mg/dL. Urinalysis is shown.  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Urinalysis 
 Color  Clear 
 Specific gravity  1.013 
 Protein  1.0 g/day 
 Blood  Positive 
 Leukocyte esterase  Negative 
 Leukocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Erythrocytes  40-42/hpf 
 Dysmorphic RBCs  Absent 
 Casts  None 
   
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s hematuria?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of acute onset colicky flank pain, hematuria, long-term history of analgesic consumption, and presence of erythrocytes on urinalysis is strongly suggestive of renal papillary necrosis (RPN).  

This condition results from ischemia of the renal papillae due to decreased blood flow through the small caliber arteries feeding this region. Diminished perfusion may result either from mechanical obstruction, inflammation or vasoconstriction--ultimately resulting in necrosis and sloughing of the papillae causing hematuria and colicky flank pain. Associated conditions include: 
  •  Sickle cell disease/trait, in which sickled cells cause mechanical obstruction of renal vessels. 
  •  Diabetes mellitus, which can cause renal atherosclerosis and subsequently hypoperfusion. 
  • Analgesic nephropathy, wherein analgesics, including NSAIDs, reduce renal perfusion by inhibiting prostaglandin production, which leads to constriction of renal afferent arterioles. 
  •  Acute pyelonephritis, wherein the inflamed kidney may compress against the renal vasculature, resulting in hypoperfusion and ischemia.

Option Analysis

❌ Urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Urinary tract infection may present with flank pain and hematuria, but it is unlikely in this patient with normal vitals and a negative leukocyte esterase on urinalysis. 
❌ Nephritic syndrome:
Incorrect: Although hematuria and proteinuria are observed in nephritic syndrome, this condition is typically accompanied by hypertension, red blood cell casts, and dysmorphic red blood cells. 
❌ Renal artery stenosis:
Incorrect: Renal artery stenosis presents with treatment resistant hypertension, flash pulmonary edema, or an acute rise in serum creatinine following ACEI or ARB administration. This patient’s normal blood pressure negates this diagnosis. 
❌ Hemolytic uremic syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome occurs in response to shiga-like toxin-producing organisms and presents with the triad of acute kidney injury, hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia one to two weeks following a diarrheal illness. 
✅ Renal papillary necrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man presents to the office for the evaluation of a lesion on the shaft of his penis. The patient first noticed the lesion around 6 months ago and reports that it has gradually increased in size over time. Past medical history is significant for hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mmHg. Physical examination shows a single, well-defined erythematous velvety plaque on the shaft of the penis. The decision to perform a biopsy of the lesion is made. Histopathology is shown below:



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The examination findings of a well-defined erythematous plaque, together with histopathological picture evident of atypical keratinocytes (hyperchromatic, dysplastic dyskeratotic epithelial cells with scattered mitoses) along the full thickness of epidermis without invasion of basement membrane, is typical of squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease).

Bowen disease is an intraepidermal malignant tumor of keratinocytes which commonly affects individuals with prolonged sunlight exposure, human papillomavirus (HPV) 16 infection, chronic arsenic exposure, or immunosuppression. It is usually asymptomatic and appears as a slowly growing well-defined erythematous scaly plaque or papule on sun-exposed areas. Bowen disease can also present as a plaque located on the scrotum or shaft of the penis.


Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons

When Bowen disease involves the glans of the penis, it is called erythroplasia of Queyrat, and it presents as a velvety red plaque. Histopathology shows full thickness epidermal hyperplasia with atypical keratinocytes (hyperchromatic, dysplastic dyskeratotic epithelial cells with scattered mitoses) without the invasion of the basement membrane. Progression to invasive squamous cell carcinoma occurs in approximately 10% of cases over the course of several years.   

Option Analysis

❌ Actinic keratosis:
Incorrect: Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion that usually presents with <1 cm erythematous macules or papules with or without scaling on sun-exposed areas. Physical examination shows a sandpaper-like texture on palpation.
