Histopathology shows partial thickness epidermal dysplasia (unlike the full thickness epidermal involvement in this patient) with atypical keratinocytes.
✅ Squamous cell carcinoma in situ:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Invasive squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Histopathology of invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) shows dysplastic keratinocytes involving the full thickness of the epidermis that penetrates the epidermal basement membrane to involve the dermis or deeper layers. In contrast, this patient’s histopathology shows atypical keratinocytes confined to the epidermis with an intact basement membrane. 
❌ Condyloma acuminata:
Incorrect: Condyloma acuminata is a sexually transmitted infection that is associated with HPV. It usually affects the coronal sulcus or prepuce of penis in men and presents as a single or multiple, sessile or pedunculated cauliflower-shaped lesions. Histopathology would show mature epithelial cells covering branching, villous, papillary connective tissue stroma. Dysplastic keratinocytes are unlikely.
❌ Peyronie disease:
Incorrect: Peyronie disease is a fibrotic disorder of tunica albuginea of penis which results in abnormal curvature of penis and pain during intercourse. A thick erythematous plaque on the shaft of penis is atypical.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of an ulcerating lesion on his left foot. He states the lesion is hyperpigmented and has been there for the past several years, but he recently noticed that it started itching and growing in size. He has been working as a mail carrier for the past 30 years, delivering mail outdoors for several hours daily. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II for 20 years. He takes metformin and sulfonylurea regularly. He is of Asian-American descent. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows a hyperpigmented ulcerating lesion on the left foot as shown in the image:



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Biopsy of the lesion confirms the diagnosis of melanoma. This lesion represents which of the following subtypes of a melanoma based on its pathologic characteristics?
questions.solution:
This patient of Asian-American descent presents with a pruritic, hyperpigmented, ulcerating lesion on the lateral surface of his left foot, which, together with the biopsy findings suggestive of melanoma, suggests acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM). This type of melanoma is the most common subtype of melanoma among patients of African- and Asian-American descent.

Clinically, it appears as a dark brown-to-black, unevenly pigmented patch (arrows). Areas of regression manifest as foci of gray-white discoloration. If a lesion becomes raised or develops ulceration (as in this patient [arrowhead]), the likelihood of invasion should be considered.



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Not all melanomas arising in acral (acral meaning affecting peripheral parts, such as limbs, fingers, or ears) sites are ALM. Histologically, ALM appears as a lentiginous array of large, hyperchromatic, angulated melanocytes along the dermoepidermal junction which eventually extend into the epidermis. If it involves a nail, it is called subungual melanoma and presents as a longitudinal brown or black band from the tip of the nail down to the nail bed and into the cuticle (Hutchinson sign), with or without nail dystrophy.



Option Analysis

❌ Superficial spreading melanoma:
Incorrect: Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common subtype of melanoma, and it clinically appears as a variably pigmented plaque-like lesion with irregular borders, ranging from a few millimeters to several centimeters in diameter. Color variegation can sometimes be appreciated in these lesions.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Lentigo maligna melanoma:
Incorrect: Mostly involving sun-damaged areas of skin, lentigo maligna melanoma usually appears as a freckle-like tan-brown macule which gradually enlarges and develops darker, asymmetric foci.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Acral lentiginous melanoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nodular melanoma:
Incorrect: Nodular melanoma constitutes up to 30% of all melanomas and clinically appears as a darkly pigmented, pedunculated or polypoid nodule. Amelanotic variants are infrequently seen.



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to her primary pediatrician for evaluation of dyspnea. The patient feels tired throughout the day, despite sleeping for nine hours every night. She additionally describes intermittent trouble breathing with exertion. The patient’s mother and grandmother have suffered from similar symptoms throughout their lives and have a “problem with the vessels in our lungs.” An echocardiogram is performed, which is within normal limits. Cardiac catheterization is performed, and the patient’s mean pulmonary artery pressure is 32 mmHg (normal <25 mmHg). A mutation in which of the following genes is the most likely etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This young patient is suffering from symptoms of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). While her symptomatology is minimal, early recognition of this disease process is key to prevent progression of disease. Her high mean pulmonary arterial pressure is diagnostic of pulmonary hypertension. Other members of the patient’s family also suffer from similar symptoms, which suggests an inherited pattern of disease transmission.

There are numerous underlying causes of pulmonary arterial hypertension; however, this patient's history suggests heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension (HPAH). HPAH is diagnosed via either a multigene assay or a single gene assay for genes which have been identified as possibly causing HPAH. There are currently approximately 6 genes linked to HPAH, most of which are beyond the scope of testing for board examination purposes. However, BMPR2 has the closest association with HPAH. Approximately 75% of mutant variation of BMPR2 have been shown as pathogenic variants causing HPAH.  

Option Analysis

❌ HFE:
Incorrect: Mutations in this gene are associated with hemochromatosis, not pulmonary arterial hypertension.
✅ BMPR2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HLA-DR:
Incorrect: Mutations in this gene are associated with rheumatoid arthritis and diabetes, not pulmonary arterial hypertension.
❌ COL11A2:
Incorrect: Mutations in this gene are associated with Stickler syndrome, not pulmonary arterial hypertension.
❌  CFTR:
Incorrect: Mutations in this gene are associated with cystic fibrosis, not pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right-sided scrotal fullness of several weeks duration. The patient describes a dull, achy pain in his scrotum when standing for prolonged periods of time. He has noticed a 4.1-kg (9-lb) weight loss over the past three months and intermittent blood in his urine. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. He has a 45-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals temporal wasting and diffuse loss of muscle tone. Scrotal examination reveals a right-sided mass that feels like a “bag of worms” and does not decompress in the recumbent position. The left testicle is unremarkable. The scrotum does not transilluminate. Right-sided flank pain is reproduced with palpation. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Inadequate fixation of the testis to the tunica vaginalis
Bowel protrusion through the inguinal canal

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a right-sided varicocele (scrotal mass that feels like a “bag of worms”), as well as systemic symptoms (weight-loss, muscle wasting), and painless hematuria. Together these findings are suggestive of underlying renal cell carcinoma.

Varicoceles arise from impaired venous drainage. Veins in the pampiniform plexus slowly dilate and enlarge over time--resulting in an enlarged, edematous scrotum. It is important to note that varicoceles occur much more commonly on the left, due to suboptimal venous drainage; the left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein at a right angle, and it can be compressed between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery above the renal vein, thereby producing a "nutcracker effect." In contrast, a unilateral, right-sided varicocele is much rarer since the right gonadal vein empties directly into the inferior vena cava. When a right sided varicocele is observed it should immediately raise suspicion of an underlying compressive mass such as renal cell carcinoma.

Although many varicoceles may be asymptomatic, clinical features of symptomatic varicoceles include dull, aching, scrotal pain, typically worsened with standing and relieved by recumbency. Varicoceles that are not altered with changes in position suggest an underlying obstructive process (from thrombus or extrinsic masses). Palpation of the scrotum reveals an enlarged, tortuous dilation of the veins, often resembling a “bag of worms.”  

Option Analysis

✅ Renal cell carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inadequate fixation of the testis to the tunica vaginalis:
Incorrect: Testicular torsion can occur in young males due to inadequate fixation of the lower pole of the testis to the tunica vaginalis. This patient’s chronic course of scrotal pain and hematuria suggests a different etiology.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A hydrocele refers to a collection of peritoneal fluid between the parietal and visceral layers of the tunica vaginalis. Although hydrocele is a potential cause of testicular swelling, it is almost always painless. Also, physical examination typically reveals transillumination, making this etiology less likely.
❌ Bowel protrusion through the inguinal canal:
Incorrect: This answer describes an inguinal hernia. This patient’s constellation of symptoms (e.g., cachexia, right-sided varicocele) suggests a different etiology.
❌ Metastatic prostate cancer:
Incorrect: Metastatic prostate cancer can present with systemic signs (e.g., weight-loss, cachexia), as well as significant lower back pain. Although this patient is at increased risk due to his age, this unilateral, right-sided varicocele and painless hematuria suggests a different malignancy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic due to a recent onset of face swelling and headaches. He mentions that he woke up with these symptoms 2 days ago, and bending down, such as to tie his shoes, makes the symptoms worse. The patients also reports a non-productive cough, mild chest pain, and dyspnea over the past 6 weeks. Social history is significant for chronic alcohol use and smoking 1.5 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, facial swelling and facial plethora are noted. Edema is noted in both upper extremities but not the lower extremities. Venous distention is present on the neck and chest wall. Cardiac auscultation is within normal limits. This patient's condition is most likely caused by which of the following?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

questions.solution:
This patient, who has a significant smoking history, now presents with an abrupt onset of face swelling, prominent vessels on the chest and neck, and headaches -- most likely suggesting superior vena cava syndrome due to lung cancer.

Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome can be the result of any condition that leads to obstruction of blood flow through the SVC, including direct invasion of a tumor, external compression, and thrombosis. The most common causes are lung cancer and non-Hodgkin lymphoma (mediastinal). Thromboses can arise in the setting of hypercoagulable states, such as cancer, or from an indwelling catheter. Regardless of the etiology, as the flow of blood within the SVC becomes limited, venous collaterals develop and form alternative pathways to allow blood flow back to the right atrium.

Signs and symptoms of thoracic central venous obstruction consist of face and neck swelling, prominent vessels on the chest and neck, chest pain, respiratory symptoms, and neurologic manifestations (e.g., headaches, visual/auditory disturbances). Patients often complain of facial swelling or head fullness, which is exacerbated by leaning forward or lying down, or arm swelling. If the swelling compromises the larynx or pharynx, dyspnea, stridor, cough, hoarseness, and dysphagia may occur. Additionally, backflow of blood may result in cerebral edema and, subsequent confusion, visual/auditory disturbances, brainstem herniation, and possibly death.



Superior vena cava syndrome resulting in significantly dilated superficial veins
Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Autoimmune disease:
Incorrect: Autoimmune diseases, such as dermatomyositis, can cause facial plethora; however, this diagnosis would not cause dilated neck veins or arm swelling. Also, other symptoms would be expected (e.g., proximal muscle weakness, Gottron papules).
❌ Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH):
Incorrect: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) can occur due to various causes (e.g., small cell lung cancer, head trauma) and lead to excessive free water retention. However, patients are usually euvolemic and hyponatremic due to the aldosterone escape mechanism. SIADH will not present with facial or upper extremity edema.
❌ Liver cirrhosis:
Incorrect: Liver cirrhosis due to chronic alcohol use can present with abdominal distension from ascites and lower extremity edema. However, it does not cause neck swelling and facial plethora. Also, other features of cirrhosis would be expected (e.g., jaundice, spider angiomata).
✅ Lung tumor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cavernous sinus thrombosis:
Incorrect: Cavernous sinus thrombosis usually occurs due to the spread of an infection from adjacent tissues (e.g., nose infection, dental infections). It typically presents with abrupt onset of unilateral periorbital edema, headache, photophobia, and bulging of the eye (proptosis). It does not cause facial plethora or venous distension in the neck or chest.

questions.text:
A 65-years-old man comes to the clinic due to the gradual onset of chest pain, dyspnea, and night sweats for the past 2 months. He also reports a nagging non-productive cough for which he tried over the counter cough syrup with no relief. He does not drink alcohol but has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, decreased air movement and unilateral dullness to percussion at the lung base are noted on the left side. Computed tomography is obtained and shown below:


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

This patient’s condition is most likely associated with which of the following occupational exposures?
questions.solution:
This patient presentation of chest pain, dyspnea, night sweats, and cough, along with the imaging findings showing pleural thickening, is consistent with malignant mesothelioma.

Malignant mesothelioma is a malignancy of the pleura that is most often associated with asbestosis exposure. It can arise from mesothelial surfaces of the pleural cavity, peritoneal cavity, or pericardium. Asbestos is a naturally occurring silicate mineral used in the past in the shipbuilding, roofing, and plumbing industries. As with other silica crystals, once phagocytosed by macrophages, asbestos fibers trigger the inflammasome and damage phagolysosomal membranes, stimulating the release of inflammatory factors and fibrogenic mediators. Additionally, asbestos likely functions as both a tumor initiator and promoter. Asbestos exposure increases the risk of bronchogenic carcinoma and, to a lesser extent, mesothelioma. Disease presentation usually occurs 20-30 years after exposure.

Symptoms of mesothelioma may include chest pain, dyspnea, cough, hoarseness, night sweats, and dysphagia. Common physical findings at the time of diagnosis are usually due to pleural effusion and thus include unilateral dullness to percussion at the lung base and decreased air movement in the involved side. Radiographic findings of pleural mesothelioma may include unilateral pleural effusion, diffuse pleural thickening, and pleural plaques (as indicated by the yellow outline) and/or calcifications.



Option Analysis

❌ Incarcerated individuals:
Incorrect: Exposure to incarcerated individuals may increase the risk for tuberculosis, which may present as weight loss, productive cough with blood, night sweats and shortness of breath. Although this patient’s symptoms overlap with tuberculosis, the imaging findings favor another diagnosis.
❌ Aerospace industry:
Incorrect: Working in the aerospace industry is a risk for exposure to beryllium, which is a cause of berylliosis. Pulmonary berylliosis shares many features with sarcoidosis, including non-caseating granulomas, nodular infiltrates, and enlarged lymph nodes. It mainly affects the upper lobes of the lungs and not the pleura, as seen in this patient.
❌ Sandblasting:
Incorrect: Silicosis can occur due to exposure to silica found in sandblasting industries. Silicosis mainly affects the upper lobes and presents with “eggshell” calcification of hilar lymph nodes on imaging. Pleural involvement is not seen.
✅ Shipyard:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Textile industry:
Incorrect: Aromatic amines exposure can occur in the textile industry (dyes) and cigarette smoke (2-naphthylamine). Aromatic amines are associated with transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic to establish care. She is starting a new job as a receptionist and wants to "take care of her irregular periods.” Her menarche was at age 14 and she has been having irregular periods since then. Review of systems is significant for deepening of voice. Past medical history is unremarkable. She only takes over the counter multivitamins. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 32 kg/m2. Physical examination shows papulo-pustular acne on the face and a receding hairline. Pelvic examination reveals normal external genitalia and a mobile and nontender uterus with no adnexal masses. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with irregular menses and obesity, together with findings concerning for hyperandrogenism (deepening of voice, receding hairline), is typical of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis as per Rotterdam criteria. Such patients are at increased risk of developing endometrial carcinoma in the long-term.

PCOS is a result of dysfunction in the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis which causes high pulses of GnRH, resulting in an imbalance of LH/FSH release from the pituitary. The end result is a lack of LH surge, leading to failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. This causes unopposed estrogen exposure on the endometrium. Moreover, anovulation results in decreased progesterone, allowing excessive endometrial build-up and thus increasing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and subsequent carcinoma. In addition, increased adiposity in PCOS also increases estrone, further raising the risk.

Other long-term complications that are associated with PCOS include nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, metabolic syndrome, coronary artery disease, mood disorders (e.g., depression, anxiety) and sleep disorders (e.g., hypersomnia, obstructive sleep apnea)  

Option Analysis

❌ Ovarian cyst rupture:
Incorrect: Ovarian cyst rupture is not a complication of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), as PCOS does not actually cause cyst formation (a misnomer). The cystic spaces seen on ultrasound are immature follicles rather than cysts. As such, incidental finding of cystic ovaries on imaging without clinical features of PCOS does not require further evaluation.
❌ Narcolepsy:
Incorrect: Although PCOS is associated with increased risk of developing certain sleep disorders (hypersomnia and obstructive sleep apnea), it is not associated with increased risk of developing narcolepsy.
❌ Virilization:
Incorrect: Virilization is not seen in PCOS, as the testosterone levels are elevated but not to the degree necessary to produce frank masculinization. If there is evidence of virilization, such as clitoromegaly, alternate diagnoses should be considered (e.g. testosterone-secreting tumor).
✅ Endometrial carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ovarian cancer:
Incorrect: PCOS is not associated with increased risk of developing ovarian cancer and does not require additional screening.

questions.text:
A 90-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of new onset confusion. Two days ago, her family noticed she decreased her oral intake. This morning, her family found her slumped over in a chair and unresponsive. She has a history of type 2 diabetes, dementia, and hypertension, for which she takes insulin, donepezil, and hydrochlorothiazide. One week ago, she was started on isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide for active pulmonary mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. Her temperature is 36.4°C (97.5° F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% breathing room air. She appears stuporous. Physical examination shows conjugate eye deviation to the right and brisk reflexes with bilateral ankle clonus. Lung exam is normal. Laboratory studies show the following:

Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
Sodium   138 mEq/L 
 Potassium   5.6 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  15 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   1.2 mg/dL 
 Glucose  120 mg/dL 
Arterial blood gas  
 pH  7.21 
 PaCO2  40 mmHg 
 PaO2  120 mmHg 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of active tuberculosis treatment along with a low serum bicarbonate level suggests a diagnosis of high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) secondary to isoniazid use. HAGMA occurs when bicarbonate (HCO3-) decreases as it binds to excess hydrogen (H+), resulting in the formation of carbonic acid (H2CO3), and subsequent breakdown into CO2 and H2O.

Excess hydrogen ions may come from increased organic acid production, as in diabetic ketoacidosis, or due to an inability of the kidneys to excrete them. The latter often occurs in cases of chronic renal failure in the uremic phase. Excess lactate production (another organic acid), as occurs in sepsis, will also result in HAGMA.

In other cases, hydrogen ions are ingested in the form of exogenous acids. These acids include oxalic acid, which can build up after an ingestion of ethylene glycol (used in antifreeze), and formic acid, which is a metabolite of methanol. Salicylic acid (aspirin) overdose can also cause HAGMA in the later phases of toxicity.

Lastly, certain substances promote anaerobic metabolism and, in turn, lactic acid production. These substances include propylene glycol (also used in antifreeze), iron, and isoniazid. Isoniazid overdose induces a lactic acidosis by increasing seizure activity, which rapidly depletes glycogen stores and promotes anaerobic metabolism.

You can remember the causes of a high anion gap metabolic acidosis using the mnemonic MUDPILES, where M stands for methanol, U is for uremia, D is for diabetic ketoacidosis, P is for propylene glycol, I is for iron tablets and isoniazid, L is for lactic acidosis, E is for ethylene glycol, and finally, S is for salicylates.



Option Analysis

✅ Increased anaerobic metabolism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased ketoacid production:
Incorrect: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) most commonly occurs in Type 1 diabetes in the setting of infection or insufficient insulin dosing. It is characterized by a buildup of ketones (ketoacids) from fat metabolism, leading to metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap. The blood sugar level in DKA is greater than 250 mg/dL.
❌ Increased renal bicarbonate excretion:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, causes increased bicarbonate excretion in the kidneys. This increased excretion leads to metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap. Acetazolamide is most commonly used to treat altitude sickness and intracranial hypertension.
❌ Impaired renal acid excretion:
Incorrect: Impaired renal acid excretion, as occurs in the uremic phase of chronic renal failure, leads to a buildup of organic acids (like uric acid) in the blood. This accumulation leads to chronic metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap. Renal failure is characterized by a markedly elevated serum creatinine level.
❌ Impaired renal sodium chloride reabsorption:
Incorrect: Gitelman syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder, impairs sodium chloride reabsorption in the distal tubule. This defect leads to metabolic alkalosis with hypokalemia, the same effect seen with excessive thiazide diuretic exposure.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset palpitations, dyspnea, and dizziness. His medical history includes anxiety and atopic dermatitis, managed with fluoxetine and topical corticosteroids, respectively. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 135/86 mmHg. Examination of the chest demonstrates pectus excavatum. Cardiac auscultation reveals a midsystolic click followed by a late-systolic crescendo murmur over the cardiac apex. ECG demonstrates normal sinus rhythm with occasional premature ventricular contractions and early repolarization abnormalities. The patient is provided with lorazepam with improvement in his clinical condition. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with palpitations, anxiety, and dizziness. Cardiac auscultation reveals a midsystolic click followed by later systolic crescendo murmur, and the electrocardiogram demonstrates non-specific repolarization abnormalities and premature ventricular contractions. Together, these findings are most consistent with underlying mitral valve prolapse (MVP).

Mitral valve prolapse is caused by myxomatous valve degeneration, wherein glycosaminoglycans inappropriately deposit in and around cardiac valves causing mechanical dysfunction. Prolapse occurs when valve leaflets shift into the left atrium, and it may be primary (idiopathic or familial) or secondary to connective tissue disease(s) (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan syndrome -- as suggested by this patient’s pectus excavatum).

Overall, mitral valve prolapse is the most common cause of mitral regurgitation. During auscultation, the midsystolic click occurs secondary to abrupt tensing of the chordae tendineae during systole. Patients are often asymptomatic, but they may present with dyspnea, palpitations, exercise intolerance, and dizziness. No electrocardiographic findings are a reliable indicator of MVP; however, ECGs commonly demonstrate repolarization abnormalities. Formal diagnosis is made via echocardiography, and repair is indicated when MVP results in severe symptomatic mitral regurgitation.

Option Analysis

❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis (AS) is heard as a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur over the right 2nd intercostal space with radiation to the carotids. AS is the most common cause of left ventricular outflow obstruction. It commonly presents with age-related calcifications in patients over the age of 60, though it can also present in younger patients with underlying bicuspid aortic valve or rheumatic heart disease. Common clinical findings include exertional dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, dizziness, syncope, exertional angina, and arrhythmias.
❌ Ventricular septal defect:
Incorrect: A ventricular septal defect results in a holosystolic murmur over the 4th left intercostal space (tricuspid area). A mild VSD may be asymptomatic, while a large VSD may induce heart failure.
✅ Mitral valve prolapse:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Coarctation of the aorta:
Incorrect: Coarctation of the aorta refers to the narrowing of the descending aorta, typically at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, distal to the left subclavian artery. Occasionally, a systolic murmur can be appreciated at the left paravertebral interscapular space. Clinical findings include hypertension in the upper extremities and weak, delayed pulses in the lower extremities.
❌ Mitral stenosis:
Incorrect: Mitral stenosis (MS) is characterized by an opening snap followed by a rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur best heard at the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space (mitral area). Patients with MS present with dyspnea, chest pain, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to left atrial enlargement.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset palpitations and lightheadedness. His symptoms began one hour ago while working in his garden. He reports similar episodes over the past several months that self-resolved. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min irregularly irregular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, a rumbling mid-diastolic murmur is heard over the cardiac apex when the patient lies in the left lateral decubitus position. Further history will most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Family history of sudden cardiac death

questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent palpitations, an irregularly irregular rhythm, and a rumbling mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex. These findings suggest atrial fibrillation secondary to mitral stenosis. The most common cause of mitral stenosis is rheumatic heart disease, which often presents with recurrent joint pain during childhood.

Mitral stenosis (MS) refers to a stenotic or mitral valve that impedes blood flow into the left ventricle during diastole. In the case of rheumatic heart disease, pathogenesis involves antibody production and a subsequent T cell response against myosin, which shares similar epitopes with the M protein virulence factor of the bacteria (type II hypersensitivity). This immune response results in recurrent inflammation and fibrinous repair of the mitral valve, leaflet thickening, and commissural fusion. Of note, 50-70% of patients with MS report a history of rheumatic fever.

Clinical features of MS include dyspnea, chest pain, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to left atrial enlargement. Atrial fibrillation often occurs in patients with MS due prolonged elevation of left atrial pressure, left atrial enlargement, and cardiac remodeling, all of which result in cardiac conduction disturbance. 

Option Analysis

❌ Family history of sudden cardiac death:
Incorrect: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is an autosomal dominant cardiac disorder that results in left-ventricular outflow obstruction. Patients with HOCM are typically young and present with dyspnea on exertion, atypical or anginal chest pain, exertional syncope, palpitations, and sudden cardiac death. Cardiac auscultation reveals a systolic ejection murmur over the 3rd right intercostal space.
✅ Recurrent juvenile arthropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypercoagulable state :
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism may result in pulmonary hypertension, right heart failure, and subsequent tricuspid regurgitation. The characteristics of this patient’s murmur favor another diagnosis.
❌ Low T4 level:
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism is a potential reversible cause of atrial fibrillation; however, hyperthyroidism would present with high T4 hormone levels.
❌ Myxomatous valve degeneration:
Incorrect: Mitral valve prolapse is caused by myxomatous valve degeneration due to glycosaminoglycan deposition in and around the cardiac valves. It may be primary (idiopathic or familial) or secondary to connective tissue disease (e.g. Marfan or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). During auscultation, a midsystolic click is appreciated due to abrupt tensing of the chordae tendineae. Patients are often asymptomatic or present with nonspecific symptoms including dyspnea, palpitations, exercise intolerance, or dizziness.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of “changing facial features” that began seven-months ago. The patient describes that her forehead and jaw appear bigger than before. In addition, she endorses deepening of her voice and “being sweaty.” Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mmHg. As part of the work-up process, serum insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels are measured. In addition, growth hormone (GH) levels are measured before and after the administration of glucose. Which of the following sets of findings will most likely be seen in this patient?

choices.text: IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load Normal  Normal  ↓
IGF-1  GH before oral glucose load  GH after oral glucose load ↓↑↑
IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load ↓↑ ↓
IGF-1  GH before oral glucose load  GH after oral glucose load ↑↑↑
IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load ↑↑ ↓

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of changing facial features, hyperhidrosis, and deepening voice raises concern for acromegaly, a disorder of excess GH that is usually a result of a functional pituitary adenoma secreting GH.

There are three steps in the diagnostic process. The first step is to measure IGF-1, a growth factor produced by the liver in response to stimulation by GH which stimulates growth of the long bones. Daily GH secretion is pulsatile, but it stimulates the liver to release a constant amount of IGF-1. As a result, there is less variability between IGF-1 measurements, making IGF-1 a better predictor of GH excess.

If high IGF-1 levels are detected, the second step is to perform an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), where serum GH is measured before and after glucose administration. In healthy individuals, elevated blood glucose will cause the body to stop producing GH. Inability to suppress GH secretion raises concern for a GH-secreting adenoma. The third step involves obtaining a brain MRI to assess the tumor’s location and size.

 


Treatment consists of transsphenoidal resection. If surgery is unsuccessful, dopamine agonists like cabergoline or GH receptor antagonists like pegvisomant can be used. Some cases might also require radiotherapy.

Option Analysis

❌ IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load Normal  Normal  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are expected in normal individuals. Oral glucose administration suppresses GH secretion and is the standard method for assessing inhibitory control of GH release. However, this patient’s history of changing facial features, hyperhidrosis, and voice deepening raise concerns for an underlying pathology of growth hormone excess.
❌  IGF-1  GH before oral glucose load  GH after oral glucose load ↓↑↑:
Incorrect: Although patients with acromegaly typically have elevated growth hormone levels that remain elevated after an oral glucose tolerance test, they also tend to have elevated IGF-1 levels.
❌ IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load ↓↑ ↓ :
Incorrect: This patient’s history of changing facial features, hyperhidrosis, and deepening voice all raise suspicion for acromegaly. However, patients with acromegaly will have elevated IGF-1 levels and elevated growth hormone levels that do not decrease after an oral glucose tolerance test.
✅  IGF-1  GH before oral glucose load  GH after oral glucose load ↑↑↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load ↑↑ ↓ :
Incorrect: Patients with acromegaly have elevated levels of growth hormone, which in turn increases IGF-1 production. However, the growth hormone levels will remain elevated even after administering an oral glucose tolerance test.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for evaluation of leg pain. He has been experiencing progressive leg pain over the past 3 months that is worse with activity. The parents report that the patient also has difficulty running and walking up stairs for the past year, and they have noticed that he always “walks on his toes.” He was adopted as an infant, and family history is unknown. Vitals are within normal limits. Height, weight and head circumference is at 20th percentile, similar to previous visits. Physical examination shows bilateral calf hypertrophy and thin, atrophied thighs. Extremities are nontender to palpation. When asked to rise from the floor the boy uses hand support to push himself to an upright position. He has a waddling gait. Which of the following laboratory tests will most likely help to develop a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder that typically results from frameshift deletions or nonsense mutations in dystrophin genes leading to a truncated or absent dystrophin protein. It should be suspected in this patient with proximal muscle weakness and Gower sign (using hand support to push himself to an upright position). Enlargement of the calf is due to muscle replacement with fat (pseudohypertrophy), which is often associated with leg pain. In addition, a waddling gait and toe walking are common findings.



Later symptoms include wheelchair dependence by the age of 12, respiratory failure because of a weak diaphragm, scoliosis, and dilated cardiomyopathy and arrhythmias, since the dystrophin protein is also expressed in heart muscle.

Serum creatinine kinase is markedly elevated in children with DMD and is at its peak around the age of 2 years. The levels typically fall thereafter, mainly due to the replacement of muscle by fat and fibrosis. Serum aldolase levels, aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT) are also elevated. An elevated creatine kinase is followed by genetic testing to confirm the deletion of the dystrophin gene.

Option Analysis

❌ Karyotype analysis:
Incorrect: Karyotype analysis can help detect Down syndrome, which can cause motor delay. Affected patients have typical dysmorphic features (e.g., epicanthal folds, single palmar crease) and language delay. Gower sign and pseudohypertrophy of calves would be atypical.
✅ Serum creatinine kinase level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum TSH level:
Incorrect: Serum TSH can be used as a screening test for hypothyroidism in this patient. Hypothyroidism in children can present with developmental delay and weakness, as well as decreased height velocity. This patient’s height is tracking consistently at the 20th percentile, and his other signs (e.g., calf hypertrophy, Gower sign) suggest a different diagnosis.
❌ Skeletal survey:
Incorrect: Skeletal survey can be used in children to evaluate for suspected fractures or child abuse. Although patients with DMD are susceptible to fractures, this patient’s examination is nonfocal, and there is no evidence of child abuse.
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound can be obtained to evaluate WAGR syndrome to detect Wilms tumor. Affected patients present with aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities and intellectual disability. These findings are not present in this patient.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents for evaluation of a painless right testicular mass. The patient first noticed the mass 3 weeks ago while showering, and he is not sure if it has been enlarging. Medical history is notable for right-sided cryptorchidism as a child, which was treated via orchiopexy at the age of 1. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 105/77 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a nontender nodule on the right testicle which does not transilluminate or decrease in size when the patient lies flat. After further diagnostic testing is performed, the physician suspects a testicular cancer and schedules an orchiectomy. Gross analysis of the tumor reveals a homogenous mass with no hemorrhage or necrosis. Histological examination reveals the following:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the serum markers was most likely elevated prior to orchiectomy?
questions.solution:
This patient has a non-hemorrhagic, non-necrotic testicular mass that demonstrates a “fried egg appearance” on histological analysis. These findings are consistent with those of a testicular seminoma, which can cause elevated placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) levels.

Seminomas are the most common type of germ cell tumor. Of note, a seminoma is the testicular analog of an ovarian dysgerminoma in women. Gross examination of a seminoma typically shows a homogenous mass with no hemorrhage or necrosis. On microscopic examination, tumor cells appear large with central nuclei surrounded by clear cytoplasm, and they are thus said to have a “fried egg” appearance. On laboratory testing, patients will have elevated PLAP levels, whereas alpha-fetoprotein and beta-hCG levels are typically normal.

In regards to prognosis, seminomas exhibit a slow growth rate, metastasize late, respond well to radiotherapy, and overall have an excellent prognosis.






Option Analysis

❌ Human chorionic gonadotropin:
Incorrect: This patient has a non-hemorrhagic, non-necrotic mass on gross examination and cells with a “fried egg” appearance on histology. He most likely has a seminoma. Although some patients with seminomas may have elevated human chorionic gonadotropin (ꞵ-hCG) levels, elevations in placental alkaline phosphatase are more common.
❌ Alpha-fetoprotein:
Incorrect: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is elevated in yolk sac tumors and mixed embryonal carcinomas. Instead, this patient has a non-hemorrhagic, non-necrotic mass on gross examination and cells with a “fried egg” appearance on histology. Thus he most likely had a seminoma, which is not associated with elevated AFP levels.
✅ Placental alkaline phosphatase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adrenocorticotropic hormone:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) can be associated with squamous cell lung cancer, pancreatic cancer, and cancers of the central nervous systems. However, seminomas would not cause increases in ACTH levels.
❌ Parathyroid hormone-related peptide:
Incorrect: Parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) is elevated in several malignancies, including squamous cell carcinoma and ovarian cancer. However, it is not elevated in testicular seminomas.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS after he was found at a public park yelling at bystanders. Several unlabeled pill capsules are found in his belongings. Temperature is 100°F (37.7 °C), pulse is 117 bpm, respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and blood pressure is 177/90 mmHg. The patient appears agitated and diaphoretic. On physical examination, the patient has noted mydriasis bilaterally. There is absence of clonus in the lower extremities bilaterally. Oral mucosa appears moist. Intranasal examination reveals septal ulceration. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with psychomotor agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, septal ulceration, and aggressive behavior--suggestive of stimulant intoxication. Cocaine and associated amphetamines (MDMA, ecstasy, methamphetamine) are psychoactive stimulants with varying effects on the enhancement of dopaminergic, serotonergic, and noradrenergic activity in the central nervous system. Non-specific features of stimulant intoxication include anxiety, aggressive behaviour, psychomotor agitation, delirium, hypertension, tachycardia, pupillary dilation, mydriasis and diaphoresis. In high doses, hallucinations and paranoia may be present. In addition, serotonin syndrome may ensue if multiple, or high quantities of, serotonergic agents are ingested.

Abrupt cessation of stimulant use manifests with effects opposite to the intoxicating effects. These features include hypersomnia, increased appetite, pupillary constriction, psychomotor retardation and depression.

 


Option Analysis

✅ Amphetamine intoxication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cannabis intoxication :
Incorrect: Symptoms of cannabis intoxication include conjunctival injection, increased appetite, euphoria, paranoid delusions and a dry mouth. Pupillary dilation and diaphoresis are not typical of cannabis intoxication.
❌ Serotonin syndrome:
Incorrect: Serotonin syndrome is characterized by hyperactive reflexes, mydriasis, and hyperadrenergic drive. One of the key findings in cases of serotonin syndrome is the presence of clonus, which is absent in this patient.
❌ Opiate withdrawal syndrome:
Incorrect: Opiate withdrawal syndrome may manifest with many similar features of amphetamine intoxication syndrome including mydriasis, tachycardia, and hypertension. However, patients with opiate withdrawal syndrome will also typically exhibit piloerection, vomiting, and diarrhea.
❌ Benzodiazepine intoxication:
Incorrect: Psychomotor depression, respiratory depression, ataxia, and hypotension are features of benzodiazepine intoxication. A normal respiratory rate and hypertension as seen in this patient suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician's clinic for evaluation of irritability, reduced concentration, and persistent headache. The headache is frontal, dull, and is not associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia or phonophobia. She has noticed that she has gained 5 lbs (2.27 kg) over the last two weeks due to an increased appetite. Prior to a week ago, the patient smoked 2-3 packs of cigarettes daily but stopped abruptly. She also stopped using several illicit substances and alcohol at this time when she found out her daughter was pregnant. The patient has a history of major depressive disorder and chronic back pain. Her current medications include escitalopram and oxycodone as needed. Temperature is 98 °F (36.6 °C), pulse is 110 bpm, and blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. The patient appears irritable. Oral mucosa appears moist. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. The patient moves all four extremities to commands with normal deep tendon reflexes. Withdrawal from which of the following substances is responsible for the constellation of symptoms observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with irritability, weight gain, dysphoria, and increased appetite consistent with nicotine withdrawal. Nicotine is an alkaloid found in tobacco products that acts as a ganglionic and central nervous stimulant. Nicotine can impair endothelial function, promote coronary vasoconstriction and generate free radicals that impair tissue oxygenation. These actions are mediated by the increase in neurotransmitters including epinephrine, norepinephrine, serotonin, dopamine and acetylcholine.

Smoking can accelerate atherosclerosis and acts as an independent risk factor for coronary disease, myocardial infarction and sudden cardiac death. Symptoms of excess nicotine consumption include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and diaphoresis. Nicotine withdrawal commonly occurs  following abstinence, as its psychoactive features cause tolerance and dependency.

Clinical manifestations of nicotine withdrawal begin hours to days after cessation and subside in 3-4 weeks. Symptoms include weight gain, insomnia, irritability, increased appetite, poor concentration, depressed mood and restlessness. Nicotine replacement therapy and drugs like varenicline and bupropion are some of the treatment options for the management of nicotine withdrawal.

Option Analysis

✅ Nicotine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ethanol:
Incorrect: Alcohol withdrawal can present within 48 hours with tremors, anxiety, reduced sleep, agitation and seizures. However, this patient had her last drink one week ago.
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Manifestations of opioid withdrawal include piloerection, yawning, dilated pupils, lacrimation and hyperactive bowel sounds.
❌ Cocaine :
Incorrect: Withdrawal from psychostimulants like cocaine and amphetamines can cause severe psychomotor retardation (“crash”) along with hypersomnia, increased appetite and signs of severe depression. However, withdrawal symptoms from cocaine typically resolve on their own without treatment within one to two weeks.
❌ Methamphetamine:
Incorrect: Withdrawal from psychostimulants such as cocaine and amphetamines can cause severe psychomotor retardation (“crash”) along with hypersomnia, increased appetite and signs of severe depression.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a severe headache and multiple episodes of non-bloody, non-bilious emesis for the past few hours. Review of systems is significant for fatigue, constipation, and problems with peripheral field vision for the past few months. Her last menstrual period was 4 months ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 58/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 92/64 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a lethargic female complaining of severe pain. Visual field is tunneled with doubling of vision. Head magnetic resonance imaging is shown below:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

questions.solution:
This patient with sudden onset excruciating headache and vomiting, together with hypotension and MRI findings of enlarged pituitary gland displacing the optic chiasm with bright white areas, makes the diagnosis of pituitary apoplexy most likely. Her ongoing symptoms of fatigue, constipation, menstrual irregularities, and abnormal peripheral vision for the past few months points towards a non-functioning pituitary tumor compressing the optic chiasm, which is known to increase the risk of apoplexy.

Pituitary apoplexy is defined as sudden hemorrhage of the pituitary gland. It usually occurs in the presence of a pituitary adenoma. Apoplexy, in addition to sudden headaches, vomiting, diplopia and rapidly worsening visual loss, may also be associated with double vision that results from compression of the nerves in the adjacent cavernous sinus which control the eye muscles. MRI of the brain shows an enlarged and hyperintense pituitary gland with bright white areas indicative of active hemorrhage. All pituitary hormonal deficiencies can occur, but the sudden onset of ACTH (and therefore cortisol) deficiency is the most serious because it can cause life-threatening hypotension. Treatment involves emergency surgical decompression, which is known to improve the clinical findings.



Option Analysis

✅ Pituitary apoplexy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hashimoto thyroiditis:
Incorrect: Although this patient is presenting with classic signs of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, constipation, menstrual irregularity), her sudden severe headache as well as MRI findings are indicative of another condition.
❌ Hypothalamic infarction:
Incorrect: An ischemic stroke of the hypothalamus can result in dysfunction of the pituitary gland and potentially explain this patient’s symptoms. However, such an event is usually accompanied by focal signs (e.g. unilateral numbness or weakness). Moreover, it would not explain the MRI findings of the pituitary gland in this patient.
❌ Sheehan syndrome:
Incorrect: Sheehan syndrome results from infarction of the pituitary gland following pregnancy complicated by intra- or postpartum hemorrhage. The pituitary gland doubles in size during pregnancy without adequate increase in blood supply, which puts it at risk of infarction. This diagnosis is unlikely here, since this patient has no recent history of pregnancy.
❌ Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH):
Incorrect: SIADH is characterized by excess secretion of ADH. It would lead to hyponatremia rather than hypernatremia. Clinical symptoms can range from mild headaches and vomiting, to more severe cases presenting with seizures and altered mental status. It is usually seen in patients with ongoing stress (e.g. infection), tumors (e.g. small cell carcinoma of lung), or as a medication adverse effect (e.g. carbamazepine)

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of dull left eye pain, which developed four days ago. He has also experienced photophobia and conjunctival injection but no visual disturbances. Past medical history is notable for ankylosing spondylitis and Crohn disease, for which he is taking infliximab. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for an intraocular pressure of 17 mmHg in the right eye and 35 mmHg in the left eye. In addition, ciliary flush and keratic precipitates are noted on slit-lamp examination of the left eye. Bilateral pupils are reactive to light. Examination of the left retina reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Separation of retina from underlying support tissue

questions.solution:
This patient has an elevated intraocular pressure and optic nerve cupping. In addition, he has a history of autoimmune conditions, as well as the presence of ciliary flush and keratic precipitates, which are concerning for uveitis. Together, these findings are consistent with open-angle glaucoma in the setting of uveitis due to deposition of leukocytes within the trabecular meshwork.

Glaucoma is a series of eye diseases resulting in optic nerve damage and subsequent vision loss, often in the setting of increased intraocular pressure. There are two types of glaucoma: open-angle and closed-angle. Open-angle glaucoma is the more common type. The condition can be subdivided into primary disease, which is often idiopathic, and secondary disease, which results from reduced trabecular meshwork outflow due to deposition of leukocytes from uveitis, erythrocytes from vitreous hemorrhage, or scarring.

Closed-angle glaucoma, on the other hand, is caused by narrowing or closure of the iridocorneal angle. In primary disease, for unknown causes, the lens is enlarged and pushes up against the iris, thereby closing the iridocorneal angle. Secondary disease can be due to hypoxia from retinal diseases (e.g., diabetes mellitus, central retinal vein occlusion), which induces neovascularization and causes the iris to be pushed anteriorly. It can also be caused by anticholinergic drugs, which lead to mydriasis and iridocorneal angle narrowing.



Option Analysis

✅ Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Narrowing of the iridocorneal angle:
Incorrect: Closed-angle glaucoma develops when the iridocorneal angle is narrowed or closed and aqueous humor outflow is impaired. The condition is characterized by a painful eye, blurred vision, as well as a non-reactive and dilated pupil. In contrast, this patient has no visual disturbances and a pupil that is reactive to light. As a result, his elevated intraocular pressure is more likely because of open-angle glaucoma secondary to uveitis.
❌ Blockage of the retinal vein:
Incorrect: Retinal vein occlusion is a known cause of secondary closed-angle glaucoma, which can manifest with increased cupping of the optic nerve and elevated intraocular pressure. However, retinal vein occlusion would typically present with retinal hemorrhage, edema, and retinal vessel dilation on fundoscopic examination.
❌ Separation of retina from underlying support tissue:
Incorrect: Retinal detachment can manifest with increased floaters, vision loss, and the sensation that a curtain is coming down into the visual field. On fundoscopic examination, the retina may appear torn or pale. In contrast, these findings are not present in this patient.
❌ Degeneration of the macula:
Incorrect: Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) can result in central vision loss and metamorphopsia, which is a type of visual distortion wherein straight lines appear wavy. However, the condition would not cause elevations in intraocular pressure or cupping of the optic nerve.

questions.text:
A 7-month-old boy is brought to the office because of a recurrent pruritic rash on his body. His parent first noticed a few lesions 4 days ago that disappeared within 2 hours. On subsequent days, similar but widespread lesions occurred that improved within a few hours without any intervention. His parent states he has not had any fevers, fatigue, or loss of appetite recently. He recently started gradually weaning off breast milk exclusively and eats boiled eggs for breakfast. He was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery, and his parent reports he has been healthy with no medical conditions. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows well-demarcated, raised, erythematous plaques as shown:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics

questions.solution:
This infant presents with recurrent pruritus and a raised, erythematous, self-resolving rash following the initiation of eggs in his diet. He is most likely suffering from urticaria, a type I hypersensitivity reaction. The underlying mechanism involves mast cell degranulation and release of inflammatory mediators following a trigger which, in turn, increases vascular permeability, causing dermal edema and the typical appearance of a wheal. Urticaria is characterized by itchy, burning or stinging, erythematous, raised plaques with well-defined margins and pale centers. Urticaria can be acute (< 24 hours) or chronic (> 6 weeks).

Common triggers of urticaria can be described by five I’s:

  •  Infection (bacterial/viral/fungal/parasitic) 
  •  Injection of a drug/insect venom 
  •  Inhaled substances (e.g., pollen, mold, dust) 
  •  Ingestion of certain food (e.g. eggs), drugs, or chemicals 
  • Internal disease process such as an autoimmune disorder
Diagnosis is based on clinical appearance, though patch testing can be performed to confirm and determine the allergen. Treatment options include avoidance of triggers, symptomatic management of pruritus with antihistamines, or corticosteroids in severe cases.

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis:
Incorrect: Cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) inhibitors, aspirin, and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs act by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandin, deviating the metabolism of arachidonic acid towards leukotrienes. These medications can result in increased vascular permeability, causing chronic idiopathic urticaria. This patient, however, has no history of COX-1 inhibitor ingestion.
✅ Mast cell degranulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics:
Incorrect: Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics by Streptococcus pyogenes results in erysipelas. This condition usually manifests as sharply-demarcated, fiery red, painful plaques and fever. It lasts for days without treatment, unlike the transient nature of this patient’s presentation.
❌ Keratinocyte detachment within stratum granulosum:
Incorrect: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by bacterial exotoxin-induced detachment among keratinocytes from the stratum granulosum. Clinically, it is characterized by an erythematous rash with sloughing and constitutional symptoms (fever, fatigue, loss of appetite). This patient’s transient erythematous plaques are instead suggestive of acute urticaria.
❌ T cell-mediated release of cytokines:
Incorrect: Allergic contact dermatitis results from T cell-mediated release of cytokines (type IV hypersensitivity reaction) to contact allergens like nickel, chromium, cobalt, and poison ivy. It presents with well-demarcated, erythematous papules or vesicles with chronic lichenification. Egg ingestion would not cause contact dermatitis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of fatigue and weight loss over the past two months. He reports early satiety and a sensation of abdominal fullness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals several nontender, rubbery masses in the left axilla and right groin. The spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. A mass in the axilla is resected, and genetic analysis reveals a t(11;14) translocation. The translocated gene in these cells produces a protein that is directly responsible for which of the following functions?
questions.solution:
Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is a rare, aggressive subtype of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that typically occurs in men older than 50 years of age. Almost all tumors have an (11;14) translocation that fuses the BCL1 gene, normally found on chromosome 11, to the IgH locus, normally found on chromosome 14. This translocation results in overexpression of cyclin D1. This protein is responsible for transition to S phase via phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma gene product, which subsequently releases transcription factors that initiate DNA replication.

Most patients present with fatigue and lymphadenopathy, often with extensive involvement of additional organs, such as the spleen, liver, bone marrow and the gastrointestinal tract; splenomegaly in particular is often present.

Diagnosis relies on tissue biopsy (either of the enlarged lymph node or extranodal sites), which demonstrates monomorphic proliferation of B-cells and overexpression of cyclin D1. MCL is aggressive and often incurable–the median survival is 4-6 years after diagnosis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Promotion from G1 to S-phase   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Inhibition of apoptosis   :
Incorrect: BCL-2 is an antiapoptotic molecule that is expressed by the BCL2 gene found on chromosome 18; it is often overexpressed in follicular lymphoma, due to a t(14;18) translocation. Instead, this patient has a t(11;14) translocation, which is involved in the promotion from G to S-phase in the cell cycle and pathogenic for mantle cell lymphoma.   
❌ Tyrosine kinase activity   :
Incorrect: Various chromosomal aberrations result in upregulated tyrosine kinase activity, such as HER2 overexpression found in many breast cancers. Instead, this patient has a t(11;14) translocation, which is involved in the promotion from G to S-phase in the cell cycle and pathogenic for mantle cell lymphoma.   
❌ Repair of damaged DNA   :
Incorrect: Defective DNA repair is often secondary to mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene. Instead, this patient has a t(11;14) translocation, which is involved in the promotion from G to S-phase in the cell cycle and pathogenic for mantle cell lymphoma.   
❌ Activation of transcription   :
Incorrect: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with translocations involving the MYC gene on chromosome 8 that result in overexpression of the MYC transcription factor. This patient is presenting with mantle cell lymphoma, which has a different pathogenesis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the office because of numerous pigmented bumps over his chin and neck for the past six months. The rash is associated with mild pain and tenderness and did not improve with emollients or cleansers. The rest of the patient’s medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are shown below. He is a Black man of Haitian descent, and the hair in this region of his chin and neck is coarse and tightly curled. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?


Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Penetration of hair in interfollicular skin
Horny plugs in hair follicle orifices

questions.solution:
This man’s presents with firm, hyperpigmented papules over the area of the neck and chin for the past six months; this presentation is consistent with pseudofolliculitis barbae (PB), an inflammatory disease of the hair-bearing area. PB is also colloquially referred to as "razor bumps," "shave bumps," or "ingrown hairs."  

PB occurs commonly among individuals with coarse, tightly curled hair, which creates short, sharp-ended hair emerging from the hair follicles; the condition is common among Black individuals. The stretching of the skin during shaving can cause the retraction of hair in the follicles, inhibiting its growth back to the surface. A cutaneous inflammatory response then results secondary to the penetration of hair in the interfollicular epidermis and dermis, manifesting as firm papules at the site of the embedded hair.    

PB is mainly a cosmetic concern but can become complicated with secondary bacterial infection (pustules), keloid formation, and hyperpigmentation over time. Diagnosis is based on clinical appearance, and definitive treatment is achieved by permanent discontinuation of shaving or switching to other hair removal methods such as waxing or laser hair removal. 

Option Analysis

❌ Inflammation of hair follicles:
Incorrect: Folliculitis is the inflammation of hair follicles that usually presents acutely with erythematous papules and pustules. Bacterial infection by Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause. This patient’s chronic history of firm papules suggests a different diagnosis. 
❌ Blockage of pilosebaceous subunits:
Incorrect: Acne vulgaris a chronic skin disease that results from blockage and inflammation of pilosebaceous subunits; it can present as noninflammatory comedones, papules, pustules, or nodules. The pigmented and firm papules seen in this patient would be atypical. 
✅ Penetration of hair in interfollicular skin :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Horny plugs in hair follicle orifices:
Incorrect: Keratosis pilaris is a genetic disorder that results in formation in horny plugs in hair follicle orifices. It commonly manifests in childhood and adolescents with spiny keratotic papules on the proximal extensor surfaces of arms or thighs. Neck and chin involvement with firm hyperpigmented papules would be atypical. 
❌ Complication of an autoimmune disease:
Incorrect: Cutaneous sarcoidosis can present with multiple papules or plaques, which may be hyperpigmented or hypopigmented. However, the embedded beard hair seen in this patient is not typically present.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of head trauma following a bar fight. During the incident, he was struck over the side of the head with a chair and subsequently lost  consciousness for a few minutes. A few hours later, he began vomiting and experienced a severe headache. Upon arrival, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 165/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient responds to painful stimuli only. There is left sided temporal bruising. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hemiparesis. Examination of the eyes demonstrates a dilated, fixed left pupil in a down and out position. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of herniation resulting in this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient who suffered severe head trauma to the lateral side of the head presents with a fixed pupil in one eye with a down-and-out position and contralateral hemiparesis–consistent with uncal herniation.

Brain herniation occurs when cerebral tissue moves either outside of the skull or across or into a structure within the skull. Herniation is the end result of a mass effect and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) subsequent to traumatic brain injury, intracranial hemorrhage, brain tumor or abscess. When intracranial pressure increases past a defined threshold, the brain can deviate across rigid structures such as the foramen magnum, falx cerebri, and the tentorium cerebelli–resulting in predictable neurologic findings. In general, herniation syndromes are divided into those that occur above the tentorial notch (supratentorial) and those that occur below this structure (infratentorial).

In uncal herniation, the innermost portion of the temporal lobe known as the uncus compresses the tentorium. This effect compresses the 3rd cranial nerve, the cerebral peduncles, and the posterior cerebral arteries, resulting in oculomotor nerve palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, and occipital lobe infarction, respectively.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Uncal herniation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Central transtentorial herniation  :
Incorrect: Central transtentorial herniation refers to downward displacement of the diencephalon and temporal lobes through the tentorium cerebelli. This process may result in small, fixed pupils with paralysis of upward eye movement ("sunset eyes") and diabetes insipidus due to compression of the pituitary stalk. Central herniation may also manifest in rupture of branches of the basilar artery (pontine arteries), in a complication known as a Duret hemorrhages (which is often fatal).  
❌ Subfalcine herniation  :
Incorrect: Cingulate (subfalcine) herniation refers to the lateral displacement of the innermost part of the frontal lobe (the cingulate gyrus) under the falx cerebri. This displacement can compress the anterior cerebral artery and infarct the frontal and parietal lobes. Clinical features of cingulate herniation may include unilateral/bilateral weakness, loss of bladder control, and coma.  
❌ Tonsillar herniation:
Incorrect: Tonsillar herniation, also called downward cerebellar herniation, refers to downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. Clinical manifestations may include neck stiffness, flaccid paralysis, decreased level of consciousness, and signs of brain stem dysfunction from compression of respiratory and cardiac control centers.  
❌ External herniation:
Incorrect: External herniation, also known as transcalvarial herniation, refers to herniation of the brain parenchyma through a fracture or a surgical site in the skull. The signs and symptoms depend upon the location and size of the herniation. This patient, however, has an intact skull.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain for the past week. The patient has also been experiencing frequent nausea and vomiting since symptom onset. He started a new job at a medical instrument manufacturing company three weeks ago. Past medical history is significant for exercise-induced asthma. Family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Physical examination reveals erythema of the conjunctiva and oral mucosa. Wheezing is heard on auscultation of the lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely precipitating factor of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has nausea, vomiting, and conjunctival and mucosal erythema, as well as signs of pulmonary irritation (e.g., cough, shortness of breath, chest pain). These symptoms, in combination with the patient’s occupation, are concerning acute mercury poisoning.

Mercury poisoning can occur due to consumption of seafood, amalgam-based dental fillings, or occupational exposure (such as medical device manufacturing). Acute toxicity can present with gastrointestinal symptoms, such as severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, as well as pulmonary symptoms, such as cough, dyspnea, and chest pain, which may lead to interstitial pneumonitis. Patients may also have mucocutaneous symptoms such as conjunctivitis, stomatitis, and dermatitis. Chronic exposure, on the other hand, may present with the triad of tremors, neuropsychiatric problems (e.g., fatigue, memory loss, irritability), and gingivostomatitis.

Mercury poisoning can be diagnosed by measuring mercury levels in the blood or urine. Treatment involves eliminating the exposure source, intravenous fluids, respiratory support, and chelation therapy with dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) or dimercaprol.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen overdose:
Incorrect: Individuals with acetaminophen overdose presents with nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and malaise. Severe intoxication can cause liver damage and elevated liver enzymes. However, this patient who recently started a job at a medical instrument manufacturing company presents with respiratory symptoms in addition to nausea, vomiting, and conjunctival and mucosal erythema, which are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Organophosphate exposure:
Incorrect: Organophosphate poisoning presents with symptoms of cholinergic hyperactivity such as bradycardia, miosis, bronchorrhea, salivation, and lacrimation. Atropine competes with acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors and reverses the muscarinic symptoms. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with acute mercury toxicity secondary to occupational exposure.  
❌ Lorazepam overdose:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepine overdose presents with nervous system depression and occasionally respiratory depression. However, benzodiazepine overdose would not account for this patient’s shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain, in addition to nausea, vomiting, and conjunctival and mucosal erythema, which are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
✅ Mercury exposure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ethylene glycol ingestion:
Incorrect: Ethylene glycol poisoning presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, and altered mental status. However, this patient who recently started a job at a medical instrument manufacturing company presents with respiratory symptoms in addition to nausea, vomiting, and conjunctival and mucosal erythema, which are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the office for a routine newborn evaluation. She was born at 40 weeks gestation to a 28-year-old primigravid mother via cesarean section due to breech presentation. The remainder of the pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and all prenatal tests were within normal limits. The infant breastfeeds every 4-5 hours and sleeps 7-8 hours at night. Physical examination shows an alert female infant with normal strength and movement in all extremities. There are four skin creases along the patient’s inner right thigh and two on the left thigh. Further examination reveals a limb length discrepancy of 1 inch. The physician gently adducts and applies pressure to the right hip which results in posterior displacement and a palpable clunk. Which of the following best describes the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Dysgenesis of the acetabulum and femoral head
Avascular necrosis of the femoral head
Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck
Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle

questions.solution:
Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) occurs when the acetabulum is shallow or poorly formed, resulting in subluxation or dislocation of the femoral head. DDH occurs more commonly in newborn females than in males; other risk factors include firstborns, breech presentation, as well as family history of DDH.   DDH is commonly asymptomatic; however, the physical examination may demonstrate the following findings:
 
  •  Positive Barlow maneuver: To perform this maneuver on a supine neonate, the physician adducts the hips and applies downward pressure to dislocate the hip posteriorly. If positive, the physician can feel a clunk or jerk with hip dislocation.  
  •  Positive Ortolani maneuver: This maneuver attempts to reduce a dislocated hip, as would occur with a positive Barlow maneuver. To perform this maneuver, the physician abducts the hip and applies upward pressure (opposite that of the Barlow maneuver); if positive, the hip can be felt relocating into the acetabulum. 
  •  The Galeazzi sign assesses for femoral asymmetry. If the hip is dislocated, the affected femur (and therefore knee) will appear shorter compared with the normal limb (limb-length discrepancy).  
  •  Asymmetry in the position and/or the number of the gluteal or thigh skin folds may be a clue for DDH (with more gluteal folds suggestive of DDH).  
Infants <4 months of age with an abnormal examination should have further evaluation via ultrasound. After age 4 months, the femoral head and acetabulum ossify, and therefore, x-rays become the preferred modality for evaluation. Confirmed DDH is treated with a Pavlik harness–a splint that holds the hip in proper alignment to allow for appropriate bony maturation. 

Option Analysis

✅ Dysgenesis of the acetabulum and femoral head   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Avascular necrosis of the femoral head   :
Incorrect: Legg-Calvé-Perthes refers to idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head that is often seen in children between the ages of 4 and 8 years of age. Children typically present with a painful limp as well as decreased internal rotation and abduction of the hip. This neonate demonstrates a positive Barlow maneuver (inducible dislocation of the hip), suggesting a different condition.   
❌ Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck   :
Incorrect: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) refers to slipping of the femoral head from the femoral neck. The typical presentation involves an adolescent male with obesity who presents with a painful limp as well as pain in the groin, hip, or knee.   
❌ Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle   :
Incorrect: Osgood-Schlatter disease is an inflammatory condition of the tibial tuberosity secondary to overuse injury. The typical patient is a child between the ages of 12-17 who participates in sports involving repetitive jumping.   
❌ Normal development   :
Incorrect: This neonate is presenting with asymmetric thigh and buttock folds, along with a positive Barlow maneuver (inducible dislocation of the hip). These findings are not normal findings in a newborn.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider with complaints of fatigue and weakness. The symptoms began 6 months ago. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient is currently taking lisinopril and metformin. She consumes 4-6 beers per week. Her pulse is 86/min and blood pressure is 152/94 mmHg. BMI is 32 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals bilateral muscle weakness in the upper and lower extremities. Truncal obesity is present. Skin changes are observed on the patient’s back and the findings are shown below:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

Similar changes are also noted on the patient’s abdomen. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s skin findings?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with muscle weakness, striae (as shown in the image), and weight gain. These are consistent with the presentation of Cushing syndrome, which describes the constellation of findings seen in patients with hypercortisolism.
