Excess cortisol leads to proteolysis. The muscle and skin, both of which are major sources of protein in the body, are broken down. This leads to muscle wasting and thin extremities. The skin becomes progressively thinner and can no longer conceal the color of venous blood in the underlying dermis, causing the purple-red striae to appear. Cortisol also stimulates gluconeogenesis, which results in hyperglycemia, and an increased appetite, which results in weight gain. This can manifest as truncal obesity. In addition, there is also fat redistribution to the cheeks, resulting in a round, moon-shaped face, and to the back of the neck, causing a suboccipital fat pad or “buffalo hump.” Cushing syndrome can also lead to hypertension. This is because cortisol can amplify the effect of catecholamines and act as a mineralocorticoid agonist.  

Patients with ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism may also present with hirsutism. This is because ACTH stimulates not only cortisol production in the zona fasciculata, but also androgen production in the zona reticularis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Excess melanin production:
Incorrect: Excess melanin production may be observed in patients with hypercortisolism secondary to a pituitary adenoma or ACTH-secreting malignancy. This is because ACTH and melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) are derived from the same precursor molecule; therefore increased ACTH production would also lead to increased MSH production. Excess melanin would result in hyperpigmentation as opposed to the purple-red striae shown in the image.  
✅ Skin atrophy and breakdown:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased adipose deposition:
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette has hypercortisolism, which leads to increased appetite and body fat redistribution. This can lead to deposition of fat in the abdomen (truncal obesity), face (moon-faces), and behind the neck (buffalo hump). However, adipose deposition would not account for the striae observed in this patient.  
❌ Paraumbilical vein dilatation:
Incorrect: Dilation of the paraumbilical veins is often observed in patients with liver cirrhosis. Cirrhosis leads to portal hypertension, the formation of anastomoses, and ultimately engorgement of the paraumbilical veins. However, the dilated paraumbilical veins would appear swollen and blue-black in color and would not extend to the patient’s back.   
❌ Muscle atrophy and breakdown:
Incorrect: Hypercortisolism can lead to severe muscle breakdown. This leads to muscle wasting and thin extremities. However, the finding shown in the image is not due to muscle breakdown but is instead due to skin breakdown.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a headache that feels “like a screwdriver” going through his right temple and eye. He says that it has lasted for approximately 1 hour thus far, and rates the pain as a 9 on a 10-point scale. He says this has happened almost every morning this week, but he cannot identify a trigger. He also describes “watering of his eyes” and difficulty seeing during these episodes. Physical examination shows ipsilateral miosis of the right eye, but the remainder of the ophthalmoscopic examination is normal. There is no tenderness of the right temporal region on palpation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cluster headaches are a type of primary headache characterized by unilateral pain around the periorbital region, and they are often described to be excruciating in quality. They often occur episodically at the same time of the day (and may occur multiple times per day), with cluster headache cycles usually occurring around the same time of the year. Autonomic symptoms are often associated with cluster headaches ipsilateral to the side of the pain, and they only occur during the headache episode. These symptoms include conjunctival injection, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion. Cluster headaches may also present with ipsilateral Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis). Cluster headaches more often occur in men than women. This type of headache can often be misdiagnosed, or confused with migraines, which are also typically unilateral. Since there are no confirmatory tests for cluster headaches, a detailed patient history is imperative. Headache diaries may help track headache onset, location, severity, and duration. Abortive treatment includes 100% oxygen and triptans, while verapamil can be used prophylactically.   



Option Analysis

❌ Migraine headache:
Incorrect: Migraine headaches are characterized by unilateral pain that is throbbing and pulsatile in quality, usually lasting 4 to 72 hours. It is often associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity or noise sensitivity. Although this patient has unilateral headache, his autonomic symptoms favor a different diagnosis.  
❌ Trigeminal neuralgia  :
Incorrect: Trigeminal neuralgia is a neuropathic disorder that typically presents with episodic, unilateral, shooting, “shock-like” pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). Symptoms are often precipitated by innocuous stimuli (e.g., brushing teeth, shaving). This patient presentation favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Cluster headache:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Tension headache:
Incorrect: Tension headaches are the most common cause of primary headache. It is usually bilateral and fronto-occipital in location, with a characteristic tightening or “band-like” quality of pain. Patients often have pericranial muscle tenderness. Common precipitating factors are stress and increased muscle tension. This patient has unilateral headache and autonomic symptoms, which favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Temporal arteritis  :
Incorrect: Temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis) typically presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue), signs of systemic inflammation (e.g., elevated ESR and CRP) and history of scalp pain/ temporal pain and jaw claudication. Also, patients are usually above the age of 50. This patient age and presentation favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 15-month-old girl is brought by her caretakers out of concern that she is not growing as fast as other children of her age. The patient was adopted shortly after birth and her family history is unknown. The patient’s height, weight, and head circumference are below the 5th percentile. The patient’s hand radiograph reveals findings similar to those in the image below:  



Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin of 6.5 g/dL, leukocyte count of  6,800/mm3 and platelet count of 175,000/mm3. A peripheral smear reveals enlarged red blood cells. Which of the following additional laboratory findings would be most likely found in this patient?

choices.text: Elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels
Elevated homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid levels
Positive chromosomal breakage test in T lymphocytes
Increased orotic acid levels on urinalysis

questions.solution:
This patient has Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA), an autosomal dominant condition causing ribosomal defects in erythroid progenitor cells. As a result, protein transcription and translation are impaired in these cells.  

DBA affects protein synthesis in red blood cells (RBCs), and as a result, individuals will present with a low RBC count but normal white blood cell and platelet counts. In addition, patients often present with short stature and skeletal anomalies. Up to 50% of individuals with DBA may present with triphalangeal thumbs, as seen in the radiograph. Moreover, patients with the condition have elevated fetal hemoglobin (HbF) levels due to stress erythropoiesis. Although stress erythropoiesis is non-specific and can be found in other conditions causing bone marrow failure (e.g. Fanconi anemia, transient erythroblastopenia of childhood), the finding may manifest earlier in patients with DBA. Patients with DBA are also at increased risk of malignancies including acute myelogenous leukemia, myelodysplastic syndrome, and solid tumors.  

The diagnosis can be made using a combination of the patient’s history, family history, and laboratory testing. Genetic testing can be ordered to confirm the presence of the pathogenic mutation. Bone marrow studies will reveal normal cellularity but a decreased number of erythroid precursors.  

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels:
Incorrect: Elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels would be observed in patients with vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency can present with macrocytic anemia. However, vitamin B12 deficiency would not cause patients to present with the triphalangeal thumb observed on radiograph.  
❌ Elevated homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid levels:
Incorrect: Elevated homocysteine but normal methylmalonic acid levels are observed in patients with folate deficiency. Folate deficiency can be due to a poor diet, which could also account for the patient’s failure to meet developmental milestones. However, folate deficiency, whether in utero or during childhood, would not cause the skeletal anomalies seen on radiograph.  
❌ Positive chromosomal breakage test in T lymphocytes:
Incorrect: A positive chromosomal breakage test would be observed in patients with Fanconi anemia. T lymphocytes from the peripheral blood are often used for the test. Patients with Fanconi anemia have defects in DNA repair that affect all precursor blood cells. This results in pancytopenia. In contrast the patient in this vignette has a leukocyte and platelet count that is within age-appropriate range.  
✅ Hemoglobin electrophoresis showing elevated HbF:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased orotic acid levels on urinalysis:
Incorrect: This finding would be observed in patients with orotic aciduria, a condition wherein there is impaired conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate. Orotic aciduria can also cause macrocytic anemia and developmental delays, but the condition does not typically cause skeletal abnormalities.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden abdominal pain and nausea that started last night. The patient’s medical history includes severe chronic alcohol use disorder, and he reports drinking a liter of vodka every day for the past week. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 132/94 mmHg. The patient appears uncomfortable and in mild distress. Physical examination shows an exquisitely tender epigastrium with bruising of his lower abdomen, as shown in the image below.  

 


Image reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is most likely contributing to this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Increased bicarbonate secretion by ductal epithelial cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s acute epigastric pain (often radiating to the back) with nausea and periumbilical bruising (Cullen’s Sign) are highly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis is characterized by sudden inflammation and hemorrhaging of the pancreas due to destruction by its own enzymes (autodigestion). The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are 1) gallstones and 2) chronic alcohol abuse; this patient’s long standing heavy drinking is the likely cause of his pancreatitis.  

Alcohol consumption leads to decreased fluid and bicarbonate secretion by the pancreatic ductal epithelial cells. This causes thickened pancreatic juices that can plug and block the pancreatic ducts, and the increasing pressure and distention results in dysfunctional cellular membrane trafficking. In addition to fluid and bicarbonate secretion, pancreatic exocrine acinar cells also secrete digestive enzymes that help break down the proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids found in food. Alcohol independently causes increased secretion of acinar cell zymogen granules (vesicles filled with proto-enzymes, especially trypsinogen), which can fuse with lysosomes in the setting of altered membrane trafficking. The result is activation of trypsinogen into trypsin by the lysosomal proteases and subsequent breakdown of cellular structures by trypsin. A flood of inflammatory cytokines are released, in addition to those independently induced by alcohol itself, attracting neutrophils that produce superoxides and more proteases. This chain reaction of cellular destruction may progress and cause blood vessel leakage along with lipase-mediated pancreatic fat destruction, culminating in liquefactive hemorrhagic necrosis.  

With hemorrhagic pancreatitis, a faint blue discoloration around the umbilicus (Cullen’s sign) may occur as a result of hemoperitoneum, and a blue-red-purple or green-brown discoloration of the flanks (Grey Turner’s sign) may appear from tissue catabolism of hemoglobin in the setting of severe necrotizing disease. However, these signs are not present in most cases of acute pancreatitis, which are mild to moderate and self-limited.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased zymogen granule secretion  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased reactive oxygen species production:
Incorrect: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are increased in the setting of acute pancreatitis, where activated neutrophils release superoxides locally and perpetuate inflammation.  
❌ Ampulla of Vater obstruction:
Incorrect: Ampulla of Vater (hepatopancreatic ampulla) obstruction can result in gallstone pancreatitis, but it is not a causative factor in alcohol-induced pancreatitis.  
❌ Decreased cytokine release:
Incorrect: Alcohol stimulates the release of inflammatory cytokines, which generate a strong immune reaction and contribute to acute alcohol-induced pancreatitis.  
❌ Increased bicarbonate secretion by ductal epithelial cells:
Incorrect: Alcohol decreases fluid and bicarbonate production by pancreatic ductal epithelial cells, leading to viscous pancreatic secretions and duct plugging.

questions.text: A medical student is conducting research on the incidence of gynecological cancers across the world. He comes to note that in the United States, endometrial cancer has the highest incidence. By contrast, in Guatemala, he discovers that cervical cancer has the highest incidence. Which of the following factors regarding the United States best accounts for this difference?

choices.text: Lower prevalence of high-risk HPV strains

questions.solution:
It is important to remember that cervical cancer is the most common gynecological cancer worldwide, due to the lack of screening and availability of vaccines. However, in high socioeconomic countries like the United States, cervical cancer is less common and endometrial cancer takes the highest incidence. Screening for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia and cervical cancer is done with a Pap smear, along with high-risk HPV DNA testing. The utilization of the Pap smear has significantly improved our ability to detect cervical dysplasia and prevent its progression to cervical cancer.  

In the United States, ovarian cancer has the highest mortality rate, followed by endometrial cancer, and cervical cancer has the lowest mortality rate. However, the mortality rate for cervical cancer is higher in developing countries because of limited access to screening programs and the HPV vaccine.  

Option Analysis

❌ Better access to barrier contraception  :
Incorrect: Barrier contraception, such as condoms, can reduce HPV transmission, which in turn reduces the patient’s risk of developing cervical cancer. However, this factor is not the strongest explanation for the lower cervical cancer rates in the United States and other developed countries.  
✅ Greater access to screening tests:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lower rates of tobacco use:
Incorrect: Cigarette smoking or exposure to second-hand smoke can increase a patient’s risk of developing cervical cancer. However, cigarette consumption per year per person is actually lower in Guatemala than the United States.  
❌ Later onset of sexual activity:
Incorrect: Later onset of sexual activity is instead protective against cervical cancer. Moreover, better access to screening tests and vaccinations are the primary reasons why developed countries such as the United States have lower rates of cervical cancer than developing countries such as Guatemala.  
❌ Lower prevalence of high-risk HPV strains:
Incorrect: The high-risk HPV strains include 16, 18, 31, and 33. These strains can be found in both the United States and Guatemala. Instead, better access to screening tests and vaccination are the main reasons why the United States and other developed countries have lower rates of cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic due to difficulty hearing for the past 2 months. He describes difficulty hearing mainly on the left side, and he notes a constant “whoosh” sound in the same ear. The patient reports feeling unsteady lately but denies any dizziness or spinning sensations. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension. Medications include furosemide and lovastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows that the patient does not respond when the physician whispers in the left ear. A tuning fork placed on the mastoid bone shows that air conduction is greater than bone conduction bilaterally. When the fork is placed on the top of the head, the sound localizes to the right ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with unilateral progressive hearing loss, imbalance, and tinnitus. The results of his Rinne test showed the air conduction > bone conduction, indicating normal results and no conductive hearing loss. His Weber test results showed that the noise lateralized to the unaffected ear, confirming sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. These signs and symptoms are indicative of a left-sided acoustic neuroma (also known as a vestibular schwannoma).  

Acoustic neuromas, also known as vestibular schwannoma, are Schwann cell-derived tumors that often arise from the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). The incidence is similar in men and women, and the median age at diagnosis is approximately 50 years. Tumors are usually unilateral, but acoustic neuromas can occur bilaterally in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2. Common presenting symptoms include progressive hearing loss, tinnitus, and unsteadiness while walking. True spinning vertigo is uncommon, because these slow-growing tumors cause gradual asymmetries, which allows the vestibular system to compensate on the unaffected side. Diagnosis can be made with imaging, and treatment involves resection of the tumor.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cholesteatoma :
Incorrect: Cholesteatomas are abnormal, noncancerous desquamated keratin debris that can develop within the middle ear space behind the eardrum. A cholesteatoma may be present at birth, but most commonly, it is caused by repeated middle ear infections. It may erode ossicles and mastoid air cells leading to conductive hearing loss. A cholesteatoma would not cause vestibular symptoms, tinnitus or sensorineural hearing loss.  
❌ Ménière disease:
Incorrect: Ménière disease, also known as idiopathic endolymphatic hydrops, is caused by increased hydraulic pressure within the inner ear endolymphatic system. Patients often present with vertigo, tinnitus, ear fullness or pain, and sensorineural hearing loss. Episodes are spontaneous and characterized by vertigo, which can last 20 minutes to 12 hours. Although some of this patient’s symptoms overlap with Ménière disease, his symptoms are constant, and he describes unsteadiness rather than true vertigo.   
❌ Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo  :
Incorrect: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) refers to the episodic sensation of vertigo caused by calcium debris within the semicircular canals. Episodes are typically provoked by head rotation and position changes. In contrast to other causes of vertigo, hearing loss and other neurologic symptoms are not seen.   
✅ Acoustic neuroma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: Furosemide, a loop diuretic, can cause ototoxicity leading to temporary or permanent hearing loss. This side effect mainly depends on the dose and rate of administration; ototoxicity may be seen when the dose exceeds 240 mg per hour. Therefore, it is more likely to occur in an inpatient setting and in patients with chronic kidney disease, rather than with oral administration. Also, vestibular symptoms are not expected.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic with chest discomfort. Over the past week he has felt heart palpitations that occur multiple times per day. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or lightheadedness. Medical history is significant for hypertension, coronary artery disease, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and myasthenia gravis. He is recovering from a recent myasthenia gravis flare characterized by double vision and fatigable chewing. Medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, carvedilol, terazosin, and pyridostigmine. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Physical exam shows mild bilateral ptosis and a regularly irregular heartbeat. ECG is obtained and shows the following:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia  

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s ECG findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with palpitations caused by second-degree Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) atrioventricular (AV) block, as seen on ECG. Second-degree type I AV block is characterized by progressive lengthening of the PR interval until one beat is “dropped.” This dropped beat is identified by a P wave not followed by a QRS complex, which manifests as a regularly irregular heart rhythm on auscultation. In contrast, with Mobitz type II, PR intervals remain the same while beats are dropped, representing a failing AV conduction system (“all-or-nothing”) that requires pacemaker placement. Compared to Mobitz type II, Mobitz type I is usually benign and does not require treatment.  



AV block may be a normal variant and is found at a higher rate in conditioned endurance athletes. Pathologic causes of second-degree AV block include myocardial infarction (the AV node is supplied by the right coronary artery, therefore AV blocks are most often associated with inferior wall MIs), electrolyte disturbances (hyperkalemia), and medications.  

This patient is taking two medications that affect AV node conduction: carvedilol (through β1 receptor antagonism) and pyridostigmine (through acetylcholinesterase inhibition, leading to increased ACh and heightened parasympathetic tone). His pyridostigmine dose was likely increased during his recent myasthenia gravis flare, and therefore it is the most likely cause of his AV block. Decreasing his dose to prior levels should resolve the AV block and his palpitations.  

Option Analysis

❌ β1 receptor agonism:
Incorrect: β1 receptor agonists like dobutamine cause increased cardiac conduction and automaticity of the atrioventricular node. Conversely, AV block may be caused by β1 receptor antagonists, including metoprolol (β1-specific antagonist) and carvedilol (mixed ɑ1/β1/β2 antagonist).  
❌ Myocardial calcium-channel activation:
Incorrect: Amlodipine lowers blood pressure via angioselective calcium channel blockade, inhibiting vascular smooth muscle cell contraction and causing vasodilation with reduced peripheral vascular resistance. Amlodipine has not been shown to impair AV node conduction, as opposed to the non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, such as verapamil and diltiazem.  
✅ Acetylcholinesterase inhibition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase agonism:
Incorrect: Digoxin acts through antagonism of the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase in the myocardium, leading to increased intracellular calcium concentration and prolongation of phase 4 and phase 0 of the cardiac action potential. This antagonism results in decreased heart rate and decreased AV node conduction velocity, which can cause AV block.  
❌ ɑ1 receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: Terazosin is an ɑ1 receptor antagonist that improves symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) by blocking smooth muscle contraction in the prostate and urethra, thereby easing urination. However, ɑ1 receptors are not involved in the development of cardiac conduction blocks.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 20 weeks gestation is being evaluated for abnormal ultrasound results several days ago. A single amniotic sac was visualized and the amniotic fluid index during that time was 25 cm (normal 8-18). The pregnancy has been uncomplicated so far, and the patient has been consistent with prenatal care and taking prenatal vitamins. Medical history is notable for asthma, managed with albuterol as needed. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft, and uterine size is large for gestational date. An amniocentesis is performed and reveals elevated levels of alpha-fetoprotein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with polyhydramnios and elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), suggesting the diagnosis of anencephaly. Anencephaly is characterized by the absence of significant portions of the brain and calvaria of the fetus, which results in elevated levels of amniotic fluid (polyhydramnios) due to decreased swallowing ability.  

Open neural tube defects (NTDs) are congenital anomalies that develop when the neural tube fails to close normally during the third and fourth weeks of gestation. NTDs may be open (e.g., myelomeningocele, meningocele, encephalocele, and anencephaly) or closed (e.g., spina bifida occulta). Anencephaly occurs when the rostral neuropore fails to close, resulting in an absent calvarium and forebrain. Open NTDs result in a persistent connection between the amniotic cavity and spinal canal, and therefore AFP and acetylcholinesterase are often elevated. Screening is done via either ultrasound, demonstrating the absence of brain and calvaria, or AFP level measurement. In contrast, closed neural tube defects (e.g. spina bifida occulta) do not result in an elevated AFP level.  

Risk factors for developing closed or open neural tube defects include folic acid deficiency, gestational diabetes, maternal obesity, and certain medications (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine).  



Option Analysis

❌ Twin pregnancy:
Incorrect: Although twin pregnancies are associated with elevated AFP, polyhydramnios is not typically seen. In monochorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancies, polyhydramnios is associated with twin-twin transfusion syndrome; this syndrome would manifest as oligohydramnios in one amniotic sac and polyhydramnios in the other sac. However, only one amniotic sac was visualized here, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Spina bifida occulta:
Incorrect: Spina bifida occulta, also known as closed neural tube defect, is a bony defect in which the posterior vertebral arches fail to fuse, with unexposed neural tissue and intact overlying skin. In contrast to open neural tube defects (e.g. meningocele), spina bifida occulta does not present with elevated levels of AFP or polyhydramnios.   
❌ Meningocele :
Incorrect: Meningolocele is a type of spina bifida in which only the meninges herniate through a defect in the spinal cord. At birth, the lesion appears as a red, fleshy growth. While AFP is often elevated, the presence of polyhydramnios favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Meningomyelocele :
Incorrect: Meningomyelocele is a type of spina bifida in which both the meninges and spinal cord herniate through the defect in the spinal cord. At birth, the lesion appears as a red, fleshy growth. While AFP is often elevated, the presence of polyhydramnios favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Anencephaly :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old infant boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. The patient's mother delivered the child at home and did not receive consistent prenatal care. The patient’s weight and head circumference are <5th percentile. An examination of the head is consistent with microcephaly. He is noted to have severe developmental delay with attainment of few milestones in speech, gross motor, and fine motor development. The infant cannot roll over or lift his head. An MRI of the brain is obtained and shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikipedia  

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant is presenting with developmental delay, microcephaly, and absent gyri and sulci on MRI, confirming the diagnosis of lissencephaly.     

Lissencephaly (meaning "smooth brain") is a central nervous system disorder characterized by a smooth appearance of the brain surface and lack of development of the gyri and sulci. The pathogenesis involves defective neuronal migration that normally occurs between the 12th to 24th weeks of gestation. The condition is often accompanied by other abnormalities, including microcephaly, ventriculomegaly, wide Sylvian fissures, and agenesis of the corpus callosum. The prognosis varies depending on the severity, and many patients die before the age of 10 from aspiration, respiratory disease, or seizures. Others may have severe developmental delays or near-normal development. Diagnosis can be made prenatal via ultrasound, which would demonstrate poorly-defined gyri and sulci with a smoothened appearance.   

Option Analysis

✅ Lissencephaly:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anencephaly :
Incorrect: Anencephaly is a type of open neural tube defect that occurs due to the failure of the rostral neuropore to close. On imaging, anencephaly is characterized by the absence of brain and calvaria. The condition is incompatible with life.   
❌ Holoprosencephaly :
Incorrect: Holoprosencephaly is a developmental brain anomaly caused by a failure of the prosencephalon (forebrain) to divide into 2 hemispheres between the 3rd and 5th week of gestation. On imaging, holoprosencephaly is characterized by a fusion of the thalami, and there is a single posteriorly located ventricle.   
❌ Dandy-Walker syndrome  :
Incorrect: Dandy-Walker malformation is a congenital malformation characterized by agenesis/hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, with cystic dilatation of the 4th ventricle and extension of the posterior fossa. On imaging, it is marked by enlargement of the cisterna magna and complete aplasia of the vermis.   
❌ Chiari II malformation:
Incorrect: Chiari II malformation is a congenital brain anomaly outlined by herniation of both the cerebellar vermis and tonsils via the foramen magnum, leading to aqueductal stenosis and noncommunicating hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner due to an episode of jerky movements that involved stiffening and twitching all over her body. According to the partner, the episode started 30 minutes ago while the patient was working on her laptop, and it lasted approximately one minute. The patient lost consciousness after the episode for approximately 5 minutes. The patient has recently been under significant stress working on a company presentation. Past medical and surgical history is noncontributory, and the patient has not had any previous similar episodes. She takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient appears confused and is unable to recall what happened. Physical examination shows a bite mark on the left side of the tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s generalized jerky movements lasting less than 5 minutes, accompanied by loss of consciousness and postictal state are consistent with a diagnosis of generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS).   

Seizures are defined as sudden, uncontrolled excessive synchronous electrical disturbance in the brain that can be focal (affecting a single area of the brain) or generalized (involving both the hemispheres). GTCS is the most common type of generalized seizures. It manifests as a generalized stiffness of muscles (tonic phase) that is followed by jerking and twitching (clonic phase). Patients tend to lose consciousness during the episode, which remains for a few minutes following cessation of the episode; this sequence is then followed by a gradual regaining of consciousness. The episode is usually accompanied by tongue biting (as seen in this patient), urinary and/or fecal incontinence, and amnesia of the event, but these symptoms are not required for the diagnosis. Certain triggers or precipitants tend to lower seizure threshold; common triggers include, but are not limited to, strong emotions, flashing lights, fever, stress and lack of sleep.  

It is important to note that one seizure episode does not mean the patient has epilepsy. The diagnosis of epilepsy requires a history of at least two unprovoked seizures occurring more than 24 hours apart.   




Option Analysis

✅ Generalized tonic-clonic seizure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vasovagal syncope:
Incorrect: Although emotional or orthostatic stress can be an inciting event for a vasovagal syncope in young individuals, syncope is not followed by the confusion, and the patient usually recalls a prodrome of pallor, dizziness, nausea or diaphoresis.  
❌ Epilepsy:
Incorrect: The diagnosis of epilepsy requires a history of at least two unprovoked (or reflex) seizures occurring more than 24 hours apart. This patient who has not had any previous similar episodes could not be diagnosed with epilepsy yet.  
❌ Status epilepticus:
Incorrect: Status epilepticus is diagnosed when there is a continuous seizure activity of ≥5 minutes or ≥2 discrete seizures between which there is incomplete recovery of consciousness. It is a neurological emergency. This patient had a single seizure lasting only 1 minute and subsequently regained consciousness.  
❌ Psychogenic non-epileptic seizure:
Incorrect: PNES is derived from psychological underpinnings. The condition tends to occur in front of witnesses and in stressful situations. Its duration is usually longer than 2 minutes, and vocalization is observed during the episode. Moreover, tongue bite and postictal confusion are not usually seen.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of “jerky movements all over the body” that lasted for two minutes. The patient lost consciousness after the episode. The patient’s parent states that the patient has been having recent gait abnormalities and headaches for the past month. For the last few days, the headaches are worse in the morning and are relieved after bouts of nonbloody, nonbilious emesis. Past medical history is significant for Hashimoto thyroiditis, for which the patient takes levothyroxine. Family history is significant for systemic erythematosus lupus in the patient’s mother. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral papilledema and gait ataxia. The patient appears confused and has a laceration on the left side of her tongue. Which of the following investigations is most likely to reveal the cause of her episode?
questions.solution:
This patient, who had jerky movements accompanied by loss of consciousness, tongue bite and postictal confusion, most likely had an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Signs of increased intracranial pressure (progressive headache, vomiting, papilledema) and cerebellar involvement (gait instability and ataxia) are highly suggestive of a cerebellar lesion obstructing ventricular flow. The patient requires urgent neuroimaging (e.g. MRI) for diagnosis.  

Seizures are mostly a symptom of ongoing structural, metabolic or systemic disorders, many of which are reversible. The mnemonic “VITAMINS” is helpful in remembering the possible causes.        

 

Option Analysis

❌ Electroencephalogram:
Incorrect: Electroencephalogram (EEG) is usually deferred immediately after a seizure because the results may be confounded by acute postictal changes. Moreover, EEG is of little diagnostic utility in this patient who has a high suspicion for a structural intracranial abnormality.  
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture (LP) is unlikely to be helpful and may be misleading, as seizure activity itself can lead to transient cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis. If necessary, LP should only be performed after ruling out a space-occupying lesion by appropriate neuroimaging studies, in order to avoid brain herniation.  
✅ MRI head:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum antinuclear antibody (ANA) screening:
Incorrect: Serum ANA is a screening test of choice for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although SLE can cause convulsions, this condition is usually associated with constitutional symptoms (like fatigue, fever, myalgia and weight loss) and classical malar rash, none of which are not seen in this patient.  
❌ Thyroid function tests:
Incorrect: Though Hashimoto thyroiditis can rarely cause encephalopathy, it usually presents with a stroke-like pattern of focal neurologic deficits and altered mentation. This patient with papilledema and headache that is relieved by vomiting instead has a high suspicion for a structural intracranial process.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to pain in her hands as well as fatigue for the past three weeks. The patient has also noticed that her urine appears darker than normal. Medical history is non-contributory, and the patient takes no medication. The patient’s temperature is 37.6 C (99.6 F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 142/87 mmHg. Physical examination shows erythema and swelling of multiple metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally, with tenderness on palpation. Physical examination of her neck and chest is shown below:  


Reproduced from: U.S. National Library of Medicine
 *Dark red spots are biopsy sites  

Laboratory findings are positive for antinuclear antibodies (ANA). Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) based on the clinical features of fatigue, inflammatory arthritis, discoid skin rash, and evidence of nephritic syndrome (hematuria and hypertension).  

 The patient’s laboratory results are also positive for ANA, which is sensitive, but not specific, for SLE and can be found in many other diseases. The next best step in diagnosing this patient's condition is to look for more specific antibodies, such as anti-dsDNA (seen in active disease) and anti-Smith.   




Option Analysis

❌ Anti-histone antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-histone antibodies are present in drug-induced lupus. This patient is currently not taking any medications.  
✅ Anti-dsDNA antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody:
Incorrect: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody is a specific antibody seen in rheumatoid arthritis, together with the less specific rheumatoid factor (IgM antibody that targets IgG Fc region). ANA is non-specific and can be positive in many systemic inflammatory conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis. However, this patient’s discoid rash and evidence of nephritic syndrome favors the diagnosis of SLE.   
❌ Anti-SRP antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-SRP (signal recognition particle) is a specific antibody found positive in both dermatomyositis and polymyositis. Other specific antibodies of these conditions include anti-Jo-1 (histidyl-tRNA synthetase), anti-SRP, and anti-Mi-2 (helicase). Although ANA antibodies are positive in dermatomyositis and polymyositis, this finding is non-specific and can be seen in many other conditions. In addition, the discoid rash and evidence of nephritic syndrome favor the diagnosis SLE.  
❌ Anti-U1 RNP antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-U1 RNP antibodies (speckled ANA) are seen in mixed connective tissue disease, which includes features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with SLE.  
❌ Anti-DNA topoisomerase-I antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-Scl-70 antibody (anti-DNA topoisomerase-I antibody) and anti-RNA polymerase III are seen in diffuse scleroderma. The patient lacks the classic signs of diffuse skin involvement and visceral involvement (e.g., pulmonary hypertension and fibrosis, esophageal dysmotility, constrictive pericarditis).

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the office due to difficulty swallowing, food regurgitation, and reflux for the past several months. The patient describes difficulty swallowing both liquids and solids. She occasionally regurgitates chunks of undigested food. Medical history is unremarkable except for a C-section 8 years ago. She has had no recent illness, weight loss or fatigue, and she does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. She has not traveled out of the country recently. A barium swallow test is performed and shown below:  

 


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following patterns is most likely to be seen in this patient on manometry of the esophagus?
questions.solution:
This patient has achalasia. The barium swallow test results show characteristic dilated esophagus with distal stenosis (“bird’s beak”).  

Deglutition (swallowing) is a complex process that involves a series of synchronized voluntary and involuntary muscle contractions. It is divided into the oral, pharyngeal, and esophageal phases. In short, the food is chewed into bolus and propagated by the tongue towards the pharynx. The bolus is then transited to the pharynx and pushed into the esophagus by sequential contraction of pharyngeal constrictor muscles. The bolus enters the esophagus and by waves of peristalsis moves downwards. The lower esophageal sphincter relaxes to allow food into the stomach.    

Achalasia is a functional disorder of the esophagus resulting from inflammation and degeneration of neurons in the esophageal wall. The condition preferentially affects the myenteric (Auerbach) postganglionic inhibitory neurons which contain nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal peptide (which promote relaxation). The cholinergic neurons that contribute to lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone by smooth muscle contraction are relatively spared. The result is decreased peristalsis movement in the distal esophagus and the absence of relaxation of the LES, resulting in dysphagia to both liquids and solids. Achalasia can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary (e.g. Chagas disease).  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This manometry result is consistent with scleroderma esophageal dysmotility. In patients with scleroderma, there is smooth muscle atrophy that results in decreased pressure and dysmotility of the lower esophageal sphincter. Patients often complain of acid reflux and dysphagia; however, other features of the condition would be expected (e.g., CREST syndrome: Calcinosis cutis, anti-Centromere antibody, Raynaud phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia).   
✅ B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: This manometry result is consistent with diffuse esophageal spasm, a medical condition characterized by uncoordinated esophageal contractions that present as dysphagia, regurgitation and chest pain. The pain often simulates myocardial ischemia but without relation to exertion. There is no relationship to food, but it can be triggered by cold fluids. Barium study may show a “corkscrew”’ pattern at the time of the spasm, not a “bird’s beak” pattern as seen in this patient. On manometry, high intensity, disorganized contractions are typically seen.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: This manometry result is consistent with hypercontractile (nutcracker) esophagus, a motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by normal peristalsis pattern but in an excessive amplitude or duration. Similar to diffuse esophageal spasm, patients also complain of dysphagia and chest pain (it may mimic MI). The pathogenesis is thought to be due to excessive excitation and smooth muscle hypertrophy.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy comes to the clinic with his parents due to progressive right leg pain. He first noticed it during basketball training, but after some time, it even occurred at rest. The pain is dull, 3/10, and often wakes him at night. Medical history is significant for an eye problem as a baby. The patient’s parents say that he was treated for strabismus and “white eye” as a baby, but they do not recall the details. The patient’s temperature is 37.8°C (100 °F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination, focal tenderness is noted over the right tibia. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. An x-ray of the right leg is shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikipedia

Which of the following is most likely to be found on further evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Constitutive activation of tyrosine kinase receptor
Abnormal G1–S checkpoint cell cycle regulation
Amplification of epidermal growth factor receptor

questions.solution:
This child is presenting with low-grade fever, progressive bone pain, and a classic Codman’s triangle appearance on x-ray, favoring the diagnosis of osteosarcoma. Given the medical history of “white eye,” the most likely mutated gene is the retinoblastoma (RB) gene.  

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. The tumor produces an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. Osteosarcoma has a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. In adolescents, it often arises in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. Radiographs usually show a destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. This bone formation leads to elevation of the periosteum and the characteristic imaging finding known as Codman’s triangle (not pathognomonic). Risk factors for developing osteosarcoma include RB gene mutation, TP53 mutations (Li-Fraumeni syndrome), prior irradiation or chemotherapy, Paget disease, fibrous dysplasia, and other benign bone lesions.  

The RB gene, also known as the governor of the cell cycle, is a tumor suppressor gene and a key negative regulator of the cell cycle. The product of the RB gene is the RB protein, which regulates the G1/S checkpoint of the cell cycle before DNA replication commences. When RB protein is hypophosphorylated, it binds the E2F transcription factor to inhibit gene transcription. When RB is phosphorylated it releases E2F, which binds DNA and activates transcription of S-phase genes. Mutations in the RB gene result in abnormal progression through the cell cycle, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and division. RB gene germline (inherited) or somatic (acquired) mutations are associated with retinoblastoma eye cancer, osteosarcoma bone cancer, and other soft tissue tumors.    

Option Analysis

❌ Constitutive activation of tyrosine kinase receptor:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathogenesis of chronic myelogenous leukemia. The condition arises when a part of the ABL gene is translocated from its normal location on chromosome 9 to chromosome 22. This fusion gene encodes the BCR-ABL hybrid protein, a constitutively active tyrosine kinase protein that leads to downstream signals and cell growth. Tyrosine kinase is not involved in osteosarcoma.   
✅ Abnormal G1–S checkpoint cell cycle regulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Impaired apoptosis:
Incorrect: TP53, also known as the guardian of the genome, is a tumor suppressor gene and is the most commonly mutated gene in human cancer. The product of this gene, the p53 protein, is a transcription factor that prevents neoplastic transformation via temporary cell cycle arrest (quiescence), permanent cell cycle arrest (senescence), or apoptosis. TP53 mutation is associated with certain cases of osteosarcoma as part of Li-Fraumeni-syndrome. However, this child’s presentation favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Amplification of epidermal growth factor receptor:
Incorrect: HER2 is a type of epidermal growth factor receptor (tyrosine kinase) that promotes cell proliferation and opposes apoptosis by activating the RAS- and PI3K-AKT signaling pathways. Mutation in the HER2 gene causes overexpression of this receptor, which leads to highly proliferative tumors and poor prognosis. The HER2 gene mutation is associated with breast cancer, but HER2-positive breast cancer is not inherited and is considered a somatic genetic mutation. This patient’s history and type of cancer favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Impaired degradation of hypoxia-inducible factor:
Incorrect: A mutation in the VHL gene would result in impaied degradation of hypoxia-inducible factor 1a and result in von Hippel-Lindau disease. The condition is characterized by the development of multiple tumors, including central nervous system hemangioblastomas, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic tumors. However, it would be atypical for von Hippel-Lindau disease to manifest with a bone tumor.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man is intubated in the intensive care unit after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident and sustaining burns to greater than 50% of his total body surface area. He undergoes several surgeries including skin grafts and exploratory laparotomy with bowel resection. On the 5th day of admission, he is noted to have worsening abdominal distension and dark stool in the rectal tube. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 90/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on 50% FiO2. Physical examination shows an intubated, ill-appearing man with extensive burns and capillary refill >3 seconds. A chest x-ray is obtained and shown below:  


 Reproduced from: Wikipedia 

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Anastomotic leak at the site of bowel resection
Reduced plasma volume and gastric mucosal sloughing
Ongoing hemorrhage from a vascular ectasia

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette, who is presenting with signs of hemodynamic instability, an ongoing upper gastrointestinal bleed, and free air under the diaphragm, likely has a gastric perforation due to ulcer formation. Gastric ulcer development is common in mechanically ventilated intensive care unit patients, particularly in patients with extensive burn injuries or elevated intracranial pressure.    

This patient likely has a Curling ulcer, a type of ulcer that develops in response to low circulating plasma volume, commonly seen in patients with extensive burn injuries, sepsis, or hemorrhage.  Burn patients have massive insensible volume losses, causing decreased circulating volume, and subsequent ischemia to the gastric mucosa. With prolonged ischemia, the gastric mucosa sloughs off and acidic secretions erode the stomach until full thickness perforation occurs. Free air under the diaphragm can be seen in this patient, as the highlighted area underneath the right diaphragm on imaging.  



Patients with traumatic brain injuries, brain tumors, and elevated intracranial pressure can develop Cushing’s ulcers, which are thought to result from overstimulation of the vagus nerve. With stimulation of the vagus nerve, efferent fibers release acetylcholine activating M3 receptors on gastric parietal cells, causing excess hydrogen ion secretion and an imbalance of gastric pH.  

Due to the high incidence of ulcers in mechanically ventilated patients with these conditions, it is common practice to place them on ulcer prophylaxis, usually with a proton pump inhibitor.    

Option Analysis

❌ Direct stimulation of vagal nuclei :
Incorrect: This describes the pathophysiology of a Cushing ulcer, which results from prolonged vagal stimulation due to increased intracranial pressure. The increased vagal tone results in increased production of stomach acid via acetylcholine release. Cushing ulcers more commonly occur in patients with traumatic head injuries and intracranial malignancies.   
❌ Anastomotic leak at the site of bowel resection:
Incorrect: An anastomotic leak can result in hemodynamic instability; however it is less likely to result in free air under the diaphragm with associated melena.  
✅ Reduced plasma volume and gastric mucosal sloughing :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Ongoing hemorrhage from a vascular ectasia:
Incorrect: Vascular ectasias such as a Dieulafoy lesion (abnormal submucosal artery that is vulnerable to lesions) present with symptoms of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, but these conditions are unlikely to present with pneumoperitoneum.  
❌ Subphrenic abscess :
Incorrect: A subphrenic abscess is in the differential diagnosis of pneumoperitoneum. However, these patient’s will typically present with fevers in addition to other signs of hemodynamic instability.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman comes to the primary care physician with a several month history of worsening epigastric pain, weight loss, and early satiety. The patient reports she has lost 11.3 kg (25-lbs) in the last 3 months. Physical examination shows a thin, middle-aged female with hyperpigmented, velvety axillary skin folds and tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. A secretin stimulation test results in a < 200 ng/L increase in serum gastrin. An upper endoscopy with biopsy is performed, demonstrating the following histologic image. Which of the following is the underlying genetic mutation causing this disease process?  



Reproduced from: wikipedia

choices.text: Loss of cell adhesion protein E-cadherin
Increased activation of transforming growth factor-alpha (TGFa)
Autosomal dominant inheritance of a mutation in MEN1
Autosomal dominant inheritance of a mutation LKB1
Autosomal dominant mutation of APC tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 5q

questions.solution:
Diffuse-type gastric adenocarcinoma is an aggressive form of gastric cancer most commonly due to genetic mutations in loss of expression of CDH1, the gene that encodes E-cadherin.  This cell surface protein is involved in intercellular connections, maintaining epithelial organization, and controlling the progression of cell cycle. Due to this epithelial disruption, the stomach takes upon a thickened, leathery appearance known as linitis plastica. Histologic analysis of this tumor will demonstrate mucin-filled cells with peripheral nuclei, referred to as signet ring cells.     

Diffuse gastric cancer follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, with most patients diagnosed in middle age. Common presenting symptoms include weight loss, abdominal pain, nausea, and early satiety. Dermatologic findings may include the sudden appearance of diffuse seborrheic keratoses (Leser-Trelat sign) or acanthosis nigricans, which is characterized by velvety and darkly pigmented patches on skin folds. Treatment depends upon the extent of disease, and prophylactic gastrectomy is recommended for any individual with a germline CDH1 mutation and appropriate family history.  

Option Analysis

✅ Loss of cell adhesion protein E-cadherin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Increased activation of transforming growth factor-alpha (TGFa)  :
Incorrect: Increased activation of transforming growth factor alpha is thought to underlie the pathologic genetic processes resulting in Ménétrier’s disease, not diffuse gastric cancer.  
❌ Autosomal dominant inheritance of a mutation in MEN1:
Incorrect: MEN1 encodes the protein menin, which acts as a tumor suppressor regulating DNA transcription and apoptosis. It is commonly implicated in a hereditary condition associated with tumors of the endocrine glands, including gastrinomas and subsequent Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. In this vignette, the patient’s secretin stimulation test is negative, making a gastrin-secreting tumor very unlikely.    
❌ Autosomal dominant inheritance of a mutation LKB1:
Incorrect: LKB1 is a tumor suppressor gene thought to be implicated in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. This disease often presents with benign hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and hyperpigmented macules on the lips and oral mucosa. The hyperpigmented areas in this vignette are instead reflective of acanthosis nigricans.   
❌ Autosomal dominant mutation of APC tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 5q:
Incorrect: This mutation describes the genetic mechanism of familial adenomatous polyposis, which results in thousands of colon polyps and progresses to colorectal cancer in 100% of cases.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a breast lump. A suspicious mass is found on mammogram, which is followed by a core needle biopsy that confirms the diagnosis of invasive carcinoma. Medical history is unremarkable. The patient’s mother died of breast cancer, and her sister was recently diagnosed with ovarian cancer; the doctor suspects a hereditary mutation. In healthy individuals, the involved gene has which of the following roles?

choices.text: Promotes cell proliferation via tyrosine kinase

questions.solution:
This patient, who is now diagnosed with invasive breast cancer, has 2 first degree relatives who were diagnosed with breast cancer, raising concerns for hereditary causes. The majority of cases of inherited breast cancer and/or ovarian cancers are caused by a pathogenic variant in BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes. These genes normally encode for proteins essential for repair of DNA damage and are expressed in many cells and tissues. Therefore, cells with defective versions of these genes develop chromosomal breaks and severe aneuploidy, ultimately leading to uncontrolled proliferation and malignant transformation. While the age of onset, degree of penetrance, and susceptibility to develop other types of cancers differ among BRCA1 and BRCA2 germline mutations, most carriers will develop breast cancer by the age of 70 years (vs. 12% of women with an average risk of breast cancer).  

Option Analysis

✅ DNA repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cell cycle regulation:
Incorrect: Tumor protein p53 (TP53) is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for the transcription factor p53, which is responsible for cell cycle regulation. Mutations in TP53 are associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome, a hereditary condition that is characterized by multiple malignancies at an early age, including sarcomas, breast cancer, leukemias, and adrenal cancers. However, this patient’s presentation is more likely due to a BRCA1/2 mutation.  
❌ Negative regulation of signal transduction  :
Incorrect: Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) is a tumor suppressor gene and a negative regulator of the phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K)-AKT pathway, which is critical for cell proliferation, cell cycle progression, and apoptosis. Carriers of this mutation are at risk for breast, endometrial, and thyroid cancer. However, this patient’s presentation is more likely due to a BRCA1/2 mutation.  
❌ Promotes cell proliferation via tyrosine kinase:
Incorrect: HER2 is a tyrosine kinase receptor that promotes cell proliferation and opposes apoptosis by activating the RAS and (PI3K)-AKT signaling pathways. Mutations in the gene that encodes for HER2 result in overexpression of this receptor, which is associated with highly proliferative tumors and poor prognosis. However, HER2-positive breast cancer is not inherited and is considered a somatic genetic mutation. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with an inherited cancer syndrome, most likely BRCA1/2.
❌ Mismatch repair:
Incorrect: Mismatch repair genes (e.g., MSH2, MLH1, MSH6, PMS2) are associated with Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). Lynch syndrome causes colon, endometrial, and ovarian cancer, but it is not associated with breast cancer.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of trouble swallowing for the last 3 months. She now needs to chew food for a longer period of time in order to swallow it properly. She also reports that her eyes have been feeling itchy, with a “gritty” feeling for the same time period. Past medical history is significant for allergic rhinitis and conjunctivitis, which is well-controlled with oral cetirizine as needed. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows redness of both eyes. There is nontender, diffuse parotid gland enlargement bilaterally. Oral examination reveals multiple dental caries and halitosis. Ophthalmologic examination reveals decreased visual acuity in both eyes. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following antibodies?
questions.solution:
This middle-aged woman is presenting with xerophthalmia (dry eyes) and xerostomia (dry mouth) for the last 3 months, making Sjogren syndrome the likely diagnosis. Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune condition that commonly affects women 40-60 years of age.  

The cause of Sjogren syndrome is unclear but may be the result of multiple environmental and genetic factors. The majority of patients have autoantibody (anti-SSA/Ro and anti-SSB/La) production, which leads to chronic inflammation and damage of the salivary and lacrimal glands. The activated T-cells and B-cells in these glands secrete cytokines, which in turn recruit additional immune cells. This signaling results in the principal finding on pathology, which is lymphocytic infiltrates in salivary and lacrimal glands. The activated immune cells can also affect extraglandular tissues, which may explain the other symptoms (e.g., lymphadenopathy, myalgia, arthralgia) associated with the condition.  

Sjogren syndrome can occur independently of other conditions (primary idiopathic Sjogren syndrome) or may occur secondarily to other autoimmune conditions, such as rheumatoid arthritis (secondary Sjogren syndrome).    

Option Analysis

✅ Anti-La antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anti-centromere antibodies:
Incorrect: Anticentromere antibodies are normally found in patients with CREST syndrome. These patients also typically have calcinosis cutis (small white calcium deposits at the extremities), Raynaud phenomenon (vasospasm of extremities), esophageal dysfunction, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasias. While patients with CREST may also have dysphagia, it is secondary to esophageal dysmotility, rather than the decreased saliva production seen in this patient.
❌ Anti-histone antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-histone antibodies are typically found in patients with drug-induced lupus. These patients present with new-onset symptoms of lupus (e.g., fever, polyarthritis, serositis) after starting a new medication. Medications that are classical triggers of this condition include sulfa drugs, hydralazine, and isoniazid. This patient has no history of starting a new medication, and the symptoms are likely due to another diagnosis.  
❌ Anti-DNA topoisomerase I antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-DNA topoisomerase I antibodies, also known as anti-Scl-70 antibodies, are typically present in patients with systemic sclerosis (i.e. scleroderma). Patients with systemic sclerosis present with diffuse thickening of skin, as well as symptoms of dysphagia. Dysphagia in these patients is due to esophageal dysmotility, unlike the patient here, who has dysphagia secondary to xerostomia (dry mouth). 
❌ Anti-Jo-1 antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-Jo-1 antibodies and anti-Mi-2 antibodies are classically found in patients with inflammatory myopathies (e.g., dermatomyositis, polymyositis). Both conditions result in proximal muscle weakness, commonly presenting as an inability to rise from a seated position, or weakness during stair climbing. This patient is not presenting with muscle weakness, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Rheumatoid factor antibodies :
Incorrect: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are generally positive for rheumatoid factor on laboratory testing. Rheumatoid arthritis presents with joint pain that is typically worse in the mornings. Although Sjogren syndrome may occur secondarily in patients with RA, this patient presents with no symptoms of joint pain, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician with a several month history of burning epigastric pain and nausea that is worse after eating. The patient reports she has lost approximately 15 pounds (6.8 kg) due to pain with eating. The patient’s only other medical problem is chronic shoulder arthritis for which she takes naproxen daily. The patient undergoes endoscopy with biopsy of the following pathologic lesion:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

From which area of the gastrointestinal tract was this biopsy most likely taken?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pain worse with eating, weight loss, chronic NSAID use, as well as a gastric ulcer with surrounding rugae, likely in the body or fundus of the stomach.   

Peptic ulcer disease is classified based on its anatomic location, either duodenal or gastric. Gastric ulcers are most commonly due to H. pylori or NSAIDs, whereas duodenal ulcers are almost exclusively due to H. pylori (>90% of cases). In either case, dysfunction of the mucosal barrier leads to increased permeability to gastric acid secretion. In the rare case of duodenal ulcers due to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, a rare gastrin-secreting tumor, gastric acid production is also augmented.  

If left untreated, gastric ulcers can perforate, bleed, and have a higher rate of developing into gastric cancer. For this reason, all gastric ulcers are biopsied on upper endoscopy to evaluate for any histologic features of malignancy

 

Option Analysis

✅ Fundus of the stomach:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Esophagus:
Incorrect: Ulceration of the esophagus is typically viral in etiology, with CMV or HSV as common agents. The image obtained from endoscopy in this patient demonstrates an ulcer with surrounding rugae, which is not likely to be seen in the esophagus.   
❌ Duodenum :
Incorrect: Duodenal ulcers present with pain that is relieved upon eating, pain at night, and oftentimes weight gain. Endoscopy will typically show ulcers surrounded by the circular folds of the small intestine.   
❌ Gastroesophageal junction:
Incorrect: The gastroesophageal junction is implicated in Barrett esophagus. This metaplastic process occurs when the stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium and goblet cells due to uncontrolled acid reflux.  
❌ Cardia of the stomach:
Incorrect: The cardia is the area just adjacent to the gastroesophageal junction. It is an uncommon site for the development of gastric ulcers.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to right-sided abdominal pain for the past two hours. She states the pain started after she had lunch, which consisted of a burger and fries. She describes the pain as dull and 5/10 in intensity. Medical history is significant for Crohn disease diagnosed 3 years ago. Medications include methotrexate and ustekinumab. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows sensitivity to touch in the right upper quadrant. An abdominal ultrasound reveals multiple stones within the gallbladder. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with Crohn disease most likely developed gallstones due to damage to the terminal ileum, leading to the malabsorption of bile acid.     Bile acid is produced by the liver cells, secreted into the bile, and then released into the intestines to aid in digestion. It is then used for fat emulsification (breaking fat droplets into smaller pieces to maximize surface area for digestion), which facilitates fat and cholesterol absorption in the form of micelles. The outline of bile acid synthesis and reabsorption is summarized in the following steps:  

  •  The liver cells synthesize primary bile acids (cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid) by cytochrome P450-mediated oxidation of cholesterol in a multi-step process, involving the rate-limiting enzyme 7α-hydroxylase; this process is one of the few methods the body has to excrete cholesterol from the body.  
  •  The liver cells then conjugate primary bile acids with the amino acids glycine or taurine to form conjugated bile acids, making them relatively insoluble in water and unable to be reabsorbed in the intestines. 
  •  Once secreted into the intestine, the gut microbiota remove the glycine and taurine groups, forming secondary bile acids. Secondary bile acids are deconjugated and available for reabsorption in the terminal ileum.     

Approximately 600 mg of bile salts are synthesized every day to replace bile acids lost in the feces. However, most of the bile is reabsorbed by active transport in the terminal ileum and recycled, a process known as enterohepatic circulation. Crohn disease commonly damages the terminal ileum, the location of bile acid reabsorption. The reduced bile acid pool leads to an imbalance between cholesterol and bile acids within the gallbladder, leading to supersaturation of cholesterol and subsequent gallstone formation.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a chemotherapy agent and immune system suppressant, whereas ustekinumab is a human monoclonal antibody; both of these agents are used to treat Crohn disease. Neither, however, is associated with gallstone formation.   
❌ Reduced cholecystokinin secretion:
Incorrect: Reduced cholecystokinin secretion can lead to hypomobility of the gallbladder, which increases the risk of gallstone formation. It can be seen in patients with somatostatinomas (due to inhibition of cholecystokinin release), with spinal cord injuries, or receiving total parenteral nutrition.    
❌ Hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Chronic hemolysis increases the risk for formation of black pigment stones, due to increased levels of bilirubin. Crohn disease can present with anemia due to malabsorption of B12 or due to chronic inflammatory state (anemia of chronic disease); however, these are not causes of hemolytic anemia.    
✅ Bile acid wasting:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Infection of the biliary tree:
Incorrect: Ascending cholangitis is an inflammation of the bile system due to bacterial invasion secondary to partial bile duct obstruction. Common presenting symptoms are fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice (Charcot triad), with occasional hypotension and altered mental status (Reynolds pentad). This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the office because of oral pain. The pain has been constant for several weeks and worsens with chewing and swallowing food. He also reports the development of non-pruritic, tender skin sores on his arms and legs, which occurred two weeks following the onset of the oral pain. Past medical history is noncontributory. He has been working as a gardener in California for 20 years. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows multiple erosions and flaccid bullae on the extremities and buccal mucosa. When lateral pressure is applied on the bullae, the overlying layer easily slips off, revealing an erythematous base. Direct immunofluorescence on perilesional skin specimens of this patient is shown.  


Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
Antibodies against which of the following antigens is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple painful mucosal erosions, non-pruritic flaccid cutaneous bullae, and positive Nikolsky sign (separation of the epidermis by light friction), together with direct immunofluorescence (DIF) microscopy revealing reticular IgG deposits in the intercellular space, is most likely suffering from pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a type II hypersensitivity reaction whereby IgG antibodies are formed against desmoglein-1 and desmoglein-3. Desmogleins are desmosomal proteins that connect keratinocytes within the stratum spinosum, and therefore, disruption of this protein results in the detachment of keratinocytes from one another. The specific triggers are unclear, but it is thought there may be genetic susceptibility, in addition to a potential association with ultraviolet radiation and exposure to certain drugs (e.g., penicillamine and captopril). It classically affects middle-aged adults (unlike bullous pemphigoid, which typically affects older adults) and can be fatal. It usually manifests as mucosal blisters and erosions affecting the oral cavity, conjunctiva, nose, and anus. Cutaneous involvement presents with painful, non-pruritic flaccid bullae and blisters on the extremities and trunk with positive Nikolsky sign.

Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation, histopathology, and immunofluorescence. The lesion biopsy shows intraepidermal cleavage with acantholysis (keratinocytes detachment) in the suprabasal epidermis and the characteristic tombstoning of the dermo-epidermal junction. Immunofluorescence shows reticular IgG deposits in the intercellular space. Treatment is by systemic steroids.  



Option Analysis

✅ Desmoglein  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemidesmosome:
Incorrect:  Bullous pemphigoid, a type II hypersensitivity reaction, results from IgG antibodies against the hemidesmosomes of the basement membrane. It typically presents with intensely pruritic, tense bullae on flexor surfaces, unlike the flaccid, non-pruritic bullae in this patient. Moreover, direct immunofluorescence typically shows linear IgG deposits at the epidermal-dermal junction, in contrast to the net-like reticular pattern in this patient.  
❌ Centromere  :
Incorrect: Anti-centromere antibodies are characteristic of systemic sclerosis, which usually presents with skin thickening and hardening, mainly involving the fingers, hands, and face. Flaccid bullae with a positive Nikolsky sign would be atypical.  
❌ Ribonucleoprotein:
Incorrect: Mixed connective tissue disease, a generalized systemic disorder, is characterized by anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein antibodies in combination with clinical features of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, and polymyositis. This patient’s presentation with cutaneous bullae is suggestive of a different diagnosis.  
❌ Double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid  :
Incorrect: Antibodies against double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid (anti-dsDNA) are SLE characteristics. These patients present with a malar rash (sparing nasolabial folds) and discoid lesions with constitutional symptoms, arthritis, photosensitivity, and other systemic diseases, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, granular IgG, IgM, IgA, and C3 deposit at epidermal-dermal junctions on direct immunofluorescence.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents to the office because of a rash and burning sensation on her hands. It started two days ago and is scaly and nonpruritic. She works as a gardener but recently started a new part-time house cleaning service near her neighborhood. Past medical history is significant for a streptococcal throat infection three weeks ago, treated with oral penicillin. She has taken warfarin regularly for the past three years after undergoing prosthetic aortic valve replacement. Family history is significant for atopic dermatitis in her mother. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are shown.


Reproduced from Flickr

Which of the following factors most likely triggered this patient’s skin condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s erythema, scaling, and burning of the hands after starting work cleaning houses is most likely due to a detergent causing contact dermatitis. Contact dermatitis is a localized inflammatory skin reaction that results from either exposure to allergens (allergic contact dermatitis), such as poison ivy, or irritants (irritant contact dermatitis), such as detergents.



Option Analysis

❌ Sun-exposure:
Incorrect: Sun-exposure is a major triggering factor for rosacea. It is a dermatologic condition that presents with ocular and cutaneous manifestations, commonly in individuals with lightly pigmented skin. Cutaneous symptoms include telangiectasias, papules, and pustules on the central face with minimal or no scaling. Hand involvement is uncommon.
✅ Detergent:
Correct: See Man Explanation.
❌ Pollen grains:
Incorrect: Pollen grains are allergens that can trigger the development of atopic dermatitis (AD) in susceptible individuals. Although a positive family history may contribute to the development of AD in this individual, it usually involves flexural areas. Involvement of the palms with scaly skin and fissures would be unlikely.
❌ Penicillin:
Incorrect: Ingestion of penicillin can cause a serum sickness-like reaction in some individuals, which manifests as fever, urticaria, and polyarthralgia one to two weeks after exposure. Although this patient had a recent penicillin exposure, none of the serum sickness symptoms are present in this patient.
❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect: Warfarin intake can rarely result in skin necrosis, which initially presents with pain and can progress to bullae and skin necrosis. It mostly occurs weeks after starting the therapy. This patient has been on warfarin for three years without any adverse events, making warfarin an unlikely cause.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician for a routine checkup. The parents privately express concern about the boy’s academic performance and physical appearance, stating that “He looks kind of different from the other boys at school.” The patient has repeatedly failed reading, writing, and mathematics exams at school and is at risk of being held-back for a year. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 112/73 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. The patient is at the 99<sup>th </sup>percentile for height. Physical examination reveals bilateral gynecomastia, narrow shoulders, and wide hips. Which of the following is an anticipated feature of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with many characteristic symptoms of Klinefelter syndrome (KS), including gynecomastia, narrow shoulders, wide hips, and learning disability. The condition develops when individuals inherit an extra maternal X chromosome and have a XXY genotype. KS has an estimated prevalence of 1:500 to 1:1000 in phenotypical males.  

 A key feature of KS is infertility. The extra X chromosome leads to the expression of proteins that cause testicular fibrosis and hypoplasia as well as subsequent primary gonadal failure. As a result, there is decreased secretion of inhibin B by the Sertoli cells and testosterone by the Leydig cells of the testes. These abnormalities, in turn, lead to an increase in FSH and LH levels. Furthermore, the extra X chromosome leads to increased estrogen production.  

Typically, individuals with Klinefelter have a eunuchoid body shape, which is characterized by a tall and slim body with long extremities. In addition, patients have reduced muscle mass; less facial, body, and genital hair; and frequently develop gynecomastia.
